name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on the Council and Commission statements on the budget of the Maltese Presidency (2017/2658 (RSP)).Before giving the floor to Joseph Muscat, I want to thank this Presidency for the work done in a particularly complicated moment, where the immigration emergency becomes more worrying every day, thousands and thousands of people move from Libya to Europe and toour continent is not easy to tackle this problem.I also want to thank the European Commission, which is working hard, like Parliament, to find solutions.I hope that the Member States will do the same.Thanks again for this difficult job.

name: Joseph MUSCAT
text: President fil-Kariga tal-Kunsill. – Grazzi Sur President, grazzi Membri ta’ din il-Kamra, li għat-tielet darba fl-aħħar sitt xhur qed nerġa’ nindirizzakom. Nistqarr li kull esperjenza kienet waħda li mhux se ninsa iżda wkoll id-djalogu li minnha tgħallimna ħafna. Fi tmiem din il-Presidenza xtaqt nitkellem ftit dwar dak illi ksibna flimkien iżda xtaqt li l-enfażi tiegħi ma tieqafx fuq dak li għaddejna minnu bħala Presidenza, li tajjeb infakkar li kienet l-ewwel waħda fl-istorja tagħna. Imma kif għidt meta ltqajna l-ewwel darba fil-bidu ta’ din l-esperjenza xtaqt li l-kontribut tagħna jmur lil hinn minn sempliċiment perjodu qasir fl-istorja kbira ta’ din l-Unjoni. Xewqa tiegħi tibqa’ li ħarsitna bħala politiċi Ewropej konvinti tibqa’ fuq kif se ntejbu ħajjet iċ-ċittadini tagħna u kif għada se nkunu aktar rilevanti mil-lum, kif se nagħtu aktar drittijiet u ugwaljanza sħiħa lil kull ċittadin, kif se nagħmlu aktar faċli biex in-negozji jissaħħu, jinħoloq aktar xogħol biex aktar żgħażagħ jaħdmu għax huwa l-ġid li joħloq ix-xogħol u x-xogħol inaqqas il-faqar. Ma rridux nilludu ruħna, għadna lura sew biex in-nies iħossuhom aħjar kif jistħoqqilhom. Kif se nispjega aktar tard, is-solidarjetà għadna narawha materja ta’ flus. Is-solidarjetà veru iżda hija kwistjoni ta’ umanità. Għalhekk nixtieq li din id-diskussjoni magħkom tkun iktar dwar il-futur tal-Ewropa u mhux biss sempliċiment dwar kliem, dwar dak illi għamilna. U dak li nixtieq inħallu warajna, reazzjoni katina li tkompli għaddejja bħala mod ta’ ħsieb anke lill-ħbieb tagħna tal-Estonja li persważ li ħa jkunu suċċess f’dak illi se jagħmlu. Tkun idea ġdida ta’ kif nidħlu biex inwettqu l-prinċipji tal-Unjoni Ewropea.  Mr President, I am here today to close a small chapter in Europe’s history but one which for us Maltese, the smallest Member State, means a lot. Even though holding the Presidency of the European Council might not have a direct effect on citizens, the Maltese people feel a sense of pride, and every time we closed a dossier and we were praised or criticised we felt part of something larger than the small island we live in. Let me start by transmitting a sense of the positivity that the EU Presidency has brought to our country. During the past six months we achieved a lot in terms of making a difference in people’s lives. We closed important dossiers – ending roaming charges and introducing cross-border portability, which affects apps we use in everyday life, and moving ahead with the WiFi4EU initiative. Other important dossiers which we closed were the Anti-Tax-Avoidance Directive, the double-taxation dispute resolution mechanism, better protection for workers from cancer-causing substances, and rules on business-to-consumer contracts for the supply of digital content. The EU joined the Istanbul Convention on Preventing and Combating Violence against Women. We have also seen serious advancement on gas security of supply, paved the way for 5G, and reached an agreement on the Malta Declaration charting the EU’s way forward. These are important issues and initiatives which, if communicated effectively, can show citizens – even the most sceptical millennials – that the EU matters for them, on issues like the use of Spotify through the available free wifi connection, to women’s rights, to enhanced worker’s rights, to facilitating future technologies. I must stress that these are all positive achievements which we should be talking to citizens about in our daily interactions on the media and when we meet our citizens face-to-face. The Presidency, however, was also a stark reminder that there are issues which we are still at loggerheads about. Migration, Mr President, is one of them. For all the good intentions which we all declare, including through signed declarations, when it boils down to real, effective solidarity, we, as Member States, should all be ashamed of our record. Countries like ours are now home to thousands of migrants and have been for the past decade or so; countries like Italy have seen hundreds of thousands of children, women and men reach their shores; and now we look at Europe, at politicians, and think ‘Well, on this issue this Europe is a failure’. So, do we blame any citizen in any country who feels short-changed because of the geographical reality they live in? How are we making a difference in these peoples’ lives? Are we just blaming them for turning to extremist parties? It is in this context that Malta supports the agreement reached between Italy, France and Germany in the presence of Commissioner Avramopoulos. We agree with the need for more financial transparency for NGOs, more specifically who is funding them and why: not to engage in some sort of war of words with these organisations, but to make sure that we all play by the same rules. We agree also that there need to be clear rules of engagement, that we should not engage in Libyan territorial waters, and that there is a need for more coordination between the coastguards involved. I must remind you that our small island, the smallest Member State, devotes 100% of its military assets to cooperating with all the relevant authorities to save lives at sea. However, to be very clear, this cannot go on forever. In the absence of real solidarity by all Member States, no one should blame the Member States affected for then trying to protect their national interest. But this is a road we do not want to go down. I think that we are still in time to have not only effective solidarity and effective border protection but also a way of managing this phenomenon together, rather than reacting once again, as we have been doing, in crisis mode. It has felt like the tail wagging the dog, rather than a situation in which we grasp control, we have an effective discussion and we move ahead, while making very clear what European values are and how they can be implemented. It is the time for choices for everyone. European Union membership is not something whereby you choose which values you adhere to and which values you do not adhere to. European Union membership is one set of values for each and every one of us. Our Presidency also had to deal with Brexit – this disastrous creature which all of us should have seen coming but none of us acted to stop. We have worked on this with some of the best people in the field, and here let me praise once again Michel Barnier’s contribution and the excellent collaboration between Council, Commission, Parliament and the Presidency of the Council of Ministers. But then again, what are we praising here? The terms of a painful divorce which millions of citizens will have to go through? What are we doing, and what are we not doing, in order to make sure that such an experience does not present itself again in the future? I believe that this self-critical analysis of our work should stand. This is not self-flagellation but a reflection of what people in our cities, towns and villages are telling us. There is another dimension which we should not disregard. Europe does not stop with its borders. Our role in the world is as crucial and central as any other continent, and has become even more so in the past few months. We are at the forefront on certain issues which cut through oceans and forests, such as climate change. In this context, we must keep on defending the agreement on climate change that was born in Paris – that was born in Europe – and spread it from north to south and make sure that it gets implemented. Europe must not close its eyes to what is happening just 60 km off our coast in Libya, because Europe is Libya’s neighbour and Libya is Europe’s neighbour. Our seas should be a force to unite the world. Our vision for the world must be to build bridges and not walls. But first we must understand that solidarity begins at home and should be shown with the smaller Members of our family and those going through a crisis. Together we have overcome so many challenges, and if we heed our people we will once again rise to the occasion and bounce back on the crucial issues that affect citizens in the workplace, in our kids’ classrooms, in our hospitals and in our homes when families sit around the table to discuss their daily successes and failures. Finally, a word of thanks to Council President Donald Tusk, to my dear friend Jean Claude and all his team and to yourself, Mr President, and your predecessor. Your constant support was the guiding light of our Presidency. Who would have thought that a small island of Malta’s proportions – just half a million in population, the size of a medium-sized city in Europe – would have managed to chair hundreds of meetings and conclude important measures affecting the lives of so many millions of Europeans? That, I believe, is the beauty of Europe. I will sign off by wishing all the best to our Estonian colleagues and by recalling what was, I think, one of the fantastic moments of our Presidency where we were together in Rome and were hosted by President Mattarella. He gave a definition of Europe to which I subscribe. He said that Europe is made up of ‘small States and those that have not yet come to realise that they are small’. I believe that really is our Europe.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Prime Minister, your concerns on the subject of solidarity are ours.The European Parliament has made her voice heard by asking all Member States to take charge of the relocation of refugees precisely in the name of solidarity.I also thank the European Commission for having listened to the voice of Parliament and for having promptly intervened on the issue of relocation of refugees.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission.- Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, the European Parliament is ridiculous, very ridiculous.I salute those who have taken the trouble to come here, but the fact that only 30 or so members are attending this debate is sufficient proof that Parliament is not serious, and I wanted to say it today.If Mr. Muscat were Mrs. Merkel - hardly imaginable - or Mr. Macron - more imaginable ... We would have a full House.The Parliament is totally ridiculous.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Please, Mr President, have a more respectful attitude towards this Parliament.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. – There are only a few Members in the plenary to control the Commission. You are ridiculous! I wanted to pay tribute to the Maltese Presidency ... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr. Speaker, please use a different language.We are not ridiculous.You're welcome!

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. – I will never again attend a meeting of this kind. The Commission is under the control of the Parliament, but the Parliament has to respect even the presidencies of smaller countries, which Parliament is not doing.  I wanted to pay tribute to the Maltese Government and to the Prime Minister. I want to pay tribute to what the Prime Minister of Malta did. He did excellent work, as did all the Maltese ministers and the senior civil servants and other civil servants of Malta. An excellent job.

name: Alfred SANT
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, the following is a statement of fact, not an indulgence in national feel good: under the Maltese Presidency some very good work has been done, and that has been acknowledged a number of times already. There was painstaking preparation for it and an all-out commitment to get the job done. Unfortunately, meanwhile, efforts were made – including in this Parliament, as we have just heard – to denigrate the Maltese Government with claims that the rule of law was not being respected in Malta. These clumsy allegations did not succeed in derailing the work of the Presidency.  Some indications regarding future prospects can be taken from the Maltese Presidency and the experience of it. First, on immigration, the Union still lacks cohesion, as Prime Minister Muscat has just said, but can this emerge through the normal deliberations that go on under different presidencies, six months at a time, under the present process? We need a special effort. Secondly, Brexit talks have got off to a slow and ambiguous start. The danger here is that, instead of reaching for an outcome that is politically fair and strategically smart, both sides get stuck in detail. Thirdly, issues relating to tax policies and financial services are increasingly being subjected to opaque, many—sided calculations at the level of the Council and also this Parliament. Still, the Maltese Presidency has passed over to its successor a state of play which, in most sectors, offers much hope of further progress soon.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Despite Malta being the smallest EU Member State, the Maltese Presidency managed to take some steps forward in areas that concern our citizens. In terms of asylum, migration and security, Malta has made a strong effort to limit illegal migration flows from Africa to Europe. Malta, for example, advocated training the Libyan coastguard so that they could stop the migrants. All this to prevent fortune seekers from Africa from illegally crossing the Mediterranean to Europe via Libya. In addition, Malta was able to significantly increase the number of people who return voluntarily. The figures prove that a vigorous and sustained approach to the migration crisis remains necessary. Last week, no fewer than 10,000 economic migrants made the crossing from Libya to Italy in just two days! I therefore hope that, building on Malta's work, Estonia will continue to address the migration crisis as a matter of priority. It is actually quite shocking to see that almost two years after the outbreak of the migration crisis, our external borders are still wide open and that we remain dependent on the non-EU countries to guard our borders. Malta also managed to align all 27 Member States on ETIAS. This is a system to pre-screen all non-EU travelers who are allowed to travel to the EU visa-free, based on American example. The intention is to keep criminals out. In short, a small country that managed to make its mark on the European scene.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr. president. Welcome Mr. Muscat, you have shown that a small island is not afraid of great responsibility. Malta has managed the general agreement of twenty states supporting the creation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which its Government, however, does not defend, and that is highly estimable. It has also managed the agreement on the proposal for a Directive on the fight against money laundering, although the text was not very ambitious either. But Italy these days threatens to close its ports to the arrival of thousands and thousands of people from Libya and Austria threatens to put soldiers on its borders with Italy while most of the member states take profile and, yes, the parliamentarians surely also Sometimes we get in profile, Mr. Juncker. France and Germany have promised Italy and Greece that they will increase relocation, but this increasingly sounds like words to buy time. The migration and humanitarian crisis, unprecedented since World War II, is rotting away and it is not a failure of Malta. It is not Malta. It is all of us who close the borders with Greece or Italy, as if we did not have a common responsibility. Malta is one of the few countries that welcomes unaccompanied minors who have arrived fleeing the war, because most do not want to know anything about minors. In the speeches yes, but, in reality, welcoming and working with minors requires assuming responsibilities, coordinating and working more and better. Not welcoming minors, minors refugees, is a symptom of Europe's disease, because these young people can become extraordinary adults and we throw them into crime. As the semesters of this term go by, we see that the gap between security and reception policies is widening. In security, there is speed and commitment on the part of the States - and I am pleased that we are quick in this. but in the others there is slowness and apathy with the most underprivileged, and that increases our shame.The semesters hide, more and more, the word "asylum" or "refugee", as if in this way these vulnerable people whom we are not caring for disappear, because we do not have the courage to draw the virtue of the collective effort involved in supporting othersand really support us.It is not innocuous: the logic of national selfishness also makes impossible our possibilities of progress in this global world.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, six months ago, during the Maltese presidency, I said on behalf of the GUE / NGL that the new presidency must take clear steps to change course from the disastrous neoliberal policies of austerity, strengthening social cohesion. The strengthening of Fortress Europe must also be stopped and a humanitarian approach and practical solidarity in support of refugees must be developed. Despite the Maltese Presidency's ambitious efforts on immigration and refugee issues and on issues related to cooperation in the Mediterranean, unfortunately the Union 's dominant policies remain deadlocked; militarization and remove all content from the social pillar. On behalf of the group of the European United Left, I reiterate our position that what is needed is a new common asylum system, legal and safe routes for refugees and a fair system for the relocation of refugees. We need practical social solidarity; we need social and economic policies for the benefit of peoples and not multinationals.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, I will start with a point of order, if I may. Mr President of the Commission, I myself come from a small State, and I fully understand your indignation: you are right to stress that the Head of Government of a small State is entitled to so much respect for A head of state or government of a large state leaves this assembly. Nonetheless, I believe it was your responsibility to deliver your speech as you planned to do and therefore not respond to one disrespect with another disrespect. Having said that, I come to what I wanted to say. Mr. Muscat, I will start with the definition of socialism: "theory aimed at transforming social organization for the purpose of human justice in terms of work, pay, education, housing, etc." I will not teach you anything, Mr Muscat, by saying that fair taxation is an absolutely crucial lever to achieve this goal of social justice. But what have we seen from the Maltese Presidency on this? First, a great silence. In the priorities announced, the words "taxation" or "taxation" were conspicuous by their absence. But should we be surprised since, with an effective tax rate for multinationals of 5%, Malta is part, like Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg, of the club of European tax havens, at least for The multinationals? Then the Panama papers and even a Maltese government agency shed light on the involvement of prominent politicians in the country in fraud, tax evasion and money laundering. So, that the Maltese presidency does not push the fires in the fight for tax justice, put up with the opacity of the trusts, which are one of the absolutely essential vehicles in this phenomenon, or want to put the top European politicians in the spotlight. shelter of a rigorous attention from banks, so this is not surprising.In fact, your government prefers tax certainty over tax justice.This is, in fact, the theme of the only initiative taken by your finance minister on the fiscal front.Let's understand each other well.It is about giving multinationals, and therefore their managers and shareholders, visibility on the taxes they will have to pay.A visibility, we are told, called into question by the flow of new rules in progress, started following the multiple scandals that we have experienced in recent years.In other words, rather than responding to the anger of those who are the victims of tax injustice, you think it is more important to reassure the owners of capital.Dear Mr. Muscat, who could guess, given this record, that you are a socialist?

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: On behalf of the EFDD Group. - The first Maltese Presidency was not only a challenge for this small and young country in the European Union, but, above all, a challenge for the European Union as a whole. How much it will show solidarity and how it will help and contribute to the huge challenges and ambitious goals. This could only be done with the clear support of all, and above all the major countries of the European Union, and the desire to truly democratize Europe. Not to demonize, but to democratize, as at the beginning of the presidency, and said Maltese Prime Minister J. Muscat. I quote: 'Let us not blame people for the way they vote, but let us focus on what they are worried about.' The European Union needs to fundamentally change its policy on preventing immigrants and terrorism. Until this is done, we will continue to enjoy only the paper achievements in the various reports.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, Malta has chaired the European Union for the past six months. Its record is very disappointing. To be sure, Malta has succeeded in pushing through the end of roaming charges. Thanks to this measure, telephone calls are no longer surcharged when made from another EU Member State. But Malta failed on two major issues. First, on controlling immigration, which was its priority. 130 Libyan Coast Guard officers have been trained, but little is seen. The migratory flood has not stopped; on the contrary, it is picking up again in Italy, where 6,000 migrants are currently arriving every day. Malta, on the other hand, has failed to improve the fight against money laundering, but this is not surprising, as thirteen European media have just proven that Malta is a tax haven comparable to Panama. Therefore, an arsonist should not be expected to put out the bleaching fire. Malta will have been, in the end, the revealer of what the European Union is: a plutocratic organization at the service of business people and not of the people. The insults that Mr Juncker has just addressed to Members of this Parliament fully confirm this analysis.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, during the Maltese Presidency of the Union, it has not been possible to develop a workable migration policy, and immigration continues.The main task of the Council is to enforce the reception quota.And they want to reduce illegal migration by legalizing it.In terms of investment, the Juncker plan failed.The failure to multiply EU funding from EUR 15 billion to EUR 315 billion will fail - the miracle of money growth will be missed.The differences between the countries of the center and the periphery did not decrease.There is a gap between wages, with an unhealthy flow of labor from east to west, causing social tensions on both sides.Recognizing this, he launched the European Citizens' Initiative of the Jobbik for Hungary Movement to catch up with wages.And it has found partners for this in seven countries and in the European Commission.We hope you get the result!

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: - Madam President, I join in praising the Maltese Presidency's balance sheet. They assumed the commitment of the Presidency at a really difficult time for the Union, where there was a rise in anti-European forces. It is true that the elections in the Basque Country and the Netherlands have shown that populism and nationalism are not the solution and have given air to the Union at a time when Brexit was becoming a reality, and also with the challenge of immigration, which was one of the main challenges; the challenge of immigration and the challenge of integration. Obviously, also with economic problems, terrorism, security and others. It is true that there are achievements and that the end of roaming has to be put on the table, which has been a historic milestone; the signing of the Istanbul Convention, in the fight against violence against women; the Marrakesh Treaty, which we are going to approve this Thursday, for access to published works for people with visual disabilities; and also the Directive against money laundering, to make it very difficult for all those who seek tax evasion. But it is true that the challenges we have on the table are many: one of them is immigration, many colleagues have said. We still do not solve in a dignified and efficient way the greatest humanitarian crisis after the Second World War. The reception capacity is today only 11% of the Member States, when it could be much more, and it will take a lot of coordination efforts by the next Presidency to face this challenge. Obviously, it was not the responsibility of Malta. It has been and is the responsibility of everyone present here and of all the European institutions. There is no doubt that the future of the Union passes through the social key. With the social key we will have a safe and secure Europe, a prosperous, sustainable and strong Europe in the international arena.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: - Mr Prime Minister, I know that you have done your best, in a situation where there is little or no attention among European governments to the refugee situation, you have made progress. You have made progress on measures to ensure the security of Europeans, less permeable borders, but unfortunately you have not made progress that also provides safe and legal routes for people fleeing war that would keep the face of Europe human. Thousands are fleeing Libya today. I do not blame you, your hospitable island, I blame all those responsible who complain the most today, saying that European policies do not work, but at the same time contribute the least to finding common solutions. It is these who are most undermining the unity of Europe. The situation in Italy is very serious. The adoption of a functioning European migration policy must go hand in hand with certain measures for the economic growth and jobs of Europeans. But without the solidarity and responsibility of all governments to manage migration, without a thorough overhaul of the asylum system, we will also be wasting the good that Europe has built. Dear Prime Minister, our results count when people live better: in Malta, Slovenia or Turkey, Syria and Libya. You said that the time has come for everyone to decide whether all Member States should decide whether we respect European values. I agree with you, let us work together to make every young man on our continent proud to say he is a European.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: - Madam President! The Maltese Presidency gave me the idea of ​​reviewing the relationship between small and large states. Last Saturday we celebrated Helmut Kohl as a great European. Helmut Kohl said that we must always treat the small states with decency and dignity. How is it now? The last Council presidencies were Lithuania, Estonia is coming, Slovakia, Malta - so small states now control Europe. Let's look: every country has a commissioner. And it's not that the big countries have the big commissioners. No! It is different. Mr. Juncker has chosen vice-presidents from a small state. Not from a big state. In the ECB, all countries, however small they are, have one vote. Also Germany - a sensational way of doing monetary policy in the world. Let's look at - Mr Juncker, you are looking at me right now - the country of Luxembourg has three presidents: you, Gaston Thorn and Pierre Werner, Germany only one: Hallstein. We now have to make sure that we remember Helmut Kohl again in relation to the relationship between the large and the small states, who might now say: Dear countries, dear members of the European Union, do not forget the interests of the large states.

name: Gesine MEISSNER
text: - Madam President! It has just been said: small states, large states. It has been stressed quite often that Malta is the smallest state - absolutely right. But I think that the European Union is characterized precisely by the fact that everyone makes their contribution, both large and small states. And I find out from my personal work perspective that Malta did a very good job there. I would now like to express my thanks to the Maltese Presidency for three reasons - three reasons that have not yet been mentioned: One is - all things that I have seen myself - an inter-ministerial conference in Malta, at the invitation of your Commissioner Karmenu Vella, to blue Growth and at the same time a further development of the economic power in the Mediterranean area and maritime tourism. It was very successful, in a very good atmosphere and with good decisions. Another point, where I would also like to thank you very much: This is something that your President Coleiro Preca is very committed to, which again fits in with migration policy and the flow of refugees. She held a conference in Malta, made a statement afterwards and then held a seminar here in Parliament in Brussels, which I was also able to host as a host, on the subject of maternal health, especially among refugee women. In other words, I saw that it is a small country, it cannot move everything, of course it does not easily manage to get the solidarity that we urgently need in Europe or to create the distribution key, but You are doing something very specifically to help these minorities, and maternal health, especially for pregnant refugee women, is an extremely important issue. A third point: You have successfully dealt with various points, various laws in the maritime field, for maritime security - I can also tell you about this on behalf of myself I would like to thank colleagues from the ALDE Group. And personally I negotiated something with you very successfully, which is special for Malta, because it was about qualification in inland navigation. You have no inland waterway transport at all, but I have to say that your negotiating team has worked very successfully with me to ensure that, against the opposition of some of the larger Member States who have said they want to legally participate, they have succeeded in increasing labor mobility in this sector improve and create something good there. So thank you again from my job. I am already looking forward to it: in October you will be holding the follow-up conference to the great UN Conference on the Ocean in Malta, which was in New York in June, again with Karmenu Vella, with whom I work very well. I think he is a very good Commissioner who is passionate about clean oceans that can then serve humanity. Thank you again from my side.

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: - Madam President, Mr Presidents! I don't take part in the big or small discussion. From a trade policy perspective, we cannot be satisfied with Malta's presidency. You, too, were unable to deliver the important mandates of the ongoing negotiations on free trade agreements to Parliament. What are you negotiating with Japan? What does the new mandate for talks with Morocco mean after the court ruling in favor of Western Sahara and the Polisario? Addressing you and the Estonian Presidency and Mr Tusk: the Council must act immediately! Then the trade defense instruments. Why were you so unable to compromise in the trialogue? China's WTO lawsuit has rightly started and we are left empty-handed. Ukraine was important to you. The import quotas for agricultural goods should be increased further. That doesn't help the country, but rather a few great owners in this country. Still, some praise: together we have lowered the quotas proposed by the Commission and linked them to strict conditions. Progress by the government in Kiev on social and employment policy is now a condition. For the first time, the Commission will have to report on the social impact of the measures in Ukraine and in the Union.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: - Madam President, Presidents! In a nutshell. First of all, I have to say that I find it shameful when the Maltese Presidency is accused of being unable to solve the migration problems. That turns the actual situation completely on its head! It is other Member States that have refused for years to come to common solutions both on the causes of flight and on the solidarity-based distribution of refugees. And one can hardly blame the Maltese Council Presidency for that; rather, those who have proceeded with harsh words are actually the causes for the inability to adopt a European migration and refugee policy. Unfortunately, we saw the failure of the money laundering directive reform in the Maltese presidency. And again I have to say: It is not your fault in the Maltese Presidency that it failed. When it comes to financial crime, many member states are soft on crime, they protect the intransparency of their trusts, Germany has no cadastre. These are all things, Europe has to work together and not everyone has to protect dirty money nationally. And Mr. Premier: You still owe me one answer, namely to the question: What actually happened to the three investigation reports from your money laundering authority? Why haven't the police opened any investigations? I'm not talking about the one against you personally, but about the other three. You did not answer that in our last debate. Please follow up here with the answer.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: - Madam President, Mr President of the Commission, Prime Minister! Yes, it was your first presidency, and I would say quite a successful one. It is especially important for small member countries to perform - European and possibly also globally. I myself come from a small Member State - from Austria - I know how important that is. And you have performed particularly in matters relating to the sea and fishing - blue growth has already been mentioned today. However, it has not been mentioned that you have concluded a far-reaching agreement on fisheries which has been pending for over a decade and which is particularly important for the European Union. You performed at the start of the Brexit negotiations, where you acted as a mediator to ensure that the European Union preserves unity. You performed on some of the topics of the Industry Committee, namely energy efficiency labeling, the harmonization of the 470 to 790 MHz band, portability, the WiFi initiative and, most importantly, the end of roaming charges. But you have also left some issues to the next presidency, namely digitization - which is certainly in good hands with the Estonians - and in the area of ​​financial services the two VAT files and the amendments to the fourth anti-money laundering directive. That may have a bad taste - it has already been mentioned - and it will hopefully be implemented in the next presidency. And of course the open issue of refugee and migration policy: Here you initiated the ETIAS negotiations, but many problems such as B. the endowment of the Africa Fund are still open.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Madam President, thank you. Prime Minister Muscat, several times in your remarks this morning you spoke of the small size of Malta. You even praised the President of Estonia’s phrase that Europe is made up of small nations and states that have not yet realised they are small. Those remarks send out a message that being small is something that cannot stand up in the rest of the world. May I remind you that, in the top 40 countries of the world, Singapore, Hong Kong, Israel and Switzerland are countries that are small but have larger GDPs than most of the nations represented in this House? The United Kingdom, my country, has the fifth largest in the world. On your flag is the George Cross, something your nation won for standing up against the aggression of a larger entity. Your remarks are a shame on those people who believe that size does not matter, that only with the bravery, the spirit, the heart and the goodwill of people in staying strong and true to proper values, can they stand forward and move on in the world. You should not think that being small makes you insignificant, as you suggest.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam President, I thank Mr. Juncker for opening the topic of small and large and, unfortunately, I give up my initial speech because I also come from a small country, Croatia, and I really do not want to feel small. And that’s why, Mr. Muscat, congratulations on what you’ve done. And do you know why I have a speaking time here this morning? Because I wanted to have a speaking time tomorrow about the Estonian presidency, but they told me there would get a speaking time of a large delegation. So the climate here is big and small. I ask all colleagues who are here to get rid of this “big and small” and try to be important. So, for me, my little Croatia is the biggest in the world. As far as your presidency is concerned, it is not fair to expect you to solve the migration policy or the asylum policy because that was simply not realistic or possible when we have been struggling to solve it for so many years. But that is why you have decided to preserve the fish stock in the Mediterranean and even in my Adriatic, and that is why I am very proud of the directive you have passed. And for everything else, there will be more time and I hope that the other presidencies, and in 2020, when Croatia will preside, that we will solve big problems and great nations.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President, I too appreciated your very sincere and I would say clear words, with which you said: we must give substance to the principles of the Union, give concrete answers. And in this regard I cite two examples: roaming, mentioned several times, but also BEFORE. I think this has been a great success for the determination with which you have pursued it. Few have perhaps realized, here, what it means to create a cooperation platform between European countries and African countries of the Mediterranean shore for the management of a resource such as water, with all the implications for energy, for food, etc. It is therefore a good success, of which I feel part of the ITRE committee. But there is a point, however, that cannot be attributed to your Presidency, but that from Presidency to Presidency is delivered within the Council in a chain without end and without solution, and that is that of migration flows. I repeat what I said yesterday in this House: my country has taken on a European issue, and today it cannot take it anymore, quite simply. The other courtly words have run out. This is the fact. President Juncker is well aware of this, he is a great ally, trying to do his utmost, but the Council absolutely must find concrete and precise solutions. We have chosen, like Italy, to save, to welcome. We want to save the flag of civilization of Europe, but alone we can't do it anymore. There is a problem of credibility in Europe, which plays on this card, I believe, its essence, its future.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: - Madam President! Mr President of the Commission! Prime Minister! The plus of the Maltese presidency is certainly a declaration on the external dimension of the European Union's migration policy, and thus a recognition that, first of all, it is necessary to act in such a way that there are fewer migrants from outside. Plus, there is also - no need to hide - references to the full use of the potential of the single market, and therefore such skepticism towards productionism. Plus it is also - congratulations - the issue of roaming. Many countries have worked on it, including us in the Euro-Parliament, but you as the Presidency have ended. A disadvantage, and certainly a big disadvantage, are the proposed directive regarding the posting of workers as part of the provision of services. It is indeed a certain preference for rich countries at the expense of poor countries. And here it cannot be agreed. (The speaker agreed to take a blue card question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- Dear colleague, I am also pleased with Malta's results.You have highlighted a few.I want to ask you: do you think that Malta, not because it is a small state, but because the country holding the presidency for six months, can do something if the other European institutions: the Commission, the Parliament, the Council do not go in the same direction?Because Malta has certainly promised, for example, the entry of Schengen into Bulgaria and Romania, but the Netherlands opposes it.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: answer to a question asked by raising a blue card.- Thank you very much for this important question.It concerns a certain philosophy of action of the European Union, and not necessarily the Maltese Presidency.It is good that the Member States, despite the appointment of the President of the Council, have the Presidency and exert some pressure in the right direction.I can only say that your country, Romania, and also Bulgaria should be members of the Schengen area. I hope that the Estonian Presidency will move in this direction.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: - Madam President, the Malta presidency of the European Union took place at a time when there was a significant change in the dominant discourse on the future of Europe. The cycle of false structural reforms has ended and a new cycle of renewal of the European project is now beginning, and the Maltese Presidency has made significant progress in dossiers that reinforce citizens' connection to the European project and make the Union's operation stronger and more transparent. This is the case with the steps taken in the field of financial transparency and the good financial functioning of the internal market and in the clean energy and circular economy packages. The emblematic measure of the end of Roaming and the new rules to guarantee the portability of online content and services are watermarks of the Maltese presidency. Your commitment to the tripartite agreement to make the WIFI4EU initiative feasible to promote universal and free access to high-quality Internet in public spaces - an initiative of which I am the rapporteur - deserves to be highlighted. There are many ways to go. Malta, however, conveyed a testimony of hope and demand for the future.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Mr President, Malta took over the Presidency of the European Union at a time when the Union was facing a number of challenges. And you have heard, we have all found that Malta has mastered this task masterfully, has issued an excellent certificate of itself. But not because, Prime Minister, because Malta is a small country, but because they have approached the problems in a very innovative way. And this is well exemplified by the broad political consensus reached in the interinstitutional negotiations on the European Asylum Agency. We are well aware that the Asylum Agency is perhaps the most important institution in the common European asylum policy. However, there are still Member States that have not understood that asylum is a European problem and cannot be solved at Member State level. Moreover, many did not realize that solidarity between Member States is one of the preconditions for the political unity of the European Union. That is why I am pleased that, at the end of it all, an agreement has been reached - and this is partly due to the Maltese Government - that will advance the common European asylum policy.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Mr President, I will start by saying that what I have learned about Malta is that, although it is a small Member State, it proves that it can do great things, so 'size does not matter', that's my understanding. counts ", I understand that). But I will talk to you about another small Member State, which is currently fighting on behalf of the whole of the European Union and the values ​​that we all say we believe in. Imagine your Member State being small, an island about the size of Malta, with one third of it occupied by a third country. Let us all talk about European solidarity, but keep it to words. You know, of course, which country I am talking about; I am talking about Cyprus, which remains committed to European values ​​and hopes that this European Union will show in practice its solidarity not with a weak and small Member State, but with its aggressive Turkey. Erdogan. This must be the European Union, dear partners and friends. (applause)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the most important issue that the Maltese Presidency should have dealt with is refugees, and on this issue I would say that the European Union has failed altogether, because the presidency can make efforts, but when there is resistance from the Member States, the problems are growing; and remember that there is a promise from the European Union that there will be 66,400 relocations of refugees from Greece. Unfortunately, so far only 12,700 have been made, ie about 15-20%, and the time for organizing and executing the relocation program is coming to an end. So, a serious issue here is that solidarity measures need to be taken. The Aegean islands can no longer stand, they can no longer stand other refugees and illegal immigrants and the solidarity of the European Union must be expressed in practice in this matter, as it should have been expressed in Cyprus, because it is the only country in which there is occupation. by a foreign power. The Turkish occupation troops remain on Cypriot territory and this is unacceptable and the European Union's solidarity with the Cypriot people must be expressed.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, I have a question for Mr Juncker. My understanding was that, during the Maltese Presidency, over the last couple of months there was an important paradigm shift in the whole migration and refugee issue – a shift from just allowing millions and millions of migrants coming to Europe towards treating the root causes, and treating the whole issue locally. Did I misunderstand something? Is this not what is actually happening? What is the policy of the European Union, following the Maltese Presidency? This kind of paradigm shift is what my country, Hungary, has been fighting for for a long time, and we shall never give up. I look forward to your answer.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I am interested in all the talk about ‘small’ because I come from a small country. We have held the presidency a number of times in our involvement in the European Union since 1973, and I think our last presidency was deemed very successful. It does prove that small countries can have very successful presidencies if they take it seriously, put in the resources and utilise the back-up that is available. I think Malta did that very effectively and they are to be complimented on their dedication and on their practicality. One thing that happened during their presidency – they cannot claim full credit for it but it will always be recorded as happening during their presidency – was the end of roaming charges. They got it over the line, made sure it happened, and it is for the benefit of all Europeans. It just shows that, whether a country is small or big, once we put our resources together and work together we can be successful for all Europeans. Malta is a perfect example and well done to them.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: - Sur President, nixtieq ngħid prosit lill-Prim Ministru Malti Joseph Muscat u lill-Maltin kollha li ħadmu fi Brussell u f’Malta għall-ħidma kbira, l-impenn u d-determinazzjoni tagħhom biex għamlu Presidency storja ta ’suċċess. Li jkollok Tal-Unjoni Presidency Ewropea għall-ewwel darba dejjem hija challenge għall-pajjiż żgħir bħal Malta. Iżda li jkollok il-Presidency waqt żminijiet turbulent fl-Ewropa, bħan-Negozjati ta ’Brexit u kriżijiet ta’ immigrazzjoni u l-qgħad jagħmluha challenges Akbar. Minkejja dawn l-ostakoli, Malta wriet il-kapaċità tiffaċċja u tilħaq il-miri fl-interess tal-Ewropa, taċ-ċittadini tagħha. Il-Presidency Maltija ħadmet fuq different active initiators u għamlet konkreti steps f’bosta oqsma important u nnegozjat ftehim biex iddaħħal leġiżlazzjoni f’għexieren ta ’setturi, fosthom fuq is-suq uniku diġitali, l-suq uniku diġitali, l-suq uniku diġitali. Bħala membru fit-tim ta ’Negozjaturi tal-ġestazzjoni tar-roaming, ninsab partikolarment kburija li l-fajl li bbenefika miljuni taċ-ċittadini ngħalaq waqt il-Presidency. Mhix sorpriża li Malta ġiet imfaħħra tant xogħol eċċellenti u impressjonanti. Malta hija pajjiż żgħir imma wriet li d-daqs ta ’pajjiż mhux important daqs serjetà, determinazzjoni u kapaċità ta’ niesha. Prosit Prim Ministru, prosit Malta.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Mr President, dear President Muscat!Malta has also become a special place globally.79 ACP countries meet once a year in one of the countries - in Africa, the Caribbean or the Pacific.But the ACP delegation also meets once a year in the country that holds the Council Presidency in the European Member States.Mr President, after a few years we did not meet in Strasbourg this year, but in Malta.Malta not only looks at the refugees on the ground, but also sees international responsibility.We should do much more as Europe: Europe away from any exit, but taking responsibility.For this we as parliamentarians not only have to show visible responsibility.Mr President Muscat!We wish you continued success for your country Malta as a sign of the responsibility that you can achieve a lot even as a small country!

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, as expected, the Maltese presidency was a success, but it also had a number of issues that it failed to address. In my opinion, the most important thing is that, although a small country, Malta managed to handle the issues assigned to it without any problems. However, without Malta being responsible, there has been no success in dealing with the serious problems facing the European Union and I focus on the lack of solidarity with Greece, whose people are suffering for the eighth consecutive year because of the memoranda imposed, and the lack of solidarity with Cyprus, part of which is illegally occupied by Turkey. Also, there was no success in preventing illegal entrants into Europe, who continue to come, and I wanted to ask the Prime Minister why he did not mention Greece at this point in his speech. Did he forget it or does he feel ashamed because the European Union has imposed on Greece its transformation into a vast concentration camp of people illegally entering Europe?

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, in total the Maltese Presidency successfully signed off a record of 20 laws in the so—called Coreper 1 Policy Grouping, and that is despite the fact that Malta was in election mode for a month and had no ministers for a week while Prime Minister Joseph Muscat formed a new government. I would like in particular to warmly thank the Presidency for the excellent cooperation on the report on the European Fund for Sustainable Development, for which I was a co-rapporteur for the Committee on Development, to promote sustainable investment in Africa and in the EU neighbourhood and tackle the root causes of migration, which is hopefully going to be adopted on Thursday. The Maltese Presidency achieved clear and tangible results on the legislative proposals regarding the setting up of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office and the revision of Eurojust. Last but not least, allow me to thank and congratulate also our colleagues from Malta, the MEPs who were so active during the Maltese Presidency.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr President Muscat, the political will that you have tried to put into play in your presidency is not in question. However, I must say that your speech, which describes reality for what it is, perhaps protects us from the point of view of intellectual honesty, but does not solve the problems. And I must say that the migration issue, which is the political and social thermometer in Europe, is unfortunately the sign of the impotence, inability and cowardice with which many European countries are addressing this issue, or rather, they are not addressing it. . So, what poses a country like Italy is a right issue, which has not only a national significance. I think he's tired of slapping on the back and solidarity in words. It is necessary to move on to facts. And I believe and hope that even in your conclusions you can say something more about it, with respect to the difficulties that exist and the responsibilities that must absolutely be recalled.

name: Jean-Claude Juncker
text: President of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am being asked about European immigration policy. On this issue, I wanted to say how grateful we are to the Maltese Presidency for making things happen, and for moving them in the right direction. Under the Maltese Presidency, on several occasions, we have been able to take decisions on migration policy which do honor to the Presidency and which testify to the will - I hope the ardent will - of the European Union as a whole to make progress in this area. The Commission will deliberate, today and in this city, on migration policy, and we will show by facts that we are going to announce that we want to remain in solidarity, in particular with Italy, which, in terms of migration policy, is proof of a truly heroic attitude. We have said, the Maltese Prime Minister and I, since the start of the crisis, solidarity is essential, solidarity is a two-way street. We do not have the right to get lost in national egoisms and we will demonstrate it today. The Commission has done a lot, but it has not been able to do everything it should have done, because our technical and financial means are extremely limited. But we will continue to act in solidarity with Italy. Viva Italia!

name: Joseph MUSCAT
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank Members of this House for the very constructive debate we have had today. I would love to take the blame for the migration problem, because that would be simple and would mean that whoever comes next would be able to solve the problem. Unfortunately, we all know that is not the case. I must also shoulder the blame, as representative of the Council, for this fiasco for the simple reason that it is not the fault of the Commission. The Commission’s ideas are very clear and, as a Member State, we totally agree with those ideas. We cannot blame Parliament. Your position as Parliament has been more or less the same since the first time I was here 12 years ago and, really and truly, there is nothing more to say about these two institutions. The problem is within the Council, and it boils down to values once again. I am afraid that it has nothing to do with politics because, if it had to do with politics, for every political problem there is a political solution. Now we have to be very honest: it boils down to what we believe in. And that is why I urge my colleagues in the Council to have an honest debate, without making excuses about why we should do something or why we should not do something, but about what kind of Europe we believe. And, rather than just Europe, what values we believe in. This is a Council problem and we have to come up with a solution. I must say that, as a Presidency, we have inched forward and made some progress. What we saw in our strategy was a constant search for what could unite us. When it comes to migration, what really unites us in the Council is the external dimension of the phenomenon. I think we have achieved a great deal in saying that we need to address this issue from both a humanitarian and a security perspective. It is not just a humanitarian problem, but it is not just a security problem either. For some this was something that couldn’t be said, but I think we managed to put forward a sensible approach when it comes to the external dimension, and we have achieved progress. I will give you a couple of examples where sterling work is being done by the Commission – things that are not said and that maybe some of you will not agree with, because they are philosophically opposed to the perspective of some – but these are things that are being done. With our missions in Libya this year we, as the European Union, have so far managed to convince about 5 000 people –double the number from last year – to go back voluntarily to their countries of origin and not to engage in crossing the sea. What is 5 000 when compared to the numbers arriving on our shores daily? It is nothing. But I must stress that, for every person who is convinced, a huge input and a huge effort is being made by all of us as the European Union, and we aim to get that number up to 10 000 by the end of the year. Will that make a difference? It is a drop in the ocean, but at least it is a drop because, until now, nothing significant was being done. I must also commend the huge efforts that are being made in Mali and at the southern Libyan border. For the first time, we are seeing the European Union engage with tribal communities at the southern border; tribal communities that earn a living from smuggling people. And, when we engage with them, they tell us quite clearly, in a very realpolitik fashion, that they are not doing the right thing in collaborating with criminals and ask us to give them an alternative. They ask how they will pay for their tribe to get food and shelter. For the first time, money from the European Union is going directly to those communities at the border to show them that there is an alternative way in which they can finance their own activities. This is only a start, but it is an important start. I must also say that we have managed, through the good offices of a number of Member States, notably Italy and the Netherlands, to train the first batch of Libyan coast guard members. Most importantly, once they had been trained, they went back to their country and did not escape because there were previous cases of training programmes where we, as Europe, trained people who ended up with militias, fighting against what we trained them to do. So this is a significant step forward, which cannot just be brushed aside as insignificant. May I just touch on the issue of smallness or greatness? When we say that we are a small country, we are just saying things as they are. We have limited resources, and I am very proud of what we have managed to achieve: a five—minute meeting on Brexit where we put forward a united European position in what many thought would have been a protracted discussion for hours on end with divisions. No; it was a five-minute meeting that ended in unity concerning the Istanbul Convention. This was a great achievement, which I think is an achievement by the whole European Union. To my colleague from Greece, I apologise for not mentioning Greece. I will say that Greece is always on our mind. After Germany, we are the country which contributes the highest percentage towards the Greek bail-out, so Greece is definitely on our mind. We did this without blinking an eye because we believe in solidarity. For us solidarity is not something that we advocate when migrants are coming to us and we want others to help us, but solidarity is something we practise when another Member State needs our help. That is part of the way we think. On the issue raised by Mr Giegold – whom I thank for his very proactive approach today – I know that there are many misgivings about the issue of fiscal policy within this institution. This is something that we need to engage with even more, not just as a Member States, but in a number of Member States where we need to understand each other better. We have to draw very clear lines on what we disagree about. Fiscal policy stands fairly and squarely within the remit of Member States to decide, but there need to be clear rules. I agree with that, and I must stress that, in the case of Malta, our tax system is OECD-compliant. It is the same tax system which the Commission approved before our membership of the European Union and it has not changed since then. So my point is that, if it was not a problem 13 years ago, why is it a problem now? Let’s discuss that. Once again I want to stress that this is an issue that lies fairly and squarely within the remit of Member States. On the issue, mentioned by Mr Giegold, of investigations: investigations are ongoing. They are independent and something which we will always respect. There is rule of law in our country, and I look forward to further debate on this issue, which I am sure we will have in the coming months. Finally, I was amused by Mr Lamberts’ speech, a Green politician defining socialism to me. I loved it. I will not engage in definitions, but will just tell you what I stand for and what my government stands for. We stand for free healthcare, we stand for free university education, we stand for free childcare, we stand for increasing the minimum wage, we stand for increasing pensions, we stand for full employment, and we stand for equal marriage, on which we will be voting in our Parliament tomorrow. So I will leave it up to you to define whether that is socialism or not.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Prime Minister, thank you for your answers and for the work you have done in this presidency of our Union.The discussion is closed.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the report by Hugues Bayet and Evelyn Regner, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs and the Committee on Legal Affairs, on the Proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2013/34/EU as regards disclosure of income tax information by certain undertakings and branches (COM(2016)0198 – C8—0146/2016 – 2016/0107(COD)) (A8—0227/2017).

name: Hugues BAYET
text: protractor. - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the dossier which will be submitted to us to vote on this noon is a crucial dossier, because we are really at the crossroads of European fiscal construction. The question is: what Europe do we want? A Europe of fiscal justice or a Europe of deregulation? A Europe which treats its citizens and its businesses according to the same rules or a Europe which encourages tax aggressiveness between its multinationals, its SMEs and its start-ups to the detriment of its citizens? Country-by-country reporting is directly linked to tax transparency. I think this is really another tool to fight all the scandals that we have known. First of all, I would like to thank the Commission, which has taken the issue of the fight against tax evasion head-on. Since the start of the legislature and, notably under the leadership of Commissioner Moscovici, a set of proposals has been put on the table and concrete measures have been adopted in this area. I am thinking, in particular, of the directive on the compulsory automatic exchange of information on tax rulings, the directive on anti-tax avoidance rules and the directive on money laundering. At the same time, Parliament has not remained outdone since, whether through the TAXE 1 and 2 reports or, soon, the future recommendations of the commission of inquiry on the Panama papers, further proof of the need to legislate in this area, we also worked on this file. Commissioner, you have offered us a text which we have amended. I would like to highlight five key elements in this report. The first is the enterprise threshold, which is set at 750 million per year. We would have liked a threshold of 40 million, if any threshold at all, so that all multinationals could be put on an equal footing. But we have reached an agreement on this threshold, as well as on the need for the Commission to carry out an impact assessment after four years in order to assess whether this threshold should be lowered and whether the list of criteria is sufficient in relation to the desired objective. The second element, which was strongly requested by civil society, concerns data: they will be published in a common register accessible free of charge to all. The third element is the list of criteria, such as the name of the company, the number of full-time employees or the value of assets, which will be published. This will allow the competent authorities to detect possible errors or fraud. The fourth element relates to sanctions. Each Member State will be able to decide to impose sanctions on companies which do not comply with the directive, and therefore which do not publish their data. Finally, the last element concerns the complete disaggregation of data, as already foreseen in action 13 of the OECD BEPS project. That is, the data should be broken down by country, by sector and by year. This is an essential element. A safeguard clause has been added in order, among other things, to protect sensitive business data, because all of us here in Parliament understand that our multinationals must also be protected. But, on this point, we unfortunately have a difference of views as to the definition of the safeguard clause, because, for us socialists, the companies concerned can ask a Member State for a derogation so as not to publish data that would be commercially sensitive, but on four conditions. The first is that this exemption must be requested again each year. The second is that its relevance needs to be assessed and reviewed by the European Commission to avoid problems with SwissLeaks, for example. If the latter considers that the request for exemption is unfounded, the company must publish the data. With regard to the third criterion, we believe that, when this exemption ends, the company concerned must retroactively publish the data which had been the subject of it. Finally, we think it is important that there is a time limit on the exemptions. For us, this limit should be the tax prescription in each Member State so as not to give an “amnesty” bonus to potential cheaters. I think it's really essential for better tax fairness that we know where the biggest companies make their profits and how much tax they pay in each of the states where they operate. Without this information, tax fairness will never become a reality. Every euro in tax that is not paid by multinationals is overpaid by households. However, we must restore confidence and fiscal justice in Europe. It remains for me to thank my colleague Evelyn Regner, rapporteur with me, as well as all the shadow rapporteurs, but, Madam President, I will come back to this in the context of my conclusions.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, dear Mr Dombrovskis! Thank you, Hugues, for presenting the key points of this report. With this position, which Hugues Bayet has now presented, we want to enter into negotiations with the Council after the votes. Public CBCR is great. Global reporting on corporate profits and taxes is exactly what we need in Europe. This directive is one of the most important initiatives taken by the Commission after the tax scandals. It holds the multinationals, but indirectly also the governments, accountable. All taxpayers need to be entitled to know what profits are made by global corporations like Starbucks, McDonalds, Monsanto & amp; Co. do where they book, where they pay their taxes for it. We in this House represent the citizens, we represent the taxpayers in all of our Member States. We have to prove that we mean business and create transparency for our constituents that prevents unlimited secrets from individual companies in consultation with governments. I therefore appeal to all colleagues, to all progressive MEPs in this House, to the liberals, to the conservatives, to all those who have made a special contribution in the TAXE and Panama committees: corrected with the adoption of Amendments 84 and 85 and 86 the regulation that was created in the committee votes. I have already received a number of signs that the clause proposed by us as co-rapporteurs is acceptable. Show us in the vote that you too are against limitless, unlimited intransparency, and vote with us! This worldwide publication of the corporate taxes that we want to introduce is correct and important for many reasons. It should be emphasized that the European Parliament, with the support of almost all political groups, is in favor of publication worldwide. We want the publication to take effect worldwide and the figures will in future be published country by country. We do not want any restriction to the states of the EU and the states of the tax swamp. If Starbucks wants to make profits in the EU internal market, it must in future also publish profits in Dubai, Shanghai or Panama. Our idea of ​​the directive only applies to the very big ones, i.e. those with EUR 750 million in sales per year. Only the data that is already available are to be published, and this is done worldwide, country by country. With this guideline, we are shedding light on global profit-shifting structures, we are making these opaque constructs more visible, we are making competition fairer, especially for SMEs, but certainly also for large companies in Europe, and we are creating fairness for the corner coffee house, such as Starbucks had to give way and could not withstand the competition. Worldwide public reporting by country is a key to transparency. It has enormous added value in terms of development policy, and it creates fairness for all those who dutifully pay their taxes. With the publication of the number of employees, everyone can see in which country employees are registered, where the multinationals have their letterbox companies and in which country they only post their profits. The transparency is an added value for all stakeholders - for customers, for employees, for investors and of course for the taxpayers. The transparency will not be anti-competitive either. On the contrary: it will attract investors, those investors who want sustainable companies and who want to invest sustainably. That means: We want sustainable companies that make their contribution to the tax systems and to the welfare state. With that in mind, I would like to express my thanks to all those who have contributed constructively. But we still have a lot to do.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission has made fair taxation one of its priorities. And, naturally, since recent disclosures have once again underlined the magnitude of the problem, calls for action have gained force. We have put forward a raft of measures to tackle tax abuse and to make sure that companies pay their fair share of taxes in the countries where their actual economic activity is taking place. In addition to measures addressing directly companies’ tax affairs and the work of tax authorities we are convinced that corporate transparency is part of the equation. Parliament has been vocal and pivotal in calling for a valid answer to the widespread public discontent. The Commission responded timely in a constructive way.  The public country-by-country reporting, which we are examining today mainly aims to address two issues. First, a growing public distrust in the fairness of the tax system, and second, the accountability of multinational companies towards our citizens. The proposed corporate transparency measure is an ambitious and unprecedented move, a move that requires striking a delicate balance between, on the one hand, the public’s legitimate demands for information, and, on the other, legitimate calls for our businesses not to weaken their world-wide competitiveness.  The Commission also paid attention to complement, but not undermine, the existing system of exchange of a country-by-country reporting by tax authorities. This system is gaining remarkable traction globally under the aegis of the OECD and G20 and with the full support the European Union.  It is easy to see the importance of the issue. Due to corporate tax avoidance, our governments miss out an estimated EUR 50 to 70 billion a year. In view of the fiscal efforts they are making and the investment demanded by the economies, these amounts are unacceptably high. So, honourable Members, we trust in your support to get this proposal agreed as quickly as possible.

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank my fellow rapporteurs for their excellent and valuable work on this crucial dossier. State-by-state reporting is a fundamental measure for transparency and against tax evasion and avoidance at global and European level. Compared to the initial proposal, Parliament has extended this obligation for multinationals to all countries in which they operate, including outside the EU. This will also allow developing countries to obtain valuable information on multinationals operating within their borders. The poorest countries, in fact, are the ones that pay the highest price for these practices, losing hundreds of billions of dollars every year, fundamental resources for development. The fight against poverty and inequality also passes from here. Unfortunately, today there are those who preach well and scratch badly in this House, wanting a safeguard clause that would allow multinationals to avoid publishing information deemed sensitive. Without at least the retroactive publication of this information, this becomes a very dangerous loophole for continuing to hide profits. So I appeal to popular and liberal colleagues, recalling that partial solutions are not enough in the face of a global phenomenon. We can approve a historical measure, and when history passes it is good not to be found elsewhere.

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the draft directive on public country—by—country reporting requires multinationals to publicly disclose all tax information. The idea behind this initiative is to increase tax transparency and to put multinationals under pressure from public opinion, to make sure that large companies pay their fair share of taxes in countries where they create value. This is yet another piece of European legislation aimed at eliminating the harmful practices of tax avoidance and tax evasion in Europe. The PPE Group has supported the Commission’s proposal from the very beginning. We are in favour of more transparency in corporate taxation, but we also want the EU legislation to be consistent with international standards for tax information exchange established by the OECD under the Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) project, and adopted by almost 100 countries all over the world.  With those considerations in mind, we have worked hard to find a compromise that would be supported by all major political groups in Parliament. We have made important concessions. We agreed on the disaggregation information, we agreed on an extension of the list of information required, and we finally agreed on the review clause for the threshold. However, we have not come to a common position on the safeguard clause.  The left side of this House insisted on much more radical proposals that would go far beyond the Commission’s draft and would undermine the OECD BEPS Agreement. Accepting these proposals would establish an uneven playing field, with EU companies subject to more demanding requirements for public disclosure than their competitors from third countries. We do not want to discriminate against EU companies and that is why we oppose some of the rapporteur’s amendments that simply put EU companies at a competitive disadvantage vis—à—vis their third country competitors, and which would also make the business climate in the European Union less friendly for investors.  Our objective is to strike a balance between the legitimate demand for more transparency, on the one hand, and the need to protect EU companies in order to guarantee more jobs and growth in Europe. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Ana GOMES
text: blue-card question. – Mr Rosati, do you not feel ashamed to invoke competitive disadvantage for multinationals when our citizens are demanding fairness in taxation, and when we see that there has not been any fairness and, indeed, that multinationals have been abusing our inability to deliver that fairness?

name: Dariusz ROSATI
text: blue-card answer. – Frankly, I don’t understand your point. I think the whole thing here is about public disclosure of tax information, not about avoiding taxes or tax avoidance. This tax avoidance is a task of tax authorities, and we have to have trust in the national tax authorities that they do their job properly. What we are talking about here is disclosure – public disclosure of information. This has nothing to do with tax evasion. This is one thing. The other thing is that we have to take into account the uneven playing field. If you put this requirement on EU companies and other companies, American, Canadians, Japanese don’t have the same obligation – that would be harmful for our businesses.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D group. - Madam President, Commissioner, dear rapporteurs, the European Parliament has played its role here following the initiatives it had taken in the banking sector and on the initiative of Sergio Cofferati. What is it about? This is to make it possible to check where companies are making a profit and, depending on that, where they have to pay their taxes. Too often, behind tax optimization or tax evasion, there is a shortfall for the budgets of the Member States and, therefore, a lack of funds for the financing of policies, whether in the field of education , health, or culture, because at the end of the day that's what it is. Through these tax optimization mechanisms, which are hidden in aggregate operations, multinationals have gone from a 35% taxation in 1995 to 22.8% in 2015. There is something unacceptable for citizens here. who are increasingly suffering the effects of the crisis. The will of the Socialist Group has been to go beyond, with our co-rapporteurs, the Commission proposal, which I would like to thank for the kindness with which it observed the work of this Parliament. We need to go further because what we got for the banks there is no reason not to get for the multinationals. We will have a meeting and we are awaiting initiatives from the Commission to go beyond the current proposal. There is also the famous question of aggregate data for third countries.
