Mr Rosati invokes global competitiveness and the elements of BEPS, but the role of the European Union in this area - the work we have undertaken in the PANA or TAXE committees - is to go beyond the agreement of the BEPS and to allow companies to, of course, develop investment strategies through this safeguard clause, but that, behind this safeguard clause, safeguard, there is not a blank check for eternal secrecy and that this investment strategy falls within the framework of the fiscal ruling beyond which there must be full transparency on the profits ofcompanies, regardless of the state in which they are carried out.(The speaker accepts to answer a 'blue card' question (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules))

name: Michael THEURER
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Madam President!Dear colleague Berès, we all agree that we want to increase transparency.We fought against money laundering and tax avoidance together in the TAXE and Panama committees.Now we have this discussion about the question of competitiveness in this context, and companies - also in France, also in Germany - are very afraid.Do you not agree with me that the Commission should give a binding answer to this question of competitiveness?Because we naturally want to achieve a level playing field.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: answer "blue card".- Mr Theurer, in the name of competitiveness, I think that excellence for European companies is to be able to say what they are doing outside the European Union, whether in countriesunder development or elsewhere.This is excellence, and this is how the European Union will increase its true competitiveness and be able to lead the fight against tax evasion and tax optimization.This is our mission.This is what we have undertaken with Commissioner Dombrovskis and Commissioner Moscovici and what we must pursue.This is what the conclusions of the report you authored in the TAXE committee meant.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: the answer to the blue card question. - It is great that public country-specific tax and financial reporting is progressing. Until ten years ago, it would have been completely utopian. Personally, I regret that the turnover limit of EUR 750 million could not be lowered to EUR 40 million in Parliament's proposal. This will put large companies in an unequal position and leave a lot of socially relevant information in the dark. In preparing the Parliament's position, I pointed out, among other things, that the arguments for leaking trade secrets were weak. Competitors in large companies are already able to commission analyzes of their competitors' business models in key EU countries. The financial statements required for this are available for purchase in most major business areas. In contrast, the key purpose of country-by-country reporting is to bring transparency to the financing and tax arrangements of tax havens. Despite some shortcomings, the proposal is a clear step towards greater accountability and transparency for large companies. This is needed not only to secure the payment of tax to the states where the actual business takes place, but also to identify the various risks. It is to be hoped that the experience gained from this directive, natural resource reporting and banking reporting can be used as soon as possible and that the scope of public reporting will be extended to all large companies in the future.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, today is an important day for this Parliament. For many years, many of us have fought to achieve more transparency and accountability from multinational companies. This is a request our voters have been demanding of us for a long time. Today, we are voting on a good text. It would affect 90% of multinationals with a turnover higher than EUR 750 million a year world-wide. This would be an amazing achievement that will enhance transparency, limit wrongdoings and increase the confidence of our citizens on globalisation. The more transparent our multinationals become, the easier it will be to defend their big and undeniable importance for our economies.  In the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs our groups reached an agreement on 95% of the report. We should not abandon it because of a small disagreement on just one issue, and weaken the broad consensus we have in this Chamber just before the Council negotiations start. We all know that some Member States will do their best to weaken this legislation. I hope that no group in the European Parliament will make their task easier. If our voters could ask us to do just three things in this Parliament, one of them would be to make more transparent the dealings of our multinationals. Having more transparent multinationals is also – and foremost – about building a healthier and more accountable democracy.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, transparency today represents the best weapon in the fight against fraud and tax evasion. In this sense, this country-by-country report should be a fundamental step in enabling popular scrutiny of the behavior of multinational companies in this area. It happens that, once again, the mountain gave birth to a rat. An absurd billing limit of 750 million euros has been maintained, which leaves out the vast majority of multinational companies. One could have gone further in the information to be included in the report, but more seriously than that, an exception clause has been added at the last minute which, in practice, will completely neutralize the directive. With the false pretext of protecting commercially sensitive information, a derogation is introduced that allows multinational companies to hide relevant information, and this exemption can be renewed ad eternum. For our part, we cannot take part in this farce. Consensus cannot be achieved at the expense of abandoning fundamental principles by which we were elected. The peoples, the workers, the eternal ones sacrificed by austerity policies deserve more and better.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam president. Today we are taking an important step to advance in tax justice: we are going to advance a rule that will oblige multinationals to publish, country by country, how many taxes they pay in relation to how many benefits they have and in relation to other data that determine their activity, and it is very important. I would like to first of all express my gratitude to the rapporteur Hugues Bayet for the work that he has carried out and the good collaboration that there has been. This legislation will prevent many multinationals from developing aggressive tax strategies. I want to say that we have improved the Commission text: the data will be disaggregated, country by country, outside the European Union; it is going to have to be explained what kind of preferential tax regimes for patents these multinationals have - this is also very important. And obviously, on some points, I have to say that our group would have liked to go much further. For example, the 750 million euro profit limit from which the rule applies is excessive and we would have preferred it to remain at 40 million. What, in any case, we do not share are the maneuvers of the right in this House to try to dilute the legislation, on the grounds of competitiveness, as if this would damage competitiveness. I want to say and I want to remind the PPE that, today, European banks are already obliged to do this, and that has not damaged their competitiveness. And that that we go beyond global standards ... Well, look, doesn't the European Union have to have the ambition to establish global standards in the framework of globalization? By this I mean - and here I end - that the safeguard clause that some are trying to introduce is a disgrace. It should not be allowed, because it would be a hole for all legislation ... (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Laura FERRARA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are finally discussing this important proposal on country-by-country reporting, an issue which is also very important for us in the 5 Star Movement, which we consider transparency as a fundamental value for the health of companies and institutions. As we know, this proposal came after the "LuxLeaks" and "Panama Papers" scandals, which showed that the fight against tax avoidance still has a long way to go. And the European Union cannot waste any more time, it must give an immediate response, on pain of losing a credibility that is already quite shaky today. These scandals have also made us clearly understand that this phenomenon must be combated by adopting rules that are also valid on a global scale, even outside the European Union. This is why we are very disappointed that the text proposed in the Legal Affairs Committee, initially appreciable and ambitious, especially with regard to reporting obligations outside the European Union, was then greatly weakened with the introduction of the safeguard clause, to the point of therefore casting serious doubts on the real effectiveness of the proposed rules. I therefore sincerely hope that these errors can be corrected through the amendments proposed to the final text also by our group, and which concern in particular the lowering of the threshold for large companies of the reporting obligation (therefore passing from 750 million to 40 million annual turnover), the obligation to report the funds received by the State and the loans made to political bodies or personalities, the fundamental obligation for multinationals to make public, in a disaggregated way and without exception, information on taxes paid in all countries of the world, including tax havens. Without these fundamental adjustments it will be really difficult for our group to be able to support this proposal and support a position of Parliament that could potentially be even worse than that presented by the Commission.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, Mr. Vice-President, tax transparency is a priority for States, because the abusive optimization schemes of large groups to avoid corporate taxes cause serious damage to our public finances. By the way, we must all thank the whistleblowers, who made it possible to reveal to the public these tax scandals, such as the European tax dumping practiced by Luxembourg under the government of Mr Juncker. These unfair practices must be sanctioned and the victim States compensated financially. The Commission’s initiative to make it mandatory for large groups to publish their sensitive financial information, broken down country by country, is a good thing. However, in the global economic war, this European transparency poses a real problem of information asymmetry for our companies vis-à-vis their international competitors. Indeed, an American or Chinese company which does not have a branch or subsidiary in Europe but which exports to the European Union or wishes to set up there will have a great deal of information on economic activity, country by country, of its competitors. It is therefore imperative to combine, within the framework of this country-by-country reporting measure, transparency and confidentiality of sensitive economic information. Under these conditions, we believe that the publicity of this information should be limited exclusively to the tax administrations of the Member States to avoid any risk of extra-European economic espionage. Thus, with this precautionary principle, the states' fiscal objective will be achieved, but the interests of our large European groups will be protected from globalist competition.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Madam President, taxation is one of the most important problems in the countries of Europe and perhaps the biggest obstacle to growth and the effort to emerge from the economic crisis. Unfortunately, most tax systems in European countries are structured to favor large multinational corporations and place most of the burden on weak citizens and small and medium-sized enterprises. In addition, some countries of the Union act as tax havens, making tax avoidance even easier and more legal for those who have the means and at the same time enjoy the benefits of the free movement of capital and goods in the Union. We can easily conclude, then, that fair tax systems must first be introduced and the tax must be proportionate to income. It is not possible today to ask small businesses in Greece to pay total charges amounting to up to 70% of total income. In addition, we need to reconsider the free movement of capital and goods, because it obviously does not work without a single tax system throughout the Union, but this is opposed by us for reasons of national sovereignty.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: - Madam President, today we approved a commitment to transparency and it is one of the rules on which the Commission has made a report that we fully support. All those companies that have a global income level exceeding 750 million euros per year must prepare and publish annual reports, country by country, for the sake of that transparency. It is true that, as that Directive says, that threshold can be revised after four years, which must be narrowed in order to be in line with the OECD. The safeguard clause is a good clause, because it strikes an essential balance between competitiveness and the necessary transparency, and it has been the result of multiple commitments until reaching a balanced point. Public information on those company data that are considered relevant, especially for tax purposes, is very important to avoid tax evasion. But that's not the only reason why transparency is important. It is important because it will undoubtedly reinforce corporate social responsibility and corporate governance as well. It is undoubtedly a benefit for all: for citizens, for workers, for shareholders, for the administrations themselves, for investors. It is true that trust and workers' rights are reinforced, because it consolidates dialogue and fosters mutual trust, since it provides objective and reliable data on the real situation of the company. It is important, therefore, to work on trust. One of the objectives of this initiative is to build trust, work on social commitment and good governance. Transparency is always a competitive value, without a doubt. It is a strategic investment, with benefits in the medium and long term; but it also has to be sensible, and that is why the safeguard clause is necessary. (She agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 16 (8), of the Regulation)

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Honorable Member!You have listed who this legislation is for everyone.Although I have my doubts about whether European citizens would be the primary winners here.I would most like to ask you, what do you think is the mechanism by which large multinational companies can represent their own interests in such an exemplary manner within the European institutional system?

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: "blue card" response.- Yes. Thank you, Mr. Tibor, for the question.When reliable data are given and when objective data is provided on how a company operates, on the business situation, workers are especially sensitized.And that strengthens trust, but also the citizens themselves, because they will know reliably where companies operate.Therefore, the culture of transparency must be created in all sectors, not only by companies, but also by business society.And it is very important that the business sector assumes this commitment.

name: Sylvia-Yvonne KAUFMANN
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen! Vice-President Dombrovskis mentioned the number again earlier: The European national budgets and thus all of us lose 50 to 70 billion euros every year through tax avoidance. What an incredible amount! What could not be financed with this money, for example for good education, good work or for sustainable public investments! The affairs and revelations surrounding LuxLeaks or the Panama Papers have once again made it clear to all of us that some companies are virtually world market leaders in so-called innovative tax-saving models and obviously have no social conscience. This has to end once and for all! The big companies have to disclose where they make how much profit and how much income tax they have to pay in which country. It's as easy to understand as the multiplication table. The fight against tax avoidance starts with transparency, which is why we need public, country-specific reporting. It is a cost-effective means of giving tax authorities, journalists or citizens the means to hold multinational companies forging secret tax deals accountable. Finally, a word on the question of the safeguard clause for exemption from reporting for an unlimited period of time. I wonder how this can be justified to taxpayers, because it is precisely this that promotes the tax avoidance practices described. We are here for a time limit, so it would be very important for Amendments 84 and 85 to be adopted today.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: - Madam President!Effective public control over multinational enterprises that avoid paying income tax requires solutions at the supranational level, especially as this problem is associated with specific losses for the budgets of many countries, not only Member States.I believe that increasing the transparency of the reporting requirements is essential in order to achieve this goal.I am pleased that the work on the report has managed to balance many controversial issues, especially of course the safeguard clauses.The Polish delegation will vote against the amendments that undermine this compromise.However, I am concerned about the pace of legislative work.It may be associated with insufficient analysis - and thus - with too vague provisions in this project.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: - Madam President, like individuals, companies as legal persons have dimensions of their lives, of their activities, which must be preserved from public debauchery.In a world, in a market where competition is increasingly intense, no one will dare to question that right to reserve or secrecy.However, this cannot be used to hide non-compliance with obligations to society and the State, namely those of a fiscal nature.The right to reserve should only be guaranteed when properly articulated with the duty of transparency, that is, with the obligation to demonstrate publicly the effective fulfillment of tax and social duties.A crime is always a fact in the public domain and as such cannot be hidden from the scrutiny of the State and society.This balance between the right to reserve and the duty of transparency is one of the preconditions for healthy economic and social development.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: - Madam President, as early as 2013 and just a few days before the release of tax evasion through the British Virgin Islands, the World Social Forum in Tunis discussed that tax justice was one of the most important steps towards democratization and the fight against poverty. A number of recent tax evasion scandals have forced the European Commission to act, in the end. Although it has stated that the fight against tax evasion and aggressive tax planning is its priority, I consider the proposal we will be voting on today to be purely cosmetic. The obligation to publish certain information will only apply to about 10, up to a maximum of 15% of multinational companies, with a number of exceptions. This is a missed opportunity. What we really need today are effective tools to combat tax evasion, money laundering and corruption, non-transparency of financial flows and, last but not least, effective civic control over public budgets. What the right in the European Parliament is presenting to us today is a mere placebo.

name: Pascal DURAND
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, there are some realities that should not be hidden in a transparent assembly like ours. It is unbearable to hear the right and now the far right, with a large part of the liberals, explain to us that they defend transparency in Europe, tax transparency, that they defend SMEs and small businesses on a daily basis and , at the same time, to see the same ones that distort competition in the European Union between large multinationals, which has been shown to sometimes pay less than 1% of taxes on profits than they realize. I am saying much less than 1% in taxes, when SMEs, craftsmen and the liberal professions are sometimes forced to pay up to 35%. We must denounce this iniquity. There are parliamentarians in this assembly who are there to defend the interests of large multinationals and not those of the European economy. 85% of jobs in Europe are in SMEs. We need fiscal equality. We must put an end to the fact that large companies are exempt from participating in the equilibrium of society. It is the social bond that is in danger: these are hospitals that cannot be financed, they are common structures that cannot be financed because the multinationals do not pay taxes. This must change. We must ensure that transparency is implemented within the European Union.

name: David COBURN
text: – Madam President, the title of this debate and the Commission’s proposals sound quite innocuous – Disclosure of income tax information by certain undertakings – and is aimed at multinational companies with a high turnover. But it raises more questions than it answers. What, for example, does it tell us about the Commission’s future intentions? We know the Commission wants big companies to supply it with information on their EU and non-EU operations for publication in an EU register. The list is modest in length, although no doubt it will cost companies a great deal of time and money to prepare the figures and also to have them audited, as the proposal requires. But it is a list that betrays a much wider ambition.  When the Commission asks companies not just about tax they pay in different Member States, but also to disclose the nature of activities in third countries – the number of employees in each location, the related net turnover and accumulated earnings – we can deduce that the EU aims to not only harmonise corporation taxes, but also to introduce taxes based on wealth, capital and turnover, rather than profits, and to challenge existing tax residency and transfer pricing rules. When multinational corporations realise this, some of them will ask themselves why they should bother investing time, effort, and capital in the EU rather than somewhere else. Some will rightly conclude that markets are growing much faster elsewhere in the world and that bigger profits can be made without endangering themselves to the avarice of an EU Commission running out of other people’s money, which is shortly about to have a budget crisis when its second largest net contributor, the United Kingdom, leaves. There are only so many eggs you can get out of a golden Google!

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the very idea of ​​asking large multinational companies to make a separate report on each country in which they generate revenue is welcome. Such a measure would be proof of the financial sovereignty of the Member States. There are, however, two issues which I am not convinced would be in the interest of protecting the financial interests of the Member States: - the first issue would be the proposed derogations. Let's not forget that their purpose is to support companies to have a healthy and beneficial activity throughout the single market space. Once granted, these derogations are a loophole that will most likely be misused, as recent history has shown. How will Member States be able to prevent such abuses? Are there any provisions in this regard? - and the second aspect would be the aggregate income reporting limit. EUR 750 million is a sufficiently large amount even for multinationals, and most will not be subject to this reporting. Thus, I do not agree that in the light of all these efforts we are making in favor of a healthy and transparent economic environment, we should end up with legislation applicable to only 15% of these entities.

name: Brian HAYES
text: – Madam President, everyone wants the corporates to pay more tax and be more transparent in their activities. In Ireland’s case the total take from corporation tax has doubled in the past three years, now representing 15% of the total tax take, as against the OECD average of 10%. The international tax agenda under the OECD’s Base Erosion and Profit Shifting (BEPS) process is working, and actions taken by the EU have reduced the opportunities for aggressive tax planning by large corporates. Ireland supports country-by-country tax reporting by multinationals. Since 2015 there is an objective for companies to report to Irish Revenue their tax profit and turnover figures on a country-by-country basis, although this information is not out in the public. I believe the public have a right to know: a right to know what business activity a company is involved with, its number of employees, its turnover, and its profits before and after tax. It is good that this information is to be publicly disclosed, but it needs to be done in a sensible way. We must not give other regions of the world an advantage over the European Union. This is a globalised economy that does not play by the same rules. Our response must not be to make our businesses – businesses that employ millions and millions of Europeans – more disadvantaged. That is not transparency. There is much agreement across this Parliament on the measures to be taken. There is still some disagreement on the question of the safety clause. I believe that the outcome from the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs in agreeing to a safety clause that requires national and Commission agreement and oversight is a better starting point, and I would encourage all Members of this House to support and back that.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the excellent work on this very important file on the disclosure of corporate income tax. I must say, as we debate this topic today, that I am a little bit surprised by some of my colleagues from the PPE and ALDE Groups who have worked in TAXE 1 and TAXE 2 and PANA and know how important disclosure is if you want to fight tax dodging by big multinational companies. I am surprised that they are safeguarding the narrow interests of big multinational corporations at the expense of small and medium—sized enterprises in Europe.  As the Commissioner said, and stated several times, small and medium—sized enterprises have a tax burden 30% higher than multinational corporations. Why would you protect multinational corporations and not protect the small and medium—sized enterprises? Also, the citizens in Europe demand disclosure, transparency. You cannot compromise on transparency. You can compromise on a lot of things, but transparency is fundamental. Then we can discuss tax levels and so on.  I think what we are seeing today, if the safeguard clause is adopted, is a big major loophole that will be created, and I do not understand why the EPP and ALDE Groups are supporting this.

name: Sander LOONES
text: - Multinationals must disclose in each country how much profit they make, what their turnover is, how much taxes they pay, how many people work there. We have agreed this internationally. We have introduced that, that information must be provided to the tax authorities. Now the European Union also wants to make that information public. I think we can all agree that we are against tax evasion. Of course, multinationals should not have more privileges or advantages than our own SMEs. And of course more transparency is needed. More information must be made public. At the same time, I also want to argue for realism and against naivety. Because in all honesty, it's always pretty much the same song. Internationally, we agree on something about closing loopholes and every time the European Union wants to go that step further. This puts our companies here in Europe at a disadvantage. They must do something and foreign companies should not. If we want to create jobs with us, we have to be particularly careful with that.

name: Fabio DE MASI
text: - Madam President! As with banks and in the raw materials sector, corporations should report publicly, country by country, on profits and taxes paid. At Apple in 2014 it was 0.005% - 50 euros for every million profit. Therefore, this is not about a competitive disadvantage, it is about finally ensuring fair conditions for medium-sized businesses or the people up there who work hard for every euro and cent. According to the OECD, the threshold of 750 million euros in sales excludes 85% of the corporations. The exception for commercially sensitive information is as flexible as chewing gum, has no time limit, and retroactive disclosure in the event of relocation of the company's headquarters is no longer provided. We have to maintain global disclosure, otherwise we will fall behind countries like Vietnam. My group will therefore not take part in the approval of a draft which kneels before Apple, Google & amp; Co. makes new tax tricks possible with this exemption.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen! I suppose, I am sure, there is no person in this Chamber who would be against tax transparency. But we must approach it logically, and we are talking about things that are self-contradictory here. This report is about tax reporting by country, not about tax policy. The European Union has no competence in creating tax policy, as it is the competence of individual member states. Another internal contradiction is that we say that if a financial barrier is established, only half of the companies will be required to do so. But ladies and gentlemen, we are talking only about companies that are European or operate in the European Union. This is less than half of the companies in the world. The rest will have no such obligation. What will this lead to? - To obviously cause that the competition between our companies, our European and those outside Europe, will be distorted. And finally, another point, disclosure is absolutely necessary, but to institutions that are called to do so. Public disclosure to journalists or citizens who will not even understand what is being revealed is not helping, it is only damaging the European economy, because we are giving information to our competitors who will ruthlessly take advantage of it.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: - Madam President! The challenges of corporate tax avoidance have increased significantly in recent years, which is of great concern in the European Union and worldwide. According to data from the European Commission, tax evasion by global companies costs European Union member states from 50 to 70 billion euros a year. A new draft law, which aims to increase transparency by informing the public about the amount of taxes paid by multinationals and where they are paid, aims to prevent this from happening. The above conclusion focuses only on companies with a consolidated global net turnover of more than EUR 750 million. It does not impose any obligations on small and medium-sized enterprises, most of which do not engage in aggressive tax planning. This means that they are not competitive with the companies that undertake such activities. In conclusion, the introduction of the proposed public control will - I hope - contribute to strengthening public confidence and ensuring that profits generated by global companies in a given Member State are taxed there, thereby increasing corporate social responsibility.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, public country—by—country reporting is the single most important action that we can take to lift the veil on profit shifting by multinationals which results, as we know, in EUR 500 billion in tax being lost each year. So we need to get it right. Limiting the proposal to companies with a turnover of more than EUR 750 million excludes 85% of multinationals; it should apply to those making more than EUR 40 million. We need to demand that companies report the full breakdown of their figures in each country – not only in EU states and countries on a future EU tax blacklist, which we know will be a very limited list. It is appalling, I have to say, that conservative groups in this House have introduced a so—called ‘safeguard clause’ on this global breakdown. This is a loophole you could drive a truck through. And make no mistake, its purpose is to continue to allow profit shifting to tax havens to go unhindered. The only people with anything to fear from tax transparency are tax cheats and their cheerleaders, so why – the question needs to be asked – are you helping them?

name: Markus FERBER
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice-President, dear colleagues! I believe that what was agreed in the OECD Action Plan against the reduction of tax bases and the cross-border shifting of profits is a good basis for ensuring fair tax competition not only in the European Union but far beyond. In Action 13 of this OECD Action Plan, provisions on country-by-country reporting are stipulated: Companies with a turnover of more than EUR 750 million should provide the tax administrations with an overview of the global distribution of income and taxes. The tax authorities are then obliged to exchange this information, and we have already implemented this obligation in EU law. So to say here that we finally have to do something - we have implemented the OECD! Now is the time to go beyond that. A mandatory publication of country-specific tax information was never the basis at the OECD level. We have to be clear that this is also about sensitive business information, and we have to be aware that the European Union will be weakened at international level if we always go beyond what we agree on internationally. We should come up with further solutions with the international bodies and not go ahead. That is why I say very clearly: Those who shake hands today to do more harm our own economy, harm our companies and do not contribute to more tax justice.

name: Peter SIMON
text: - Madam President! It's pretty interesting in the house this morning: on the one hand, we have colleagues like our colleague Ferber, who says that, in order to protect competition, we have to be careful here that we don't oblige companies too much. We have colleague De Masi, who says that all the exceptions that we have now written in to avoid public country-by-country reporting are actually only intended to be a window dressing and help multinational companies continue to practice their tax tricks. I think the truth is somewhere in between. The truth is that there can, of course, be legitimate interests that need to be protected and which may prevent a full public if one wants to protect industry in Europe. But that cannot be left to the companies and the Member States themselves to determine forever what is withheld from the public. Because let us be aware of what we found out in the LuxLeaks, what we saw in the Panama Papers: It is often enough precisely the member states of the European Union that contribute to state-organized tax dumping becoming a business model of states! Do we want to make it possible again for the tried and tested partners - multinational companies and these Member States on the other hand - to play together without restriction? That can not be! I appeal to you, dear colleagues, to accept a line that says: Yes, we will meet such special requirements for protection of competition in individual cases, but not indefinitely, forever. There must be a point where the public is informed and the European Commission and the public as well as all of us can check whether there really were reasons for competition here or whether we have an interaction between unfairly acting partners, such as we've seen this in the past.

name: Angelika NIEBLER
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! For years we in the European Parliament have been campaigning for more fair taxation in corporate taxation, knowing full well that tax legislation is a matter for the Member States. But it is clear: medium-sized, small companies, medium-sized companies pay their taxes in the countries in which the added value takes place, while the large multinational companies across Europe can happily optimize their taxes. We set up the TAXE committee, the Panama Papers committee, and through the work of colleagues on these two committees, we have seen how tax avoidance works. If you want to prevent tax avoidance, you have to react. In this respect, I believe that the proposal that the Commission has put forward is a sensible one. At the same time - and many colleagues have pointed this out - there are of course also international rules of the game, the BEPS action plan, which we have already implemented here in Parliament. I think that in times like these, when competition is fierce, it is really important internationally that we keep an eye on competitiveness for our companies as well. That means: transparency, yes, but please do everything with a sense of proportion. So I would therefore ask colleagues to vote in favor of the EUR 750 million threshold in the vote this afternoon, not to go beyond it. And I also believe that this safeguard clause that is provided, which has been tabled, is a sensible provision. So here too I ask for your support accordingly.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, our mandate since 2014 has been punctuated by a long list of scandals involving tax optimization, tax evasion and fraud. In short, all these elements show that urgent action is needed and that we need energetic and concrete action in the fight against tax evasion. We have taken a position regularly, thanks to the work of the TAX 1, TAX 2 or PANA committees, to say that we need concrete measures, including this country-by-country accounting declaration, and all of this in great unanimity with our colleagues from the Liberals. and the right. And now that, finally heard by the Commission, we have a concrete proposal on the table, they may be frightened by the idea of ​​transforming words into action, they are in a hurry to establish privileges, discretionary conditions to allow multinationals to escape their obligations. That, with no time limit and with completely opaque criteria, is this famous exemption. Tomorrow, during the vote, I hope that we will be firm enough to concretely limit these privileges and ensure that a real tax transparency measure is adopted for the benefit of citizens, because, my dear colleagues, do not forget who elected us and who we represent in this Chamber.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, this is very important subject. It is part of our effort to achieve a better and fairer way to collect taxes and to protect people from the consequences if we fail to do so. But it would be good to look at this proposal from a broader perspective. The first aspect is international. We are not the only ones tackling this global problem. The more global the effort is, the more successful we are. The OECD has released its method, and country-by-country reporting is a very important part of this initiative. But this initiative was never intended to be public. It was never designed to be public and we should be aware of that. The second aspect is, I think, European. We took many measures to improve the situation and I believe we achieved certain improvements. This is only one of them. I believe that exchange of country-by-country reporting data among the tax authorities is the key improvement, and public access to this data is the thing that should ensure public tax authorities are doing their job properly. We should also take into account the concerns of our non-EU partners and the legitimate interests of companies.  It was the intention of the Commission to right the balance here, and I guess it should also be also our aim to achieve not the most extensive result but the most efficient one. I hope we will do that.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: - Democracy is by no means just financial power.Democracy means solidarity.Democracy means equality before the law.Democracy means paying your contributions as absolutely everyone else pays.We currently have a lot of secret agreements between very large companies and governments.These secret agreements have affected European democracy, affected European construction and affected the European single market.If we are to build a strong European Union, a stable democracy and a developing and competitive economy, then we need to shed light on where it is now a secret, where there is a lot of obscurity.Today or rather tomorrow, when we vote, we take a very big step forward, but there is one regret: that we failed to raise that threshold from 750 million to 40 million, as was necessary, in order to have even more transparency..

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Madam President, this debate is not about whether we are to fight tax fraud and tax evasion or not. With country-by-country reporting, public authorities will have all the opportunities to fight tax fraud and tax evasion. When some here say that the discussion is about the idea that some are defending tax fraud, that is not true. That is political fraud and reality evasion. Because in reality what is happening is that we are supporting international agreements in the framework of OECD and the proposal of the Commission.  But our socialist friends are undermining these international agreements. Come on, tell us: why are you undermining the international cooperation that is needed in order to fight tax fraud? And how will it look in the future when the European Union is not sticking to the international agreements and when other partners are saying it is not ideal to have agreements with you. That is political fraud – to undermine the international cooperation for fighting tax fraud – and you should be ashamed, or vote for us tomorrow.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - The European Parliament has long called for legislation to make multinational groups disclose information on profits, turnover, taxes, employees and other relevant information, broken down by country. The aim is to allow public scrutiny of tax avoidance strategies, to shed light on profit transfer techniques and to deter multinationals from engaging in aggressive tax planning schemes. In addition to the astronomical losses in tax evasion and fraud for national budgets and the European budget, I recall that the Commission concluded that SMEs pay 30% more taxes, on average, than large multinational companies that resort to aggressive tax planning. It is, therefore, absolutely regrettable that the PPE, ECR and liberals have surrendered to the undeniable interests of multinationals. Come here to invoke the OECD and BEPS when you know perfectly well that nothing in this area is binding. They have the opportunity to apply and pass binding legislation here and they betray the interests of transparency, they betray the interests of citizens, because the truth is that by allowing a safeguard clause, they are serving the interests of multinationals against transparency, against and equity, regarding the tax justice that citizens demand.

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: - Madam President, I welcome this proposal for a directive on the communication by certain companies of information on income tax.It is indeed an important step towards greater transparency and the prevention of aggressive tax planning.Mr. First Vice President, I regret that in my country, in Romania, this directive will not be able to be applied because the government installed last week proposed in its government program to replace the profit tax with the turnover tax.Please enter into a dialogue with this new government because we are not discussing the reasons why the government wants to make this replacement, but the fact that the replacement of corporate tax with turnover tax is contrary to European regulations on taxes on the movement of goods and services.

name: Romana TOMC
text: - The business environment is, of course, very demanding, the competition is relentless and only the best survive.To be better than the competition, however, companies use a variety of methods that may be legal, but not necessarily moral.And the legislator, that is to say in this case, we, are the ones who set clear rules, and are responsible for making those rules fair.I hope that the reporting obligation that we are introducing will ensure greater transparency and help ensure that taxes are actually paid where they need to be.At the same time, we must also make sure that the obligations of companies operating in the European Union are comparable to those of companies from the rest of the world.What we have on the table today is, of course, a compromise with which we have taken a step forward, but in my view we are still a long way from tax justice.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, of course, the Commission's proposal for such a report is welcome, we all want transparency, we all want to know if everyone is paying their tax obligations. I would like to congratulate the two rapporteurs who have worked to improve the Commission's proposal. Honestly, I do not understand why the Commission has proposed a threshold of 750 million and I do not understand why the right wing of Parliament claims in public speech that we want fairness and ethics. At the same time, when it comes to voting for a report that really brings ethical transparency to operating in the single market, this is not the case. It is a first step, I am not satisfied with the ambition with which this report came out and it is not our fault, of the S&D, that we wanted, clearly, not only a part, 10-15% of the companies to report , but everyone has to report because the threshold is huge and most of those who are now evading will come out of the report. That's why I want it to be just a first step and move on.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, tax evasion and avoidance are on the agenda in all the Member States of the European Union. The various multinationals are taking advantage of the triangular relations, saving billions of euros, and all this is happening in a phase of enormous poverty and unemployment in the European Union itself. We have witnessed the famous "tax rulings" in various countries, in Malta, in Luxembourg, in the Netherlands, essentially unfair practices which really create huge problems in the European Union, as we now have aggressive tax planning. So we need to set things up so that multinationals pay taxes where they really make a profit, and I think we need to close all the way to avoid tax evasion, as the OECD's famous standards leave a lot of gaps. , as well as the limit of 750 million euros.

name: Marco VALLI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, multinationals have to pay taxes. I challenge anyone in this House to go into a public debate to argue otherwise. Unfortunately, what happened? It happened that in a discussion that is also quite simple, like this one, where we ask for publication and reporting, therefore transparency, to multinationals on profits, on taxes paid, on information that must be made public, especially when you are a reality multinational that therefore moves very strong interests ... Here, the thing to denounce is that in the competent committees, therefore the legal and economic ones, in the vote concerning transparency on this information, an amendment proposed by the liberals has passed - therefore the ALDE, the EPP, with the votes also of the ECR - which has led to the impoverishment of the proposal and to ensure that a multinational with a headquarters outside the European Union is not obliged to make information transparent. This is a shame. We hope that the vote will be overturned, but in any case those people who are in conflict of interest must be denounced when they hold the wrong positions.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Madam President, in the context of the single market, transparency and equal fiscal treatment are essential denominators in combating inequality and functioning of the economy and trade sectors. But for European citizens, tax evasion and tax evasion, both by individuals and businesses, are a continuation and a misnomer of political corruption. As politicians, we demand corporate jurisdiction, while the citizens of our countries demand political accountability and accountability. Especially for the Greeks who, hit by the memoranda, have lost more than 50% of their income and suffer inhuman tax measures, every notion of regulatory intervention of the Union in Greek tax policy is now casus belli. The intervention in the fiscal policy of Greece is so crude, with the consent of the Greek governments, of course, that it shows that you have turned my country into a protectorate. The Union imposes memoranda and acts unjustly. It is time for the citizens of the Union to act vigorously and claim their national sovereignty.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: - Madam President!Profits are still being made in countries where not a single employee is allowed to work.That must be turned off.Country-by-country reporting is one way of doing this.We need transparency, we need publicity.The country-specific reporting requirement does not solve the problem of tax loopholes, but the disclosure requirement creates pressure.We therefore support the intentions of this report of worldwide disclosure of profits and the worldwide disclosure of how many employees work in the countries where the profits are made and how much tax is paid on them.We have to step up the pressure, the Member States are not there yet, and the disclosure requirement for banks has shown us how important it is to extend it to include companies.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: - Madam President, I believe that we are taking a very important step in an area that is also very important for citizens, but I think we have to recognize that this step is not enough. I believe that there are too many exceptions in the safeguard clause and that the amount is excessive, be it in billing, or in the number of workers, and so on; so that the step is very important for transparency, the step is very important for tax justice, but it is not enough. In this sense, I would like to recall that the Socialist Group has been demanding that some amendments be supported that would make a more just and effective Directive. I would also like to recall the importance of the European Commission playing a role in coordinating the tax services of the Member States. If there is no attribution of responsibility to the European Commission, there will be no efficiency in these measures. And I think it is also important to demand unitary legislation in all tax matters.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Madam President, I consider it a great step forward for the European Union to make transparent the key data, the revenue and the amount of taxation of multinational companies operating in European countries.But I am asking for the opinion of the representative of the Commission present and the opinion of the rapporteur on whether it would not be possible to go further and make transparent the benefits, subsidies, exemptions that multinational companies and large foreign companies receive in some countries.So to speak, e.g.job creation, which is not given to local SMEs at the same time.And would they agree that this should simply be classified as serious discrimination?And when it comes to job creation, the Member States should go in the direction of supporting their small and medium-sized enterprises.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the principle that everybody should pay their fair share of tax is undeniable and applies to individuals as well as big corporations. But we have seen in the past that big corporations will use every loophole to avoid paying tax so it is up to us, as legislators, to close those loopholes and that has been done at OECD level and within the European Union.  This is a global problem and, speaking as a member of the PANA Committee, we can see that it needs a global response. One area we have to be careful about is having legislation that would disadvantage companies with headquarters within the European Union as opposed to those outside the European Union. I think that is something we have to be careful about. Country—by—country reporting is important – as Mr Karas and others have said – but I think that we have to look at the bigger picture as well. The only way to tackle this is a bit like with climate change: a global agreement with the same rules applying across the globe.

name: Valdis DOMBROVSKIS
text: Vice—President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank everyone for this debate and also to take the opportunity to thank the rapporteurs, Ms Evelyn Regner and Mr Hugues Bayet, for their dedicated work, and all the Members of this House who continue to bring corporate tax transparency closer to reality. We must continue to work together as the EU to achieve public tax transparency and, at the same time, we must be mindful not to jeopardise our competitiveness. We believe that our proposal strikes the right balance and hope that we will get this proposal agreed as soon as possible.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: protractor. - Madam President, as rapporteur, I would like to thank all of my colleagues for their interventions. As I said when presenting this report, we are really at the crossroads of European fiscal construction. Our debate demonstrates this, and I am delighted that we can vote on this text this afternoon. I hope he gets the largest possible majority. I would just like to make a technical reminder, because it is clear that every politician can defend his ideals, but I think it becomes problematic when we say the reverse of what is actually written in the texts. It may be a problem of understanding, but with regard to competition, I would like to ask all those who are in doubt to reread before the vote Article 48 ter, paragraph 3, which provides that any non-European company which has a subsidiary in Europe is subject to the same advertising conditions. This therefore means that an American or Asian multinational company that has a subsidiary in Europe will have to publish exactly the same information as European companies. There will therefore be no distortion of competition and I know of no, absolutely no multinational which has a turnover of 750 million euros, which has no subsidiary in Europe or which could do without 'a market of more than 500 million consumers. Therefore, I think there is obviously a misunderstanding of this article. Finally, I really hope, in all humility, to have been able to convince you of the need to vote for the safeguard clause, which is the most transparent, because I would really like that we could never again blame the political world for future scandals. fiscal. I will close by thanking all of the shadow rapporteurs who have worked with Evelyn and myself, for their work, their persistence and the understanding and respect they have shown during all this work relating to this dossier, which is - you have all understood it - difficult, technically and politically.Finally, Madam President, dear colleagues, a special thank you to my colleague Evelyn, with whom it was a pleasure to work.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! Dear Mr Dombrovskis, as you can see, it will be heated until the end. So our debate really triggers a lot emotionally. I would also like to express my sincere thanks to everyone, especially to Hugues for this intensive cooperation and for the enthusiasm we are devoting to this topic. You said yourself, Mr Dombrovskis: it is about trust. It is a question of the trust of the citizens in these tax systems, which should be restored. And of course it's about reporting, it's about disclosure requirements. But with this transparency, with these disclosure obligations, we can do a lot. Hence a word about this famous safeguard clause. This must be properly drafted. If it is too excessive, if it goes too far, then here is another hole in the Emmentaler. And we don't want to produce Swiss cheese, we want to nail it with our heads. We are in the legislature. And even if everyone in the Panama and TAXE committees always rants: “Let's tackle this issue”, then let's really tackle it - nationally, globally, but now and here in Europe. And we want to face this responsibility and hope that we will get a strong mandate. Because the really tough negotiations are of course to be conducted primarily with the Council, which is often much more on the brakes than this European Parliament. So please give us the greatest possible support, dear colleagues! There is still a long way to go.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- Civil society is in demand for public transparency extending to all subsidiaries of multinationals in all countries.Currently, multinationals still take advantage of the international tax system to organize their almost complete immunization from corporate income tax.The IMF estimates the loss of tax revenue due to these tax optimization maneuvers by multinationals at $ 600 billion per year and $ 200 billion per year only for developing countries.In the United States, President Trump and the Republicans have successfully repealed all forms of corporate tax transparency.Let us not follow in their wake.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - Due to the growing mobility and global and pan-European economic activity, it is necessary to take measures to organize corporate governance and support the fight against tax avoidance on an international scale. A key element in this process is the definition of clear corporate reporting rules for tax-relevant data. When taking action in this area, however, we must ensure that European Union companies do not find themselves in a less advantageous position compared to their competitors in third countries, for example because of disproportionate reporting obligations that do not apply to non-EU companies European. It should also be remembered that the fight against tax evasion can only be effective if concerted action is taken at international level. Unilateral actions, even very ambitious ones, have no real chance of success. In my opinion, the document adopted by the European Parliament adequately promotes tax transparency, on the one hand, and, on the other hand, protects the competitiveness of European companies and the investment climate in the European Union. At the same time, I expect the Community - while remaining a global leader in the fight for tax transparency - to coordinate its activities to a greater extent with the activities of international entities, e.g. within the OECD.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: We will begin the ceremony of the solemn tribute of the European Parliament to Simone Veil. Mr. President of the European Commission, thank you for being here. Dear colleagues, on behalf of the European Parliament and the peoples of Europe represented here, I pay tribute today to Simone Veil, the first President of this directly elected Parliament, a Frenchwoman, a European, a Minister of State, an academician, a deportee from Auschwitz, a great figure of our time, a politician, a woman. In her extraordinary life, she has been all of this and more. The story of her life is the story of our continent, that of a torn, lost continent, which has known the worst atrocities of which humanity is capable, but which has succeeded, as it has, in finding the strength to go up the slope, to rebuild and be reborn. Seventy years ago, all was lost, for Simone Veil as well as for Europe. 78651 is the number the man's infamy imprinted on her skin when she was only 16 years old. This number, which she wanted to engrave on her French Academy sword as a warning to future generations, marked much more than her arm. It must remain forever imprinted in our collective consciousness and constantly remind us of the ultimate reasons why we decided one day, from the ashes of war, to pool our destiny. Let us never forget it and repeat it over and over again to the younger generations, for whom the collective memory of this catastrophe is in danger of fading, so much so that peace is now taken for granted and taken for granted. Simone Veil has always been aware of the fragility of peace in Europe since 1945. In her eyes, this peace constitutes an exceptional good. It was with the energy of a survivor who knows the price of peace that she fought in countless battles in France and in the European Parliament, battles that have advanced the rights of all citizens. Simone Veil belongs to that generation of great minds, of which Helmut Kohl was also a part, who succeeded that of the founding fathers of Europe. They took over from European construction in a very difficult period and continued what their predecessors had started. Simone Veil's contribution was fundamental to this. An example of determination, her commitment to Europe led her to become the first President of the European Parliament elected by universal suffrage. I want to express here all our admiration and deepest gratitude for the essential role she has played as President of this Assembly. In her inauguration speech on July 17, 1979, she fully appreciated the weight of the responsibility that was her own. Here are his words: "For the first time indeed in history, in a history which has seen them so often divided, opposed, bent on destroying each other, the Europeans together elected their delegates to a Common Assembly. These elections are, without a doubt, a major event in the construction of Europe since the signing of the treaties. " It is a twenty-three minute speech in which she clearly outlines, with extraordinary lucidity and vision, the lines of development of Parliament for the next forty years. I invite you to reread this speech, which I find surprisingly timely. You will find there the enthusiasm, the hopes, the expectations, the intentions of a whole generation of men and women who sat on these benches long before us. He inspires us and obliges us. In the aftermath of the first European elections, no one knew what would become of this newly elected Assembly. No one, except Simone Veil! Today no one knows what this Parliament could have become without her. If we are what we are, if this Parliament has been able to expand its powers, become what it is today, it’s mostly because of her. Aware of the historic task with which it was entrusted, it accompanied the young Parliament in its first steps, steered it in the right direction and laid the foundations for its future development. Our debt to this great woman therefore remains immense. In his view, Parliament, with its legitimacy derived from elections, should now fully play its role of democratic control, which, according to him, is the primary function of any elected assembly. It was also to exercise, with wisdom and conscience, its new budgetary power, which she considered fundamental among the powers of a parliament. In addition, Simone Veil was convinced that the duty of the new Parliament should be to constantly give impetus to European construction. She firmly believed that it was necessary to make full use of the powers, still limited, which Parliament then held. She also felt that it was not enough and that more had to be done. “Parliament,” she said in her speech, “must also be a body of general policy control within the Community. Let us not believe that the strictly institutional limitations of its powers can prevent a Parliament such as ours, from making heard at any time, and whatever the field of Community action, the voice conferred on it by political authority. resulting from his election. ” In other words, Simone Veil wanted a political Parliament. Great destiny that of Simone Veil. Sentenced to die at the age of 16, she has just entered the immortality of history today after a long and intense life, during which she worked tirelessly to defend the ideas and values ​​that were her own, and which have become ours. The rocket of his academician's sword is made of two hands that shake each other, a symbol of reconciliation between peoples. His exemplary life was the image of this reconciliation, which required extraordinary courage and the greatest love. His life has shown that it is possible to resist the temptation to hate. Her life has been and will remain a tremendous testimony for all of us and for future generations, because Simone Veil had the courage to continue to believe in the goodness of man despite everything. On behalf of all of us, I pay tribute today to this great lady. I express the greatest admiration for his courage, intelligence and deep humanity. I express our gratitude for the love and passion she has shown in everything she has undertaken. I declare loud and clear our pride in having had her as the first President of this Assembly. When she was inaugurated as President in 1979, she declared: “Our Parliament will have fully satisfied the hopes that it has raised if, far from being the place where the internal divisions of Europe resonate, it succeeds in expressing and to make the Community perceive the momentum of solidarity so necessary today. " Thank you, Madam President, thank you Simone, for these words, so current, and thank you for everything you have done for us and for those who will come after us. * * * (Broadcast in the hemecicle of a video retracing the journey of Mrs. Simone Veil) * * * (The Assembly, standing, applauds)

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, dear colleagues, President Tajani did me the honor of giving me the floor at this tribute ceremony, because Simone Veil was a great lady of the liberal and democratic family. She belonged to this generation which, in fact, preceded mine and guided my commitment, this generation which Europe marked by the worst of its history, but which will have been able to make the best of a destiny shattered by war. and deportation. Simone Veil, née Jacob, an old French Jewish family, was 16 when she was deported to Auschwitz with all of her family. We were only a year away from the defeat of Nazism, but the death camps were still in full swing. Only Simone and her sister will survive this hell, where they will see their father, mother and brother disappear. She will live her whole life with the number 78651 tattooed on her arm. The Shoah, its horrors and its memory will forge - I believe - the strong and entire personality of Simone Veil. Young married, she studied law, at a time when the woman was at home, and quickly became a renowned magistrate. When she was appointed Minister of Health, in 1974, by Valéry Giscard d'Estaing, nobody in fact would have bet a former French franc on this high official responsible for making the President's flagship promise vote, that is to say - say the decriminalization of abortion. (Applause) Yet, faced with an Assembly almost exclusively made up of men, as she herself will point out, Simone Veil braved all political dangers to form a majority in the center under the boos of the old traditional right and, sometimes , anti-Semite. This feminist fight, this progressive fight propels Simone Veil into politics through the front door. However, it is not towards France that its ambitions are directed, but towards Europe. As has already been said, in 1979, in fact, Members of the European Parliament are, for the first time, elected by universal suffrage, giving this ballot a test value of the people's attachment to European construction. It was the Auschwitz survivor, who harbored no hatred or resentment against Germany, who was elected. On the contrary, she pleads for reconciliation around the shared values ​​of liberal democracy and the rule of law, and it is on this speech that her list comes far ahead in France. She rallies the liberal group, of which she will be the victorious candidate to become the first President of our Assembly. This is the start, Mr President, dear colleagues, of a long parliamentary career until his return to the French government in the 1990s. It would take too long to list all the achievements and all the successes of Simone Veil, who was to chair the liberal group from 1984 to 1989. Parliament then had few powers, but it deployed all its energy to support the major projects of the time: the Single European Act, the accession of Spain and the Portugal, which thus became part of our European family, and also the reforms which were to bring Europe out of or bring out of its torpor, which at that time was called "eurosclerosis". In reality, Simone Veil never really left public life until her death, and after having made her eternal by making her an academician, France is now questioning her elevation to the Pantheon. But it is right that, in this forum, too, Mr President, here in Strasbourg, a place so symbolic of this dual French and European destiny, tribute be paid to this truly exceptional character, the embodiment of our shared history and also the incarnation of our common future. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: This concludes the ceremony to pay homage to Simone Veil, the first female President of the European Parliament directly elected by the citizens.

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: - Madam President, my point of order is based on Article 3 (1), Article 4 (4) and Article 6 of our Rules of Procedure. As you know, Madam President, legislative elections were held in France, after which a number of our colleagues were elected to the French Parliament. I congratulate them on that. They belong to various political shades. These colleagues currently sit in the French Parliament. Consequently, their seat is vacant, but the French authorities refuse to communicate the names of their successors, on the grounds that appeals have been brought by various citizens against their election. It seems to me that this process is unfair, because these colleagues are now sitting in the French Parliament, regardless of the outcome of the appeal against them. It seems to me, therefore, that the parallelism of forms should lead the French authorities to communicate to you the names of their successors so that they can sit in the same way in the European Parliament, obviously awaiting the outcome of these recourse. This is the reason why, based on Article 4 of our Rules of Procedure, which provides that the President can address the national authorities to ask them to communicate the names of the successors for the vacant seats, I believe that this approach should be made by our President, with the support, I hope, of the President and members of the Committee on Legal Affairs, which is responsible for the verification of credentials.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: Mr. Gollnisch!In any case, I can inform you that we will first of all wait until we have the official notification from the authorities of the French government and then we will have the normal procedure.That means that the names will be passed on to the Legal Affairs Committee and the examination will then be carried out, as is customary in our Parliament.There is no reason to do it differently than usual.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The next item is voting time.(Voting results and other details of the voting: see Minutes.)

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: rapporteur.- Madam President, there has been no debate on this matter.The proposal we will be voting on makes a tangible simplification for the lives of European citizens.Specifically, it is about protecting the weaker party, the victims of road accidents with a cross-border element.This is a minimum harmonization of limitation periods, start, end and length.This proposal was adopted by a large majority in the JURI Committee without difficulty, which is why I ask you, ladies and gentlemen, to support this proposal here in plenary as well.

name: Emil RADEV
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am happy to present to you today the report on the establishment of common minimum standards in civil proceedings. It is indisputable that this project is of pan-European interest. Discussions on the harmonization of civil procedure in the European Union started two decades ago with the presentation of the so-called Storm report. As a result, the European Union has adopted measures to approximate the rules of civil procedure of the Member States, which, however, are not sufficient. I call on the European Commission to propose a directive with specific recommendations for the establishment of common minimum standards in civil proceedings at European Union level. Citizens must be empowered to invoke the fundamental right to a fair trial and an effective remedy wherever they are in the Union, and to be able to assert those rights and to bring proceedings before the courts of other Member States as easily as in its Member State. This proposal must be seen as a first step in the process of further harmonizing and converging the civil justice systems of the Member States and establishing a longer-term European Code of Civil Procedure.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, we have a long way behind us but a long way before us. We would like to go back to the committee in order to enter into interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I am very grateful that we have reached the conclusions of this trialogue in such a timely fashion, because Ukraine is counting on our support. You have to remember that, while conducting profound reforms, the Government of Ukraine needs to deal with the consequences of the illegal annexation of Crimea and, at the same time, has to tackle the military conflict provoked by Russia. Moreover, the Russian authorities have imposed further restrictions on the Ukrainian economy, including the embargo on agri—food imports and the banning of transit of goods to Central Asia. This is the price the Ukrainians have to have to pay for their Euro—Atlantic aspirations. At the same time, it was necessary for us to address the concerns of EU producers and farmers, as well as the issues which are still problematic in our relations with Ukraine: corruption. We have done all that. By granting new concessions, we want to back the ongoing reforms, strengthen small and medium enterprises and provide the necessary boost for increasing trade flows. I hope this will prove to be both economically and politically advantageous for the people of Ukraine.  I would like to thank all my shadow rapporteurs and Parliament’s Administration for all their efforts in order to proceed swiftly with this file. I would like to stress that I am very committed to continuing my work as the standing rapporteur in the International Trade Committee for Ukraine, and I am looking forward to working and helping Ukraine even more. (Applause)

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: rapporteur. – As agreed with the shadows on this report, I want as rapporteur to introduce an oral amendment on paragraph four – after ‘except for self—defence’, we want to introduce the following: ‘and under no circumstances should private security companies be allowed to take part in or conduct interrogations’.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: The voting time is now closed.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President!We live in a world of progress and development.The use of new techniques and technologies, on the one hand, and the integration of the economies of not only European Union Member States, but the entire world, on the other hand, requires the unification of standards.Standardization in this process is therefore crucial.However, it should be conducted in close partnership and cooperation between industry, public authorities, standardization bodies and others.It seems to me that standardization in digital transformation should play a crucial role these days.Therefore, priority should be given to standards in the field of 5G, cloud computing, the Internet of Things, data security and cybersecurity.That is why I consider this dossier important and necessary.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, the glory of European civilisation has always been found in its diversity, its variety and its pluralism. Unusually among the great civilisations of the world, this continent never became centralised as a single empire, but remained rather a diverse plurality of competing states.  Let me make a little reference to something said by the great liberal German economist Wilhelm Röpke in 1952 as he saw the European project get underway. He said ‘in antiquity, Strabo spoke of the “many shapes” of Europe; [...] Montesquieu was to speak of Europe as a “nation de nations”; [...] decentralisation is of the essence of the spirit of Europe; [...] to attempt to weld Europe into one block is a betrayal of Europe and the European patrimony, and a betrayal made all the worse for being carried out in Europe’s name.’

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, due to its tourist vocation and its almost 7 500 kilometers of coastline, Italy is a country which, more than others, lends itself to exploiting the full potential of its sea. The climatic characteristics and a mostly artisanal and seasonal fishing make our nation one of the main targets of the initiative report voted today. Coastal regions and islands are suffering from severe economic decline due to shortages of fish resources or overly restrictive or even wrong policies. In recent years, the so-called "fishing tourism" has helped to create new jobs, but it is not the solution. The report, therefore, is overall positive, but presents some criticalities. We need to make the most of the available funds, all of them, not just the EMFF, but we need to ensure that fishing tourism and other alternatives are not the solution. These proposals must not be a patch to cover the holes made over the years by wrong and unsuitable policies for our sea, but only represent forms of economic integration necessary at certain times of the year and in well-defined circumstances.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the coastal areas are in great suffering. The increase in the constraints imposed by the common fisheries policy, the scarcity of resources, the competition of products arriving from abroad have brought to its knees the classic productive activity of these areas, which is fishing. So how to allow coastal communities to survive, to maintain their traditions, to respect their vocation and to have a decent income? The coastal areas are naturally an attraction for tourism. It is therefore necessary to create spaces for fishermen as part of the services offered to tourists. Boat trips or fishing trips offered to tourists by chance and left free - and sometimes disorganized - initiatives are certainly not enough. With the right incentive policies and an organic development strategy, tourism can also become a stable source of income for fishermen.
