We need to invest in structures, in overcoming seasonal tourism, in connections. We need a link with entrepreneurs, tour operators, restaurateurs. We need to work together as a team and politics.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of the report because it is successfully trying to tackle the problems facing fishermen. At a time when there is a crisis and a reduction in fishermen's income, measures must be taken to support this industry and I believe that fishing tourism can really contribute to increasing fishermen's income. At the same time, fishing tourism is an opportunity to attract tourists and this is very important, especially in areas that are remote and insular. We must keep in mind that rod fishing, as the report states, offers various social benefits and is important for human health and well-being. At the same time, the socio-economic benefits of tourism will become apparent mainly during the summer season and I also consider this to be positive. However, I think that a legal basis must be formed for fisheries tourism, to support blue growth and, of course, to support a sustainable and solidarity-based economy.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, the fishing community is one that has faced growing pressures from a multitude of factors in recent years, including pollution, climate change and overfishing, which make it increasingly difficult for fishermen to earn a reliable income. Due to the diversification of the fishing industry to include other activities, such as fisheries—related tourism, communities that rely on their fishing industry will hopefully be revitalised and incomes will be stabilised.  Coming from a country like Ireland, where fisheries have always played a vital role in coastal communities – and indeed the wider economy – I am pleased to support this proposal, which will re-energise the fishing industry at a Europe-wide level and, hopefully, create jobs. In view of the decision at the weekend by the United Kingdom Government to withdraw from the London Fisheries Convention and, inter alia, the common fisheries policy, the fishing industry certainly needs new markets and new measures.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, during the Maidan Revolution the people of Ukraine made their European ambitions very clear. The price they had to pay for that wish to get closer to the EU has been enormous. Russia has occupied Crimea, causing combative war in eastern Ukraine, and imposed numerous trade sanctions. Ukraine faces economic hardship, and the effects of the fragile economic recovery have not yet reached its population. This is why the EU needs to show unanimous support. The proposed autonomous trade measures will increase trade flows and give its economy the necessary support it deeply needs. It will also send a strong signal to the Ukrainian Government that its ambitious reform agenda is widely embraced by the EU. The people of Ukraine now want to see their future in Europe, and we have to help them get there. This is why I am proud that we voted for this report.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Today we approved 100 million euros to the Republic of Moldova, but this money will go conditionally.One: the bill in Parliament on changing the electoral system must be withdrawn.The Venice Commission also said that the mixed election system only helps rich parties and rich politicians.Secondly, money must support and support even smaller and medium-sized parties, as many parties as possible, because that is democracy.Not to screw Plahotniuc and Dodon to power in the Republic of Moldova forever.And lastly, if you withdraw this bill from Parliament, if you fight corruption, tax evasion and fraud effectively, if you do independent justice, then yes, the first tranche of the 100 million euros will come to the BankNational Championship of Moldova.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, I supported this proposal, which includes financial support for Moldova. I see it as extremely important to geopolitically support the former Soviet Union, where Russia is still trying to maintain power, and to encourage them to be more a partner of the European Union than Russia itself. I think that's very important. On the other hand, it is necessary to give clear conditions for the use of this money so that this money is not subject to corruption and does not end up in the pockets of the oligarchs, but is really used for the Moldovan people and for the development of Moldovan infrastructure. So I think it is good that we have finally voted in favor of the proposal, it is good that Moldova has an association agreement with the European Union. It is clear that we should show these countries that the European Union is a partner for them and that, in the future, if future developments pave the way for democracy, freedom and economic prosperity, they can one day expect full membership.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Madam President, the taxation of multinational companies must take place in the country in which they operate. Otherwise, the fight against tax evasion remains empty-handed. If we do not do this and if they are not taxed in the country in which they operate, we are only taking the money to tax havens and maintaining tax havens. Secondly, bearer actions are very important. They must be removed from all Member States, including my country, Romania, because the bearer shares are anonymous, secret, confidential, leave no trace, whatever happens to them, and when he changes his hands - a paper passes from one hand in the other - then the control of a company changes and possibly. If we want to fight tax evasion effectively, which turns into money laundering, to make clean money, which means three trillion euros a year lost, then we have to do these things.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, I would like to explain that I support the proposal for a European Union directive on the disclosure of income tax information by large companies, that is to say, those with a turnover of more than EUR 750 million. The abuse of tax havens and tax evasion is a challenge at both European and global levels. The recent publication of an example of the Panama Papers scandal is also evidence of this. Tax evasion by some companies is very negatively perceived by citizens who lose confidence in tax systems and lose faith in justice and equality before the law. I believe that, in order to be effective, the fight against tax evasion must be taken together at European level. In conclusion, I therefore supported the legislative resolution because no amendments were adopted that would broaden the scope of companies that would not protect competition and sensitive business information. So the proposal became acceptable.

name: Molly SCOTT CATO
text: – Madam President, the Greens have long been pushing for public country-by-country reporting and we are really pleased to see it making headway with this Commission proposal for public disclosure, supported and strengthened today by Parliament. I am pleased that the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs supported disaggregated financial information from all countries inside and outside the EU, making tax transparency a truly useful tool, but I am sorry that certain parties in this House have sought to introduce loopholes allowing for no public disclosure in cases where information is considered commercially sensitive, something that it is impossible to define accurately. We also need a much lower threshold than the current EUR 750 million turnover, which will mean that only 6 000 of the biggest companies need to report their information. I am sorry to say that while my colleagues on the right may claim to be parties of business, by undermining tax transparency in this way they are really ensuring that small businesses cannot compete fairly with the largest global corporations.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Madam President, I personally was able to support this resolution because, in my view, it contains a number of good ideas and is relatively balanced.I consider the public reporting of company data, which is a fundamental fight against international tax avoidance and evasion, to be very important, and I have been drawing this issue quite strongly in the European Parliament for many years.With increasing mobility and, above all, a global and pan-European economic way of doing business, transparency in terms of disclosure is a prerequisite for strong governance and a tool for improving corporate social responsibility.That is why this proposal, this resolution, has my full support.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am not the rapporteur, there must have been a mistake. However, I make my explanation of vote, an explanation of vote that is convinced against it, because I think that a shameful political game is being played on macro-financial assistance to Ukraine, it is a question of political and commercial support for the parafascist regime of Poroshenko, which continues to repress and oppress the civilian population in Donbas, not to respect the Minsk agreements. This is an agreement which, in addition to supporting the parafascist regime of Poroshenko, creates harmful measures for our products, for European agricultural products such as honey, grapes, wheat, barley and other cereals. In short, here we want to describe Poroshenko as pro-European Union, actually removing the presence of the ultra-right in his regime and removing what he is doing against the people of Donbas. This seems to me to be sufficient reasons, together with the damage to European farmers, to vote against.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Madam President, I made a mistake about the place for this explanation, but I will now give it in its proper place.  The people of Ukraine, during the Maidan revolution, made their European ambitions very clear. The price they have had to pay for the wish to get closer to the EU has been enormous. Russia has occupied Crimea, engaged in war in eastern Ukraine and imposed numerous trade sanctions. Ukraine faces economic hardship and the effects of its fragile economic recovery have not yet reached its population. This is why the EU needs to show unanimous support. The proposed autonomous trade measures will increase trade flows between the EU and Ukraine and give its economy the necessary support. They will also send the strong signal to the Ukrainian Government that its ambitious reform agenda is widely embraced by the EU. The people of Ukraine want to see their future in Europe and we have to help them arrive there. This is why I am proud that we voted for this report.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, first of all, I want to react to Ms Forenza’s absolutely unacceptable language about Ukraine: Ukraine is under aggression from the Russian Federation, which came to the eastern part of Ukraine and supported so—called separatists who are in favour of killing their former countrymen. Russia – not any country – came to Crimea and occupied and annexed that part of Ukraine. The EU is not coming to Ukraine with weapons, but is extending a hand of cooperation and trade. This is the best track: to improve the economic situation in Ukraine, to help people to raise up economic developments and to look to Ukraine as a future partner. I will never be aligned with statements like this – calling Ukraine a fascist country. That is completely wrong.  (Applause)

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, I voted against the report because the implementation of temporary autonomous trade measures for Ukraine is hurting the national economies of some countries in economic crisis, such as Greece. In this case, European farmers and especially Greek farmers will face unfair competition in both cereals and viticulture issues. Even honey, very cheap but of dubious quality, is imported to Greece from Ukraine. In addition, the European Union-Ukraine Free Trade Agreement will dissolve the livestock sector in Greece. We will have a total import of dairy products - always of dubious quality - and meat, and so the Greek breeders who are already facing many problems, due to the impoverishment that has occurred with the memorandum, will be in an even worse position. That is why I voted against the report.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, the stated aim of this legislative proposal is to increase existing trade flows and to foster bilateral trade and economic cooperation between Ukraine and the European Union, but in the same document it states that the European Union will see a loss of customs revenue corresponding to less than EUR 50 million annually, with very limited impact on EU own resources. ‘Limited impact’ means that in reality this proposal is empty. It is the lowest possible result. Nevertheless, the Committee on International Trade suggested additional cuts for certain product groups such as wheat, maize and processed tomatoes. We can compare this to a situation where somebody presents a gift to a friend in a big beautiful box, but inside there is only a very small candy at the bottom. Such a gift can be perceived only as a mockery.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I know it is not appropriate for me to react to a colleague at this minute, but I will not be able to do that. What Mrs Forenza said is unacceptable, it is offensive to Ukraine, and I am surprised that such words can be heard in this Chamber. Be it. For me, the agreement, or rather the measures to support Ukraine, is, of course, insufficient. But I still decided to support them, because I think it is our duty to support a nation that is in a very difficult test. I cannot imagine that, after 1994, when we gave certain guarantees - from the Western powers, the United States and the United Kingdom - to Ukrainian sovereignty, that we would not support them in this conflict. I would like us to support those regions which, of course, are on track in this agreement, they are certainly parts of Greece, they are parts of the agricultural sector, but in my opinion it is not possible to leave Ukraine at this time. I voted in favor.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Madam President, dear colleagues, cooperation with countries that are neighbors of the European Union is important. However, I strongly believe that the assistance and assistance they receive should not be to the detriment of European producers. Beekeepers, producers of oils and other products from my country - Bulgaria, have repeatedly appealed for a review of imports from Ukraine, because they feel strong pressure from low import prices. Tariff quotas are a mechanism that guarantees protection against unfair commercial practices and, in my opinion, should be granted only after a risk assessment by all Member States. Sending positive political signals to third countries is important, but it must not take the form of economic pressure on European producers. I did not support the increase of duty-free imports from Ukraine, because I believe that this measure is bad news and a mechanism for producers from countries like mine - Bulgaria.

name: Catherine STIHLER
text: – Madam President, for too long consumers buying a fridge or a hoover or a washing machine have been faced with the fact that the goods are just not made to last the way that they used to be, and when they break they are easier to replace with a new product than to repair. If we want to address climate change and be more sustainable as a society, we need to tackle this use-and-dispose culture which runs counter to our commitments to the environment. Today’s vote on product life cycles go some way to highlighting the problem and suggesting solutions such as ambitious design models, creating durable goods, finding easier ways to repair rather than replace, and supporting fair-usage-based sales models. If we can achieve a more sustainable base system for the sale of consumer goods across the EU we can start to realise the circular economy, creating new business models and supporting EU innovation and start-ups whilst protecting our environment. This must surely be a win-win for consumers and the environment.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President!The provisions of the report we are talking about are intended to benefit consumers, the environment, and also entrepreneurs.Its goal is to ensure that the devices, machines, cars, household appliances, electronics, computers, telephones, etc. we buy, work and serve us as long as possible, but if they break, they can be easily and inexpensively repaired.So the idea is very important and right.I believe that the records of the report reflect this idea.So they relate to the issues of warranty and guarantee, as well as the right to make repairs using substitutes, not just original parts.In the end, however, it must be remembered that the right balance between quality and price should, however, be provided by the market, not just paragraphs.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I voted in favour of this proposal, which will support consumer rights through the improvement of product lifespan and by increasing the reparability of products through guarantees and increasing the accessibility of spare parts. Consumers must be protected from the growing trend of planned obsolescence, something that has become particularly prevalent in the software industry, and they should be assured of a reasonable product lifespan. By establishing minimum resistance criteria, this proposal will lead to longer-lasting products and will benefit both consumers and companies. In voting for this proposal, we are protecting the rights of the consumer and supporting the development of a functioning economy. Our message is: repair rather than replace, old is often better than new, and save rather than lose. Well done to you on your chairing of today’s session, and have a good time in the future.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: - Madam President, we all know that. Immediately after the warranty, our TV, laptop or phone will suddenly break down. Repair in a workshop is no longer possible because the manufacturer no longer supports older models or simply lacks spare parts. Products spoil too quickly and consumers have to constantly buy new ones, even if they don't want to. It's not just about electronics, it's also about toys, sports equipment, clothes or white goods, and we can't do without it. Longer durability and better product repairability are therefore not only an element of a fairer approach to customers, but also part of the key to mitigating the impact of climate change. But also to increase the employment of small businesses. I can imagine that thousands of skilled craftsmen will be put in for repairs, and let us be sure that they will be needed in every town. I can also imagine that the production and supply of spare parts will increase, so I see great pluses here. A uniform indication of the durability of the products can help to do this, for example by stating the guaranteed durability of the product directly on the packaging, or a guarantee of the repairability of the product. That is why I voted in favor.

name: Lucy ANDERSON
text: – Madam President, I welcome this report. It is particularly important that it aims to strengthen consumer protection, especially in relation to those products which are reasonably expected to last for a significant period of time. This is particularly important in the context of ongoing discussions on contract-law rights for consumers. It is important that we pursue greater value for money for reliable and durable products and that we benefit companies and the wider society by reducing waste. It is also positive that this report reflects the need for minimum criteria on issues such as reparability and the ability to upgrade easily, especially when it comes to software. I was pleased to see that the amendments I put forward regarding battery technology issues and improving battery technology were included, and that the report calls for consumer safety to be protected, arguably in relation not only to general issues but also to spare parts.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: - Madam President! At the Srebrenica memorial site there are 149 Selimovic. 149. I do not know who they were, I do not know what they were working on, I do not know if they were poor or had dandruff in their hair, nor did those who executed them. That's the whole point of the genocide. Do not kill one and then one and then another. Without all. Every. The question I have been asking myself for a long time is of course why these 149 Selimovic and not this one? It's an anxious question but I promise you, you get used to it. I have lived with that question for 22 years. Next week, July 11, we will celebrate the anniversary of the genocide. We will remember not to forget what suffering people have experienced. To not do so is to offend them again. For its own sake, for the sake of its future and for the sake of respect for the victims, therefore, Serbia and Republika Srpska must acknowledge that genocide. This report does not mention it, but I am voting in favor of it in the hope that it will help in that way.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Madam President, ignorance always helps the aggressor, not the victim.We know very well which are the two great financial powers that finance terrorist groups that have interests in the area and that can stop aggression, genocide, death, but they do not.The International Criminal Court is now investigating nine countries, most of them African.Syria and Iraq should also be included in the list of these countries.Let us not forget that, beyond politics and words, there are people - people who are tortured, who are raped, children who are made soldiers, people who are subjected to forced religious conversions and so on.For them we must do politics and for them we must not forget.Once again: let us not be ignorant, because we are not ignorant, let us tell the truth, to help the victims, that is, the people.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: - Madam President, I voted in favor of this report because I personally believe in the need for the international community, led by the European Union, to step up its efforts to monitor and resolve any conflicts that could lead to crimes, and in particular crimes against humanity.In this context, I would like to call on the European Union, the European Commission and the European Council to do more to resolve in a timely manner crisis and conflict situations that may lead to the commission of cruel crimes.I would also like to point out, in particular, the importance and effectiveness of the exchange of information and coordination in investigations or preventive measures between institutions.I think that is very necessary.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, I also supported this report. In my opinion, the International Criminal Court and support for the Rome Statute in general are in the European Union's own vital interest. If we want international law to really apply to all aggressors who commit war crimes, including genocide, it is undoubtedly necessary for the International Criminal Court to give its jurisdiction to the vast majority of countries. This is not the case today, and it is in the European Union's interest to get this support to the maximum, of course. I appreciate the report, which unfortunately was not discussed in plenary, apart from a very short presentation, that it strengthens the element of prevention and cooperation within the international community. I think that this is absolutely crucial, especially for the prevention of this crime, which must not be time-barred. I think it is important to reiterate that people who commit these crimes must not escape justice at any time in their lives and hide from this justice and their responsibilities.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President!Ladies and gentlemen,The use of war tragedies to promote prenatal infanticide is an act of complete cynicism, especially in a situation where we have banned the use of the death penalty for perpetrators of war rape, even murder rape.This approach documents the complete disease of our civilization: the multiplication of laws to protect evil and the systematic dismantling of the protection of goods for which each civilized state is responsible.Only a return to the ethics of the Decalogue and the Gospel, only listening to the deep inner voice of our civilization can save it.This should be repeated all the more, the more our civilization is in danger in its existence.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Madam President!For years I have been dealing with security and defense issues, and with some satisfaction I noted the interest of the European Parliament in the condition of security companies.It is a market with a turnover of 35 billion annually and employing 1.5 million people.Let me remind you that over 40,000entities are protected not only by water treatment plants, but also, for example, by power plants.It is very important that this document does not over-regulate the way these companies operate, because they operate in different economic conditions.It is important, however, that there will be an exchange of information about criminal activities with some members of security groups, and that a list of companies that can be recommended for tasks requiring extraordinary quality will be created.I would like to emphasize that the work of the initiator of this project was very good.For this reason, I was able to support this report.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Madam President, on this report, I admit that I was reluctant to support it, and I must say that without the rapporteur's statement in Vautmans today and the tabling of an oral amendment, I would not support this report. Of course, I recognize the importance of cooperating with private agencies in ensuring security, but at yesterday's mini-debate, because unfortunately there was no debate on this point again, I think, the important fact that the private security services that involved in ensuring safety must have no role in the investigation. They may not, in principle, have more rights than those provided for in the laws of the national Member States than ordinary private individuals. That is important, and this reassurance, which was given by the oral amendment, aroused in me precisely the positive expectation. That is, in the end, I supported this report.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Madam President, like my fellow speaker, I was reluctant to support the report, and finally, thanks to the oral amendment that was adopted, I supported the report. It is also important to me that, in short, private security agencies have clear rules and do not accept the powers of public authorities, state bodies, whether in the form of troops, that is, military units to which international military law applies, or in the form of, say, other armed forces. which are regulated by state power, public law, etc. I think it is always necessary to distinguish and make clear where the boundary is between public power and between private agencies that are private in nature. I do not question their importance, as auxiliary bodies in resolving conflicts, they certainly have their significance in dealing with the consequences of conflicts, and that is why I do not oppose them in any way. On the other hand, as I said, let us not forget that these are private entities, and that is important to emphasize all the time.

name: Curzio MALTESE
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in Europe and in the world, we have been immersed for decades in a process of devaluation of work which is the primary cause of crisis in democratic systems.A society that does not recognize the right to decent work is a society that destroys the foundations of citizenship.Today we have all the tools to reverse this march towards nowhere, starting with the achievements of technology, which are a conquest of all humanity, which today are put at the service of a few super rich, instead of being used to free the masses.of workers from the slavery of a boring, repetitive job.I therefore want to thank the author of the report, Hon.Sylikiotis, for framing the terms of this true social drama with precision and courage and for offering a number of very good suggestions.But concrete action must be taken immediately, before it is late.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, despite the comforting messages about the resumption of employment, full-time work at Union level is still below the level of 2008. The optimism about employment rates is due in many cases , to an increase in zero-hour contracts, but also to a range of atypical formulas that affect the rights and dignity of workers. Precariousness has risen above all in the last ten to fifteen years, especially in construction, agriculture, aviation and the hotel sector. Then there is the phenomenon of illegal hiring, quite widespread in Italy, but also known in other European countries, and which is similar to slavery. It is an illegal form of recruitment and organization of labor, especially agricultural and construction workers, through intermediaries - the corporals - who hire, on behalf of the entrepreneur, daily workers outside the normal employment channels, without any respect for the envisaged contracts, taking possession of much of their salary and often segregating them. From this point of view, there is still a lot to do, but the actions against precarious and undeclared work, envisaged by the proposal, go in the right direction. This is why our vote is in favor.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, globalization and international competition, in addition to the Chineseization of wages, have now led to the breakdown of labor relations. As a result, we now have too many forms of informal work. Also, dependent work is becoming more and more limited, resulting in supposed forms of self-employment. All this, of course, creates problems for social cohesion. Undeclared work is also a huge problem, especially at a time when we have millions of poor people and, of course, armies of unemployed people. In addition, women, who make up 46% of the workforce, are the weakest link in the labor market, as they say, because they are under pressure and earn at least 16% lower than men. Therefore, measures are needed on employment issues.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Madam President!The world is changing, along with these changes, the economy, as well as the labor market.Until now, the main form of employment, the standard form, was an open-ended and full-time contract.However, in the last 15 years we have seen an increase in the number of non-standard employment contracts.They include, among otherspart-time employment contracts, temporary employment contracts, contracts of employment from home or telework, zero-hour contracts or civil law contracts.In this situation, it is the duty of the Union, but also of the Member States, to ensure that workers - regardless of the legal basis of their employment - are guaranteed the minimum: social, health, safety and health at work, etc.it could be as flexible as possible and free of excessive bureaucracy, otherwise it would serve neither employees, nor the employer, nor the labor market.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Madam President, the introduction of new technologies and digitalisation open up great opportunities for new jobs. At the same time, however, this process poses a number of challenges for both employers and workers. Zero working hours contracts and job insecurity are only part of this issue. I believe that, in these circumstances, it is imperative that the European Parliament take a firm stand on precarious employment and working conditions. A new regulatory framework is needed to ensure decent working conditions for the new types of employment that are yet to be created as a result of digitalisation. I supported Mr Siliciotis's report because I believe that the European Commission and the Member States must ensure maximum protection for workers in the European Union. Special attention should be paid to young and old workers, as well as to people with disabilities who are most vulnerable.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Madam President! The report we are debating clearly focuses on negative trends in the labor market, including, in particular, the abuse of flexible forms of employment. However, we cannot stigmatize them. Very often they give the only chance to work for young people with no experience, women raising children or people who value independence. It seems to me that the boundary condition, the breach of which leads to numerous irregularities and pathologies, is forcing employees to adopt a flexible work base when we only want to increase productivity and competitiveness at the expense of employee rights. Thus, while we should not combat flexible forms of employment, effective mechanisms must be developed to prevent their abuse at the expense of employee rights. A necessary solution is to ensure that all types of work provide adequate social protection, for example in accordance with the Decent Work Agenda of the International Labor Organization. Unfortunately, the report also refers to the revision of the Posting of Workers Directive. This politically sensitive topic that we are working on should be included in this report. Therefore, I abstained in the final vote.

name: Evelyne GEBHARDT
text: This concludes the explanations of vote.

name: Bogusław LIBERADZKI
text: - The next item is the Commission statement on the preparation of the Commission's work program for 2018 (2017/2699 (RSP)).

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, today’s debate launches our joint reflection on the priorities for the coming year. Over the past few days, we have made real progress towards better coordinating our efforts between Parliament, Member States and the Commission. We need to maintain this positive dynamic. Only together can we achieve tangible results in the key areas where our citizens and businesses expect the Union to provide an effective part of the solution. The structured dialogue between Parliament and the Commission is working well, and together we have designed a focused and prioritised agenda. We have read the summary report from the Conference of Committee Chairs and I look forward to hearing your further input in our discussions today.  Halfway through its term of office, this Commission is effectively delivering on the 10 political priorities established at the outset, and on the basis of which this House approved our appointment. We have kept the focus on the big things, where effective European action can make a concrete difference in addressing the challenges facing Europe. Some of these challenges were predictable. Our digital agenda, for example, addresses the need to adapt to – and lead – the fourth industrial revolution that is underway. Others, such as the migration crisis, have evolved at a rate, and on a scale, that requires us all to be innovative and quick on our feet in finding ways to manage the situation effectively. Today we see what is happening in Italy, and we have just been discussing in the College of Commissioners today the series of immediate measures that can be taken by the EU Member States, the Commission, the EU agencies and Italy itself to accelerate our response to the pressing and dire situation in the central Mediterranean. The implementation of the 2017 Work Programme is well under way. We have many important proposals on the table and we will redouble our engagement with you and the Council in the coming months to ensure real progress on measures such as the European Pillar of Social Rights, where I look forward to the interinstitutional proclamation to be signed by Parliament, the Council and the Commission before the end of this year. The string of brutal terrorist attacks on European cities again shows that we must deliver on the European security agenda by reaching timely agreement on tackling money laundering and on the European Travel Information and Authorisation System. With rising security threats and instability in our neighbourhood, we need to make good progress on the European Defence Fund, and I see a lot of political momentum on this subject. In the autumn we will present further measures, including on tackling tax fraud and tax evasion and on EU company law. We will deliver on our circular economy strategy with important proposals on plastics. Commission President Juncker will deliver a State of the Union speech here in this House on 13 September. As usual, our letter of intent will be sent to you in parallel. On that basis, I look forward to further exchanges between us all. I hope that we will also have productive discussions with the Council in the latter part of this year so that we can adopt our Work Programme for 2018 on 24 October 2017. Our work next year will remain focused on delivering on the remaining actions provided for under our 10 priorities and the strategies for implementing them. We will pay particular attention, in terms of implementation, to the adoption of pending proposals. We will maintain a focus on regulatory fitness. The opinions of the REFIT Platform will feed into the discussions on the Commission Work Programme so that we continue to deliver on our shared policy ambitions without any unnecessary complexity. We want rules that will actually be implemented and thus bring real results on the ground, with a special focus on small and medium—sized enterprises. Indeed, above all, 2018 will be a key year for delivery. When this House rises for elections in 2019, citizens will judge for themselves whether Europe has done what they expected. The Commission will continue to be your loyal partner in helping to find compromises and reaching agreement on key legislative measures. The joint declaration on the EU’s legislative priorities, signed by the Presidents of our three institutions in December 2016, has proved very valuable. After six months, we have been able to complete work on terrorist offences and firearms and on boosting the Capital Markets Union. The day after tomorrow – on Thursday – you will vote on better access for blind and partially sighted people to copyright works, as well as on the European Fund for Sustainable Development to address the poor living standards and lack of work opportunities which push people to migrate. But more effort is now needed on legislative proposals that have not really progressed so far, including on the European Deposit Insurance Scheme and the Common European Asylum System. This joint declaration process is not a matter of fast-tracking or undermining the quality of scrutiny and decision-making by the co-legislators. That would be counterproductive as it could only lead to poor results that do not address the challenges we face. But our cooperation does help to ensure that, where problems or delays arise, everyone is focused on finding solutions. We have shown with the European Border and Coast Guard and the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) that, when we all work hard on a shared priority, we can achieve the right results at the right time. I hope that agreement on EFSI 2.0 is close in sight. So I look forward to the three Presidents’ agreeing later this year on a new joint declaration to shape our work for next year. All this programming and planning is not a bureaucratic process or a means in itself. Our dialogue about priorities is deeply political because it is about the sort of Europe we want to create. The Commission has launched a broad debate on the future of Europe with you and with national parliaments, with local and regional authorities, and with civil society at large. I count on your support in spurring an active, inclusive debate around where we want to be as the EU in the future, not just next year but also in the years to come.

name: József SZÁJER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I will start where the Vice-President of the Commission stopped. Europe is still facing a crisis that we have not overcome yet, and that means much closer attention is required. We cannot just act like in normal peace times, so the exercise of determining the next year’s legislation is a very important debate. It is also a good way of mapping out how the various political parties here in Parliament are thinking about that. On behalf of the PPE I would like to say we still believe that a competitive social market economy is the cornerstone of the European society. We also have to be very careful and pay attention to citizens and their needs. In this framework I would like to say clearly that we have asked the Commission to make efforts to further improve the work-life balance. We have also asked the Commission to determine their key priority actions to strengthen industrial competitiveness, enable companies to compete in domestic and global markets and reinforce the capacity of the Union and its Member States to support the development of businesses, with special attention to small and medium-sized enterprises. We also would like, in the context of completion of the digital single market, to see special attention paid to cyber security, interoperability and the digitalisation of the transport sector, including road safety. In the area of migration, which is the big challenge ahead of the European Union, we consider it of the utmost importance to tackle the root causes of migration by upgrading the Union’s development and cooperation policy in Africa as well as its role in the resolution of conflict in its neighbouring countries. The other area which citizens are demanding us to pay special attention to – and we are doing that by forwarding the demand to the Commission – is security, which, in both its internal and its external aspects, should be a priority, with commitments to the neighbourhood and to ensuring the stability and implementation of the European Defence Action Plan. In the financial area, we are expecting the Multiannual Financial Framework post-2020 and the proposal on own resources to be tabled by June 2018. This is very important if they are to correspond with the Commission’s and Parliament’s political cycles. Simplification of cohesion policy and the future of the common agricultural policy should be key elements. The PPE Group wants to insist on implementation. The Commission is taking the right course in that, instead of addressing the many areas where there is a demand from the left in this House for regulation, it is concentrating on how we implement the existing legislation. The Commission has its role to play, together with the Member States, because we need to use all the available tools before creating new laws or legislation.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, we know that now is a very important time to prepare the Commission work programme and set the right course for the European Union. This year is particularly important because we are also discussing the future of Europe, and Parliament should be involved in these discussions taking place everywhere. We are in a new situation. This is a kind of moment of truth, of clarification, because the right-wing political parties have decided to table their own resolution – a very conservative one, as we see it. Let me be precise. What is really needed in the European Union today? Progressive forces, and I believe the majority of citizens, are sure that we need to have a new growth and jobs strategy driven by sustainable development goals. This is very clear. Progressive forces and the majority of citizens know that we need a stronger social pillar, making sure that everybody – in whatever kind of job, including in the digital-economy transformation – has a decent labour contract and full access to social protection. We also need to make sure that we have the means to invest in people, particularly in children with the ‘Child Guarantee’. Well, I must say I find it regrettable that the motion tabled by the conservative forces in this Parliament does not agree with any of this. They do not include these requirements – which are so clear – in their motion. We also know that in order to really respect the Paris climate deal we need to translate our commitments into a real investment policy supported by the Union budget, and we know that in order to cope with the current refugee crisis the real solution is a European asylum system, which requires full reform of the Dublin regime. This is so clear. Nevertheless, it is not recognised by the right-wing coalition which is now organising the European Parliament. Finally, we know that, in order to cope with these external challenges, we need to strengthen internal cohesion among Europeans, and this means tackling the divergence in the eurozone, with the Banking Union and fiscal capacity being introduced. It also means having a forward-looking Community budget, counting on our own resources, based on corporate taxation, and based on energy emissions. We need to turn Europe to the future and not to the past. I believe that Parliament must be involved in the discussion which is coming in the European Council and everywhere. This is the purpose of our motion and we believe we can get substantial support.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, the European Union will only thrive if we take reform seriously. We face many social and environmental difficulties, as has been outlined by Commissioner Timmermans, but I want to focus on the enormous economic challenges we face: competitiveness, the loss of jobs to overseas employers, low growth rates, eurozone stagnation. These have led to unemployment levels in parts of Europe that are far too high and poor wage growth that has led to stagnant household incomes for far too long.  So as the Commission designs its work programme for 2018, the foremost objective must be to address Europe’s economic weaknesses by pursuing measures that unleash and encourage the creative capacities of our entrepreneurs and businesses, especially SMEs. This will deliver benefits for the whole community. If we can get that right, so many of our other political, social and environmental problems will be easier to overcome. If we are economically weak, we will be dominated by others who may not share our democratic traditions or political principles, but if we are economically strong, we will be in a position to defend our values and promote our common interests in what will be a very difficult century ahead.  To help set an agenda of renewal, we have been pleased to work with the EPP and ALDE Groups on a joint motion. Of course, our Groups have very different political visions for Europe – there are many areas where we do not agree. But what we have in common is a desire to address Europe’s shared problems in a practical way, with a programme of constructive reform. So we have come together on the specific issue of the 2018 work programme to help set a strong and positive agenda for reform on key issues which would deliver tangible benefits to all our citizens, and I commend it to you.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, we note the absence of the Council, which is not innocent. This morning I heard – I was not present myself – that President Juncker was very upset at the low turnout of MEPs in this room and called us ridiculous. Well, I would like to say that the absence of the Council is fairly ridiculous because we are three EU institutions, the Council representing the Member States and the Member States are responsible for a very important part of the implementation of the things that we are talking about today. We need the Council on board and yet the Council doesn’t seem to think that they need Europe or the Commission or Parliament. It is very symbolic that the Council is absent because we all know that there is a big problem in the implementation and the enforcement of European policies. Despite our occasional differences, the Commission and Parliament are usually singing from the same hymn sheet. We do our homework, we adopt policies and then the problems start because the Member States fail to implement. If I may give you one blatant example it is of course the famous EU Passenger Name Record Directive which had to be adopted in a big rush. So where are we now with the implementation? Absolutely nowhere. And this is typical for most of the files. When it comes to implementation and enforcement I would also like to look at the Commission because – yes – we are talking about important topics today that we would like the Commission to take initiatives on, but we would also like the Commission to be a bit more assertive when it comes to enforcing EU law against the Member States. We have been talking here a lot about issues relating to fundamental rights and the rule of law, but I am also thinking about something like Dieselgate. Why does it have to be the Americans who take action, who find out? Why isn’t it our own authorities? If we agree that it is the national authorities that implement EU policies we have to be absolutely sure that that is what they are doing: implementing, applying, enforcing the policies. Because if they fail to do that then they should not have that power; then it should be at EU level. Another request to the Commission: we note that when it comes to files relating to, for example, fighting terrorism, there is a systematic absence of impact assessments. Can we please make sure that from now on, every proposal relating to the fight against terrorism and crime will be accompanied by an impact assessment? Finally to my colleague Ms Rodrigues, who referred to us as conservative right-wing forces. I think that is very funny because when it is about other topics I am usually accused of being left-wing, so whatever. I am probably in the middle. I would say, you know, conservative forces are right-wing and left-wing these days. On your topic of a social Europe, the Liberals are very much for a free Europe but also for a fair Europe. And that means fair opportunities for everybody, and confusion is often in social Europe equates a socialist Europe, well we see it differently. We believe in opportunities, in opening our borders and giving young people access to the labour market, rather than replacing outdated social security systems at national level with one at the European level. Let’s finally give young people an opportunity. People have been excluded from the labour market – yes, dear colleague – excluded from the labour market. Let’s finally give them the same chances as those who are already in a job. I hope that we can do this together with the Commission.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Mr Timmermans, the European Union and the Commission need to change a lot, in practice and not in words, to regain citizens' trust, because inequalities, unemployment, poverty, social and regional inequalities, the gap between rich and poor, and from this the idea of ​​a united democratic Europe loses and the far right that wants to break up Europe gains. But citizens no longer want words; they are asking for positive, concrete steps that they will see reflected in their lives, in the economy, in society, in the quality of democracy, in economic and social cohesion. They call for a strong social pillar with content, not an empty box, to tackle growing inequalities and social dumping, a European Social Charter that legally binds on a common mandatory framework of rights for the poor and workers across Europe and a new employment and growth pact that will put an end to the doctrine of eternal austerity and strengthen cohesion policies. They are calling for tax harmonization - finally - in Europe, to stop consistent taxpayers, whether employees, retirees or small and medium-sized enterprises, from paying the cost of a giant tax evasion by multinational corporations, and calling for respect for human rights, racism, and European solutions in solidarity with the refugee, so that not only the Italians and the Greeks bear this burden. The European Union needs radical changes to boost development and social cohesion, because otherwise it will face disintegration, inequality and the danger of an extreme right that wants to take us back eighty years.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Mr Timmermans, according to the World Health Organization, each year between 20,000 and 30,000 Europeans die from asbestos, a substance that has been known to be carcinogenic since the early 1960s. However, it was not until 1997 that it was banned in Europe. In the meantime, hundreds of thousands of lives have been ruined or lost. You are going to say to me: "What is the link with the Commission's work program?" Quite simply this one: when I see you at work, I see in you again and again the same obsession, that of deregulation. You are going to tell me: “No, not at all”. But the facts are there. Despite growing opposition from our fellow citizens, you persist in wanting to conclude tailor-made free trade agreements for multinationals, like, again this week, with Japan. Ten years after the onset of the global financial crisis, what do we see? Rather, the Commission is proposing to reverse financial regulation by opposing any increase in banks' equity capital, at the very moment when, in Italy, taxpayers are once again called upon to put their hand in the wallet to save these same banks. You persist in wanting to make our fellow citizens swallow glyphosate willingly or by force and, listening to you, we will only be able to ban endocrine disruptors when they have proved their harmfulness, that is to say, as in the case of tobacco or in that of asbestos, when the health disaster has been observed. As for your recommendations on work, they are based on a totem: flexibilize, flexibilize and flexibilize. Mr. Timmermans, when you talk about better regulation, who do you mean? To our fellow citizens or to the owners of capital? When you talk about impact analysis, are you talking about impact on life or impact on profits? These rules that you so easily call "Non-tariff barriers to trade" we prefer to call them for what they are, namely protections that should ensure the possibility of a life of dignity for all of our citizens.Mr Timmermans, you and I were kids in 1968. What I mean by that is that neither you nor I are bound by that slightly crazy May slogan, according to which it would be 'forbidden to'to prohibit".When there is certainty or a substantiated presumption that financial, chemical, agricultural, food, or general-purpose products are toxic, the only responsible attitude is to ban them.

name: Laura AGEA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, let's face it: today Italy represents the stupid state of the European Union for all of you gathered here. Let's not fool ourselves. It hurts to admit it, but that's the way it is. Whose fault is it, gentlemen? Of Germany and France, who raise the walls and turn their backs on us in a moment of emergency? Or of all the past Italian governments, which have bowed to compromise for crumbs of notoriety? It's a shame! It is a shame to discover that Italy, with Renzi, after the "Mare Nostrum" operation signed the "Triton" agreement, which you proposed as a solution to all evil: European boats in exchange for migrants. It is a shame that the Italian banking system is collapsing in the name of the austerity rules that you have imposed and that the Italian governments have accepted. It is a shame that the European Union, born to create a path of solidarity between states, is today the symbol of a failed plan. We, gentlemen, unlike what is reported in the press, we believe in the dream of a united and united Europe, and we really believe in it. But today it remains only a dream. Because in words you are all good at making promises. Do you want to regain some credibility? Then hurry up! Number one: let's immediately remove the noose of austerity from the neck of the weakest; number two: let's immediately tear up the Dublin regulation that has transformed Italy into the refugee camp of all of Europe. Are you willing to do it?

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today I am more disappointed and more pissed off than usual. Pissed off at you, feel-gooders from half of Europe, because after years of guilty silence you suddenly wake up and tell us that too many illegal immigrants arrive in Italy. But how? I've been telling you this for at least five years and you, all of you, have always accused me of being a racist. The truth is that I am not a racist, we are not racist, we are just realists. Thousands of illegal immigrants continue to disembark in Italy: 85,000 in the last six months, brought by ships flying flags from all over the world. Why everyone in Italy? Why are other countries closing their borders and Italy cannot do it? To the European Commission and the Italian government I say only one thing: be ashamed! Today you announced a new action plan to reduce migration flows. The usual fried air. You are like the Italian government: only chat and badge! You are like the "Renziloni" government, which threatens to close ports but does not have the courage to do so. Because all of you are complicit in this wild immigration. But now our patience is over. Fi-ni-ta! And we of the Lega, together with thousands of Italian citizens tired of listening to your lies, will physically close the ports and not let the illegal immigrants off those ships. Zero tolerance and armored borders. We will defend ourselves against this invasion.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Mr Chairman! The preparation of the Commission's work program for 2018 is the start of building this plan, and that is what the Vice-President put forward. Of course, our debate takes place under certain conditions. Firstly, we are presented with a White Paper with five options for the future of the Union. In addition, there is a debate on the budget after 2021, also in five variants, and the actual start of negotiations on the exit of Great Britain from the EU, which are expected to end sometime at the end of 2018. This will, of course, largely determine our work in Parliament. The mid-term budgetary review has also started and is still ongoing and certain conclusions will be drawn. We are also in the process of making very important decisions on the functioning of the Energy Union, proposing solutions that apply to a resource-efficient Union, especially in relation to the circular economy, and there is still a real decision on the defense union and its challenges ahead of us. , in particular when it comes to fighting terrorism and our external security. Here, too, we should consider the policy towards our neighbors in Europe and Europe's neighbors. It is also necessary to implement and finalize the assumptions of the single market strategy and the digital single market, in particular the European data-based economy. Therefore, I am particularly pleased with the declaration that the role of small and medium-sized enterprises in the economy will be made visible, because it is a guarantee of stable, good jobs in Europe.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission! These days are the days of the big names in the European Parliament. We thought of Simon Veils today, and Helmut Kohls here on Saturday. We could just as well commemorate the life's work of a Helmut Schmidt, a Willy Brandt, a Giscard d‘Estaing, all of whom have contributed to Europe in unison. I wonder what the message of these attributions is these days. Among the challenges of Brexit, international globalization, climate change - what would your message be? In particular, I hear one sentence from these life's works, a very brief one: Have courage, have courage, keep up with the times, not yesterday, if you want to defend Europe! And tells people that it is only Europe that can protect them and lead them on the way to a better future. But then I ask myself, dear colleagues: Why is it so difficult? Why can't we adopt a joint paper in which every employee is granted the right to decent work, to protection, to social protection within employment, but also in private life? Why can't we tell the children of Europe that you don't have to grow up in poverty? And that, Ms. colleague in 't Veld, is the difference: We share the opinion that people want to live their freedom, that they want to shape their own lives. But we also believe that they can do it all the better if they don't have to worry about everyday life, don't have to worry about the adversities of everyday life. So why can't we produce a common paper by giving the Commission a guideline on it? This is my appeal! I don't get it, I would like the other groups to be up to date and help us get this through.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: - Mr President, good afternoon, Mr Timmermans! My friend here in the European Parliament recently complained that she now has a lot less work - she's a translator - and that is a direct result of the fact that the Commission is now putting far fewer legislative proposals. I find that very commendable. This is also a good thing because the Commission now has time to address the biggest problem facing the European Union - that is the migrants. First they came via Hungary, then via the Western Balkans, then via Turkey, now they come via Libya. In the meantime, the rescue organizations are the biggest smugglers because they pick up the migrants 20 kilometers off the Libyan coast and transport them all to Italy. You are well aware of that. It would be time to rethink parts of the Geneva Agreement so that individual asylum law cannot be abused for mass migration. That was never intended for. In any case, the solution is not to distribute the migrants across Europe, but to stop them. And what I don't understand is that France will not be punished for exceeding the deficit, Hungary and Poland will be punished.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, debt, euro, banking, three fundamental lines of action and necessary break with the constraints of the European Union. The debt response requires the initiation and supports the public debt renegotiation processes, in terms, amounts and interest, along with the cancellation of its illegitimate component, ensuring that the debt service is compatible with the social and economic development of each country. . Breaking with the garrote that is the euro, a political instrument of concentration and economic control, which imposed a brutal dynamic of divergence in the euro area, requires the creation of support programs for those countries that consider that their stay in the euro has become unsustainable and unbearable providing adequate compensation for losses caused by a negotiated exit from the single currency. To reject banking union means to free countries from the strategy of concentration, centralization and alienation of national banking abroad as a necessary way to regain public and democratic control over the banking system. No people are condemned to be tied to these or other European Union constraints contrary to their interests and sovereignty, and it will be the will of the peoples and their struggle that the alternative to the future of impoverishment and exploitation that can be predicted in any of your countries will be built. scenarios. This struggle will pave the way for another Europe of peace and cooperation, of progress and social justice, of free and sovereign states equal in rights.

name: Kristina WINBERG
text: - Mr President! It is often said that one should solve the causes of a problem, not just treat the symptoms. I would like to say that there are simpler solutions to the migration crisis, which is the crisis we should be talking about all the time in this House. The crisis created by an overly generous immigration policy in, above all, countries such as Sweden, with a well-meaning thought in itself, but which in practice is catastrophically counterproductive for the well-being of a democratic state. In addition, the crisis is caused by the enormous population growth that is taking place outside Europe and the dysfunctional nature of these areas and countries, which results in high unemployment and very bleak future prospects. In Italy, economic migrants are mainly pouring in right now. Some days there will be thousands. The solution is not to arrange a mandatory redistribution from Italy to the rest of Europe. It's like pouring water out of the boat but not plugging the hole in the boat, if I am allowed to use such a parable in these contexts. The Commission and some Home Affairs Ministers presented a solution on this day, which will, among other things, help the Libyan Coast Guard to better patrol its coast. We also want to help Libya secure their enormously long southern border. It is not said who will do this. It sounds like building a new state apparatus in Libya, which will be a big challenge. I have a simpler solution. Return asylum legislation to each country. Give Italy the right to limit the number of people seeking asylum. Decide on a break in asylum applications, or why not the right to say no to the boats from various organizations that are currently basically transporting migrants almost all the way from the Libyan coast to Italy. I am aware of objections to asylum and other international law, but this must be resolved.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: - Mr President, colleagues, Commissioner. I will talk today about industry and jobs. We know that our goal in Europe is to increase the share of industry in GDP to 20%. Sounds beautiful! These are jobs. But the question is, why do we not have so many jobs in industry in Europe, why are we not developing? And here we must remember that European industry competes in the world market, competes with America, with China, with Japan, with other economies. And raw materials prices are important for the whole industry, for the whole industry, to be competitive. Prices! Especially energy, especially electricity. The lower the electricity prices, the more competitive European industry is. Mr Timmerman, as a representative of the Commission, I call on you to pay particular attention in the eighteenth year to the fact that this so-called winter energy package, which would actually promote it through the law to develop the electricity market, is really moving forward through both Parliament and the Council. could come up with a new law in Europe that will promote competition in the electricity market, lower prices, which will make our industry more competitive, so that we can achieve this twenty percent target.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, today we are talking about how the Commission could work more effectively. Yes, a quality social agenda that goes hand in hand with well-thought-out economic measures is a precondition for reducing unemployment. Yes, we will only achieve sustainable development if we work together to meet the challenges of climate change and globalization, and yes, the Union will be a leading global power if we speak with one voice. However, the Commission will achieve absolutely nothing without strict adherence to values. And Slovenian citizens are well on their way to losing confidence in the Commission. After this Commission sponsored the arbitration agreement between Slovenia and Croatia and participated in the decision that it was part of the Croatian accession package, it is now indecisive. Why don't you, Mr Timmermans, speak out loud that it is simply a matter of respecting international and European law? To honor the eminent international judges, on the border between the two countries, which was adopted a few days ago. And, in fact, we citizens may be most afraid of this when they feel that, instead of in the interests of all citizens of the European Union, the Commission is working solely in the interests of certain countries or individuals or groups. Then it will be too late for any work program and quality policies. Thank you very much.

name: David CASA
text: - Sur President, iva, l-ikbar sfida għalina fis-snin li ġejjin, jiġifieri l-abbiltà li nsibu bilanċ bejn it-tkabbironomiiku u sostenibbli - u allura qed nistaqsu kif se nindirizzaw and? Hu essenzjali li l-ħaddiema jkunu kapaċi jaddattaw irwieħhom u jsibu impjieg li jkun paragunabbli mal-kwalifiċi tagħhom u jkunu kapaċi jittrasferixxu l-ħiliet tagħhom bejn industry u oħ ieħ. It-taħriġ u t-tagħlim huwa neċessarju sabiex nassiguraw li t-tkabbir fl-impjiegi jkun imqabbel mal-provvista tax-xogħol, u dan jgħodd mhux biss għal dawk il-ħaddiema ta 'età avvanzata iżu wklu fidal dinja tax-xogħol għall-ewwel darba. Irridu ninvestu fil-ħaddiema sabiex inkunu nistgħu nħaddmu potenzjal sħiħ tas-suq u forom ġodda ta 'xogħol. Il-pajjiżi Membri għandhom jiġu inkoraġġuti sabiex jinvestu fi programmi ta 'tagħlim ta' matul il-ħajja għall-ħaddiema kollha f'kull qasam. Irridu wkoll nanalizzaw is-swieq tax-xogħol sabiex insibu l-bilanċ ġust bejn it-taħriġ vokazzjonali u dak universitarju, sabiex b'hekk nissodaw il-ħolqa bejn id-domanda u l-provvista tas-suq tax-xogħ. It-trawwim u l-istimular tal-intraprenditorija huwa crewjali, ukoll f'termini nassiguraw it-tkabbir u s-salvagwardjar fi ħ and swieq tax-xogħol diversion. It-tieni ħaġa hija li l-intreprenditorija ma tgħoddx biss għal dawk li jkunu qegħdin ifittxu l-impjieg, imma għal dawk li jkunu qegħdin joħolquhom ukoll.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: - Sir. Chairman! Sir. First Deputy Chairman Timmermans! The Commission's work program must address where Europe's citizens are struggling with real problems and concerns in their daily lives. In 2018, the EU must lay a common ground under corporation tax, stop and punish tax havens and international tax evasion, create new jobs and safeguard the jobs that already exist: in short, we must have a solidarity pact in Europe. From 2001 to 2016, corporation tax in the EU member states has fallen from 30% to 22% on average. It is a race to the bottom between the countries of Europe, not to create growth, but to steal growth from each other. It's deep good night! It is not a Europe that works together, but a Europe that cheats itself for billions of tax dollars. It must be stopped now! Therefore, we need a common corporate tax base and a common consolidated corporate tax base. But not only that: for the companies that earn the most, tax evasion costs every citizen in the EU 15,000 kroner in lost welfare every year due to tax havens, tax evasion, aggressive tax planning. That is why we must have a common European blacklist of tax havens with harsh, automatic and cash sanctions for both tax havens and the companies and wealthy individuals who use them. Finally, the EU to-do list for 2018 should create new jobs and protect existing ones. We Social Democrats will never accept a common market where workers are forced to undercut each other on poor working conditions and on wage conditions from which one cannot live. That is why we need a solidarity pact, and we should work on that in 2018.

name: Peter LIESE
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen! I want to address the issue of health. It is a subject which, in accordance with the Treaties, is to be dealt with by the European Union - at least in certain areas - and yet we have not received a single legislative proposal since the Juncker-Timmermann Commission took office and we are working on this here in plenary. There are proposals that have come from the old Commission, but nothing new. It's not like we don't have any tasks. We are urged by patient associations, by industry, that something has to be done in the area of ​​technology assessment in healthcare. We need incentives, and very specifically - not just in an action plan, but in legislation - to combat antibiotic resistance in order to bring new innovative drugs to the market. I believe that Parliament has repeatedly made proposals in recent years, including in the EPP resolution that is now before us with other groups. I would ask the Commission to really take this up and not just keep making plans, but also making specific legislative proposals. We don't want to regulate everything, but it is necessary in certain areas. If you ask citizens on their birthday or New Year's: What do you want most? Then there is no stable institutions, economic growth or the like, but health. That is why we must also bear our share of responsibility in this area.

name: Kathleen VAN BREMPT
text: - As has often been the case, once again with my colleague across the street, Peter Liese. And that is why we from these groups are disappointed that no broad common progressive progressive vision is being developed. For example on global warming and the implementation of the Paris Agreement. You should all agree on that, right? Surely it should be at the heart of our action and the action of the Commission? In the first instance, Mr Vice-President of the Commission, that requires that we go the extra mile. Because the initiatives taken by the Commission, which are meritorious, in the field of clean energy for example, were taken before the implementation and assessment of the implementation of the Paris Agreement. This means that we have to be more ambitious than those proposals and that we really have to translate the Paris Agreement into what we are doing here, for example by speeding up initiatives on CO2 emissions from cars, and that we also have to be very ambitious. to do. In connection with this, I would also like to draw attention to the conclusions of our EMIS committee of inquiry, which has put forward very ambitious goals and new initiatives with regard to the Euro 7 standard. Because another problem, Mr Liese, is the health and quality of our air: we have had the cheating software, and now we notice that consumers across the European Union are removing filters from their cars, which means that a modern Euro 6 car today more emissions than a Euro 3 or Euro 4! So I would really like the Commission work program to put such initiatives - climate, sustainability, clean air - at the top of the political agenda.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Commissioner! From the DEVE Development Committee's perspective, as an EPP group, we would like to point out the need to emphasize in the Commission's new work program the issues related to tackling the root causes of migration by strengthening development policy and multi-level cooperation with Africa. The European Consensus for Development and the monitoring of institutional and political changes are indispensable tools for the effective implementation of the 2030 Agenda and the UN global development goals. Working with the private sector is an essential part of achieving these goals, and mobilizing private funding is essential in addressing the root causes of illegal migration. However, in order to monitor the implementation of instruments such as the Trust Fund for Africa or the new European Fund for Sustainable Development and to regularly evaluate their effectiveness, a specific reporting mechanism and adequate parliamentary oversight are necessary. Promoting democracy, good governance and respect for human rights is key to building security in partner countries. Therefore, when working towards peace and stability, account should be taken of the updated ODA criteria in this regard. The new framework for cooperation with ACP countries, to be negotiated to start in 2018, should place emphasis on political dialogue, development cooperation and trade. Regionalization should also be strengthened and the cooperation model adapted to the area in question.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Mister President! In spite of all prophecies of doom, the European Union is in a phase that could give cause for cautious optimism. In such a situation it would be important for the pro-European forces to come up with a clear and unified message pointing the way. We missed this opportunity, unfortunately there is no joint resolution. Pointing blame for it doesn't get us any further. From the perspective of the Social Democrats, the Commission's work program should above all address the problems of the socially disadvantaged and those who have lost their way. Europe will only inspire people if the broad masses also see benefits and there is no legitimate feeling that inequality is growing continuously. So we need the much-invoked social pillar. Without them, the European house will collapse at some point. You can't be a little social. That must be a promise for everyone - within Member States as well as between Member States. Many people are insecure today. Providing security is the task of responsible politics. But there is only security if it goes hand in hand with social security, and that is only there if we are prepared to regulate certain things and not just leave them to the market. Social security and welfare also require everyone to meet their obligations. This includes tax justice and the containment of tax avoidance. We need this clarity, and our amendments try to establish it.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! It is absolutely clear that the next year will be a very decisive one, and it is just a matter of doing what is important better and what is perhaps less important. If you look at the catalog of the important things, of course the fair design of globalization is part of it. And - I think - you have presented a very good piece of paper on this, but that has to be implemented. I think five elements are crucial here. People want z. B. know where the textiles they wear come from and that there is no social or environmental dumping involved. So a mandatory corporate due diligence must be on the table. We also want to ensure that workers' rights can be enforced if they are violated. That is why we need a proposal for a binding regulation of workers' rights in international treaties. We want to make sure that the international governance system is preserved, that we can really proceed actively based on international rules. We have to make sure that we get a lot more transparency in our international negotiations so that people regain more confidence in the European Union's performance. We must also ensure - and this is also indicated in your paper - that a connection is made between the external and internal dimensions of globalization. It must not be that only a few benefit from globalization. We have to make sure that everyone benefits from the fact that internal equality and justice are established in the same way.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice-President, you have two years left for this Faint Hope Commission. Also, listen to what the socialist group has to say to you. I don't know if our resolution will pass. I hope so, but whatever its fate, the messages we send you today in this debate constitute the essential roadmap. Indeed, if we only listen to the conservatives, you will not regain the confidence of the French, because you will not fight as you should, by engaging the Commission, with all the European institutions behind your power of initiative, to tackle inequalities within Member States and between Member States.
