You will not restore the reality of democracy, which means that Economic and Monetary Union will not be able to develop on the basis of a budget which only concerns meetings between governments. We also need - as my colleague Kathleen Van Brempt said - to use the energy, the dynamics, the vector and the engine that represents the result of the Paris conference to modify, change and transform the economic model of the euro area and the European Union. This is what will allow us to reconcile citizens with Europe, with the European Commission and its work program. It's up to you, you have all the cards in your hand!

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: - Mr President, a courageous Europe that does not hide, that is committed to the social dimension, to the rights of the working class and does not allow wages that lead to poverty;a Europe of solidarity, facing the challenge of immigration and refugees, with common policies that do not bury the dignity of people;an open Europe, egalitarian between men and women, sustainable, and that undertakes and is capable of facing the challenges of globalization.That is our bet, that of the European socialists, that we do not renounce a different political project that restores people's trust.Unfortunately, the right wing of this Parliament believes that we can allow ourselves to remain the same, that we can turn our backs on the problems of citizens.We are on time.Let's not let it be too late.Let's not make Europe a problem.Let's make Europe a solution.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Mr Vice-President, the debate is a bit confused, because actually next year will be the year of debate and, we hope, of achievements on the future of Europe, on which you have presented many documents. We regret not having as Parliament succeeded in having a joint resolution on this package on the future of Europe, but we want to remind you that we have approved three reports which address all the major issues that you, in your documents, have begun to transform into proposals. I would like to remind you that those remain our pillars, but I would also like to remind you that, for the future, we are facing an important problem, namely that in many areas on which you make important proposals - one for all, common defense - the role of Parliament it is very limited in the current treaties. It is clear that, in terms of treaty changes, action can be taken, but it is also clear that interinstitutional systems should be proposed to address this issue. I also remember this with regard to the future of the monetary union.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, as you hear, the European Parliament has great ambitions for 2018. I think we are all calling for clear priorities.Personally, I would really expect an emphasis on managing the migration crisis, both inside the European Union and outside the European Union, that is, in the foci where this crisis arises, be it the Middle East, Africa.I think this is a priority for the end of 2017 and the whole of 2018. This year will also be declared the European Year of Cultural Heritage.I believe that this will be a successful year from this point of view, and we will remind citizens of the common foundations on which the European Union was built.I think that this remark will be very much needed at a time when there are currently tough negotiations on Brexit.I would like to draw attention to two more initiatives.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have great faith in 2018. First of all, the social dimension of European integration cannot be reduced to free movement. A serious reform must aim to improve working conditions, reduce poverty and social inequalities, accelerate the convergence of economic performance and income levels between countries and strengthen economic, social and territorial cohesion. We need to be more ambitious in the environmental and health sectors, first of all in the area of ​​endocrine disruptors and antibiotic resistance. In agriculture it is no longer possible to postpone a legislative framework proposal to combat unfair commercial practices in the food chain and provide support measures for farmers in cases of unfair competition. Safe and legal ways to enter Europe need to be guaranteed for those seeking international protection and for asylum seekers. We need to step up efforts to reform the Dublin system, establishing and implementing a real common European policy on asylum.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Madam President, one of the main tasks of the Commission in the coming period should be to create the preconditions for maximizing the benefits of the single market for all Member States.That is why the announcement of French President Macron about "Europe that protects" does not help at all.And that is the way in the wrong direction and could cost us billions of euros in foreign investment and bring new unnecessary regulation into the single market that will make it harder for businesses from smaller and less developed members to do business.Macron is said to have indebted the European Union with his victory over populism.But that does not give him the right to be an economic populist himself and to contaminate Europe's single market with protectionism, which is a legacy of some former times.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I think that, unfortunately, the millions of unemployed people in the European Union, the millions of those who have precarious work, if they listen to us - because I doubt it - those who listen to us, either listen to us sadly or at least look to us in a way that shows that they do not understand us and do not believe us. Secondly, I would like to refer to the environment and say that the European Union must have a very clear position, a unified position, towards the new policy that Mr. Trump wants to impose. Finally, I would like to refer to the public debt of Greece, which should have been a point of discussion, because I believe that without a real retreat on this issue, the country can not get out of the vicious circle of memoranda, and the fact that these people has been suffering for many years, maybe eight in a row to date.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Madam President, Members of the Commission do not usually give us any answers, but I would like to ask Vice-President Timmermans to kindly make an exception. Vice-President Timmermans, speaking about the preparation of the Commission’s Work Programme in 2018, don’t you think that it would be high time to address the issue of the major wage and income gap between Central and Eastern European – that is to say ‘new’ Member States and old Member States in the west – that causes enormous internal migration from our Central and Eastern European countries to western countries? As you very well know, we have a lack of a medical doctors, nurses and even waiters and tourist personnel. We are in trouble. What is the attitude of the Commission towards this? I am glad that you accepted the initiative of eight Central and Eastern European countries towards the so—called wage union, but what is going to happen next?

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Madam President! 2018 will be extremely important for work on the new EU budget after 2020. It will certainly be one of the dominant topics. As announced by the Commission, we can expect the assumptions of the new budget perspective to be presented in the middle of next year. We already know that mainly due to Brexit the new budget will be smaller than the current one. Therefore, the negotiations will not be easy. On the one hand, the budget must take into account the emerging new challenges, for example in the area of ​​security, but on the other hand, it should remain primarily an investment budget. Cohesion policy is the Union's main investment policy, with proven results and significant added value, therefore its share in the new budget after 2020 should remain at the same level as it is today. In addition, it is important that work starts on time and that the new budget, and therefore specific policies, is adopted without delay.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, I have listened carefully to your speech. In your introduction you talk, among other things, about your willingness to work for European small and medium-sized enterprises. However, this Parliament, for almost two years now, has been asking you for a simple measure, precisely for the benefit of European SMEs. This measure is the extension of geographical indications for non-agricultural products. It is the guarantee of maintaining employment in fragile territories, of maintaining know-how, and it is the guarantee of better protection of consumers, with real traceability on the artisanal products made in our countryside, throughout Europe. . This is not a local concern. We have seen companies from Spain, the UK and the Czech Republic asking for this protection. It is a simple measure which shows that the European Union can act for the benefit of European citizens and SMEs. It has been almost two years since this Parliament asked you for a legislative proposal to guarantee this protection. I therefore ask you not to wait any longer and to put this proposal on the table as quickly as possible.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, Mr Timmermans, I will focus on refugees, because this is a problem that plagues Europe, especially Greece, Italy and, from what I see, Spain, and we need to take it seriously. The question is what will happen with the relocation process, because 66,400 relocations should have been made from Greece and only 12,700 have been made, ie the program has been executed at about 15%. At the same time, however, the relocation process ends at the end of September. What is going to happen; Will the program be extended? Will we have a process of real solidarity with Greece and Italy, which are currently suffering from huge refugee and migration flows? We have to take very specific measures, because at the moment the situation in the Aegean islands is unbearable. The islands of the Aegean can no longer withstand refugees and illegal immigrants. I want a position on this, Mr Vice-President.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: - As chairman of the committee, I have two questions. First: when does the Commission intend to present a legislative proposal on unfair commercial practices? Commissioner Hogan has announced that he intends to conduct an impact assessment on this issue. In light of the above, we have concluded that no legislative proposal will be adopted in 2017. In that case, when could such a proposal be finally adopted in 2018? What would be the timeframe for the legislative procedure? From January 1, 2021, a new CAP reform should enter into force. However, a number of recent events indicate that the adoption of the legislative proposals for the reform of the CAP (direct payments, common market organization, rural development, horizontal rules) may be significantly delayed, in particular due to the usual delays in presenting proposals for the new multiannual framework financial. Late legislative proposals for the CAP are likely to be presented in 2018, making it more difficult to predict the completion of the legislative procedure before the end of the parliamentary term in 2019.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - Madam President, the word solidarity in today's debate is a key directive for common European policy. However, I would like to point out one crucial element of this for a sustainable future. For solidarity with the rural, rural population. In most Member States of the European Union, it is no longer possible for the rural population to be subject to persistent discrimination in terms of living conditions, opportunities and access to modern infrastructure. In this context, too, it cannot be said that Europe, although capable of doing so, does not feed all its citizens properly. According to Eurostat alone, one fifth of Europe's population is malnourished. Forward-looking ideas and project plans are available for the common agricultural policy, the budget and other relevant Community policies - e.g. such is the “smart villages” project. Effective, proactive action by the Commission is now the key to moving forward.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, yes at some point in this debate I had the impression this was turning into Commissioners’ question time rather than the debate on preparing the Commission work programme. But I have to say that my role in this debate is to listen very carefully to you and take note, and that what you have said is then duly reflected in the preparation of our work programme when we come back. I hope for some understanding of the fact that I am not going to go into individual questions which, by the way, sometimes have nothing to do with the Commission work programme. What I see in the contributions of your Members, Madam President, is a great ambition to tackle the huge problems Europe is facing. Migration: very clearly, we are tackling today what is an unacceptable situation in Italy, and European solidarity is warranted. And urgently warranted, because the Italian people have shown an incredible level of humanitarian outreach to people in need, but they cannot be left alone in solving this problem. And that is when Europe needs to act. The same applies to the situation on the Greek islands. It is a lot better than a year or a year and a half ago, but still far from being solved, and we need European approaches to solve those problems. Many Members mentioned the issue of inequalities in Europe. At every level, the crises we have faced over the past couple of years have increased inequalities. And, if I understood this House correctly, fighting these inequalities is something Members see, broadly across this Chamber, as one of the priorities for next year. We are talking not just about inequalities within the Member States and between social groups and because so many people were left behind in the crisis, but also about inequalities between Member States. The whole idea of European integration and the structural funds and all the influence we have is to create convergence between Member States. Ms Morvai, you draw attention to big wage differences between Member States which have a disruptive effect. If you can create economic convergence, wage divergences will decrease. And we need to use the opportunity in the coming years to use the instruments we have already put in place: the digital single market; the energy union – extremely important – perfecting the internal market – still a lot to do – creating a fairer tax system, helping Member States to do that and also making sure that multinationals pay taxes – these are all steps that we need to take in the next couple of years. I fully understand the depth of the challenge, but where I would like to caution you a bit is not to be too gloomy about where we are. Unemployment is decreasing, and sometimes even quite rapidly. There are more jobs in Europe than ever before. Youth unemployment remains too high, but there are also elements of hope. Economic growth is increasing in every single Member State. A year ago, a prominent politician in the country I know best said there would be a patriotic spring in Europe this year. He said this because he thought there would be a wave of ultra-nationalism breaking up our European cooperation and the European Union. What have we seen? Indeed, a patriotic spring! A European patriotic spring, because after the election in the United States the rest of the world is looking to Europe to make sure the Paris Agreement will stand, and to take the lead in making sure the Paris Agreement will stand. After the election in the United States, other parts of the world are looking to Europe to create free and, above all, fair trade agreements so that we maintain the values and economic growth that we stand for. Europeans have come together. European leaders have met in Bratislava and in Rome to say that they want to chart the future of Europe together and not be left alone or think that they can find solutions individually. This is the background against which we will formulate next year’s programme. Yes, the challenges are daunting. Yes, we still have a lot of problems, but things are looking better than a year ago, better than two years ago. We have things to build on, we have opportunities to create a dynamic at the European level that will make Europe the global leader in many of the main issues the world is facing today and tomorrow. I hope we can reflect this in the Commission’s work programme for next year.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: I have received seven motions for resolutions tabled in accordance with Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure.I close the debate.The vote will take place on Wednesday, 5 July 2017.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: in writing. - I would like to highlight two important issues that should be included in the Commission's 2018 Work Program. Firstly, the need to strengthen the funding of Erasmus +. We need at least doubling the budget for this program in order to ensure its effective functioning and to keep it attractive. In this context, I fully support the proposal by some Member States to increase the funding of the program up to tenfold in order to facilitate the participation in it of socially and economically disadvantaged students, staff and students with special needs and people from remote regions. The second issue is the rights of citizens. As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education on Strengthening Citizens' Rights, I urge the Commission to continue its efforts to promote awareness among EU citizens about their rights and to ensure that these rights are uniformly respected across the EU. I also draw attention to the importance of high-quality inclusive education in order to guarantee equal rights for citizens, encourage active citizenship and participate in the democratic life of the EU.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: In written form. - Europe is gradually recovering from the economic crisis. However, European citizens still do not feel a tangible improvement in their standard of living. It is as if politicians remain deaf to their concerns. I expect the European Commission, in its work program for 2018, to propose concrete actions in several key areas. First, an adequate response to high unemployment, and especially youth unemployment, which remains high in a number of Member States, including Bulgaria. I call on the Commission to ensure stable funding for the Youth Employment Initiative by 2020. Secondly, a workable digitalisation strategy is needed that takes into account not only the needs of businesses but also those of citizens. In the EU, 40% of workers do not have digital skills. In Bulgaria only 31% have basic digital skills. I will expect the new Commissioner, Maria Gabriel, to propose concrete measures to develop digital skills so that all European citizens can reap the full benefits of the digital single market. Third, a strong European pillar of social rights. It is time for the Commission to propose legislation to ensure decent working conditions for all. Access to social protection must also be ensured for new forms of employment related to digitalisation.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is the debate on topical and urgent subjects (Rule 153a): EU Defense Plan and the future of Europe (2017/2752 (RSP)).

name: Sabine LÖSING
text: Draftsman, on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! The EU global strategy was adopted about a year ago. It is the prelude to an unprecedented expansion of European military structures. Important interests are an open and fair economic system and access to resources. In order to be literally prepared for this in the future, the EU global strategy calls for the development of top military capabilities at the same time, and this is exactly what is now being massively started. Even if the opposite is constantly being claimed - the vast majority of the population does not want this militarization. What people want is a peaceful, democratic and social European Union - today more than ever. And what are you doing? Exactly the opposite! Some examples: As part of the so-called permanent structured cooperation, important parts of the EU's foreign and security policy are to be placed in the hands of a few countries. How might that affect the EU skepticism that already exists in many countries? As one of the goals of the EU peace project, no country should ever regain supremacy in Europe. Yes, how much do you want to deny reality? The big and richer countries - above all Germany - are telling the others more and more where to go economically and militarily. That's bad, that's dangerous. Next example: The new EU headquarters has existed since June. It is declared to simplify and accelerate military operations in the future. But that is not what the citizens want. In Germany, for example, over 80% of the population want fewer, not more, military operations. Yes, for many, all of the Western military interventions of the past few years are part of the problem, not the solution. You too, Ms. Mogherini, always say: people want security, they want security from the EU. Of course, who doesn't want security? But more Guns and more military do not bring more security. This is mainly about access to raw materials. And by the way: For the majority of people, security also means social security, and unfortunately the EU doesn't have much to offer here, especially not for the people in Southern Europe. That is why most of them do not want to spend more money on armaments in view of the social imbalances - money that is needed much more urgently elsewhere. But no, it will go purposefully in the other direction. For the first time in the next EU budget, an armaments budget - known as the Defense Fund - is to be set up with a total of EUR 38.5 billion, although the EU treaties prohibit expenditure on military policy from being taken from the EU budget. It is in the paragraph on the CSVP. But according to the motto “what does not fit, is made suitable”, the prohibition is to be circumvented, a different chapter is simply taken for armaments money - no longer in the chapter on CSDP, but quickly relocated to the promotion of competition. Well, one can really lose faith in the law. Dear colleagues, once again: the citizens want a democratic, peaceful and social Europe. Act on it at last! Let's finally act accordingly and leave the warpath on which the EU is currently located!

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, as the rapporteur rightly pointed out, work to strengthen the European Union in the security and defence field started with the presentation of the global strategy in the Council exactly one year ago. By the way, this is why, for the first time in two and a half years, I am sitting on this side of the Hemicycle because it is clear in our Treaties and in the work that we have done that the work on EU security and defence lies in the hands of the Council competences. Last year we started on strong, unanimous – still at 28 – and sustained work to respond to the need for security of our citizens. Let me say first of all that security and a European approach to security is a priority for all European citizens. No matter in which country – east, west, north, south – and no matter what kind of political background our citizens have, European defence and security is mentioned as a top priority in all the Eurobarometer surveys that have been conducted in the last year or so.  Second, we realise that we have to make full use of the instruments that the Lisbon Treaty gives to the European Union. This is an issue on which Parliament has always been very strong, demanding the full use of all the instruments we have – I remember very well that in the hearing I had in the Committee on Foreign Affairs at the beginning of my mandate, this was a point that was very strongly made – so it is not something that was started as a reaction to some external factors, or semi—external factors like the British referendum, but there were some accelerating elements or, I would say, factors that intensified the political will to make security and defence in the European Union one of the fields where the Council wants to relaunch the European Union integration process.  This is why in Rome, during the celebrations for the 60th anniversary of our Treaty, this field was clearly indicated as one of the priority fields for the relaunch of the European Union.  Clearly not the only one, and here comes the picture in which we do our work on security and defence, because I want to clarify, first, that our work is not leading to a militarisation of the European Union. This is not leading to a European Union army. If there is anyone in the world that knows the power of soft power, the need to combine different instruments, the need to have an integrated approach in responding to crises and conflicts, in using all different tools from the diplomatic to the humanitarian, development, economic and cultural, it is the European Union.  There is a genuine European way to security and defence. It is made of civilian and military means together, hard and soft power together, cooperation with our partners, and also strategic autonomy. Let me say that, in particular in times such as these, if we want to be able and free to do security in our own European way, we need to strengthen our own capabilities and capacity to act also as a security provider for our citizens, and also for our partners in the world. The European Union not only is, but will stay, the most relevant donor of humanitarian and development aid. That is going to remain. We are going to stay the main pillar of the multilateral system based on the UN agencies and UN values and principles, as well as on the approach that preventing a conflict is always better than dealing with it militarily.  We know very well that there is no single crisis or threat in the world that can be dealt with through a purely military approach. This is the European way to security and I want there to be no doubt about the fact that this approach is not changing. But, at the same time, we can – and we must – do better and more efficiently on defence and security in the narrow sense of the word. I often say that security for us is also development cooperation, climate change action, investment in peacekeeping, and so on. Having said that, we also have a responsibility to use the instruments we have when it comes to security and defence in the narrow sense. As I said, this work has been taken forward in the follow-up to the EU global strategy since last summer. It includes the work done by the Commission – on which Jyrki Katainen and Elżbieta Bieńkowska will share more details with you – and includes work that has been taken forward in full cooperation with NATO in line with the joint declaration signed at the NATO Warsaw Summit last July.  I also want to be very clear on this: the work we are doing to strengthen European defence is also a matter of strengthening NATO and is beneficial for both. Last week I reported with Jens Stoltenberg on the 42 joint actions that the European Union and NATO have taken together as organisations different in nature but both contributing to European security.  Let me also recall that the decision on defence budgets – spending more on defence – is not a matter for the European Union institutions but for national governments and national parliaments. So a debate about how much we should spend is not for here. This is a national competence. The whole two—percent debate is for Member States that are also allied in NATO. It is not for the European Union to tackle this. But, regardless of how much Member States decide to spend, what the European Union can – and must – do is help them spend better and more efficiently, which means spending together.  I always quote two numbers: Europeans invest in defence 50% of what Americans do, but the output of European investments in defence is 15%. So there is an investment gap. This is not for us to tackle. It is a national sovereign choice, but the output gap – how efficient the investment is in output – is something the European Union can help with. So it is not about militarising, but about rationalising. It is about the efficiency of the investments, namely how we can use our resources with economies of scale – that is the point – and also how we can use the instruments for acting together as a Union in the world. I will mention a few concrete steps that either have already been taken or are ongoing with decisions already taken in the Council – either the Foreign Affairs Council or the European Council recently – with the support of the EEAS and the European Defence Agency. You often think that I have two hats, but I actually have three hats because I also have the European Defence Agency and, in this case, the Agency is proving its added value. First, we will enhance the coordination of national defence plans through the new coordinated annual review on defence. A trial run of the review will already be carried out this autumn.  Second, we will launch an inclusive and ambitious permanent structure cooperation (PESCO). This is based on more binding commitments between Member States to jointly develop and deploy military capabilities. A few weeks ago the European Council agreed that a common list of criteria and binding commitments will be drawn up within three months. This should pave the way for notifications to the Council to start the formal process of establishing a permanent structure cooperation and I am confident that this process can be done before the December European Council if Member States are coherent with their commitment to proceed in this way. Third, the Commission – and here I will not enter into the work that has been done with Jyrki Katainen and Elżbieta Bieńkowska – has set up proposals for a European Defence Fund with, by the way, excellent interinstitutional cooperation and coordination that I think is also exemplary for other fields of action. I think that will continue in the months to come. The ideal would be to have PESCO projects financed by the European Defence Fund. Fourth, work has been launched to make the Battlegroups – launched and established exactly ten years ago – fully deployed. We have never deployed them and this will be addressed during the review of the Athena mechanism in the second half of this year. Fifth, we have established the first ever command centre in Brussels for the operational planning and conduct of military training and advisory missions. This capability is already providing support and guidance to our training missions in Mali, Somalia and the Central African Republic and is working closely with our civilian command centre to strengthen the synergies between our missions. Sixth, and finally, we are also working to improve our civilian crisis management to make it more responsive and make sure it has all the capabilities it needs. All six of these measures have either already been taken or are underway with a speed that is quite remarkable – a few months of work – and a unity – all these decisions were taken unanimously at 28 in the Council – and with a great sense of unity and responsibility. Let me add that the work on the future of European defence should not make us underestimate the current work of European defence. We have today men and women in EU uniforms serving under the EU flag, already contributing to the security of our citizens and our own region. Just last month, a Portuguese surgeon who served in our training mission in Mali was killed in the terrorist attack in Bamako.  We should honour the men and women that are serving peace under the EU flag. Our EU men and women are supporting our African partners in their work for peace and security in extremely challenging environments. Our training missions are supporting the local security forces as they fight against terrorism or against criminal networks. This is the European way.  We are a cooperative power and a multilateral power, always believing in an integrated approach, always believing in prevention. We are a force for peace and human development. This is how and what we are, and this is how and what we will continue to be, with more instruments to serve this way of working on security. We are – even more so – a security provider for our citizens and for our partners and this is how we use our military: in the service of peace, in the service of the UN Charter, and in the service of multilateralism.  Developing EU strategic autonomy to do so is even more important today than it was in all the previous decades. A stronger European Union in the field of security and defence is good for Europeans and good for the rest of the world.  (Applause)

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, it is a pleasure to be here to discuss the future of European defence and security. We have had excellent team work in the Commission and with the High Representative/Vice-President, so the Member States and the Commission have worked together in order to identify possible tools to deploy for defending our values.  This discussion here in the European Parliament is as important, because we have to identify the strong political will, in which direction, and how deep we want to go in order to protect our values. Actually the rapporteur said rightly that a peaceful, democratic EU is our peoples’ core value. These are not only core values here in Europe, but they are the same values that we represent outside Europe, and that is why we need the capability to defend our core values both inside Europe and outside Europe. And this is the reason we are talking about the future of security and defence today. The High Representative/Vice President already mentioned a few concrete political issues, like finding solutions to pad up group financing. This would be a significant improvement in our capability to defend our values. Also, a NATO-EU declaration is not only a political declaration, but also a very concrete action plan on how the two organisations can work together in order to get better output, as the High Representative/Vice-President mentioned. I encourage Member States and the European Parliament to be active in developing deeper security and defence cooperation. PESCO offers an excellent opportunity for this, and, generally speaking, our Treaties allow the Member States to do basically whatever they want. One important and necessary opportunity would be to create a European cyber and hybrid defence capability, but everything depends on the political will – the political will of this House, and the political will of the Member States. Let us be clear: it is not the Commission’s power trap. It is a matter of timing and the level of ambition on the Member States’ side. Equally important, NATO will remain a provider of security in Europe that a stronger Europe will reinforce. Our proposals are complementary to NATO. Two weeks ago, the Commission adopted its reflection paper on the future of European defence, a communication on the European Defence Fund and a proposal for a European defence industrial development programme.  With the reflection paper, we have launched a debate on what role the EU will have in the future in this very important area. We have proposed three scenarios, which range from a security and defence cooperation scenario, under which Member States would still decide on the need for security and defence cooperation on a voluntary and case-by-case basis, to a much more ambitious common defence and security scenario, which foresees the progressive framing of a common union defence policy, leading to common defence. While the three scenarios differ in the level of ambition, they all present a step in the same direction: strengthening European defence.  Now we need an honest debate on the kind of future we see for Europe in defence policy. Therefore, the debate today in the European Parliament is very welcome. When looking at the economic side of defence cooperation, we do everything 28 times – or, in the future, 27 times – so the problem is that we duplicate everything so many times that the application problem with NATO is not a relevant problem, because nobody wants to do it. Duplication also has a price tag. The lack of cooperation in defence and security between Member States is estimated to cost annually between EUR 25 billion to EUR 100 billion. This is not an efficient way to use our resources. How should such a large amount of money be used? We must do it efficiently to ensure the best security the taxpayers deserve. For this reason, we have created the European defence fund, which has three different angles.  The first angle is defence research funding. Research organisations can apply together for the funding of collaborative research projects from the EU budget. We want to change the way defence research is done in Europe, pulling together both human and material resources. We have allocated this year EUR 25 million, and with your support we will allocate next year EUR 40 million and EUR 25 million in 2019 – altogether EUR 90 million in three years.  The second angle is support for joint development of capabilities, using the EU budget to incentivise joint development of prototypes. To qualify for support under the European defence industrial development programme, there must be at least three companies from a minimum of two countries which can apply to build joint prototypes, for example in drone or satellite projects. For 2019-2020 we have re-allocated resources from the EU budget worth EUR 500 million for these purposes. Our proposal is that for the next Multiannual financial framework (MFF) period the EU budget funding will be EUR one billion per year. With the support of Member States co—financing the programme, we could generate a total investment of EUR five billion per year. This will be a game changer in terms of strengthening defence research and industrial capabilities, and it makes our public spending more effective. Importantly, the fund is not only for big countries and big projects, but also for small countries and for smaller companies in the defence value chain. We want to make sure that everybody can participate.  Finally, the defence fund is meant to help Member States to do joint acquisitions of capabilities. Instead of buying capability separately, Member States could do it jointly using different types of financial models, and these can range from pooling to debt financing and can help overcome challenges of different budget cycles and reduce the cost for individual Member States. Honourable Members, this is one of the biggest challenges for our future. We have to make sure that we can protect our values inside Europe, but also externally.

name: Michael GAHLER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President! The EPP Group warmly welcomes the new defense package, and I would like to thank Vice-President Katainen, Commissioner Bieńkowska and Mrs Mogherini - with their at least three different hats that she wears in this context. We support this package because it provides the right incentives to support Member States' defense efforts with the procedures we are familiar with in the EU and with EU budgets. In fact, it is not about designing a European army on the drawing board, but rather about significantly increasing the efficiency of our expenditure and, of course, ultimately equipping our soldiers with the most innovative and best material so that they can Contribute to the success of the jointly decided or to be decided CSDP missions. That is why the key words that we hear in this debate today are the key words that we in Parliament have been calling for over and over again for years, at the latest since the beginning of this electoral period, but also with the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty. Thank you very much for the defense action plan, for the reflection paper, for the defense fund and also for the European defense industry support program, which has been mentioned here. These are the measures that, if we put it right, will mean that we will finally make progress on this issue and will therefore also be more attractive defense partners for our American partners.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, our Group also welcomes the defence package and its recently adopted measures, which have to negotiate very carefully the fine line between national responsibility and EU common action. As the EU will act as initiator, facilitator and reinforcer of cooperation and collaboration between the Member States, the latter will remain in control. But as we begin this journey together, I would like to warn against the possible temptation in the future of imposing certain measures, particularly if considered in line with some other measures representing EU reform in general. To my mind, the highest probability for that to happen is in relation to the single defence market, a major component of the future European defence union. Although eliminating the current fragmentation and duplication in the European defence industry – a product of historical evolution – is desirable, politically this should be done better through integration rather than through buying-out, even if accompanied by compensation, as some suggest.  Moreover, a strict buy-European in defence would be politically justified only in the event that the EU increases its corresponding share in the territorial defence of the Member States. Otherwise, as long as NATO, with the US in the lead, remains the main security provider for the EU NATO Member States, the appeal to buy European, leaving aside the important questions relating to availability, price and location of production, would be likely to remain minimal, particularly in the east.  In general, my feeling is that the eastern-flank Member States would favour the development of cooperation between the EU and NATO along the current lines, with each organisation doing what they are best at, rather than, as some suggest, attempting to create and consolidate an EU pillar within NATO. However, let us remember that working to align the strategic cultures of the Member States would alleviate many of these potential barriers.

name: Geoffrey VAN ORDEN
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, listening to Ms Mogherini and Mr Katainen you would imagine we are starting from scratch on defence. We have very fine, capable armed forces right across Europe. We have a well-tried defence alliance, NATO, which binds the United States to European security and in which, with two very minor exceptions, all the EU Member States are fully involved as members. So why does the European Union want to create autonomous defence structures? We all know it is about European political integration. That is what it is about. Listening to Ms Mogherini you would imagine that an EU army has already been created, although everyone denies that they want an EU army. So you need to make up your minds, Commissioners. Do you want it or don’t you want it? What is the latest justification? Well, we used to hear a lot about the comprehensive approach. Interestingly, in this reflection paper on European defence, the words ‘comprehensive approach’ are not mentioned once. Instead we get a new justification and it is all about figures. It is all about the numbers of tanks and aircraft and things being produced across Europe, and invidiously comparing these with the capability of the United States. For example, it says the United States has just one type of main battle tank while the European Union has 17. This, of course, is complete nonsense. Realistically, there are two main battle tanks in Europe – the German Leopard II and the British Challenger II. The same with fighter aircraft: the US has six main types in service, and, according to this, the European Union countries have 20. This is complete nonsense. Basically there are two main fighter aircraft in service in the main European Air Forces – Tornado and Euro Fighter. Some also have the American F-16, of course, and the French went their own way with Rafael and the Mirage 2000 series. These arguments just do not stand up to scrutiny, and why are you doing this, Commissioners? We all know you should come clean: it is all about political integration.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - We in the ALDE Group also support this package of measures that is before us today. And if we want to make Europe future-proof, if we want to convince the citizens of our European project, then we know that we must focus on tackling asylum and migration, on the fight against terror, but especially also on European defense. More than two thirds of our European citizens are right to ask that Europe invest more in European defense! So I welcome the proposals you are making here today. I honestly think we have made more progress in the last two years than in the last 60 years. Defense was a key issue in the creation of the European Union, but we have relied on the Americans for far too long to ensure our security. It is very clear to us liberals: the most ambitious scenario is the only scenario that will help us. The Commission presents three scenarios. For us liberals a real European defense union, and as for me personally, I would very much like to move towards a real European army. That may be a step too far for many, but I believe that if we are to ensure the safety of our citizens, it is the most necessary step. Ms. Mogherini has rightly quoted the figures: 50% of the US defense budget, an output of 15%. There are studies that say that we waste between 26 and 100 billion euros a year by not working together! So please let's do it now. Also NATO's argument, with Trump's statements, with Brexit on its way. If we don't take those steps now, Europe will be doomed. So please, for me and the ALDE Group: very, very quickly, that European Defense Union, with a headquarters, with operations and, as far as I am concerned, with that European army. Then let us assure our citizens that we can ensure their safety.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the new defense plan announces the beginning of the process for the full militarization of the Union. Is this the future you want for Europe? Aren't the wars so far, the foreign interventions, the bloodshed of the peoples and the waves of refugees enough? You are calling for investment in the defense sector, for the strengthening of the military industry and for the development of the Union's military capabilities, so that it can be a stronger partner in the military sector. You are proposing the creation of permanent military structures and a European defense fund, with a budget of € 5.5 billion a year to finance war systems. Really, who is the enemy we must defend ourselves against? Especially when, instead of denouncing the wars and invasive policies of NATO and the US, further cooperation and full cooperation with their policies is announced. Not only will these proposals not benefit the Union, but they will have catastrophic consequences. They will condemn the people to poverty, exile, misery and insecurity. Instead of investing in a new pillar of militarization and proposing an even less social Europe, use the Union's funds for social development and social solidarity. The Union has a duty to take initiatives for full demilitarization, for peace to prevail and for the promotion of social prosperity. What the people need is development policies to boost the real economy, to fight unemployment and poverty - not war funds. Only in this way will we achieve real security for the peoples of Europe.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! This week, the Commission launched no less than three proposals for increased ambitions in the field of defense, and it is not possible to debate the defense union without talking about all three parts of the package, and they are in turn also part of a long-running trend to shift focus from civilian efforts to more military, not least in terms of budget. So we should discuss both the basis for discussion on the future of EU defense, the new Defense Aid Fund for Member States and an investment aid program for the arms industry. The scenarios that the Commission paints in the discussion paper include a proposal to gradually transform the EU into a military alliance. But instead of turning the EU into a NATO 2.0, we want to green that we increase cooperation on the civilian tasks that the Treaty of Lisbon already states that the EU should deal with, such as. crisis preparedness, conflict prevention, mediation and peacekeeping operations. The 28 EU countries have a total of 178 different weapon systems. The USA has 30. We have 17 different tanks, the USA has one. We have 29 different ship models, the United States has 4. We have 20 different fighter jets, the United States has 6, while the United States has twice the budget. The Commission addresses this issue of overcapacity, fragmentation and inefficiency in its documents, and we can only agree with that. If the countries cooperate and coordinate their production better, then everyone is a winner. However, in order to solve the problem, the Commission is proposing that cooperating Member States receive lubricants from EU funds to bring about this cooperation, which has been on the table for several years, but which is not due to a lack of will in the Member States. The EU already spends more than 200 billion euros on defense every year - most in the world after the United States. The problem is not that there is a lack of money, but what operational capability we get for them, and we think it is the wrong way to go with a militarization of the EU budget because the money tend to be taken from civilian spending areas such as aid or humanitarian peacekeeping operations.This case will also involve reduced budgets for the European Investment Bank, the Strategic Investment Fund, SME programs, regional development, Erasmus +, Copernicus and others.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: As I take my seat in this rostrum, I would like to remind you that we are in a topical debate and that, according to the rules, this does not involve any intervention on demand or a blue card.Here, I take the liberty of reminding a certain number of colleagues who signal to me for blue cards.

name: Bill ETHERIDGE
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, I think that after this I am going to have to report to the doctor because I think I am having a hallucination. I must be having a fantasy because I am sure I saw Ms Mogherini saying that there was going to be EU defence spending and EU armed forces and battle groups. Now, during the referendum campaign in the UK the Remain side told us this was fantasy. No such thing! It couldn’t possibly be true. They couldn’t have been lying, so I must be dreaming you Ms Mogherini. It is quite a bizarre dream I am having. The reality is: this money that is being squandered on this crazy political project, which will make no difference to anybody except losing money from the taxpayers, should be within the nation states, and they should be spending it on the one thing that actually does keep our nation safe – that is NATO. I suggest that each and every one of these nation states gets up to their 2% minimum spending, or maybe a bit more to make up for all the money that they have not put in over the years, and we will have a really serious defence plan through NATO, rather than this political fantasy.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, these Europeanists are formidable: this morning they praised and moved us with their words in memory of Simone Veil, a formidable pacifist. A few hours pass and they have all become warmongers: they want the European army, they give us justifications that with great education I define laughable, they speak of great savings by entrusting Europe with control of European defense spending. Well, let's think about how Europe has managed the economy, the currency, the euro… and then one really thinks we're joking. There are many problems left open, for example the role of member countries with NATO, the role of national armies itself, which will be subjected to a double command. Nothing clear is said about it and clearly they want to hide the real motivations, because we cannot think that there are no motivations. Perhaps you are afraid of the revival of patriotisms? Perhaps you are afraid that individual countries will recover or hope, try to regain the levers of their own sovereignty, which is so important, which belongs to our tradition. Being pro-European - and I think I am a pro-European - does not mean denying, putting in the cellar the sense of national belonging, the pride of belonging to one's own homeland. Of course, there is also a larger European homeland, but we cannot allow such mockery of our people. You say that all Europeans, in your polls, want this European defense. But why has no parliament asked for it? National parliaments have never asked for anything of this kind, you know very well. It is yet another scam.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Madam President, here we are talking about setting up a common EU army for the future of Europe. Although first, in the light of Brexit, a much more important question should be clarified: where to go next, European Union? Towards ever closer cooperation, towards a superstate, or towards looser cooperation that respects sovereignty? There are those here in the majority who support the first version and see themselves as pro-European and those who want looser cooperation as anti-European. But let’s see how the public makes a statement about this. Only 26% in Germany are in favor of ever closer European cooperation, and 43% would return competences to the Member State from Brussels. In Hungary this ratio is 17% and 40%, in Poland only 9% support ever closer cooperation. I ask: then, in this Parliament, which is proud to represent the people, who is right? Who is on the side of the people? Who represents what the majority wants?

name: Arnaud DANJEAN
text: - Madam President, we can only congratulate ourselves that the European institutions, including the Commission, are finally in line with the wish of our European fellow citizens to devote a major effort to security and defense. Indeed, contrary to what some colleagues say, all the opinion polls over the past ten years have shown, in all countries, including the most eurosceptics, that in the forefront of the concerns of our fellow citizens, areas where they expect that the European Union is doing better and doing more, there is security, defense and diplomacy. Thank you, Madam High Representative, for your persistence. We can only rejoice at the announcements that have been made and the efforts that are being made. I would just like to warn against two aspects, one for the Commission and the other for the Council. For the Commission, of course, ensuring competitiveness and avoiding duplication is important. The economic dimension of the defense effort is very important, but we are not talking about a market like any other. It’s not all about competitiveness. We talk about strategy, we talk about strategic autonomy, we talk about critical capacity and we talk about operations. Consequently, we must have materials which are, of course, competitive, but we must have materials which are effective to protect our forces and to protect our fellow citizens. Then, addressed to the Council, and to the Commission as well, moreover, I can clearly see that the announcements made are very focused on the capability aspect. It is very commendable, useful and important. However, I would like us not to forget the operational aspect. It is very important to know that, as you recalled, Madam High Representative, many of our forces are serving under the European flag in missions which need help, financial aid as well, and I would be very helpful to you. grateful to urge Member States to finally reform the Athena mechanism to better share the burden and express true European solidarity.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: - European defense is probably one of the most important projects we need to invest in in the coming period, but it is one of the most important factors for the political consolidation of the European Union if it is carefully managed and really responds to the direct and daily needs of citizens. Europeans. Despite some hesitation in this room, most of us can agree on the first steps we need to take: using the full potential of the Union, civilian and military capabilities, using all the tools at our disposal, creating the Fund European Defense Fund, primarily for research and development, the development and strengthening of PESCO's permanent structured cooperation, which is ambitious and open to all Member States with European funding. Last but not least, and I insist on this, guaranteeing and strengthening cooperation and complementarity, not competition with NATO. If we look at our regions, the East, the Middle East are regions of great insecurity and instability and Europe must draw its own conclusion between soft power and hard power. The only chance for the Union to be globally relevant is to strengthen its own defense capacity.

name: Anna FOTYGA
text: – Madam President, within the Common Security and Defence Policy (CSDP) the majority of competences still belong to the Council, and therefore I would like to mention and emphasise the importance of the common perception of threats while discussing CSDP, and this common perception is still lacking within the EU. Do we honestly foresee the deployment of real CSDP missions in our eastern neighbourhood, thus challenging the ambitions of the Russian Federation in this area? Do we assess, for example, the energy security situation that deteriorates the position of these countries? There are many aspects of security, and we have to take these into account as well.

name: Urmas PAET
text: – Madam President, we are in a unique situation today where we have the support of the people and of governments to do more on the defence and security of the European Union. We need to take advantage of this and make things happen. The latest steps taken by the Commission and the Council in launching the Defence Fund and establishing a command centre in Brussels are good and encouraging, and we need to continue. Let me just remind you that the European Parliament adopted a report on the European Defence Union last November and there are still many things, 20 to be precise, on the list in the report that need to be ticked off in order to reach the goal of a truly functional defence policy. We need better coordination of investments in the areas of security and defence, full use of fiscal and crisis-management capacities, to name but a few. I am glad to see that the EU is moving from ideological discussions about the Union’s defence to real, concrete action.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: - Madam President! There are many citizens who are disappointed with the EU because it is too big a marketplace for big business, because it does not succeed in upholding the rule of law, because it has allowed social dumping, but I have not met a single voter who asks that the EU needs more military capability. Not a single one. So where does this awful idea of ​​militarizing the EU come from? It's reckless. I think a lot of the ideas come from the security and military industries, of course. But why do you open the door for them? Why do you open the door for them? I think that when you get the idea that the EU must be its own master and if you are, MAN should be, then you must have your own cannons and buffers. It is patriarchal and it is one-dimensional. This is a lot of money, money that for 10 years could finance all women's contraceptive needs in the world. You are so ashamed that we have to put them on cannons and buffers that the citizens have not asked for. If the EU is to be a peace project, it must contribute to disarmament, not rearmament. We must ensure that European arms exports are reduced, not increased, and that all our foreign policy energy must be spent on diplomacy, human rights, the development of democracy and sustainable development. Citizens want care, school, care, welfare, democracy development and a planet to live on. They do not want more cannons.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: – Madam President, there is much to be supported in this defence package. I am not going to go through all the details but we are able to support many elements of the three different scenarios worked out in the package. I would just like to highlight one missing element and the crucial question around it: the missing element is the capability requirement in the different scenarios. That is important, because that will define four structures. Somebody should do the planning for four structures, and it would be better if those who do this planning were answerable to somebody, possibly a parliamentary body, at the same time. Put simply, we should not let R&D and procurement be driven by the needs of the defence industry. They should be driven by the strategic needs of the European Union.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, common European defense: cui prodest? If it were only to cut waste, fill technological gaps, exploit economies of scale and have a more transparent defense market, I would certainly say to European citizens. And we would sit at the table with keen interest. But, given the precedents, more than one suspicion hangs in the air. And I ask you: when the centrality of mutual assistance and solidarity is emphasized in the reflection document, what solidarity are we talking about? That of the self-styled pro-European champion Macron, who denies access to French ports and brings migrants back to Ventimiglia? That of Juncker, which is limited to a pat on the back of my country, calling it heroic? Or perhaps the solidarity of Angela Merkel's Germany which, on the strength of its frightening trade surplus, in defiance of the rules, crushes the economies of other member states, thanks to a currency, the euro, tailored to its needs? The occasion appears tempting for Berlin, and is military, geopolitical and industrial. The instability at the borders and the unpredictability of the Trump-branded US are the perfect alibi to justify a massive rearmament of a country that if it really spent 2% of GDP on defense, in a few years it would become the third military power in the world. We ask for caution and also for clarity, because as usual, instead of having a European Germany, we would end up with a German Europe, even in defense.

name: Jean-Luc SCHAFFHAUSER
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, what a missed opportunity! A Europe of security and defense would make sense if we put our common interests at the service of the fight against terrorism, security and development. Let me take the G5 Sahel of July 2 as an example: a real security plan, without the development component, is estimated at 500 million. Europe is committed to the tune of 50 million and without a timetable; Chad, Mali, Niger, Mauritania and Burkina Faso are quite unable to fill this gap. This means, for Europe, more immigrant trafficking linked to organized crime and the drug route. Defense Europe is an illusion. For some - the Baltic States and Poland - it is a question of fighting against Russia, which is nevertheless a partner for peace and the fight against terrorism. For others, it means paying for bondage to NATO and the United States, as in the past with the Warsaw Pact. For still others, it is off-shelf rationalization to destroy our entire European industrial base, or rather what little we have left. Europe has but one word, the abandonment of national sovereignty for servitude, with incompetence and inefficiency on top.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Madam President! We start talks about the Union's armed forces at a dangerous moment. In Europe, fascism is looking up, for example, a few days ago the Bundestag passed a law threatening a fine of 50 million euro for posting untrue content online - even Adolf Hitler did not apply such high fines. I would like to remind you that a few days ago I did not manage to find out from Commissioner Mary Gabriel who would determine what content is untrue, and in the times of the Polish People's Republic I was imprisoned for several years for spreading false information that could seriously harm the interests of the Polish People's Republic. The armed forces of the Union will have no military significance. Srebrenica was a perfect example of their value. France alone has 300 nuclear warheads, compared with 7,000 in Russia and the same in the US. It is obvious to me that these forces are created only to provide so-called fraternal help to a country that would rebel against the occupation of the European Union. Besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: – Madam President, this is indeed a point of order. Mr Korwin-Mikke accused the Bundestag of fascism. I think you should check the protocol, the minutes, and you should censor him for that remark.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I remind the audience that they are not allowed to speak either.Mr Bütikofer, we will indeed do what is necessary to listen to this intervention again, as painful as it may be.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Madam President, the primary purpose of European integration was to defend peace. It is precisely for peace and security that the emancipation of European defense is necessary. I therefore welcome the proposals presented by the Commission in early June. Of the three paths outlined in this discussion paper on the future of common defense, I am clearly in favor of the third option. This is the path to common defense in maximum coordination with NATO. What I am missing in the text is the clear naming of security threats. Calling threats by their real names is necessary and healthy. Russia's aggression is not the only reason for building a common European defense, but the clear name of this security threat should be heard. Sometimes I feel that the Commission does not have the courage to name Russian threats by their real names. I unequivocally welcome the creation of the European Defense Fund. This should help to eliminate duplication and a high degree of fragmentation. After all, there are only 17 different types of battle tanks in the EU countries. Last week, the Chairman of the NATO Military Committee, General Petr Pavel, defined the identity of European defense as a healthy process. NATO and the EU do not compete in the defense process, they complement each other. The process of this cooperation will not be cheap, we should ask how much one kilogram of peace costs. Peace is an expensive commodity. Security is not free.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! Let me immediately settle two rumors that have arisen here. Nowhere, dear colleague, does any of these papers say anything about 2%. Do not spread such rumors! This is a completely different discussion between other partners. And secondly, it is expressly not a question of carrying out more military operations instead of civil ones. We're not suddenly drunk with guns! It is about providing more efficient, if necessary also military, support for civil, peacekeeping and peacekeeping measures. That is what it is primarily about: more efficiency and more contemporary material, not more military armament. And let me say: We Social Democrats are heading in the right direction and that is why we support you. But that does not mean that we do not have a lot to discuss, for example the question of what rights this Parliament actually has, other than saying to you: 'You did well.' And secondly: where does the money for the fund come from ? You know that is a hobby of mine: if you order more, you have to pay more. This also applies to the European Parliament.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: – Madam President, stretched defence budgets in Europe and an isolationist President Trump in America, who is ambivalent about NATO, and soaring populations across some of the poorest parts of the world without jobs to match, have led to political instability in many countries ,whilst a rising China and an assertive Russia are unwinding the post-1991 international consensus. Therefore, moves towards a European defence fund, a European defence industrial development programme, in addition to exploring the viability of permanent structured cooperation and the funding of EU battle groups via the Athena mechanism are all interesting developments in this direction. These are sensible measures aimed at improving European collective security, and strengthening the role of the EU Member States that they can play together in association and within NATO. I am pleased that the UK Government has announced it will not be making any moves to block these plans as an exciting EU Member State. And I hope that as Brexit negotiations progress, creative ways will be found for the UK to stay as plugged-in as possible into the common foreign and security policy and the common security and defence policy.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: - (FI) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen of the Commission, the greatest threats of our time are not military, but threats threatened by our own actions, such as climate change, famine, lack of drinking water, communicable diseases, poverty and inequality. Europe is responding to these threats with the Defense Fund and the development of the Defense Union, although the official consensus so far has always been that EU budget funds are not used for defense purposes. In my opinion, the development of cooperation between authorities, adequate resources, greater cooperation in civilian crisis management and development cooperation, and the elimination of inequalities between people would be more in line with the needs of this era. If Europe were to direct funds earmarked for the defense industry directly to the civilian sectors and put all our prestige at stake to stop growing European and global inequality, and instead replace international armaments, we would begin to defuse tensions, resolve ongoing conflicts and demand international disarmament again. Returning to the roots of European peace is, in my view, a wiser solution for nations than a constant increase in tensions in the spirit of increasing equipment.

name: Reinhard BÜTIKOFER
text: - Madam President! Mr Danjean was right, Madam President. Our citizens want Europe to do more for defense. I don't have the time to enumerate what seems to me to be absolutely right about this defense package - Mr Tannock mentioned a few things. But I want to mention a few points of criticism. First, we don't have an investment gap, we have a huge crater of inefficiency. We don't just duplicate, we triplicate and quadruple, and that doesn't make sense! The first would be to apply the 2009 procurement guideline consistently before you want to spend more money. Second: At a time when Mr Oettinger is discussing whether we are missing 12 billion or 20 billion in the European budget, it makes no sense to say that we are now spending additional money on defense from practically all funds that can be found ! Third: In the third scenario, conceiving the EU as a kind of second NATO is completely absurd. Second NATO without the USA would either mean that the idea of ​​strategic autonomy is a dangerous self-deception, or one has to consistently resort to the European atomic bomb. And fourthly: I find it completely unbearable that the idea about the governance of these expenditures also includes provision for industry to be allowed to operate self-service, because it should have a say in what money is spent on armaments.

name: Janice ATKINSON
text: – Madam President, another new shiny building, stuffed full of six-figure salary functions. Ms Mogherini, where is your army coming from? All military personnel joined their forces to serve their nation-state, not the EU. Will you recruit from the millions of unemployed young people the EU has created? Perhaps it is your idea of a job-creation scheme. You oppose the nation-states erecting external borders, but you cannot control the millions of marauding migrants invading our continent. Yet you propose this military force. It’s just grandstanding. The EU shouldn’t be allowed to lead a group of boy scouts, let alone army tanks.  The enemy is ISIS. What are you doing to tackle this? Instead of an EU army we should be lifting Russian sanctions and working with them and the US to defeat ISIS. Ms Mogherini, this is a very dangerous proposal, led by you, a low-grade socialist, promoted beyond your capabilities.

name: Steven WOOLFE
text: – Madam President, René Magritte, the famous Belgian surrealist painter, used to paint pictures of pipes, and he would then say ‘this is not a pipe’. The EU has actually copied Magritte. Firstly, they said that the EU created peace in Europe, when in fact it was NATO. And secondly, they say they don’t want an EU army – in fact, what they want is a European Security and Defence Force, when everybody can see that what you want is an EU army. The European Rapid Operational Force (Eurofor) had 12 000 personnel: the size of an armed division. EU money for extra drones and the military industrial complex will get tax deductions under proposals from this Chamber. And of course, as I see today, more and more MEPs want to have war with Russia – the new bogeyman. The idea that we have to have an army, so therefore we must have an enemy. The EU is attempting to create a new world order with a new EU army. This is what Magritte would have called surreal.

name: Arne LIETZ
text: - Madam President, High Representative! The SPD has long been an advocate of the pooling and sharing approach. The ultimate goal must be to Europeanise national defense capacities in order to use the defense budget more efficiently and to save costs. I think it makes sense to Europeanise armaments policy, as it helps the NATO member states of the EU to move away from NATO's absurd 2% target. Instead, we must focus on improving the defense capabilities we need together. The Commission proposal envisages making several billion euros available from the EU budget for arms research, development and procurement. However, the rights to the technologies and products financed in this way will not be transferred to the European Union. That can not be! Contrary to the wording of the Commission proposal, I am calling for real participation by the EU and especially the European Parliament in the export of arms and ammunition that have been financed with EU funds. In addition, the Commission should supplement the defense plan with a program for the conversion of armaments industries into civil industries, if we want to make a change here.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: - Madam President! The tragedy is that, in connection with Brexit, there has now been talk again of a European defense. I am glad that my own country, Denmark, has a reservation in this area. However, it is incomprehensible to me why major NATO countries such as Italy, France, Spain and Germany insist on a new European defense initiative when the same major European countries repeatedly fail in their NATO commitments, including their commitments to deliver two percent of GDP for the common defense, but also the many NATO missions and other missions associated with NATO co-operation that one does not want to participate in, or participate in proportionately less than smaller countries. Our position on this issue is quite clear: NATO is the cornerstone of European defense. The United States is a prerequisite for a common European defense, and I will be happy about the security guarantees of the United Kingdom and the United States, to a much greater extent than I will be happy about French and German security guarantees in defense policy.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank the High Representative for the extensive work carried out in recent months on the common security and defense policy. Much progress has been made since the last debate in November. In fact, in less than a year, the common European defense is no longer a federalist dream, but is really starting to be a reality. I mention only two of the many actions undertaken: the launch of the European Defense Fund by the Commission, which will have research as one of its fundamental areas, with an important impact also for the Member States, and the agreement, by part of the June Council, to launch an ambitious permanent structured cooperation, with concrete indications of the times and methods of accession by the Member States that intend to participate. A historic event that will make it possible to make greater use of the provisions of the treaties which have not been used so far. Parliament will follow this crucial phase with great interest together with the national parliaments. He will have to be involved and informed, and we expect a clear commitment on this. These steps forward will allow the Union to save money, avoid waste and generate investments and to assume full strategic autonomy, albeit in full cooperation and complementarity with NATO, in an increasingly unstable global context.

name: Roberts ZĪLE
text: - Madam President, Madam Vice-President! The European Defense Plan has two obvious financial features: one is to give money from the European Union budget for military research and development, and the other is to order a Member State's military orders only from European Union military industry companies. In my opinion, this is a more regional regional policy instrument, because if we look at it, only a few countries in the European Union have a serious military industry, and it will become even less after Britain leaves. Mr Juncker often likes to say that we need to reduce the number of tank models from seventeen to one, as is the case in the United States. Then, however, I would like to say that we need both tank models that can work well in desert operations in sub-Saharan Africa and those that work in swamps on the Russian border. The United States has invested heavily in resources for many years and has gone much, much further than Europe in terms of military technology. And for countries bordering Russia, it is important to get this best technology in the military now, not ten years from now, when we will probably catch the United States.

name: Eva KAILI
