text: Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, the current situation of a Trump, the new US President, an Erdoğan, a NATO ally, but also of Brexit, which removes great defense potential from the European Union, as well as new challenges of demographics in our neighboring countries and -of course- immigration, are challenges for the European Union that force us to make leaps and bounds and to make our common defense policy a priority. This is extremely important, not only because we need to secure our internal and external borders, but also because we will have a very large reduction in defense spending, at least by 30%, not only through cooperation between Member States and cooperation at the level of research and exchange of know-how, but also from the exchange of information required. Our enemies no longer know borders and the new challenges are cyber attacks and cyber defense, and it is necessary to exchange information. But in order for it to be equally equal and beneficial for the Member States, in order to increase spending, budget and participation, we must be prepared to talk about border integrity in all Member States, regardless of the source of the threat.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Madam President! If freedom is valued, there is only one answer to the aspirations of the European Union authorities to take control of the defense of our countries: power is not increased by those who exercise it irresponsibly. Because it is really about power, as Geoffrey Van Orden put it very well, it is about political integration, that is, taking power of states, and it is not about defense, because President Mogherini has said very frankly that our goal is not militarization. We saw the attitude of the European Union leadership to our security during the immigration crisis, and the test of defense solidarity is simply to respect the security of other European countries and to respond to their position. So it is enough to look at the construction of Nord Stream2 to see what the fictional sanctions against Russia were like, which were supposed to protect us, and to see the whole absurdity of the concept of common European defense, i.e. taking control over the security of our countries.

name: Ana GOMES
text: - Madam President, I pay tribute to the Portuguese sergeant Paiva Benido, who lost his life in a terrorist attack on a European Union mission in Bamako, with Vice President Mogherini. In Portugal, last week, there was a serious theft of military material that can be used for terrorist purposes - not only, but also due to a lack of investment in security and defense in a country where the State was disarmed in all dimensions by neoliberal policies. of austerity. This is one of the reasons why we absolutely need a European defense plan and to invest in a Europe of security and defense, with strategic autonomy to act for our citizens, for international law, for peace, for the responsibility to protect and for the resolution of conflicts globally, within the European framework, NATO, the UN and other partnerships. To do this, we need a solid industrial defense base, with cooperation and pulling and sharing of resources between Member States and European investment in research and technology. To this end, the European Defense Fund has to be injected with contributions, without overburdening the European budget. We also absolutely need to strengthen democratic control, including so that our Member States do not continue to stupidly spend taxpayers' money on duplication, overlap and waste. Above all, we need more than President Trump to unite; we need a European vision and strategic direction, which articulates foreign policy, security and defense, internal security. Syria and Libya are there to demonstrate the Defense Europe that we need and that we don't have so far.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: - Madam President! One of the many problems in the Commission's proposals is the reversal of the hierarchy of threats. Russia and attempts to destabilize key EU countries are currently the biggest threats to the security of the whole of Europe. However, the Commission's plans seem to suggest that it wants to compete in the arms industry with the United States. And this is the second main goal, next to that of Geoffrey Van Orden, of this political goal - to strengthen European integration. The Commission wants to focus on financing research into new arms systems that may be important for the security of Europe in a dozen or so years, and this in the event of a conflict with a strategic dimension. Meanwhile, in my opinion, the Commission should concentrate rather on doing everything it pledged in the joint EU-NATO declaration signed in Warsaw, for example on carrying out exercises on hybrid threats - they were planned together with NATO for the current year. It should also focus on fulfilling the decisions of the European Council of June this year, for example on increasing the co-financing of the final deployment of battlegroups.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - The Union's commitment to defense and security is vital at this time and has always been.At the same time, we must not in any way undermine the development of the defense industry in every Member State.On the contrary, we need to increase investment.NATO and the European Union must work together.We are not enemies.We must invest and work together to defend Europe and the world, as we have always done.I welcome the launch of the European Defense Fund, but before any plan for a joint army is the increased exchange of information between intelligence agencies.An increased exchange can save lives today.I know that intelligence agencies are reluctant to exchange information with all services in the Member States.It is a matter of trust, it does not exist in everything, but it is vital that the volume and quality of this exchange of information increase.

name: Mirosław PIOTROWSKI
text: - Madam President! From time to time, ideas of creating a European army emerge with varying intensity. It must be clearly stated that building a separate EU army alongside NATO would be detrimental to the North Atlantic Treaty. As Jens Stoltenberg, the head of NATO, recalled recently in the European Parliament, currently 90% of EU citizens are citizens of NATO member states, hence there is no need to build a separate army. It is likely that this initiative will be put to an end by the departure of the UK from the European Union, which - as the President of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker recently admitted - has a real army, while others have ambitions. These ambitions, however, must not lead to the dismantling of NATO. The North Atlantic Pact must be strengthened. As US President Donald Trump recently recalled, the real guarantee of the security of the European Union countries is the fulfillment of obligations towards NATO, that is, allocating 2% of the Member States' GDP to defense. Consolidation of the defense systems of individual countries within NATO should also be considered.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the honourable Members for this discussion. As you have probably observed during the last few months, defence policy has become very high on the political agenda, and such discussions are very much needed and welcomed. I am sure that defence will be a cornerstone of the future of Europe.  In the Commission, we made very decisive and concrete steps towards a Union that is secure and protects, as Federica Mogherini mentioned before: this is very high on our citizens’ agenda. Citizens want a Europe that protects and that is secure. We moved decisively with the defence package. Of course, the reflection paper launched a much wider and forward-looking debate, and the European defence fund encourages Member States to cooperate on defence research, development and acquisitions.  It was never clearer that Europe must become a security provider and to ensure progressively its own security, because currently no Member State is strong enough to meet on their own the evolving threats and challenges we are facing. So this is definitely – and I want to underline this – not about militarisation. This is definitely not about grabbing any power from the Member States. This is about securing and ensuring Europe’s strategic autonomy, and for this we need a very competitive European defence industrial base, a European defence industrial sector, and with the European defence fund this is what we aim to achieve. This is the industrial pillar of our action; this is the one we are moving together quite fast. The defence fund will support the whole capability development life cycle, as we mentioned before – as Jyrki Katainen mentioned – from research through prototype development to joint procurement and acquisition, which is very important for us.  The Commission is for the first time making all its efforts, using all its tools – including the EU budget – to support and promote stronger defence cooperation, especially on the industrial front. This is important, both from a strategic perspective and from an economic perspective. A few more details: a single market in defence is not in contradiction with the European defence fund. On the contrary, with the European defence fund we want to open the defence supply chain cross-border. There is a very high need to build trust at the level of industrial cooperation, and through the EDF I hope – and I am sure – we will do that. I also want to underline the importance of the procurement and transfer directive, and I want to commit to doing my best to execute both of them. On one more thing – maybe a little too detailed, but I think it is important to answer the question – we have taken the specificities of defence in building the European defence industrial plan. We are fully aware of those specificities. That is why, as I said, it is not about grabbing power. The Member States will stay in the lead; they will decide on the priorities, on the capabilities, and finally on the projects, so this is not the role of the European Commission. Everything will be owned by the Member States, and the Member States only.  Thank you very much for your cooperation; I am looking forward to our future discussions, and I also count on your support during our work on the adoption of the whole plan.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, let me start by picking up on something that some of you mentioned during the debate. The European Union is not a military alliance. It is not meant to become a military alliance, and that is why the work we are doing, in parallel to strengthen European defence and to strengthen EU-NATO cooperation, is working so well. I do not know where one of the speakers got the information that NATO and the NATO Secretary-General are not supportive of this process because the Secretary-General has repeatedly, publicly and privately, stressed the fact that strengthening European defence also strengthens the Transatlantic Alliance. I am ready and, as always, willing to discuss different political views, but at least starting from the facts and the actual objectives that we have in reality. Let me clarify this too: there is a cost for the European Union not working together on defence, and what the Commission is doing in relation to the industrial base is a clear demonstration of that. The fragmentation of investment has a cost for the budget – for the taxpayers’ money that we often refer to. It is not the case that we are investing more on defence, because you might have noticed that Member States – as I see every day in dealing with Defence Ministers, Prime Ministers and Foreign Ministers –have their own national defence budgets. They have their own investments; they have their own capabilities. We are not working to increase that. We are working to make that spending and investment more efficient by making investments together among Member States, with the support of all the EU institutions. Also, Member States own one single set of forces and they are perfectly capable of deciding whether to use their forces in EU missions and operations, in UN missions, in NATO missions or in their own bilateral or multilateral initiatives. Investing in strengthening cooperation among Member States on defence makes it possible for Member States, which in some cases are also NATO allies (there are five Member States that are not NATO allies), free to make their own strategic choices. We are not building a European army. I understand that, for political reasons, or propaganda reasons, some of you want to continue to refer to this, but this is not the reality of the facts. We do have headquarters of our military and civilian missions and operations and, by the way, I would like to remind our friends in the UK that one of our headquarters is currently in the UK. It is the headquarters of the European Union’s Operation Atalanta. After the UK leaves we will probably have to move the headquarters somewhere else. But we do have EU mission and operation headquarters currently working to support ongoing EU operations and missions. What is the reality here? It is that we need to make the system of command and planning of the existing operations and missions more effective because having a fragmented system of headquarters – as anyone who deals with military issues a little bit knows and understands – is not necessarily the most effective way of managing a military operation. So this is not about building a big headquarters. It is not about creating a headquarters of the same kind as the Supreme Headquarters Allied Powers Europe (SHAPE): it is about rationalising the existing headquarters that we have spread around everywhere, including in the UK. By the way, I would like to stress that all the decisions we have taken so far, the ones that have been already implemented and the ones that have yet to be implemented but are on the way, have been decided unanimously by all the 28 Member States, with the UK fully involved, sitting at the table of the Council that I chair and fully participating in the decision making. And I am very happy about that. Some of you mentioned, I think, that this can be one of the fields in which future cooperation with the future third-party UK might be explored. Another point: what are our militaries doing? I would like to clarify this because our militaries are not making war. Our militaries are supporting peace. This is the European Union way to security, and I would like us to be very clear about that, because it is also a way of honouring our men and women serving under the EU flag. They are there for us. Just as national parliaments are responsible for the national participation of men and women in uniform in military missions or civilian operations, we as European institutions have the responsibility to recognise and honour the work that men and women in uniform are doing serving the EU around the world. I believe we need a reality check here. Our militaries are saving people in the Mediterranean Sea. Our militaries are training and supporting African security forces in trying to implement agreements or carrying out peacekeeping. This is the kind of work that our EU militaries are doing. I would ask some of the honourable Members, please, to refer to the reality of the facts and not to ideas they want to use for a political purpose, because this is where the roots of so many European problems lie. We have to start from the reality of the work we are doing. Last, but not least, two small points. One of you referred, and rightly so, to the need for all our work on defence to start from the security needs we have assessed. That is perfectly correct: it is exactly what we are doing. That is why the sequence of our work began with an assessment of the security environment. That was done last year. Then came the presentation of the global strategy identifying the strategic priorities for our foreign policy and security policy, including in the defence sector. Only after having shared a common level of ambition, which was achieved in November, are we now strengthening our approach to capabilities and the industrial base. So the sequence is clearly this: we start from the security needs and then we develop the instruments we need to fulfil this level of ambition. A last point on financial resources. If we, the Commission, Council and Parliament, set a target for our level of ambition, a target for what we want to do on security and defence at European Union level, then – and I see Commissioner Oettinger here in the room, so it is an appropriate time to say this – we also have to define how we finance the level of ambition we set ourselves. This will be part of a necessary further discussion in the future.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I support the new defense package presented by the Commission.We must consistently implement the goals of our common foreign and security policy that have already been agreed.The proposed measures will help to increase the efficiency of each Member State's spending and strengthen the EU's role as a strategic player in foreign and security policy in the world.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - European monopolies and the powers that defend their interests, that colonized markets from the center to the peripheries of the EU, in successive enlargements, and that launch themselves out into the world with their well-known and natural avidity, need a state ready to defend their interests, its imperialist drive, its rate of profit. For that, they count on the great national powers (their “home” states), but, more than that, on the “European superstate” - the EU. In the confrontation on a global scale by the dispute over markets, raw materials and areas of influence, the EU powers do not do without an interventionist and militarized EU, at their service. The European Commission's “reflection paper” on “the future of European defense” points the way: boosting the military, armaments and defense industry, and integrating them at EU level; more cooperation in the fields of research and development in the area of ​​defense, the development of new weapons and external civil or military operations; the close articulation with NATO. The path that the EU symbolizes and defends for Europe is a danger, a huge threat to the future of the continent and its people.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: In written form. - Over the last few years, we have watched with concern as the atmosphere of security and stability in Europe is constantly deteriorating. The civil war in Ukraine, the incessant terrorist attacks on civilians in Europe, the declining trust and cooperation between the countries of the continent are creating an atmosphere of unpredictability and tension, which could lead to escalation and new waves of violence. In this regard, I believe that the EU must do everything possible to deepen security and defense cooperation between Member States. The Union must guarantee the future and peace of mind of all European citizens, and this can only happen by increasing investment in the development of defense equipment and strengthening the single security market. Last but not least, I would like to emphasize that security in Europe depends on partnership with NATO. The creation of a common European army, in full cohesion with NATO, will create a direct link between the EU and NATO and guarantee peace and stability in Europe.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: in writing. - The EU, as a union of European monopolies, is moving in the direction of competition with Russia and China, but also with the USA, for the sources of wealth and the control of the markets. Juncker's statement that "war is not a thing of the past" reflects the direction of EU policy against peoples. All this is reflected in the formation of the European Defense Union and the relevant Fund, the Euromilitary, the Headquarters, the Coast Guard and, more generally, the further militarization of the EU and its joint action with NATO. The Greek government gives "land and water" for the promotion of imperialist plans, takes excellent performance in spending for the needs of the Euro-Atlantic mechanisms and involves our people in great dangers. It is in the people's interest to intensify their struggle against the EU and NATO, against imperialist wars and interventions, and to demand that there be no involvement of their countries, no military missions abroad, and the closure of Euro-Atlantic bases.

name: Julia PITERA
text: in writing. - The Directive on the protection of the EU's financial interests will allow the introduction into EU law of a common definition of crimes affecting the EU's financial interests. The directive is also related to the establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office. Its tasks will include on conducting preparatory proceedings, bringing charges and bringing perpetrators of financial crimes to trial. This will help to overcome the deadlock between OLAF and Member States that do not always follow its recommendations. However, it should be remembered that citizens may treat the European Public Prosecutor's Office as an institution interfering in the internal affairs of the Member States, and not as an institution protecting the financial interests of the Union. The Polish government justifies its lack of acceptance for this project as a threat to the independence of the Polish prosecutor's office. That is why it is so important to clarify that the purpose of establishing a European Public Prosecutor's Office is to protect European taxpayers' money spent by member states.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - The document for reflection on European defense published by the European Commission coincides in time not only with a series of similar documents on the future of the EU. It also coincides with a series of specific actions by the European Commission, under the authority of the Member States, to make the Common Security and Defense Policy no longer just in name. All the proposed scenarios assume some progress in defense cooperation. As the authors of the document themselves note, the three visions of the future differ primarily in the depth of cooperation, not its individual elements. It is happy to emphasize the role of NATO in the European security architecture. It is also worth paying attention to the need for greater synchronization of arms purchases and planning to avoid wasting the enormous resources that are spent on military equipment and capabilities. In the future, I would also like to see an extension of the use of existing infrastructure, which is originally intended for civilian use, but which can be of great help in increasing our resilience and security. An example is the already built and implemented satellite systems Copernicus and Galileo. Such a suggestion appeared in the scenarios presented and deserves full support.

name: Janusz ZEMKE
text: in writing. - The European Union is rightly dealing with the issue of its defense and security more and more. In this context, I want to highlight a growing problem. The sum of defense budgets of all European Union member states accounts for approximately 50% of the US defense budget. In Europe, we spend 1.3% of the EU's GDP on defense, while in the USA around 4%. The problem, however, lies not only in too low defense budgets, but also in the very poor effectiveness of their use. By spending 50% of the US budget, Europe has only 15% of the combat capability of the US Army. The dire situation concerns especially research into new military technologies and implementation of new technologies. Therefore, I consider it advisable to create a special defense fund in the EU budget, which would allocate EUR 500 million annually to research and EUR 500 million to the implementation of new technologies. This should improve European military capabilities in the field of reconnaissance, the production of military drones, the acquisition of air refueling and other next-generation weapons.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls for the debate on the Commission statement on the reflection paper on the future of the EU's finances to 2025 (2017/2742 (RSP)).

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, ladies and gentlemen! In March of this year, the Commission took a comprehensive look at the European Union in a White Paper, ventured an outlook and presented the future of Europe in different ways with five options. This White Paper process leads to the European Parliament, leads to the Council, leads to our social partners, to our citizens, to the European public. We are keeping the White Paper process for the European Union, the EU-27, on the way in, particularly along some of the most recent developments, such as the goal of our British friends to leave, but also along with important challenges that our citizens have to face and through the next decade for a good offer. Building on this, we have now presented five reflection papers over the past few weeks - papers for thinking, thinking. The social dimension of Europe, defense - Mrs Mogherini just spoke about this - deepening economic and monetary union, we have considered globalization and what this means for jobs and the European internal market, and now we have the reflection paper a few days ago on Europe's finances 2025, the future. That roughly coincides with the preparations for the next multiannual financial framework, which will apply from January 2021 and which must be worked out together with you over the next few months for the five or five plus five or seven years of the next decade. It is very important to me that our paper is open-ended. We don't have any priorities yet, no preliminary determinations, no preliminary decisions, but we ask the questions that arise. We point out the problems we have. We show the opportunities that Europe has and then give different answers without preference. That is why the paper on finances is in An invitation for the next decade, a starting shot for a public debate - first and foremost with this House, the European Parliament, but also with national parliaments, the governments, the Council, the Committee of the Regions, the European Economic and Social Committee, ours Citizens. And I would like to ask that you, as outstanding personalities in your home country, in your regions, in your constituencies, also promote this debate. It is possible that President Juncker's State of the Union address in September will discuss initial preferences and insights. In any case, we want to propose conclusions to Parliament and the Council and the European Council for December or for the first quarter of next year. According to our legislation, the Commission is required to present its proposal for the next financial framework before the end of the year. Our preparatory work is also well advanced. But two important foundations are not yet in place either at the moment or in the next few months. On the one hand, if we want to take the White Paper process seriously and implement it credibly, then we have to wait for the detailed statements from Parliament, national parliaments, Member States, the public and the social partners, then evaluate them and then weight them - option five, that is option three , two, one and four or a mix of several options. But this will not be possible until the end of the year at the earliest, more likely in the first quarter of next year. More seriously, if the financial framework - the Commission's proposal for the next MFF - is to include budgetary clarity, budgetary truth, realism, then we need to know what the financial implications of our British friends' exit will be. We assume that there will be no serious problems with the implementation of the current financial framework. I am grateful to the British - me come back to it later - that they accepted the mid-term review. 2018 is a budget that is on stable footing. 2019 from the end of March: our expectation that the rights and obligations of the MFF will be honored by 28 member states. 2020 the same case. Let's wait and see. Then there are subsequent commitments which Mr Barnier will have to talk about with Minister Davis over the next few months. I am sure that by the end of the year we will know far more about incoming payments, about outstanding bills, about amounts due from the budget on the way into the next decade, concerning the United Kingdom. That is why - I have already discussed this with your Committee on Budgets and with the rapporteurs, Mrs Thomas and Mr Olbrycht, and I also raised it a few weeks ago with the group chairmen and the President - we, the Commission, consider it preferable that we include the white paper process and our reflection paper for the next MFF and that we include the effects of Brexit as much as possible and therefore in the middle of next year, in any case before the summer break, maybe in late spring, that is, as early as possible and so want to present the next financial framework late as it makes sense - budgetary clarity, budgetary truth. We speak openly over five years or seven years - we all know the arguments - over five plus five years, and we should see that the reflection paper should reflect on traditional and new tasks and responsibilities in the European Union. I currently see two or three gaps in Europe's finances over the next decade. The first loophole: After a phase of transformation and after the departure of the United Kingdom, we will structurally and recurringly be missing ten or eleven billion euros every year because the British were net contributors - whether their economic strength or their high pro- Head ESD. And we need to fill this gap. And the second gap arises from new tasks, new responsibilities, which it makes sense to assume at European level. In general, I want to say that it has to be our ambition - I want to make this an explicit requirement for all of my considerations: for every euro, for every cent that we invest in Europe through the European budget, we should demonstrate the added value - added value. That is the principle of subsidiarity. This means that if a task, a project can be carried out just as well and just as cost-effectively by the member states, then there is no added value. I therefore want to speak to you, also along the lines of the paper, about the question: What does added value mean? Four examples: If we tackle a major research program or a major project like Galileo or high-performance computing or robotics together, because no company and probably no Member State can do this alone, there is added value for the European economy, our labor markets in global competition. Second example: If we upgrade the rail line along the Danube from Austria to the Black Sea - across borders - there will be clear added value if this is coordinated and also co-financed at European level - the “Connecting Europe” facility. Third example - even more difficult: Erasmus + is a great success story. One could also say: why are we doing this in a European way in terms of financing? Because I believe that, on the one hand, it educates people - young people -, is interested in Europe, gives them the opportunity to get to know other foreign regions, cultures and languages, and to make friendships for life. That's why we see added value in it. But if a rail line starts in Bulgaria and ends in Bulgaria - in one country - and is co-financed by us through the Cohesion Fund: is there any added value? More difficult. I think so, by Through this investment aid, we are making Member States in which the gross national product per capita is less than EUR 10,000, while in other Member States 40,000, 50,000, 60,000 - four, five, six times - more competitive , make their location more attractive, increase the quality of life and therefore bring these Member States - our citizens - closer to the European average of an income, a standard of living, a labor market. But as I said: We want to prove the definition of “added value” for each project and program individually in the financial framework. The Cohesion Funds certainly play an important role. I am therefore grateful that Mrs Creţu was co-author and jointly responsible for this paper, because her programs are extremely important for the infrastructure and economic and social development of Europe. Migration, border protection, border control, defense research and defense are also new tasks. If you look at all of these new tasks that are performed more sensibly, more cheaply, more efficiently in Europe and thus relieve the Member States, then there is another coverage gap of ten billion, at least ten plus ten. And then the ambition of perhaps bringing funds from outside - the European Development Fund - into the budget, in order to fully comply with Parliament's right to vote, and to give you overall responsibility as co-legislator for all financial flows at European level, could be a third one Be point. And we have to work together - and this is also what the paper serves - to examine how we can close these two to three gaps - 20 to 25 billion euros per year. The way to the bank and debts are blocked. Europe is the only level that has no debts, is not allowed to do so, does not want to do so - in contrast to member states, regions and municipalities. We should therefore also look at the options - although, if I may be frank, option two (Europe is reduced to the internal market, nothing else) is not my option, a purely theoretical, fundamental option, I am more between five and three and five and four, but still open-minded - Know: Before we ask the Member States for new money, we have to see that our investments get even better. The expenditure balance serves this. We have to modernize our programs, if possible, to simplify them, we want to go into the future with even more flexibility, we should do everything to ensure that the investments are convincing, project after project, and bring sustainable benefits to economic strength, the quality of the location and jobs, and indeed not just a flash in the pan, but permanent. So it could be that we say: We have to cover the Brexit gap through optimization and cuts and reallocations, but also through new money - 50/50 or 40/60 or 60/40. But new tasks that we take on - if we co-finance defense investments and weapons orders, we relieve the member states - that is, for new tasks we first and foremost need fresh money, supplementary income from the member states. An important question is the diversification of income. Should it only be contributions, some customs duties, is the sales tax still up to date, or can own resources, based on the report by Mario Monti and his high-level group, be a useful addition? If not now then when? If you have new tasks, tackle noteworthy new tasks, you should also have the courage to propose new income for them - in addition to existing sources of income. The connection to energy, to the ETS system, to CO2 emissions and their purchase, or the financial transaction tax - nine proposals were made. We are waiting for your feedback and that of the public, and we will definitely get two or three of them the proposed options on the revenue side in our MFF proposal in late spring of next year. We then have to look at the discounts. The British negotiated a permanent discount back then - Prime Minister Thatcher. If the British leave, this is a chance, no, a logical reason that all other discounts that were only created because of the British discount, which legally expire at the end of 2020, will not be extended either. If the mother of all discounts goes, I want to dismiss the children too and thus achieve a clear administrative simplification and a reduction in bureaucracy. A budget without discounts and thus with far less horse-trading would be a step forward on the way to a decision, particularly among the Member States in the Council. Ladies and gentlemen! I want to come back again and I want to ask you - not because we don't want to work, if you expect it, we will present our budget before the end of the year. But we will certainly have to make a supplementary proposal in the summer of next year, because only then will the issue of Brexit consequences become apparent. My request is that you take note of the fact that the Commission will finalize its financial framework for the next decade on the basis of the analysis of the reflection paper on finances 2020, 2025 and on the basis of a reliable interim result by Michel Barnier before summer next year, in late spring - so as early as possible, as late as makes sense, to ensure budgetary truth and clarity - will be presented to you. My request: Participate, and if we come later with our MFF, I would like to offer all the groups, the Committee on Budgets and every Member of Parliament that we can discuss individual points that are clear - the elimination of discounts, own resources, new priorities - earlier Discuss in a politically binding manner and express your expectations as comprehensively as possible the then developing Commission draft can be incorporated in advance.We should make the best possible use of the time until the summer of next year so that discussions with the Council can begin immediately afterwards - perhaps even before the next European elections.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I would like to greet the Commissioner, congratulate all the colleagues and all the colleagues, and congratulate him, Commissioner, on the realistic ambition he has and the commitment. On the side of Parliament, it will have this accompaniment: realistic ambition and commitment. I hope that the Council will have the same desire; I hope that our proposals, our ambition, will echo in the Council. I advocate a structured dialogue for this objective, which is to have the best budget for the European Union after 2020. To speak of the budget is to speak to the citizens; it is talking about employment and, in particular, youth employment, research and innovation, agriculture, fisheries, support for local authorities, culture, support for education and universities, mobility, means of communication, public water supply and sanitation; it is talking about improving the quality of life, but it is also talking about competitiveness; it is also talking about solidarity, which in the European Union must exist between the Member States and within the Member States. And it is also, today, new priorities and I speak of security and defense. We need predictability, we also need stability, and that adds to our obligation. We must present, in this legislature, a multiannual financial framework for the European Union. It is an obligation we owe to citizens, to those who elected us. Your tips, your proposals, some of them subtle, are important. I emphasize the reinforcement of the social dimension and, for example, the Guarantee for Children. The objectives of the European Union Strategy, of the Europe 2020 Strategy, continue, but, as I said, we have a new priority, which is security and defense, and this needs additional resources, additional funding. Fines and fines, for example, must remain in the European Union budget, it does not make sense for them to return to the Member States. It is also important to flexibility and simplicity, and I welcome the proposal that the “rebates”, the compensations, end.The added value is something that depends on the location.The added value cannot mean only large projects or cross-border projects.There are small projects that bring enormous added value and the political component here is essential.Added value also means economic cohesion, social and territorial cohesion.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, we have read the reflection paper in detail, and if I had to highlight one sentence it would be this: 'The concerns and expectations of European citizens must be an important factor in shaping the new budget of the European Union ». In recent years, more and more is expected of the Union when it comes to tackling challenges for which it has neither the competence nor the financial resources and, indeed, Europe today is not experiencing its best moments. There is growing disaffection precisely because we are not doing enough, and that is what we have to give an answer to: we have to propose a courageous project, which will once again excite Europeans, which will attract generations that we have not lived or wars or dictatorships. And that is now or never. We have to respond to the refugee call for help from Europe because the Member States are not doing so. We have to lead the fight against climate change in the face of a Trump who is an arsonist. We have to make a bigger European Youth Guarantee available to young people because we are denying them the future and the present. We have to Europeanize defense and security policy because together we will be much more effective. We have to continue financing, one hundred percent, the common agricultural policy to ensure quality food at an affordable price, and we have to continue with the productive investments of cohesion policy. And, for that, we need a solvent budget. It is time to talk about the new resources: we really have to start a financial transaction fee; we need a European corporation tax. We have to fight tax fraud; we have to put an end to the gift vouchers that half of the Member States - by the way, most of the rich - receive. And, for example, we also have To incorporate - it is a proposal - the fines that the European Commission is imposing on companies for infringing competition laws.President, Commissioner, this morning we remembered Simone Veil.In her speech as President of this House, she said: L ’Europe de la solidarité, d’ abord.Je veux dire de la solidarité between the people, between the regions and between the people.I see no better tribute than defining the future of the Union based on these words.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Speaking out in this debate, I would like to emphasize very strongly that the budget cuts suggested by the Commission in connection with Bexit and the consequent shortage of around EUR 70–100 billion in the EU budget after 2020 are unacceptable to most Central and Eastern European countries. These cuts would apply to the two most important EU policies: the cohesion policy, the common agricultural policy, and it is these policies that are the most important instruments for equalizing the level of development between the old and new member states. Moreover, such restrictions on expenditure from the EU budget are a breach of the principle that more developed EU countries pay certain funds to the budget in return for unlimited access - in this case to 150 million consumers of Central and Eastern Europe - and despite the fact that this title is making enormous profits, now they will try to reduce the burden on this account. On the other hand, the proposals for cuts in funds for the common agricultural policy, in a situation where already in the current financial perspective they have been reduced by 11%, i.e. by EUR 48 billion, with additional tasks being imposed on EU agriculture in the field of environmental protection, climate, landscape and ensuring biodiversity , they seem to be an attempt to sabotage their implementation.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, your reflection paper on the future of the finances of the European Union is really very interesting. I don't have much time, so I'll limit myself to the basics. I fully share the concern expressed in your document to establish a link between respect for the fundamental values ​​of the Union and access to the various European funds to support public and private investment. Member States which opt out of solidarity in one area do not have the right to demand solidarity in other areas. I also support - and I quote your document - "the priority which is investment in people". I read: "A guarantee for children, supported by funds from the European Union, could thus be set up on the model of the guarantee for young people". This is new and interesting, Commissioner. I am in favor of the creation of a macroeconomic stabilization mechanism, aptly called in your document "bad days fund". I support the idea of ​​creating a crisis reserve financed by unused appropriations from previous years and the creation, in spending programs, of an unscheduled reserve, which would be available to deal with unforeseen events. Finally, as co-rapporteur on this dossier, I fully support the need to implement new own resources in the next multiannual financial framework. These new own resources are essential, as you said, in order to face three realities: the consequences of Brexit, the burdens resulting from the new challenges and the reluctance, it must be admitted, of many Member States to increase their contribution. to supply the Union budget from their budget. The options that you are proposing in this area, or in any case that you are suggesting, further to the Monti report, are relevant: no more discounts, establishment of a basket of own resources, in direct connection with two priority objectives of the Union - decarbonization and deepening of the single market - and new revenue from European policies.I would add, Commissioner, that within the framework of the next multiannual financial framework, I am in favor of limiting, by the end of this financial framework, the proportion of GNI resources for supplying the budget.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, change course or follow the same failed recipe as always in the face of Europe's challenges? That is the dichotomy of the European Union. Brexit requires a budgetary reshuffle, of course it does: it implies the loss of a net contributor of around € 10 billion a year - 7% of the European Union budget. But it is also a problem that the elites and financial powers continue to dictate the guidelines for the future: more austerity, more cuts, more deregulations, more privatizations, etcetera, etcetera. With the same recipe you are not going to get miraculous results, but the same as always. For this reason, we must propose a larger budget, to which the States contribute equitably, and public and serious investment plans, because the Juncker plan looks like a cushion to socialize losses that neither promotes the energy transition nor the model change, nor the cohesion between the different territories of the European Union. Same recipes, same results. It is time to reinvent the European Union.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I welcome the latest of the Commission’s reflection papers with the hope that all these reflections will not only foster the debate about the future of Europe, but also help us to make the right choices towards a political, social and sustainable Europe. Most of us here would agree that Europe will have to face big challenges in the coming years, whether the need for a more inclusive and sustainable growth, the fight against inequalities and climate change or security issues. To face them, we will need not only a clear political will, leadership and ambition, but also money. Therefore, we welcome the Commission’s underlying idea to link the future EU budget framework with a clear project for Europe. Since we in the Greens/EFA Group would like to see a stronger, fairer, more efficient and greener Europe, we would also like to see a strong, fair, efficient, flexible and green financial framework, a budget able to deliver results where we are most in need of them, a budget that invests in the future – for instance by building better chances for our youth or increasing research and development for the good of all of society – and a budget aligned with crucial commitments such as those reflected in the Paris Agreement. At the current pace, we are going to fall short on the 20% climate-related spending objective. However, we need to deliver more on climate by significantly increasing efforts and the share of climate—related spending. On the revenue side, there is a clear need to reform the own—resources system. With Brexit there is a unique opportunity to reform it and to scrap all rebates and corrective measures altogether. We should leave the current system – which is overly based on GNI contributions – behind and move towards a budget which is more autonomous of Member States’ transfers. To conclude, I ask the Commission to put forward not only thoughtful reflections, but also ambitious proposals for the next MFF.

name: Marco VALLI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have a remark to make to all my colleagues, because I see that they are rightly looking with concern at the future of EU resources. What is the fundamental point? That when the monetary policies implemented by the ECB in this extraordinary period cease, we will still have to deal with what is the structural economic problem of the European Union, that is a situation where expansionary austerity does not work, where Member States will most likely still plunge into a recession phase and where it will be very difficult to ask for a greater contribution from these States. We need an absolute and even quick revision of the problems linked to expansive austerity: it is a contradiction, something that does not work. There is a monetary drug in place, we need to ring the alarm now to be able to reverse this trend, and then we can also talk, perhaps, to give some more resources for interesting common projects. But as long as this dogma linked to expansive austerity remains, which is a great contradiction, we will not be able to bring home any results.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased to see that while Europe, the real one (not the EU), and its citizens are sinking, the European Commission finds time to reflect, publishing dozens and dozens of meaningless papers to make pretend that there is a semblance of democracy and that decisions are not made first at the table. In my opinion, it is already quite clear what will happen with the next multiannual financial framework after Brexit and what the Commission's idea is. Not, as it would be logical, in my opinion, given the departure of 60 million citizens from the EU, to reduce commitments and payments, but to ask for even more money from European citizens with new community taxes disguised under the name "own resources" or with an increase in transfers, especially from net contributing countries such as my country, Italy. I welcome what the Commissioner said about the effectiveness and results of the budget lines, but words must be followed by deeds. For too long we have been talking and talking about performance budgeting without doing anything. I want to know what concrete results big budget lines and big budget lines produce, and if there are - and I think there are - budget lines or tasks that can be done better at the national level. I am talking, for example, of the 8 billion we have spent on the Youth Guarantee, without significant results: there are millions and millions of unemployed in the European Union and unemployed young people have reached record figures. I am talking about the 5 billion in pre-accession funds we are giving to Turkey, a country led by a dictator. I am talking about the billions of euros spent by the Commission every year on propaganda. It is clear that deeper reasoning needs to be done and that the next multiannual financial framework must be based on a budget that is not used as political propaganda, such as unfortunately it happens today.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, during last year’s referendum people in the United Kingdom were told that a vote to leave the European Union would bring upheaval almost from day one. So dire were the consequences, we were told, that sticking with the EU was really the only show in town.  This reflection paper on the EU’s future finances makes grim reading for taxpayers across the remaining Member States. It points to a EUR 12 billion annual shortfall as a result of the UK’s exit. Now, as before, the Commission goes down a predictable path of creating new spending priorities – spending on the European common defence policy, the challenges of migration and other ambitious plans could well add another EUR 12 to 13 billion to the deficit, making it in the region of EUR 25 billion per year.  Commissioner Hogan has confirmed a three billion black hole in the common agricultural policy budget. Just last week, Commissioner, you confirmed that other major programmes would not be immune to cuts. Inevitably, this will mean that countries like Germany, France and the Republic of Ireland will pay in more and will receive less in return. It will inevitably mean the raising of further direct taxes from citizens in order to finance these grand ambitions. These are challenging times for all of us. We are entering a crucial phase of negotiation on the UK’s departure from the EU. Reading this report should remind this House just how important it is that we construct an agreement that is to the mutual benefit of all of our citizens, and not just the federalist ambitions of some.

name: Jan OLBRYCHT
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! It has only been a few days since the publication of the debate paper on the future of funding. This proves how seriously the European Parliament is taking this debate by reacting immediately to the European Commission proposal. This proposal only opens the possibility of a serious discussion on the financing of the European Union. But let us note that this document is not written for the European Parliament. This document is also being written to open up a debate among the governments of the Member States. This debate must run in parallel. We will also be waiting with great impatience in Parliament for what the governments of the Member States say and how they react to this proposal. The proposal, which today, according to the white paper, is divided into several scenarios, poses the basic question: are we able to do more with less money? Is it even feasible? It seems to me that the first reaction of the European Parliament after reading this document thoroughly is: this cannot be done. You can't do more with less money. Therefore, the European Parliament is obviously taking action on the debate. We will discuss very carefully what to propose to the European Union, what to propose to governments, in order to prove that it cannot be done as proposed and that the approach to financing the European Union must be absolutely changed.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to congratulate you on the quality of the discussion paper you have produced and I want to salute your desire to establish a serious, frank and open dialogue with Parliament. We will be there for this discussion. In this dialogue, we will not be sterile opponents or mere goads, but partners in building together the project for financing the future of the European Union. Article 25 of the financial framework provided for the Commission to present its draft future financial framework before 1 January 2018. I do not want to play the procedure to the detriment of politics. However, I alert you to the credibility of our institutions. How can we ask our fellow citizens to respect the law if we ourselves break free from it? At the very least, the approval of the co-legislators is required. In any case, it is time to start work on the financial orientations of Europe after 2020. However, it is a very strange exercise in which we must engage to prepare the future financing of the Union without having defined neither the strategy, nor the level of ambition, nor the priorities. Everyone expected the Commission to exercise its power of initiative and clearly indicate its proposed course for the future of the Union. Unfortunately no, we are faced with five alternative scenarios. I prefer to be honest, Parliament will not work on five scenarios, but on its vision and priorities for the Union. Commissioner, I share your observation that the current financial framework is under-sizing. I share your concern about the downward trend in expenditure ceilings since 1993. I share your criticisms on rebates and on the current system of Union budgetary revenue, dominated by the contribution of the Member States, which inevitably leads to the deadly logic of the just back. I also share your requirements democratic as to the duration, budgetary unity and sincerity of the next financial framework. Finally, I want to agree with you on most of the goals you indicate, such as economic strength, sustainability, solidarity and security. However, as I read you, I see the impossible equation of wanting to do more with less money resurfacing. Investment, migration and youth have constituted new programs in the current financial framework, with all the funding difficulties we have encountered and the sacrifices we have had to make on key programs, such as research. You add to it - and we could agree - new commitments related to security and defense issues. This expenditure may in no case be to the detriment of solidarity programs, such as cohesion, youth, social or development aid. With new expenditure, new revenue! Our future must be based on three pillars: consolidated solidarity for our fellow citizens and our territories; an economic power oriented towards sustainable development, which will give us energy and food autonomy; a security policy to ensure peace. Finally, Commissioner, we would be inclined to reject the current budgetary under-dimensioning and more motivated than ever to demand new own resources for the European Union, as you propose. I wish you and I wish us every success in bringing together an ambition worthy of the name for the European Union.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - The departure of the United Kingdom leaves a hole of about EUR 10 billion in the European budget every year. The question is of course: who will pay for that? Not the Member States. Because then Brexit would be a punishment for the net payers who are left behind. And not the European Union, which will then levy taxes. Taxation is reserved for countries, for states, and the European Union is not a state. So there is only one solution: savings must be made! And that can be done as follows. Let's really spend the Structural Funds on the poorer regions of Europe. A country like the Netherlands can easily finance its own cycle paths, we don't have to do that. So let's tackle those Structural Funds. That is one. Two: The UK is currently home to the European Banking Authority and the European Medicines Agency. Let them come to Strasbourg. Parliament can leave Strasbourg, which saves hundreds of millions a year. Three: stop the pre-accession funds for Turkey. Four: the Economic and Social Committee can be disbanded. Five: At least half of all agencies can disappear. Brexit offers opportunities: so make efficient cuts! (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question under Rule 162 (8).)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: Question asked under the 'blue card' procedure.- I have listened to the point of view on this reflection paper.But do you think that there is no need, through the new budget for European Union funding, to set goals that lead primarily to social cohesion?Because I did not hear this in the Commissioner's presentation.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: "blue card" answer.- Regarding social cohesion, I made a clear point about that in my speech.We must now really direct the Structural Funds much more towards the regions in Europe that really need that money, because they are lagging behind many other parts of Europe.So that means that we can focus the Structural Funds on certain regions that really need it.And a country like the Netherlands, I already told you: in my country, for example, bicycle paths are partly paid for by the European Union.That is really not necessary.We can easily pay for that ourselves.So more dedicated structural funds, and that doesn't just mean social cohesion.That also means cutting back.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to welcome the publication of the long-awaited reflection paper on the future of European Union funding until 2025 and, above all, the pragmatic and realistic approach set out in it. The main emphases that I want to emphasize are, above all, the search for added value and maximum impact in financing the priorities of the European Union. The Union's reduced budget is expected to play a greater role in new policy areas such as migration, internal and external security and the European Union's defense. The increased focus and drive for greater impact in the fight against climate change has found a place in the report. Support for structural reforms in the Member States creates the necessary conditions for the implementation of European policies and must, of course, continue as a trend in the preparation of the multiannual financial framework. European territorial cooperation is one of the examples of added value when a minimum effect is achieved with a minimum of resources.

name: Martina MICHELS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, my dear colleagues! With its priorities, the reflection paper on EU finances is heading in the wrong direction. Right at the front for you are: internal market, security and defense policy. In the case of solidarity, however, cuts are accepted in four out of five scenarios. I think it's a mistake. After all, cohesion policy can stabilize regions in the long term, and that is precisely why it is a foundation for a competitive Europe. Citizens expect living conditions to be equalized and improved, and they expect this to take precedence over ideologies of competition that only benefit internationally successful companies. In June, this Parliament spoke out in favor of a cohesion policy without a straitjacket and without priority over financial instruments, which further undermine the democratic control of services of general interest. Change the course and stick directly to sufficiently financed European solidarity, to the cohesion of the regions!

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: - Mister President! So today we are talking about the Commission's discussion paper on the future of EU finances, that is to say about tax money. This is preceded by a quote from Jean-Claude Juncker, which means: “We need a budget to make our plans come true. The budget is therefore a means for us to achieve our political goals. ”The EU has risen above the member states and wants to abolish them. A central or federal state - a superstate - should take the place of sovereign nation states. If the budget is measured according to what the political goals are, then I say: not a cent for this European Union, because the dissolution of the nation states is not our goal. But if the goal is to strengthen a Europe of the fatherlands again and to strengthen the fatherlands, then I am happy to support the household. I think then 15 billion instead of 150 billion will probably be enough.

name: Auke ZIJLSTRA
text: - I have read the Commission piece in its entirety and it is a long Hallelujah story.The Commission considers the European Union a success.And now the Commission wants more money in a new way.But in practice, the European Union does not deliver at all.Not in the field of employment or economic growth, and certainly not in the field of security.But the European Union does spend a lot: millions on distant foreign dictators, on the Frontex ferry service for illegal immigrants to Europe and on development aid that has never yielded anything.Madam President, it is not about how the money should come in.The point is that the EU budget is a waste of money.And Madam President, what does not cost anything and works is free trade!We need more of that.And no, those are not those trade agreements that the European Commission is trying to conclude.What does not work and costs a lot is the European Union itself.We should have less of that.Much, much, much less!

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, the European Union's revenue and its finances in general are perhaps the most important debate. European Union refunds are paid by the European Union itself. I am not referring only to the money paid by each state, but mainly to the lost national sovereignty and the mortgage of national wealth which is the real price for the benefits of the Union. The Union is willing to fund and subsidize public works and infrastructure, because it knows that this is the easiest way to impose its economic and cultural expansionist policy. The cases of Greece, but also of Hungary and Poland, clearly show that the first thing the Union intends to do as soon as a state tries to pursue a different policy is simply to close the money supply. With one hand the Union gives, but skillfully with the other it gets much more. But the people of Europe have now begun to openly question the very well-organized operation of the Union. You can make as many plans as you want for the future resources of the Union, but soon developments will make those plans meaningless.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: - Commissioner, I think the document you presented is a very good document. You put all the questions on the table. Now, in the ensuing debates, we need to find answers to both the duration and our own resources and how to cover the losses caused by the UK's departure and what it means to fund new priority policies, defense, security and the continuation of current cohesion and agriculture policies. So, I think it's a document that creates the basis for the next discussions. But at the same time, I believe that the MFF must be approved before the 2019 elections. I believe that people need to know, they need to know from us what Europe means in the future. They need to know what their lives mean next. And if we are left to talk only about Brexit, I think we will have a big problem and that is why my request, and I think that many of our colleagues, is to come up with this proposal as soon as possible. You mentioned that you have to take Brexit into account. True, you have to take Brexit into account because some money is disappearing, but you have to take it into account in the sense that you have to find your own resources, you have to find flexibility, how to cover this loss. But I do not think that Brexit should influence Europe's decision for the future. You also mentioned the added value. I think that, it is true, there must be added value, but we must discuss the definition because the single market also has added value and sometimes creates problems.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the Commission and the Commissioner for the work they are doing and for the debate, and of course my colleagues too. It is a high-profile, high-level discussion that forces us to respond to the challenges, to the questions that arise. And the main question is, when discussing something that has to do with the future, what kind of Europe do we want for the next few years. This is the fundamental question. There is a Europe that survives itself and survives what it has been until now, or there is a Europe that is growing again, a Europe that tries to challenge modernity and contemporaneity, a Europe trying to relaunch its political project and relaunch its policies. The next financial framework on which we will have to work, on which you are called to work - and then we, consequently - must give certain answers to citizens for the coming years. You can no longer have a financial picture that is uncertain and indeterminate. Certain answers must be given, above all certain, new, innovative and even definitive answers, with a very, very clear orientation and horizon. And these answers must be given above all to young people, who have not had any answers in recent years, to businesses, investors and citizens in general. I understand very well your speech, Commissioner, on the need to work urgently, but also to wait for events, to want to wait for next summer to have a clear picture, to understand what framework to present for the next financial framework. But, you see, we need these challenges, these answers that citizens are waiting for, to be given and given fairly quickly. And on this I would like to say that we also need to link the issue of own resources, at the same time, we need a new budget, modern and also independent of the will of the Member states.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Designing and agreeing the multiannual financial framework is never business as usual. The previous 2007-2013 perspective had to take into account all the financial consequences of the historic enlargement of the European Union - ten countries, then Bulgaria, Romania, Croatia - all net beneficiaries. The current financial perspective was overshadowed by the great economic crisis and under enormous pressure from Prime Minister Cameron, and he was putting pressure on budget cuts to avoid Brexit, to convince the English that there was money to save in Europe. And paradoxically now, this project that will be born has Brexit as the biggest unknown, because the budget is a vision of Europe in numbers. The budget is about numbers and it's hard to budget this budget with little idea of ​​what the financial deal with the UK will look like. So it makes sense to delay its submission by the Commission for next year. We have five scenarios so far, of which the fifth - perhaps the closest to Parliament's expectations - is written in such a way as to be rather rejected. Because there is talk of "significant growth". Who will agree to "significant growth" today? If "rational growth" or "reasonable growth" were written, perhaps it would be more digestible in the current climate of the European Union. On the good side, however, I notice the readiness to move to the income side of the budget. There is an opportunity here in connection with Brexit.

name: Jens GEIER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to use a minute to talk about my home country, about Germany. In the negotiations on the medium-term financial framework, a previous federal government enforced that the contribution from national budgets should be limited to one percent of gross national income at the time. Today we see that what was felt to be a success in Germany at the time is causing problems for the EU. Because the European budget is underfunded, and in view of the new additional challenges - I'll just mention combating the causes of displacement and improving border management - that is fatal. Now something interesting is happening: Members of the current government are saying we should definitely let the EU cost us more. Because in Germany two insights prevail. First: Germany is only doing well if our neighbors are also doing well. And secondly: Anyone who examines the financial flows will see that the money, e.g. B. flows through the structural funds into the EU states, flows back as purchases or orders to the Federal Republic. Let us therefore boldly discuss how that should continue, what the EU should be able to afford in the future and how the claims that are growing can be financed. I am in favor of ending the underfunding, ending the discounts, increasing the GNI own resource again and creating new own resources.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner for his paper and to convey my apologies, as I listened to part of your contribution, Commissioner, because another meeting, on Brexit and the budget, beckoned. So we were linked, but not in the same room. I have studied this paper and I am happy that you have set out scenarios that are not all pessimistic, because I was concerned – certainly as a Member of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development I was concerned – that the narrative in this debate was about taking money from the common agricultural policy and giving it to new areas or to other policy areas. I think that the idea of robbing Peter to pay Paul is unhelpful. It is very unhelpful to say to the rural parts of Europe that they must lose funds to other policy areas. There are some interesting ideas in this paper, and some challenging ideas too around possible reforms of the common agricultural policy, including the distribution of payments, and some food for thought around how we will design a policy that meets the challenges of climate change and biodiversity and delivery. But let us not forget the income challenge in agriculture and in rural areas. It is frankly enormous, so this paper is really important. We also need to hear from the Commission, and I think Commissioner Hogan will be delivering on the commitment on sustainable food supply chains, and on action to tackle unfair trading practices. So I think we are making progress – and thank you, Commissioner. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Blue card question.- Honorable Member!It was absolutely from my heart, as far as the cause of the countryside is concerned.But in fact, in theory, let me ask the question: when we formulate the tasks of agriculture, do we see the fact that 20% of Europe's population, one-fifth, is still malnourished to this day?In English, I can’t imagine how to solve such problems with less money.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: blue-card answer. – If I understand the question, I suppose my answer would be that I agree with you. I think that, in a world where we have more demands and more policy areas that need support and we are concerned about existing areas including rural communities, then we do need more resources. But I also think we have to answer as to how money is spent. The Commissioner makes the point very strongly in this paper that we have to demonstrate added value, so it is incumbent on us here in the House to show that our policies, which we defend, do add value.

name: Constanze KREHL
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! Cohesion policy takes up a lot of space in your reflection paper - thank you for that. But when I look at the various scenarios you are preparing, cohesion policy does not seem sufficiently taken into account. Cohesion policy must not become a scapegoat for a misunderstood austerity policy, and it must not be used as a source of funding for new challenges. We cannot play defense policy and cohesion policy off against each other. Cohesion policy must continue to be open to all regions in the future. The added value is obvious. All citizens must be able to feel that the European Union cares about their problems and supports them. Yes, we need reform. We need simplification. We need better communication about what we have achieved. We need more flexibility. Reforms, yes, but we do not need cuts in cohesion policy.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: - Mr Chairman! One cannot ignore the facts and the existing reality in the reflection. In the current financial perspective, the agriculture budget has been reduced by 11.5%, ie by EUR 48 billion. We have an extremely difficult situation in agriculture. The farmers' average income has already fallen below 50% compared to other professional groups. The number of young farmers is drastically decreasing, the countryside is rapidly aging and depopulating. Life is disappearing in many areas. Liberalization of external trade too often worsens the competitive position of our farmers. The countries that joined the EU after 2004 still need considerable support to modernize their agriculture. New challenges such as security and defense? Let us remember that one of the dimensions of security is food security. New work places? We can create them in rural areas, for example through renewable energy sources. Farmers produce many public goods that are important to people, the environment and the climate that must be valued and paid for. We need to explain to the European taxpayer what he receives from farmers through the measures of the common agricultural policy.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, thank you both for the document you have provided us and for your scenario-based approach, but also for the comments you made earlier about the news missions and new resources. Indeed, we are talking about a lot of resources. I would like to draw your attention to the missions, as has just been done, and in this regard, look at the issue of the common agricultural policy. We will certainly have to reorient the CAP, consider the living world differently, link agriculture to food, human health and the protection of our environment. But there is one essential issue to which I would like to draw your attention. This is the issue of food security. Indeed, we can no longer think about our policies within the European Union by looking at each other and remaining in the middle. We must look at what is being done elsewhere, on the other Continent States: at a time when all the other Continent States increase their budgets in terms of agricultural and food policy, it would be totally inconsistent that at Union level we were reducing it. I draw your attention to the policy of China which, today, thinks in the medium and long term the strategy as regards agrifood at the continental scale. We must draw inspiration, over the next twenty years, from these policies.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the Commissioner very much for the good presentation today and the ideas behind it. In fact, when you talk about added value, we can immediately go to the centre: it means to keep Europe together. It does not mean the parts of Europe that are the winners. The rest are followers and what do we do with the rest of the rest? Give it to the Chinese? Sell it? This is the key point when we talk about cohesion. As you said, there are new priorities, but beyond that we can be more creative in the way we deliver our funds and our economic, social and territorial cohesion. Here we might come up with a framework with rules under which funds can work better directly for citizens and for the beneficiaries. Let me say one thing about the speed that we need: if you can come forward with your MFF at the beginning of next year, we will, as Parliament, finalise the work on the regulations before the elections. This is in fact what we have to do: added value in the work we deliver here and you in the Commission.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, while the European Union has to face new strategic areas, such as immigration, internal security, defense, to name but a few, it must at the same time ensure its competences in matters of cohesion, common agricultural policy, economic development, humanitarian intervention, etc. Today she is facing her fate. Will she be able, as Apollinaire says, to "rekindle the stars"?
