Article 311 of the TFEU is clear: the Union is equipping itself with the means necessary to achieve its objectives and carry out its policies. Brexit cannot be used as an excuse, and we must find new resources. Who says "new European taxes" does not necessarily say "surcharge for European citizens". Whoever says "new community tax" does not say "loss of sovereignty for the States". The tax on financial transactions, that on CO2, and the taxation of multinationals are, among others, avenues that we must explore to bring in real own resources in order to meet new challenges and, ultimately, "to rekindle the stars. ".

name: Monika HOHLMEIER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! No matter how hard we try, there will not be infinite amounts of money, regardless of whether the governments are black, red, green or whatever they look like. So we will have to think - based on the five scenarios that have been presented - which areas of responsibility need to be reconsidered and checked. Where have we perhaps not been as successful as we intended, and perhaps do not want to gloss over it and should not gloss it over? Where do we have to change, where do we have to be more innovative? And I believe that innovation and especially science and progress are one of the most important areas in order to create perspectives for young people, so that we don't just hold on to everything and believe that we can add something to it. And if you read through the five scenarios, then I read them in such a way that there are potentially new tasks, and for them there will have to be additional financial resources because they are very specific new tasks. Then the proportion of old tasks will be lower in some cases because the portfolio has a larger scope of tasks overall. I hope that we will simply approach these tasks openly and specifically and thereby prove that the European Union spends the money sensibly and can handle it sensibly.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: – Mr President, you have to cut your coat according to your cloth: if you have less money you need to adapt to that. A problem when we discuss the budget of the European Union is that we tend to forget that the main areas of public spending in Europe are at Member State level. Healthcare, social security, pension systems, defence, schools, education, universities – that is where the bulk of public spending is and must be. And what we can do at European level is in addition to those things and addressing the special challenges we have. We need to put pressure on Member States to prioritise, because they have their deficits, and we should not live in the illusion that we can simply move money around, creating bigger deficits or higher taxes without priorities. The watchword now, and from now on, must be priorities. We cannot have the same priorities today as we had yesterday, nor the same priorities in the future as we have today. Research in science, regional policy directed at the parts of Europe that need support, securing our borders, being a strong partner to our neighbours, enlargement, security – these are the areas we need to prioritise. And then we need to adapt because you have to cut your coat according to your cloth.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! If you have listened to the debate, you get the impression that a lot of reflection papers have been drawn up. I would like to refer to the gift of selection shown by many of my colleagues here. I believe that the reflection paper is more than just reflection, there are clear directions. And it would of course be important now for you, Commissioner, to say which path you want to go with. We have to deal with agricultural policy - in contrast to the safeguarding of the vested rights that we heard today - but we also have to deal with the structural funds. Simplification yes, better results, value for money - that is the path that we have to go, especially because we are accountable to taxpayers. I believe that this paper, if implemented, will contain many interesting elements, starting with the farm cover for large farms, so that we can achieve budget policy goals for new priorities, but also improve existing policies. I believe that we have a great opportunity to improve the policies we have so far. And that's exactly what we should do when we have less money to do it.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this Parliament has constantly asked for the Union's budget to be financed from its own resources. We need new resources to significantly reduce the share of national contributions to the EU budget and also make up for that gap of 11 billion a year linked to the UK's withdrawal. There is a wide range of possible new resources, such as a financial and multinational transaction tax, a serious reform of the emissions trading system and coal taxation, transport taxation, electricity taxation. But we cannot allow cuts in agriculture, as feared by the reflection paper. Farmers are the ones who have suffered the most from the economic crisis and their position in the food supply chain is not a fact that can be resolved with technicalities. But neither can we penalize cohesion policy, not least because social inequality has grown exponentially in many areas of the continent in recent years.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the functioning of the internal market and, at the same time, the structure of the euro area, the crisis, unemployment and austerity policies have essentially marginalized the European South. Cohesion policies must therefore be strengthened. The two keywords are coherence and solidarity. At the same time, however, the funds given to the countries of the European South must give an added value, that is, the local economies must have the opportunity to develop and not just transfer funds and, in fact, return to the countries that give this money. either by technology transfer or as fees for materials, etc. What is also happening - of course - in Greece at the moment is that the hard core countries, in practice, now own or exploit large projects. The Rio-Antirio bridge is owned by a French company, the highways in Greece are operated by Spanish companies and, in the past, 40% of the shares of "Eleftherios Venizelos" belonged to Hochtief.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: - Mr President, the budget represents a real test of the European Union's political honesty. There is no rhetoric that can block the evidence of a decreasing budget, which is less and less oriented towards cohesion and which increasingly fuels security and defense policies. The text is absolutely clear. Expressions such as "effectiveness", "added value" and "reforms" continue to fuel this idea of ​​doing more with less. We do not believe in the miracle of bread multiplication and, therefore, the priorities set out in internal and external security, in border control, in fighting terrorism or in the European army will be financed through further cuts in terms of cohesion and the common agricultural policy. , as has happened, moreover, with the present multiannual framework. This debate has the merit of revealing the true nature of this European Union and revealing all its political hypocrisy. Social and economic cohesion is not achieved through neoliberal reforms, let alone rhetoric; it is done with a redistributive budget and with real development policies at the service of citizens and workers.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: - We are at a time when we are talking about the future of the European Union.We know that one member is leaving the European Union, and we are talking about the future financial framework.When we talk about the future financial framework, we must set ourselves the key goal of making the European Union united.I myself am convinced that this is the most important thing, so we must continue to bet on both cohesion and agricultural resources, and certainly help those who are given more difficult living conditions by the cruel market.Public spending in Europe, if EUR 50 is public spending in Europe, is only EUR 1 within the European Union.Therefore, I think it is right to say that in such situations we will simply have to increase the contribution rate by a small proportion, that is, to transfer more funds through the European Union, either with the contribution of countries or with special taxes.I am convinced that this is the right investment and that it is the right added value for the European Union, because it will make us more united, stronger and more successful.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, the future of the Union is uncertain, says Brexit. Whatever communication techniques are used to convince European citizens to the contrary, they are doomed to fail. This document presents limited options, without vision and on the wrong basis. While documenting the main problems, current difficulties and future challenges, it focuses on management reforms and half measures. The Union is declining because it is pursuing wrong policies. It imposes blind fiscal discipline on the Member States, leading to distortions and inconsistencies. Money, transparency in financial management and balanced budgets are of no value to European citizens living in misery, poverty and misery, with terrorist attacks and illegal immigrants. A sustainable future for Europe exists only when money is the means to the well-being of its citizens and not an end in itself.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger, the reflection paper is good, your speech today was also good. I miss that he didn't even talk about the CAP, or about agrarian policy today. Yes it did in the Commission. I want to tell you: right now let's stop using the Brexit excuse systematically. It is important, without a doubt - without a doubt, that money is important - but if we have ambition, and now is the time to dream of a different and better Europe, we cannot speak of fewer resources, or that with fewer resources we do more things . I agree with a new defense policy and with improving security in Europe, of course I do. But if it is in exchange for Community agricultural policy and cohesion policy, I do not agree. The citizens are not going to understand it. Cohesion and agrarian policy directly reach each and every one of the peoples of Europe and, therefore, they will not understand it. Let us have ambition for a better Europe. And for this, let us be brave, let the Commission be braver, and let us all ask for more resources - this Parliament, the Commission - and let us address it in the Council and also in the States. I am going to do it, in my country, in Spain, and I hope that others will do the same.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! For me, your requests to speak were the beginning of our joint reflection. Certainly the White Paper and with it these five papers go first and foremost to the Member States, but you are also the same addressee, all the more so when the budget is discussed in the White Paper process, that should be your right as king. That is why I think this timely referral is an important start today. We will evaluate your requests to speak and will be happy to come back to you. In essence, it's about the following: A household currently has around 150 billion in income and expenditure - I am simplifying. If the British leave, we will miss 15 percent of the income, we will be short of 23 billion, and therefore the consideration will be that the budget structure for the next decade will be either 125 billion per year, or 150 as before or 160 more. In the suspense - 125 to 160 - let's move. You know that very well, because you are not floating in a vacuum here - by the way, neither do I, I speak every day with ministers from our remaining 27 Member States, including representatives of the regions. There are a significant number of Member States who say: if the British go, there will be no money. But let the one percent cap remain. A clear line, I can tell you in a private conversation which better-spending member states I mean. A clear calculation: 150 minus 23 equals 127 - that's it. I share my colleague Geier's opinion. This budget is structurally sewn to the edge and even underfunded. With flexibility between budget years and budget chapters, we can halfway compensate for what is necessary to finance new tasks and maintain existing programs. To put it straight away - because I can feel this concern: the two major investment and spending programs, including agricultural policy here Both pillars, and here cohesion policy, should - however we decide - not suffer from clear cuts. Agricultural policy is the only fully communitized policy, a not insignificant economic sector, and cohesion policy serves to strengthen regions and bring them closer to the European average. This task will remain an important priority for the next budget, especially in the context of enlargement over the past decade. I cannot guarantee that we will receive the funds now, but we will avoid deforestation. The two pillars, the two major programs, must remain efficient. With our balance sheet we will show where we can do even better. I claim that we are not bad at all, the Court of Auditors alone, our internal audit process and your competent budgetary control committee ensure that this is the case. We're not that bad. I know budgets and budget implementation at local, regional and national level. In comparison, I would like to say that the quality of our household advice is good, that our budget execution is orderly, that the bookkeeping, the control takes place, that abuse is avoided as far as possible - the error rate will also be in 2016 (we will send you that in a few weeks forward) continue to decline - and that the added value of our investments is quite considerable, the number of lost investments is manageable. The expenditure balance is intended to deepen exactly this consideration. MEP Valli - I don't see him anymore - said: as long as everyone is in recession. No, not everyone is in recession anymore. We still have a few countries in stagnation, but most countries, including program countries - Ireland, Portugal, Spain, Cyprus - are developing much better than planned two years ago. Europe is currently with its economy, with its structural growth and still too high Pedestal is also surprisingly good when it comes to new jobs. For the first time, we have shown a slight lead in terms of economic growth in our competition with the USA. We shouldn't talk to each other worse than we are. The key question is: What about the one percent cap - it was also mentioned. I'm not talking about three or two percent, but if we don't get something - 11, 1.2, 1.25 over one, then the fulfillment of our tasks will not work. And I would like to avoid competition or competition: migration and defense are financed at the expense of the Cohesion Fund. That would be a new split in our European family. Some might say: yes, refugees, they don't want to go to structurally weak areas, they want to go to Denmark, Sweden, Holland, Germany, Austria - that is, to net payers. If you then make migration investments there at the expense of the Cohesion Fund, I definitely want to avoid this split. We need an integrated approach to the next multiannual financial framework. Everything was also said beforehand on the subject of net contributors. For every euro that comes to Brussels - from Berlin or Vienna as an example - and goes back from there to Bratislava, Tallinn, Warsaw, Riga, - incidentally, then increased by national funds - 60 percent, 70 percent go back to the construction industry, building materials industry, construction equipment industry , Building trade, civil engineering, plant construction, mechanical engineering, truck construction, planning offices, architecture offices. In truth, my home country is a net beneficiary of a common European cohesion and investment policy. Should structural funds only be given to poor regions? I am open, we ask the question. But the fact that we need acceptance speaks against it. And if there are only poor regions, the acceptance in economically stronger regions decreases. That, in turn, would be anything but integration, as solidarity. And since there are often cross-border projects - Interreg - we should achieve that every region that wants to cooperate with other regions in other member states has certain resources from us so that projects can be carried out jointly from the European budget. Mr Solé, we take the 20 percent target for climate protection seriously. We are monitoring this month after month in the implementation of the budget, the Court of Auditors is currently examining this and is presenting a report to you, and I want to be responsible for the fact that in the end one can say - and also use this as the basis for the start of the next draft budget: The 20 percent can be demonstrated in expenditure and investments in favor of energy savings and climate protection in the execution of the household. We don't want to steer a union. We do not want to burden the citizen with new taxes, but one consideration: climate protection is European policy, Paris, Marrakech is a European success development. The ETS system is European legislation. Industrial companies, steelworks and coal-fired power plants buy licenses for emission rights on European exchanges. All legislation of this House. then the idea that the revenue will go to the European budget is not entirely remote. It would be two sides - legislation and revenue - of a single coin. We will have to examine the question of conditionality. Keyword bike lane: Well, dear Member of Parliament van Dalen, - I don't see him any more, generally the critical requests to speak are all absent and those who agree are present - in any case: we don't want bike lanes, bike lanes make sense for reasons of mobility and that Environmental protection. But it is up to the Member State to decide whether there are bike lanes or bypass roads or whether it is a community center, because up until now the Member States or regions have decided what to use for funds from our structural funds. This is exactly where our consideration starts - European Semester and country-specific recommendations. Shouldn't we work out these recommendations on the strengths and weaknesses of the member states, on priorities, even better and earlier, together with the national ministries and administrations and regions, but then also make them a blueprint for calling up funds? A thought from my previous area: We could show very precisely where in rural areas the digital infrastructure is bad, where there are dead spots, where you should invest in broadband and fiber optics. If this were a priority in the recommendations, ultimately decided by the Council and developed by the Commission and the Member State, then the Member States would be required to call up substantial resources from our structural funds for this. The exciting question is: does this still complement the rule of law, i.e. civil rights and the rule of law, as a condition for the call of funds? We also presented this openly with our reflection paper in the room. Finally, I want to come to the timing. If you do not contradict me, I would like to simply give you my impression that, although you are not pleased, in the light of the prevailing circumstances - the White Paper process and Brexit - you are ready to take note of when the Commission and that the Commission in late spring, at least before the summer break next year, will present her budget and her proposal. If clarity arises earlier - keyword Barnier and Davis, Brexit negotiations - then accordingly earlier. That is, as early as possible and as late as it makes practical sense. But there comes the crucial point: If the proposal is on your table in May or June next year, if you like, then there will be two large time windows for the deliberations in Parliament and the Council, and ultimately in the European Council. I will point them out to you. Here we are only service providers. You decide and the council decides when. And both Time windows are about a year long. The one time window would be the usual: at the very back with time pressure - five to twelve to five past twelve. It would be after your European elections, you first have to establish yourself, have to organize your internal structures, order functions, then there was the summer break, then the new parliament, with many new members, with a breath of fresh air, but perhaps also without experience in November will be ready. We have exactly one new commission - the next commission from November 1st. There remains a time window from November 2019 to November 2020 - one year. The other time window - check it out - would be: We will present it in May and we will negotiate from May 2018 to May 2019, with the time pressure of the upcoming European elections, with this Parliament, with your experience, with our Jean-Claude Juncker Commission. The advantage of the second time window would be clear. Last time we were late. Before Christmas 2013 - that was the Barroso Commission, incidentally no change of commission, it was the same Parliament, and it was Lewandowski, your colleague - we finished shortly before Christmas. The year 2014 was a lost year because the implementation, the implementation until the rural area had the guidelines, was at the beginning of 2015. We had a year, basically, without any significant implementation. Only now, in 2017, will our structural programs pick up full speed. Should we allow ourselves this again? Shouldn't we learn from mistakes? If we want to continue budgeting at full speed for research, defense, structural policy, infrastructure, rural areas and agriculture immediately after the 2020 budget has been implemented, then we would need our financial framework between the Council and Parliament to be approved much earlier. The question goes to you, and the question goes to the Council and the European Council: when are the heads of state or government in the end? inclined to look at our budget?But not through the laying on of hands, but through intensive processing.And if this decision is clear - time window November 2019 to November 2020, or time window May June 2018 to May 2019, one year each - then we can prepare this accordingly with us.You decide.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The discussion is closed.Motions for resolutions to be tabled under Rule 123 (2) of the Rules will be notified subsequently.The vote will take place during a next part-session.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - As the challenges increase, new fields of action are opened up at European level, such as migration, internal and external security, defense and the social pillar. Europe, which also maintains a leading role on the world stage, as a leader in the fight against climate change, must be able to respond concretely to the growing challenges, in a context in which the EU budget will be destined to deal with the UK exit. Today most of the contribution to the EU budget comes from the coffers of the Member States, compared to a small part that comes from customs duties and value added tax. It is therefore appropriate to review the financing mechanisms of the budget and to consider the possibility that, as requested by the Group of Socialists and Democrats, the contributions to the EU budget by the Member States are not calculated in the deficit count. The successes brought by investments such as Horizon 2020 and Erasmus + can serve as an example for a budget review, which knows how to respond to the concrete needs of citizens, finding resources far beyond the contributions of individual Member States.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: In written form. - The document launches a complex debate on the benefits of cohesion policy for the Union. The criterion for efficiency is the long-term added value, as the projects with high added value receive full funding, and the less effective ones are partially or completely excluded from the budget. At the same time, Brexit and the prioritization of migration, security and defense policies will lead to significant budget deficits. Cohesion policy has a proven high added value for the EU as a whole, not just underdeveloped countries. For the period 2007-2013, with a budget of 347 billion euros, it provided employment for more than 9.4 million people, supported more than 400,000 small and medium-sized enterprises and created more than 1 million new jobs. Over 480 billion euros of investment is expected to be guaranteed for the period 2014-2020. At the same time, net financial exporters receive an 80% return through the free market. However, in four of the five proposed scenarios, cohesion funding has been reduced in favor of the new priority policies. I insist on maintaining the commitment in the cohesion policy, as well as on further simplification of the application process. It is also necessary to maintain the level of funding through grants and to stimulate co-financing through private capital, as well as to expand the policy of co-financing from complementary European funds during the various stages of projects.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. - The economic crisis and the current migration crisis have one common impact that should never happen again in the future. Of course, the crisis usually appears unexpectedly, but I firmly reject that this means that funds must be transferred from already running and well-functioning initiatives and projects. Funding for programs and projects is planned years in advance and citizens are counting on it. Therefore, if the Commission and the Council are to launch new initiatives, they should also be aware of the need to create a new flexible financial source. In this respect, the 1% of GNI barrier to the contribution to the common budget will have to be broken. Compared to the US contribution to the federal budget of 21%, our 1% is really ridiculous, even though its effectiveness is absolutely fantastic. All Member States, whether they are interested in funding cohesion policy, agriculture or science and research, enjoy the benefits of a common budget and integration. Therefore, if the current budgetary policy stance does not work ideally, as confirmed by the annual speculation between net payers and beneficiaries, it needs to be changed, cleared of all opaque rebates and discounts, and replaced income based on a Member State's gross national income with more neutral and sustainable income.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. – Any government’s values and priorities are reflected less in political statements than in their budgets, which are the clearest expressions of their means and intent. This is why talking about the future of EU finances in a period when old socio-economic challenges are compounded by new ones, such as the impact of Brexit on revenues or heightened migration and security concerns, among others, is of such a great importance. The upside about being at such an important turning point is that the current situation might provide a strong impetus for reform. Over the years the EU financing system has become increasingly complex, opaque and riddled with exemptions. Similarly, on the expenditure side we can also witness duplications and overlaps between instruments which threaten efficiency and strategic coherence. The Commission’s reflection paper rightly points to the need to modernise EU finances and streamline our financial instruments to make them more efficient. I hope that based on it we will succeed in building a strong consensus around what we want to achieve together in the future.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Siegfried Mureşan, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the mandate for the trilogue on the draft budget 2018 (2017/2043 (BUD)) (A8-0249 / 2017).

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the debate that we are starting right now is the debate about the mandate that the European Parliament will go with to next week’s trialogue with the Council and with the Commission on the budget of the European Union for the year 2018. And why is this important? Because in this report, which I drafted and which I brought in front of you, we are providing the first reaction of the Parliament: the evaluation of the draft budget of the European Commission on the basis of the political priorities of the Parliament, which we have adopted with a large majority in the plenary of the Parliament in March 2017.  Before we talk about political priorities and the in-depth evaluation of the draft budget, I would like to say one thing very clearly ahead of the next week’s dialogue and towards the Council that we are going to meet next week: the European Parliament will not accept automatic cuts to all budgetary lines – to all headings of the budget – as the Council has been doing in recent years. The European Union’s budget is not made by machines for machines, but it is made by politicians for the people on the basis of political priorities and taking into account the expectations of the people. Automatic cuts made by the Council to all headings of the budget, not taking into account the political priorities which the Council and Parliament have given ourselves jointly, is clearly irresponsible.  What are the political priorities of the European Parliament? We have said since the beginning of the year that we have two main priorities: firstly, growth and jobs; secondly, the safety and security of citizens. How do we want to achieve these? On growth and jobs, we want to use the limited resources which we have in the EU budget to strengthen our economy and to make it more competitive, so we want to strengthen innovation, infrastructure, SMEs and the Erasmus programme, because that is also a support for labour mobility in Europe – it supports young people. I want to say very clearly, Commissioner Oettinger, that the draft budget which you presented at the end of May 2017 generally corresponds with and is in line with the important political priorities which we adopted in March 2017. I think you did the right thing on the first priority – on growth and jobs – to strengthen innovation (the Horizon 2020 programme, infrastructure, connecting Europe facility, Erasmus). We will have to work together to see whether the amounts foreseen for the COSME programme, for SMEs, also fulfil our objective of creating more employment, more jobs in Europe, because SMEs are where jobs are being created. We need to make sure that the amounts foreseen by you in the COSME programme are also sufficient. You also propose in the draft budget, and we agreed, that the Youth Employment initiative should be continued:  EUR 233 million for next year. That is good, but in parallel we also have to make sure that this money is well spent. We owe it to the citizens of Europe to make sure that every single euro spent is well spent, and concerns expressed by the Court of Auditors with regard to the Youth Employment initiative we will take very seriously.  The second priority – security, the safety of citizens – is important because there can be no growth and no jobs without safety. If people do not feel safe in Europe, then there is no labour mobility, no investment. To achieve this objective, we wanted to see the agencies of the Union which have responsibility for justice and home affairs strengthened – you are proposing this. We will have to work together in the upcoming months, and also with the Council, to see to what extent that corresponds to the needs on the ground, or whether we will have to do more. My report on the mandate for the trialogue clearly supports the preparatory action on defence, because in those areas where Member States are ready to cooperate at European level on defence research, we have to enable this. We have to stop spending money 28 times in 28 Member States at a national level, but spend it once at European level and then share the results amongst all of us. When it comes to neighbourhood policy, you increase the ENI East programme; we think that is very good; we have to see whether the amounts allocated for Western Balkans are sufficient on the ground. Lastly, I want to say that we need – and this is a call towards the European Commission as a whole – a quick decision on the continuation of the Turkey refugee facility. That is not for you to decide, but the Commission as a whole needs to provide us with clarity – we need to know how much money will be needed for this important programme.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! Dear Mr Mureşan, your introductory words, but also the mandate and the report on it that you have drawn up, are largely confronted with concurrent considerations by the European Commission. 2018 will likely be the last normal budget year. In other words, with 28 Member States, with the multiannual financial framework moving forward, which incidentally ended two days ago - three and a half years are behind us, three and a half years are still ahead of us. And that's why I look forward to an objective debate in the further deliberations with optimism. Indeed, we believed that blanket cuts without looking at the individual programs and without adopting budget implementation in 2017 were wrong. Your priorities are our priorities, and Parliament's cooperation with the Commission in the run-up to this has also been reflected accordingly. It's about economic growth, it's about jobs, it's about combating youth unemployment, it's about us building something new for young people in heading 1a with the European Youth Solidarity Corps, without taking it away with a negative impact in Erasmus +, and it It's about continuing our proven programs, but also tackling new issues - migration as an established focus in the European budget. With the topic of defense research, we are feeling our way forward in the form of experiments by pioneers - 40 million in 2018, 90 million in the three years up to the end of 2019. From this knowledge it makes sense! If you - keyword defense drones - conduct research on a European basis and proceed in a coordinated manner, we will gain knowledge that will be very important on the way to the next financial framework, into the next decade. You raised the issue of Turkey / EU. We attach great importance to this: every euro comes Refugees benefit people and their homes in refugee camps - shelter, warmth, cold, water, food, clothing, security, education - and the three billion will be in the very foreseeable future, probably around the end of the year, in the form of obligations be issued by commitments. Now we are waiting to see how the next few weeks go - keyword G20 in Hamburg - in general, how and whether you can continue to work reliably with the Turkish government in some areas to fight the smuggling problem, to give people human dignity on the ground - three million There are refugees in Turkey, an enormous number. So we once marked a house number with the 230 million in the next household. We are thus credible and negotiable. We will have to ask the Member States to give us substantial additional money - as last time. Our British friends have to decide whether to stick with it - which we would welcome - and if necessary we have to increase the funds accordingly by reallocating them by November during the procedure. We will keep you informed of the progress of this agreement with Turkey over the next few weeks. It was very important to me that the mid-term review held, that the British were fair and collegial after their election, that the Purdah was only valid until election day and that the mid-term review is now being implemented in law, giving the flexibility that is needed in the Budget years 2018, 2019 and 2020 makes a lot more possible. All in all, I claim that it is a draft that corresponds to the priorities of the vast majority in Parliament. We will work together to ensure that there are no blanket cuts, but specific individual considerations - title by title, group by group, project by project and program by program. The trialogue starts on July 13th, and then we have tough ones in September and October Work ahead of us.But from many conversations with you, Mr Mureşan, and with others, I have gained an impression that the level of expertise in Parliament is very high and that we are both responsible for ensuring that this draft budget is roughly as it was drafted by us, can be implemented into applicable law in November.We are on schedule.Thank you very much for your effort!

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Ladies and gentlemen! The opinion of the FEMM committee, whose rapporteur is Barbara Matera, recalls that equality between women and men is one of the key values ​​of the European Union. In the opinion, we draw attention to the fact that the European Union's 2018 budget, which is primarily aimed at sustainable economic growth, social cohesion and the creation of new jobs, especially for young people, should take into account measures to strengthen female entrepreneurship - especially in the fastest growing sectors, the most important for the economy of the European Union, like the ICT sector. It is about programs such as COSME, HORYZONT 2020, and the European Social Fund. Women's representation in programs such as the Youth Employment Initiative, where internships and training are offered, should also be increased, especially in the ICT sector, in technical sectors where women are under-represented, as Europe's future cannot be built without the participation of women and we can also afford to waste and not use their talents and competences. We also express our support for increasing funds for the European Institute for Gender Equality in order to build an observatory on violence there and to monitor policy in this area throughout the European Union.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – Mr President, I would first like to thank Mr Mureşan and the shadow rapporteurs for the good cooperation; we had a successful exchange of views on this topic in the economy meeting. The role of agriculture and rural development in delivering a number of EU objectives is not a question. We consider important the active farmer clause, the producers’ groups, the fight against unfair trading practices, the new market observatories, the phytosanitary actions and the smart approach. Because of the difficult situation of farmers, we cannot allow any cuts to the agriculture budget, and no reallocations to other sectors should take place. The system of the pilot projects and preparatory actions is an important tool which targets sustainable, renewed projects such as the SMART villages concept.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, employment is the backbone of every house economy. That is why we must make sure that employment and growth are properly addressed in the budget. This opinion had consensus amongst the political groups: that growth should be our key focus. In particular, we addressed youth unemployment, which is still too high: 19%. There are also large discrepancies between Member States, and the budget should focus on programmes that target these discrepancies. We also looked at funds for vocational training and professional qualifications to address youth unemployment and reduce the skills gap – especially in sectors like IT, where companies have problems finding qualified people. We need close cooperation between the Commission, Parliament and the Member States to achieve the best results in the next years.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, Dear Colleagues, first of all, allow me to say a word of thanks, congratulations, to all those involved in this work - always hard work - and, above all, to the rapporteur Mureşan, for the quality of his work. work and the involvement of all political groups. It is clear that the European Parliament is united, once again, in this work. We look forward to the European Commission's valuable contribution and we hope that Member States will also be up to this annual challenge. It is essential that the objectives are in line with the means. It is necessary to have sufficient financial means to - on the other hand and above all - achieve the objectives to which we set ourselves. The European Union budget is, above all, an investment budget. About 70%, for example, of investment in my country comes from the budget. It is also clear that, when I say that the budget is an investment budget, I am referring to the fact that only 6% of the budget is associated with administrative expenditure, 94% of the European Union budget is for investment across Union. We have urgency in the execution of the funds. It is unacceptable that, at the moment, there are almost a hundred management authorities to be appointed in the European Union. It is important that funds that are for growth and economic development are implemented quickly. Another issue has to do with the agreements, Commissioner. Agreements have to be kept - pacta sunt servanda. We had stated, we had decided, that we would not touch the Connecting Europe Facility again, that we would not cut back on the Connecting Europe Facility. On the one hand, the Connecting Europe Facility is strengthened and, on the other hand, we want to cut back to another extremely important program, such as the Fund for Strategic Investments. We want the European Fund for Strategic Investments, but we cannot accept the cut of around 500 million euros at Connecting Europe Facility.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mister President! First of all, I would also like to thank our colleague Siegfried Mureşan for this report. In this report we find light and shadow on the part of the ECR Group. We are pleased that some points are justifiably prominent here, for example the funds for the migration crisis. Overall, this is very existential for us. At the same time we miss a link to real sustainable politics, because just spending money will not solve the problems. We are also a little unhappy with certain things, such as the demand for more own resources for the EU. That, we think, is not the way to go. I would like to close with a positive outlook. I am very pleased that you are here for the Commission today, Mr Oettinger, because I also hope that, given the number of colleagues present, you will not scold us as much as your Commission President might have done.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, the basis for the acceptability of the Union is that EU funds are allocated correctly. The exercise of budgetary authority is therefore one of the most important and important issues in the work of Members of Parliament. Citizens do not want the EU to be a machine that spins tax money through the twists and turns of bureaucracy and, at worst, wastes some of its money. The process is not important, the results are important. EU funds and the EU budget must bring added value. The aim must be for every euro spent by the EU to bring benefits to the Member States - benefits that would otherwise be lost. I am pleased that our report takes into account SME and training. They create an important growth base for the whole of Europe. Climate change and the fight against it is something where together we can be more and alone very little. In this matter, I continue to call for the EU to be able to fulfill its commitments under the Paris Agreement. We must also ensure that we do not act inconsistently. The EU budget must not finance a carbon economy that is accelerating climate change. Finally, I would like to remind you that even the negative consequences of the EU's common foreign policy must be common. We have to carry them together. We have rightly imposed sanctions on Russia, but the burdens of counter-sanctions have largely remained at the expense of our farmers. Together, we must also take care of the reverse side of the coin, which is to support and offset the burdens.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, Is iad tosaíochtaí lárnacha do Bhuiséad 2018 ná cruthú fás eacnamaíochta inbhuanaithe; poist mhaithe, chobhsaí agus d’ardchaighdeán; comhtháthú socheacnamaíochta; an imirce agus ár ndualgais dhaonnúla; mar aon le aghaidh a thabhairt ar athrú aeráide. Is ceart bunúsach é an imeascadh sóisialta i gcomthéacs an chruacháis ina bhfuil go leor inimirceach agus ní mór aghaidh a thabhairt orthu agus acmhainní mar ba chuí a chur ar fáil i mBuiséad 2018. Mar aon leis sin, tá gá bearta sonracha a thacaíonn leis na réigiúin, go háirithe in Éirinn, tír a bheidh curtha uirthi go dona de dheasca scoir na Breataine ón Aontas Eorpach. Theip ar an EFSI an bhearna infheistíochta a líonadh ar fud AE. Ba cheart plean infheistíochta poiblí uaillmhianach a chur i bhfeidhm ar fud fad AE chun cabhrú le hinfheistíocht straitéiseach agus struchtúrtha, a sholáthróidh ardleibhéal breisluach sa gheilleagar, san earnáil phoiblí, sa chomhshaol agus sa tsochaí go ginearálta. Déanfadsa, agus mo comhghleacaithe i Sinn Féin, diúltú láidir d’aon iarrachtaí acmhainní a chur i dtreo míleatú AE nó do thaighde cosanta thar ceann AE. Ní hionann AE agus NATO, agus seasfaimid go láidir i gcoinne aon leathnú amach ar an gcomhghuaillíocht sa chomhthéacs Eorpach. Ba chóir go dtabharfadh Buiséad 2018 aire do dhaoine atá faoi bhrú in ionad féiríní a thabhairt do chuideachtaí ollmhóra nó arm ollmhór a chruthú ar mhaithe le lucht an rachmais. Caithfimid a bheith réadúil mar gheall air seo agus aghaidh a thabhairt ar na daoine go bhfuil géarghá acu leis.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, before I outline Green thinking on a few main points in next year’s budget, I would like to thank Mr Mureşan for the great job he has done. No one would have believed that an adventurous and joyous student of Humboldt University, such as he was, would become such a statesman only 10 years later, able to manage all compromises on this issue, which were quite complicated. The first of them – and I was extremely pleased to hear this from Commissioner Oettinger – is that the new initiative on the European Solidarity Corps will not be financed at the cost of the Erasmus programme, and that deserves applause from the Green Group in Parliament as well. Secondly, I keep my eyes wide open on climate action, and we have still not managed to meet the requirements of the European Court of Auditors report, in that we still do not spend enough on climate-change deterrence action, and the situation is becoming more and more serious. The latest scenario I read is that this place – this very place, Strasbourg – could be turned into a swamp in just 30 years if the ocean level rises only 2.5 m. And this is where we need to help Finland, as President of the Arctic Council, to explain to other members, like the USA and Russia, what is actually happening up in the Arctic.  Finally, this is not a Green point but it is my pleasure personally, unlike Ms Ní Riada, to welcome the European defence initiative. This is a serious matter, and a second pillar of NATO needs to be created here.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, it will not surprise you, I’m sure, to learn there is much that I disagree with when it comes to the proposals for the 2018 budget. Firstly, using our taxpayers’ money for projects which are broadly political in nature, whether so-called information campaigns or pre-accession funding given to third countries. And secondly, there are projects which would be better funded, better achieved, by Member States themselves. Rather than sending money across to the European Union for it to come back, it is sometimes better to simply cut out the middleman. Thirdly, there is the waste, mismanagement and fraud within the EU budget – and we still do not really know, with EU funded projects, whether they have actually added enough value to be worth the money that has been spent on them. Fourthly, there is a failure to respect subsidiarity: doing things at EU level when there is no actual need to do so. And fifthly, of course, the waste in administration, which is so well known anyway. There is much more that I could say on this, but what it all leads to is a budget that is perpetually too high, and it leads every year to the EU scrambling around to find ways to increase funding. In the UK in 2010, when Labour was voted out of office, the Chief Secretary to the Treasury famously left his successor a note saying ‘There’s no more money left’, and this seems to happen here every year. If you tried to do less but better you would not find these issues coming up so often. Remember: a spending cap is meant to be a cap, not a target.

name: André ELISSEN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Today I can deliver my first speech in the European Parliament, thank you. The topic I want to talk about is the 2018 budget. While getting into this file, the scales fell off my eyes. I already had the impression that the EU was a money-wasting institution, but in practice it turns out to be many times worse. I will give some examples. Faulty leases, such as that of the European Medicines Agency in London. Cost: only 348 million euros. The House of European History in Brussels. Cost: only 55 million euros. And still struggling to find a single meeting location for the European Parliament. Absurd to move every month, inefficient, costly and inexplicable to the taxpayer. And plans for an absurd, hundreds of millions of euros costing new building for the European Parliament in Brussels. If it were up to me and my party, we would rather close the entire circus of the European Union and Parliament today than tomorrow. But until we have done that, we will continue to be in the thick of things and follow all proposed expenses critically. Thanks for your time and attention.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: - The budget for 2018, the budget proposal presents a good coverage for the transport policy (I am the draftsman for the Committee on Transport) and this is also due to the fact that the budget rectification has been implemented and there some measures have been taken that I requested some time ago in the FC project and now they have been applied, but I would have some more remarks. I am referring to Galileo, which is an extraordinarily important program for the Union economy as a whole. Almost 10% of the economy is based on satellite systems and for transport of course it is important. I think the Prague agency needs staff - it required 23, only 5 were approved. Implementation is needed, because by the end of this year, Galileo will become 100% operational and also EGNOS, which, again, it is an important satellite system, because air transport policy needs very little funding for the full coverage of the Union, to build ground stations in North Africa and Ukraine to do all the coverage. I also hope you find a solution for the Interrail program.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: - Mr President, my colleagues and the rapporteur have already spoken about our mandate, so I would like to take this opportunity to remind the Council - which is not here, but is surely listening to us - that its position on the 2018 budget must be consistent with the Union's political priorities - policies that they themselves decide in their meetings - and which should therefore contain a true political position and not be a mere accounting adjustment in which the budget is cut without taking into account the needs. And when we talk about needs, we mean very specific things: we need a sustainable growth model based on research, on innovation, that creates quality employment, capable of facing the challenge of migration and refugees or change. climate. And that is why we need sufficient means for these programs, because we know that they work and that they reflect the enormous added value of the European Union. And finally, I want to remind you that when we talk about budgets, the Council and the European Parliament - both of us - are the Budgetary Authority and therefore we negotiate on an equal footing.

name: Sander LOONES
text: - 2,889 times.Turkey has already been convicted 2,889 times by the European Court of Human Rights.That is the worst result of all countries!That is also the reason why we voted in favor of a resolution here in this European Parliament last year to stop, drain and freeze European funding for Turkey.But a week later, a week after the vote on that resolution, the 2017 budget was voted here in that same Parliament. What was the result?600 million euros towards Erdogan, towards Ankara, as accession aid for Turkey.And to be honest, I was surprised when I saw the budget, the draft budget for next year 2018. What does it say?Another 640 million euros for Turkey, again as accession aid!This is no longer normal!This is no longer serious.I therefore hope that this Parliament will finally be consistent and vote against this budget, together with the N-VA members of the European Parliament.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: - Mr President, first of all, congratulations to our rapporteur, Mr Mureşan.Clearly, he is establishing himself as one of the most talented representatives of the new generation of parliamentarians.Overall, we agree with the thrusts of his report.I just briefly recall our priorities.First, SMEs, because they create jobs.Second, prioritizing the younger generations, with Erasmus + and the Youth Employment Initiative.Third, a humanist policy, united, but also realistic in the face of the massive influx of migrants and refugees.Fourth, support for the European Defense Fund.Fifth, that at least 20% of the Union's expenditure be allocated to achieving the objectives set by COP21.We will make sure that is the case.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: - Mr President, first of all I must really congratulate my dear colleague, Siegfried Mureşan, on his excellent work, who has really focused on what expresses and satisfies us. We want and claim this budget in the European Union, the development budget, the budget for small and medium-sized enterprises, for the ordinary citizen, innovation, research, for everything that gives another Europe, a more social, more humane, more developing and more competitive Europe. That is why we approve, vote in favor of and support this budget; because it reflects and represents all these principles. I must emphasize that small countries, such as my homeland Cyprus, do not have the capacity and ability to respond and raise funds from European programs, even from the Juncker project, because they do not have the means and capabilities. This budget must also take care of these small countries, which do not have the means and capabilities. I support Mr Oettinger's policy of strengthening defense policy. The European Union must, in practice, defend itself, defend its external borders, defend the European Union as a family and as a united group of countries, which will not leave small and weak countries like my homeland, Cyprus. , be endangered and threatened daily by countries such as Turkey. And I will emphasize that countries that are members of the European Union cannot threaten, provoke and occupy small countries, especially a member state of the European Union, such as Cyprus. The European Union must also respond and send the right messages, especially at this time.

name: Jens GEIER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! As the standing rapporteur for the Agencies Committee on Budgets, I would like to take a position this evening. The current medium-term financial framework has decided that the staff in the institutions and thus also in the decentralized agencies should be cut by 5%. The 2018 budget is where this operation is supposed to be completed, and so will the agencies. It is important for me to emphasize at this point that many agencies have achieved far more, because they had to use the so-called redeployment pool to generate part of the jobs that have become unavoidable at selected agencies - think of the growth in staff at Frontex . I would therefore like to state that the 2018 budget will be the last one in which agency staff will be cut. I think some of them have reached what can be called sclerotic. But the Council has a chance, ladies and gentlemen, to demonstrate its willingness to save elsewhere. The EBA, the European Banking Authority, is being withdrawn from the UK and it would be very sensible, from an austerity point of view, to merge it with the other agencies, either the one in France or the one in Frankfurt. My feeling is: this will not happen.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to emphasize by all means that, when giving a negotiating mandate next week, we must not allow the budgetary values ​​set out in the budget to deviate. We must not allow redundancies that are mechanical, without taking into account policies. As the Commissioner mentioned, we need to look at everything line by line. In particular, I would like to note the proposed increase of 25.7% in the level of payment appropriations under heading 1b in the 2018 draft budget, as well as a 2.4% increase in commitment appropriations. It is extremely important to keep these budget parameters in order to be able to pay off the increased requests for payments under the Structural Funds and the implementation of the programs. This is important for proving the quality of the programs, it is important for maintaining the confidence of European citizens in the European Union.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the Member States can no longer always ask for more from the Union, while reducing its budgetary capacities. The strategy of undressing Paul in order to dress Peter has gone on for too long. It is our responsibility, in the European Parliament, to speak out loudly and to be determined to have the Council accept that the Union deserves the means of its ambitions. After Commissioner Oettinger's speech, we understood that the Commission was more on our side and we can only congratulate ourselves. It is essential to remember that any new policy must benefit from new funding. A defense fund is undoubtedly necessary, but it cannot be financed to the detriment of existing policies, and in particular policies of solidarity. The need for new money is imperative. The European Union cannot suffer from any further disappointment as its future unfolds today. A European budget cannot be the addition of guarantee funds and other financial arrangements. It must be readable and no longer be subject to national contributions alone, or almost, but call on genuine own resources.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, thank you also for your understanding. I would like to thank you, I would like to thank the rapporteur, the Hon. Mureșan, with whom I take the liberty of saying that we are following an interesting, important, very beautiful path, and the work we are doing is a real parliamentary work, not just partisan. This of course does honor to the work that the colleague does and I think it also does honor to the work we are doing as the Chamber. What we are discussing in these hours, these days, and which we will vote tomorrow, is a very broad mandate, in my opinion. a mandate that will allow our rapporteur, and therefore our institution, to have a broad, very clear and serious discussion with the Council and the Commission on the prospects for next year's budget. What we have been discussing in recent weeks, in recent months, and that we will vote tomorrow, really has to do with some of the answers that citizens are asking of us, especially on the most important, most urgent issues, and therefore I naturally think of work, I think of investments, I think of the need to have a Europe that returns to growth - and these considerations are made - that also has a capacity for vision. Of course we cannot hide - and my colleague Mureșan knows this, his colleagues know - that there are still differences in this Parliament, that there are still elements that we will have to deal with, of course, with the Commission - and I also thank Commissioner Oettinger for the support he will give us - and then with the Council: I am thinking of immigration issues, I am thinking of security issues, I am also thinking of issues related to youth mobility ... But I am sure that with this document, and with the vote we will have tomorrow , our Parliament will have a very strong position, our rapporteur will have a very strong position to be able to go and start this negotiation with the Council for the budget of the next year.Thank you President, I repeat, thank you for understanding.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr President, congratulations to the rapporteur on a job well done and to the Commission and the Commissioner on an excellent budget proposal for 2018.Europe is projected to grow by 1.5 to 2% in the medium term.We can by no means be satisfied with this economic growth, and we can only change that with an ambitious budget and quality investments in innovation, science, research and development, education, youth.This is all recognized in this 2018 budget proposal.Also investing in priorities that are important for a favorable business environment, such as energy and transport, but also security and stability.Without security and stability there is no trust, without trust there is no investment in growth and development and that is the clear message of this 2018 budget proposal.I am especially pleased with the increase in payments in cohesion policy of as much as 25%.This is the right moment for this policy to really become visible, because so far it has almost never been.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, sustainable growth, socio-economic cohesion, security, migration and climate change remain the main priorities of the European Union budget for 2018. But there are also other aspects to consider. For example, I agree with the increases proposed by the Commission for the "Youth Guarantee" initiative, even if they are still insufficient. This initiative must be further improved and made more efficient, ensuring that real European added value is brought to the youth work policies of the Member States, and not as a substitute for existing national policies. However, the cut to the COSME program cannot be shared. SMEs play a key role in job creation, and the adequacy of funding for this category of companies must remain the priority of the EU budget. Finally, the unprecedented use of special instruments has shown that the Union budget was not originally designed to address problems such as the current migration and refugee crisis. The proposed cuts are not in line with the European Union's commitment to tackle the problem of migrants efficiently and adequately.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the mandate for the tripartite dialogue on the 2018 draft budget must be clear, it must be strong and it must be based on specific axes: strengthening the Common Agricultural Policy, because Europe's farmers are really suffering; supporting cohesion because the countries of the south of Europe are lagging behind; supporting employment by creating new jobs, especially for the young generation who are currently facing many problems; supporting small and medium-sized enterprises, because only through them can there be real growth; all, so that we can really get rid of the problems of poverty and social exclusion. In addition, support for innovation and research, because only then can there be competitiveness and - of course - there must be funding for refugees and security issues. Finally, no funds are needed for Turkey, which violates human rights and illegally holds 37% of the Republic of Cyprus.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Mureşan, with whom I have had the opportunity to speak on the issue of cohesion policy and its allocation, and at the same time I would like to thank the Commissioner for seeing our speech in this way. I watched him at the meeting. I think that the priorities that have been mentioned for our 2018 budget are too many, it turns out that the main thing will be just a selection. Priorities are increasing, be it migration, the security of the situation in Europe. And of course the budget is not inflatable. We can basically take this as a general for the post-Brexit period. The moment the UK leaves and does not meet its budget contribution, there will be even more money. So I would like to express the hope that the budget will be responsible, that it will cut where it is really possible, and that it will support those priorities and policies that are important for our future. I firmly believe that we will agree with the Council on the mandate. Because then we would disappoint in the eyes of the most important ones, in the eyes of the citizens of Europe.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! The time and the following items on the agenda in a nutshell: I think it is remarkable and positive how broad the mandate that Mr Mureşan has worked out for himself emerges from your remarks. I believe that strengthens his authority and your authority. The fact that the Commission's draft budget and your assessment, your comments and your additions have a large majority here in this House is also a clear sign of your strength in the trialogue negotiations. I am pleased that they will start on July 13th, based on the mandate, and I promise my support in all negotiation rounds. Most of the points were mentioned: migration, social affairs, infrastructure, cohesion, rural areas, research. Perhaps just a few more thoughts on three points: We are monitoring the personnel situation in our services very closely. We will have made the 5% staff cuts in the establishment plan as a commission this year - for other services next year. And then our services - this applies to Parliament, it applies to all institutions, it applies to the Commission, it applies to the agencies - a few years of stabilization on the basis of an establishment plan and legislation that goes into the next decade. And when agencies have more work, have new tasks, do extraordinary work, we always have the option of fine-tuning, adding a few positions so that the agencies can also fulfill their tasks alongside the general directorates. I will be in contact with the spokesman for our agencies over the next few days to hear their expectations. Galileo is a project of a decade, a century - the industry just couldn't get it right. We are late, but we can do it and thus create our own European sovereignty in a technologically outstanding area and are no longer solely dependent on the import of navigation services from overseas. The creation of the European Museum of History has been criticized. I recently saw a group of visitors there, young people from Europe who were there - they were thrilled. I think the Parlamentarium and the House of European History are excellent opportunities for further training, especially for our European citizens, especially for the younger generation. Because, whether we want it or not, whether you don't want it or I want it: there is a European history, unfortunately there is a European war history, there is a European cultural history, a European social history - Karl Marx - there is there is a European history of religion and the history of the Reformation in the Luther year, and there is basically also a European history of our changeful politics, from the Romans, the Greeks, before, the Hohenstaufen, from Charles I to Napoleon. And not to show this to young people in particular would be a sacrilege. I think - with all the pride in home and nation - a nationalistic straitjacket would be wrong. And our children, the Erasmus generation, would neither attract nor accept them. That is why my request is: speak to citizens who come from this House of History! I am sure you will then see for yourself that this 50 million has been a worthwhile investment in the education of our citizens across the continent in all its diversity.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like firstly to thank my colleagues and Commissioner Oettinger for this very rich and interesting debate tonight. I would like particularly to thank the shadow rapporteurs, with whom I have been working very well and closely. They were very constructive throughout the work. I see with us still in the Chamber Bernd Kölmel and Indrek Tarand – my thanks to you, and also to Daniele Viotti and Anneli Jäätteenmäki, who were with us earlier. The rapporteurs for the opinions from the various committees were instrumental in putting together a mandate for Parliament which reflects the will of the colleagues in this House and that is why I anticipate that we will be able to adopt this with a large majority tomorrow. In addition to this, before concluding, I would like to say that growth and jobs and the security and safety of citizens are our biggest priorities. This is what we agreed with the Commission: that these things should receive priority next year. In addition, as was said before, we should not forget the traditional policies of the Union – cohesion and agriculture – and we should ensure proper financing. In this regard, the Commission did the right thing by proposing an increase in payments under Heading 1b to Cohesion and Structural Funds by 25% because we expect and we want to see money flowing into the programmes next year. This is why we are making money available for the real economy, so that NGOs, SMEs and regional and local stakeholders can benefit from the EU budget. I am confident after today’s debate that, together with the Commission, with Commissioner Oettinger, and with the Council – starting next week in the trilogue and then in autumn – we will be able to put forward and adopt a meaningful budget, a Union budget for 2018 which corresponds to the needs of the year 2018 and which respects and complies with European citizens’ expectations vis-à-vis the Union next year.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place on Wednesday 5 July 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: signed up.- The report on the mandate for the trilogue on the draft budget for 2018 is very important from the perspective of the future of sustainable growth of quality jobs, especially in SMEs, research and youth.That is why we have proposed to the Commission to allocate a reasonable budget for increasing the digital capacity of startups, as well as for the internationalization of European SMEs.Europe's reindustrialisation can only be achieved through increased skills, innovation and research and education that is appropriate to the demands of the economy.It is necessary to allocate an adequate budget for the functioning of the customs union in order to combat fraud and economic crime.I encourage the Commission to increase funding under Horizon 2020 and to support European businesses that prioritize inclusion and job creation.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the statement by the Vice-President of the Commission and the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy on the election of Saudi Arabia as a member of the UN Commission on the Status of Women (2017/2721 (RSP)).

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, the entire Middle East is going through an era of deep transformation and radical change. Our attention is always focused on the latest political developments, from the conflicts in Syria and Iraq to the diplomatic crisis in the Gulf, but the topic we are discussing today, the condition of women in Saudi Arabia, is no less relevant. Definitely, inequality always makes a society weaker, and this is true of inequality between men and women. Our work for gender equality is not only consistent with our principles and values but it is also a matter of stability and resilience and it is a matter of economic growth. No country can achieve its full potential if half of its people do not have the same opportunities to work – and, of course, to learn and to have a say. In times of great change in the Middle East, it is essential that we constantly monitor the new threats to gender equality, and also the opportunities that arise for women’s empowerment. I can only concur that the situation of women’s rights in Saudi Arabia remains difficult. The European Union continues to engage the Saudi authorities on a number of human rights issues, including gender matters, and we consistently refer to the recommendation made during the last UN universal periodic review process on Saudi Arabia, which was concluded in 2014. EU Member States actively and constructively contributed to this exercise under the coordination of the European institutions. As you all know, the European Union does not vote in elections within UN political bodies. The decision on whether to support Saudi Arabia in the Commission on the Status of Women belongs to our Member States. But since Saudi Arabia has now been elected, I believe we should work to turn its membership of that Commission into an opportunity for Saudi women. Saudi society is changing, more or less slowly but constantly. The country’s authorities are starting to talk about reforms, and this is something we should encourage, and are encouraging in our diplomatic contacts with them. The new Crown Prince has publicly said that he believes it is time for change in this respect. This year we have seen a timid but interesting attempt at reforming the guardianship system, the system that forces Saudi women to ask for a man’s authorisation to travel, work or marry. A petition from local communities to introduce reform was signed by thousands. The Saudi leadership has acknowledged that the current system is not efficient in economic terms and could be an obstacle in fulfilling the ambitious objectives the Kingdom has set out in its ‘Vision 2030’. For the sake of Saudi women, we cannot miss any opportunity to encourage and accompany change in this country. We will continue to ask the Saudi leadership to demonstrate that it takes gender equality seriously. A useful first step would be for Saudi Arabia to ratify the Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Discrimination against Women. Let me add that Saudi women are very well organised and, with an international platform, I am sure that they can manage to make their voice heard. The UN Commission could offer this platform. We hope so. Already many Saudi women are fighting every day for their rights – like so many other women in all parts of the world. They are not subjugated, they are not resigned, and they are proud of what they have achieved with much hard work. These women can be the drivers of change inside their society. Let us take this opportunity to amplify their voice, to support their work and to advance gender equality in Saudi Arabia and right throughout the Middle East.

name: Teresa JIMÉNEZ-BECERRIL BARRIO
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr. President, when I learned that Saudi Arabia had been elected to the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women, I thought it was a mistake, because it is incredible that one of the most misogynistic countries in the world may be in a body dedicated to the promotion of gender equality and the empowerment of women. How can a country that does not respect women's rights defend them, a country where unrelated men and women are criminalized together, a country where women cannot drive, a country where women are subjected to violence for life? guardianship of a male. Can the women of this House imagine that to travel, open a business, receive medical treatment, marry, study, or simply to walk down the street, they needed the approval of a man? It is unimaginable to me, and my only hope is that the inclusion of Saudi Arabia in this UN Commission on Women will serve as an impetus to improve the situation of women in a country where discrimination against them is systematic in law and in practice. It must be recognized, as the commissioner has said, that reforms are being made and this is opening a crack in intolerance, but it is very frustrating that the first advice that was made in Saudi Arabia on women was composed only of men. I want to finish by denouncing all the countries where being homosexual is punishable by jail, and Saudi Arabia is one of them: another violation of human rights that we who have the freedom to denounce have the obligation to denounce.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Saudi Arabia is a misogynistic country, where women suffer systematic discrimination, where crimes are committed against women that go unpunished. Society is governed by the male guardianship system: parents, siblings or partners decide if the woman can study, access a job, or even get a driver's license. Well, this country has been elected member of the UN Commission on the Status of Women. It might sound like a joke if we weren't talking about a very serious subject, but it is not a joke, it is a grotesque that we cannot silence. The Group of Socialists and Democrats strongly condemns this appointment. And, furthermore, we consider it intolerable that this was possible with the support of at least three countries of the European Union, according to the information available to us. We must ensure the European commitment to defend gender equality as a fundamental right and that this is reflected in a coherent position of the European Union and its Member States. It is in our hands not to allow these international organizations to lose their credibility. Let's be firm in the defense of women's rights.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I have been watching a great new TV show based on Margaret Atwood’s novel ‘The Handmaid’s Tale’. Women are forced to do domestic chores, wear complete cover-up clothing, head dresses that act like blinkers on a horse; they cannot travel, drive, shop or even eat and drink without a man’s permission. They are entirely the property of men, with no legal identity of their own. The programme is described by its producers as ‘set in a dystopian future, a woman is forced to live as a concubine under a fundamentalist theocratic dictatorship’. We are all horrified! Can we imagine a path whereby our world could come to this? Well, no, this is fiction, right? It is not, because almost exactly these conditions exist in modern Saudi Arabia. This is not a country that we should be listening to on the UN Commission on the Status of Women. This is a country that we should be condemning, and we should condemn this appointment in the strongest possible terms.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
