text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President: thank you, Commissioner, for being here today, submitting to the control of Parliament, as appropriate, even though we are few and it is nine o'clock at night. I share the concerns expressed by my colleagues but, after careful consideration, I must say that I do not share their solutions. Yes, Saudi Arabia oppresses, subjects and barbarically discriminates against women. Yes, we must fight tirelessly for every woman persecuted or imprisoned for defending her rights, human rights. But we should do so directly and with confidence in ourselves. Having Saudi Arabia sitting in the United Nations Women's Commission, as Iran has already been, allows us to tell the truth to their face, without complexes and without intermediaries. If the conviction for the detention of Loujain Alhathloul, a women's rights activist, comes from a commission in which Saudi Arabia is represented, it will carry more weight. Therefore, Mr Stylianides, I am not going to ask you to promote the exclusion of Saudi Arabia from this Commission. I ask you to combat the Paleolithic mentality of Saudi Arabia in and from the United Nations Commission on Women. These commissions should not be ivory towers for progressives to agree with each other and condemn the barbarians who are not present. Citizens are tired of commissions that make resolutions that are then not enforced. Let us defend our principles in front of Saudi Arabia, head on; let us use the institutions to achieve the common goal. And if not, look at the case of my colleague Beatrix von Storch, who is not here today, my colleague and namesake of the xenophobic far-right Alternative für Deutschland party. After a few years with us in Parliament's Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality, she now fully supports the candidate of her party, a lesbian woman who lives with another woman. Well, let's do with Saudi Arabia what Parliament European has done with Mrs. von Storch.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, the election of Saudi Arabia as a member of the UN Commission on the Status of Women is akin to something that you would read in a parody publication. At least three, possibly five, EU countries voted in favour of this shameful position – voted for a country where women are effectively legal minors their entire lives, where they require a male guardian’s approval to travel, to attend education, to access some health care. Shame on those Member States! A Freedom of Information request from me to the Irish Department of Foreign Affairs was refused, but it did show a flurry of email activity on the matter. Ireland is like the others who chose to hide behind the excuse of the secret ballots. But then, in Ireland, women’s rights and dirty secrets are nothing new. But what possible justification could there be for EU Member States to endorse the world’s leading oppressor of women now as a promoter of gender equality? In one word: trade!

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, on the situation of women in Saudi Arabia, which you have described and explained to us, we know what the situation is, the legal situation, the day-to-day life of women in Saudi Arabia: a real torment, a real aberration. But what interests me today is not only that - which too - but the diplomatic failure of the Member States of the European Union that have allowed this situation. Up to five have allowed it. And then, I would also like you to give us some explanation, because you coordinate positions within the framework of the United Nations. They have that role, as the European External Action Service, and I would like to know what happened, what Ambassador Almeida told them, how this situation was achieved. And later, I am also concerned, and I would also like you to give us some explanation - I know that you do not vote, I know that you are not there, but you play a role, I insist - what is going to happen to the work of the Commission From now on, in what way are we going to allow the Commission to continue with its normal work and not be hindered by a member who directly has a policy that violates the rights of women. I would like you to clarify those two things, as the European External Action Service, because that is what concerns us.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr. President, "Linking Saudi Arabia to the protection of women’s rights is like appointing an arsonist fire chief." I quote here the president of the NGO United Nations Watch, who describes with humor and not without finesse the situation in which the UN Commission on the Status of Women finds itself today. On April 21, thirteen new members were elected to this commission, which aims to defend the dignity of women around the world. Among these thirteen countries is therefore Saudi Arabia. How not to believe in a hoax? How can we imagine that this country, which had received the title of the most misogynistic country in the world from several NGOs, could become a member of a commission for the protection of women? How can a country that forbids women to drive, to go out alone, that hides them under the niqab and goes so far as to stone them, be considered a defender of female dignity? How to understand this, if not as an affront to women around the world, as the victory of the money of the petromonarchies over any moral or political consideration? Of the 54 voters, 47 were said to have decided that yes, Saudi Arabia could embody and promote women’s freedom. The women of this country will appreciate it. As a woman, I protest against this nomination and as a Member of the European Parliament, I denounce the complicity of the five states of the European Union which voted "yes" to the entry of Saudi Arabia. Finally, I would like to share with you an anecdote from The Independent newspaper. In March 2017, the Saudi authorities organized the first meeting on the topic of women's rights, a first step forward in the matter. Imagine that, during this meeting, the women were seated separately, in a separate room, single-sex required, and that they do not even appear in the photos. In 2015, Saudi Arabia was already elected to Commission on Human Rights and had, in the process, executed 153 people, up from 26 in 2010. Hopefully the revival will not be more difficult.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, the decision of the UN Council to elect Saudi Arabia as a member of the Committee on the Protection of Women can only come as a surprise. Saudi Arabia is a highly conservative Islamist country where the right of all sexes is clearly defined by law and this is clearly against women. Every woman should have a male prostate who will take on all the crucial decisions and control her life, from the moment she is born until the moment she dies. Women are also not allowed to drive, not allowed to be painted, not allowed to talk to men and much more. So you understand how much Saudi Arabia will promote women's rights at the UN. But if you consider that this country has the largest oil reserves in the world, is the largest exporter of oil in the world and that most of the UK weapons systems end up in Saudi Arabia, you will realize that it is not difficult, despite the fact that Saudi Arabia is funding terrorist acts around the world to persuade some of its enemies to support it at the UN, while voting there is secret.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: - Mr President, I am not going to tell what happens in Saudi Arabia with women because we all know it. We, the Members of this House, know it, the Commissioner knows it and, above all, the Member States of the European Union that voted in favor of Saudi Arabia occupying a space in the United Nations Council for Women. This is the question. I do not come here to even judge Saudi Arabia, rather to worry that Member States of this Union are capable of playing this practical joke on us, and especially on Saudi women, for whom this decision is the worst. It seems to me that they do not realize to what extent these kinds of decisions undermine the multilateral system, which is a multilateral system that many would like to see blown up. And these are arguments for those who want to blow up the multilateral system; and our obligation, as representatives of the European Union, its citizens and its institutions, is to denounce this so that it never happens again.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: – Mr President, I would like to know from the Commissioner how come that reportedly five EU Member States voted in favour of Saudi Arabia becoming a member of the Commission on the Status of Women. Had there been no coordination in New York on that, Commissioner? We want an answer to that, we want transparency about how EU Member States vote. Is it because some of those Member States export arms to Saudi Arabia, despite an EU code against arms exports to countries that wage war against others, like Saudi Arabia against Yemen? Or is it because they have good business relations and don’t want to harm them? Do women’s rights really count that little? I do not want to see that in the EU or elsewhere. We know that Saudi Arabia is one of the worst violators of women’s rights and human rights. Even men like Sakharov Laureate Raif Badawi, who have demanded women’s rights, are imprisoned for 10 years. So I really want to know from you, Commissioner, what happened there? Why did all the EU Member States not vote against Saudi Arabia joining the Commission on the Status of Women? That should have been done.

name: André ELISSEN
text: - I too would like to say a few words about the election of Saudi Arabia as a member of the UN Commission on the Status of Women. It seems like a misguided joke, but unfortunately this election actually took place. This election shows once again that Arab countries within the UN and the football organization FIFA have a lot in common. Let me give you some examples: checkbook in hand buying votes from poor countries, colluding countries by distributing commissions, silencing critics at home and abroad, blackmailing by threatening to cut funding for UN projects . No sane person in such a committee wants a country that oppresses minorities, grants and executes the death penalty in a medieval way, obliges women in the country to cover their entire bodies and even forbids them to drive a car! As far as we are concerned, this is a certificate of incapacity for the UN and for the Member States that voted in favor of this ridiculous proposal.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Saudi Arabia is 134 out of 145 states in the ranking on gender inequality which, incredibly, was drawn up by the United Nations itself. I believe that there is really only one word to describe even this debate, to describe this very serious decision to choose Saudi Arabia as a member, to elect Saudi Arabia as a member of this commission which aims to promote and deal with , in fact, of the status of women. And the word, Commissioner, is "ridiculous". This is the word that you should have used and that we would have liked to hear, because we know dramatically too much about the condition of women in that country, we know everything. Then you will understand that we are here to ask you for an account of this decision which continues to appear to us to be truly incomprehensible and very serious! And then we ask you: how was it possible to reach a decision, such an election? I fear that, as often happens, other interests have prevailed not only with regard to women's rights. And then I think it would be time for real to put an end to these havoc that we are forced to notice every day.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Mr. President, Saudi Arabia has just been elected to sit on the UN Commission on the Status of Women.The election was held by secret ballot.Of the 54 voting countries, 47 voted in favor, including, unfortunately, 5 Member States of the European Union.France claims to have voted against.Hopefully that's true, because this election is a farce.Who can believe that Saudi Arabia will stand up for women’s rights?Saudi Arabia is the medieval country that beheads adulterous women with sabers in the middle of the street, it is this country that denies women the right to drive and locks them in burqas.This is not the model of society I want for France.The UN has failed, the European Union is getting lost in a deliberate confusion between women's rights and the rights of ethnic minorities and LGBTI, but the National Front is resisting.Radical Islamism will not pass!

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Mister President! There are things that cannot be invented because they are so grotesque - like the decision to appoint Saudi Arabia of all places as a member of the UN Commission for Women's Rights, a country that systematically discriminates against women and places them under male tutelage, not allowing them to open a bank account or drive a car, a country where women are subject to systematic use of physical violence. How should representatives of such a state be able to constructively participate in the further development of women's rights? But it is even more absurd that EU member states have obviously voted for Saudi Arabia. The fact that stupidity or ignorance was decisive can be ruled out. So what was it then? Were there economic reasons? That would be a grave accusation that can only be refuted if one faces a public discussion. It is high time for transparency and clarity because it cannot be that some Member States condone discrimination against women. And, unfortunately, I do not share the optimism of the Commissioner, whom I hold dear. It would be nice, Commissioner, if you were right, but I am afraid that is not the case.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, with the complicity of five Member States of the European Union, Saudi Arabia will therefore join the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women next year. In these circumstances, why not appoint Bernard Madoff as head of the IMF or award the North Korean leader the World Press Freedom Prize? Because, for those who have a short memory - and there are many - I recall that the Saudi government advocates the practice of an ultra-rigorous Islam, which includes forced marriage, the excision of young girls and the stoning of women guilty of 'adultery. These daily violations of women's rights should however challenge them. Unfortunately not, out of interest or cowardice, some have preferred to confine themselves to cutesy lyrical flights in this European theater, where they only have a role of extra. So, before asking little European girls to play with the car, let's start by ensuring that women are no longer considered inferior to men in one of the member countries of this committee.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, for all the respect I have for you, you know what is really ridiculous - since that is the word today - it was not having heard a single word from President Juncker about the election of Saudi Arabia as a member of the Commission United Nations on the condition of women. Saudi Arabia is a regime that despises women. They are forced to have a man as a guardian, they cannot travel, they cannot study or work without the authorization of a man, they cannot drive, they cannot practice sport, they have to hide their bodies and faces, even the clothes they buy have to be experienced at home. What does this election mean? An incentive to Saudi Arabia? A prize for good work, but what work? Who won with this election? No, Saudi Arabia is not the only state in this United Nations commission that discriminates against women. There are many more! But Saudi Arabia does not disguise, by far, what it thinks about women. This is the United Nations' greatest shame ever.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, we can all agree that Saudi Arabia being elected to the UN body that is supposed to promote and defend women’s rights is both preposterous and absurd. But whenever something like this happens on the international stage we get a chorus of right-wing nationalists bashing the UN and international cooperation, when in fact the opposite is what we need. Unfortunate situations like Saudi Arabia’s election come about because governments do not assume their responsibilities on human rights and gender equality, and choose to follow narrow national interests. That applies, unfortunately, also to some EU Member States. The UN, similar to our European Union, cannot function effectively without the political will of governments. So, instead of simply bashing the UN, let us ask ourselves if we have done enough to promote women’s rights and gender equality in the world and in the Middle East. Have our own governments stepped up to the plate to promote these values at home and abroad, and how can we strengthen international collaboration and cooperation?

name: Ana GOMES
text: - The election of Saudi Arabia to the Commission on the Status of Women at the UN is revolting and makes it mandatory, here and here, that Saudi Arabia be confronted with the systematic violations of women's rights. In the report on the European Union's relations with Saudi Arabia that I drafted and which this Parliament approved in 2014, we describe the medieval regime that oppresses and governs the country, with the worst record of gender inequality in the world, where women are unworthily subjected to. a male guardian. Therefore, it is important to ask the High Representative whether, at least, she tried to coordinate the Member States in this election at the UN, and whether she will expose the other four members, besides Belgium, who voted in favor. Perhaps they are the same ones who sell arms and support violent repression by the Saudis in Yemen and Bahrain and indirectly the Muhabi proselytism that promotes and finances extremists and terrorists around the world. It is up to European governments now to ensure that this election serves to confront the Saudi regime and also to give encouragement to women and men who, in Saudi Arabia, are fighting for freedom, human rights and justice. Women and men like Raif Badawi, Sakharov Prize still incarcerated in Saudi Arabia. (The speaker agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Karol KARSKI
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.- I have a question: We always face a dilemma in such situations, which will bring this type of choice - does the deputy also get the impression that maybe this choice, apart from its kind of negatives, also has a small positive aspect, that is, Saudi Arabia will be confrontedwith these standards, to which it will also have to refer, and this may - albeit to a small extent - put the country on the paths we would like.In other words, if the state is dragged into this procedure, it may - though not for sure - be forced to take action that benefits women's rights.

name: Ana GOMES
text: blue-card answer. – I have visited Saudi Arabia and we do not keep a dialogue with Saudi Arabia. We need to keep that dialogue and at the same time confront them – confront them in the UN and here – for the violation of human rights and of women’s rights in particular. In this way, we will be giving a very clear sign to those who are fighting for human rights and for women’s rights in Saudi Arabia, because they exist there and they need our support.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is difficult to hide the strong opposition caused by the vote that elected Saudi Arabia in the United Nations Commission on the Status of Women: it is an ultra-conservative country without rights and in which women suffer systematic discrimination. What to say? This election represents a slap in the face of common sense and there is no state reason that forbids it to be said with force and determination. Now you, Commissioner, have suggested a path steeped in political realism, which states: "it was not Europe, but some Member States that voted in favor. Now the vote has taken place, there is no going back, we work for to make things change in Riyadh ". I have the impression that this political realism of yours will have to deal with those European countries that voted "yes" to Saudi Arabia to obtain in exchange, or continue, the arms trade, and which do not have rights in mind. . And so I would like to understand from you tonight what tools the European Union wants to use to really change things in Riyadh.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I have listened very carefully to your speech and it has more or less not addressed at all the issues we are dealing with here, that is, Saudi Arabia's membership of the UN Commission on Women's Rights. I was waiting for you to tell us, for example, whether the Commission has examined which European states have elected this country, which is shamefully violating women's rights, to this body, and I would also like to know, like some other speakers, what the Commission will do to European countries in the future. better coordinate their choice in such international fora so that such disgrace does not occur in the future. In my opinion, the choice is absolutely scandalous, it is a huge shame. If we are serious about the human rights agenda in the European Union - and human rights are a key agenda for us - then it is impossible to get caught up in diplomatic phrases that Saudi Arabia is making small shifts, as you said it is making timid reforms, timid changes. . I think that a radical and clear position for the European Commission is needed.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, we have a provocative decision, the election of Saudi Arabia as a member of the UN Commission on the Status of Women. An unacceptable decision for a country where human rights do not apply, women are oppressed, it is forbidden to leave the house unaccompanied and they are not even allowed to drive a car. A country where executions are on the agenda, a country on which ISIS jihadists rely. This is reality. And we have 47 of the 54 countries, including five European Union member states, that have supported the Saudi election. It is a given that what happened was a transaction. The states that made this election, purely for reasons of economic interests, have challenged reality itself and this must be condemned, because instead of having the rule of law, we have the right of the strong.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: – Mr President, the EU enjoys both a long-established relationship and a constructive dialogue with Saudi Arabia, which is an important partner in the unstable Middle East region. Nevertheless, the EU should not turn a blind eye to the worsening human-rights situations in the country, particularly when it comes to women’s rights. Saudi discrimination against women is visible in law and in practice. Unfortunately women in Saudi Arabia continue not to have equal rights with men. They are forced to live under the oppressive male guardianship system which enables men to maintain control over female relatives. From this perspective, I do not believe that Saudi Arabia’s election as a member of the UN Commission on the Status of Women will promote women’s rights, empower women or bring about gender equality in the world. Therefore I call on the EU to monitor the human-rights situation in the country closely and to become more actively involved in guaranteeing the rights of women.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, "a girl has nothing but her veil and her grave": is a famous proverb from Saudi Arabia, the same country which has been given full membership in the Commission for the next four years. United Nations on the status of women. The royal decree of last May certainly, yes, graciously canceled a series of rules that portrayed women as a handicapped being, but we can perhaps forget that in that country women have to submit to a guardian who accompanies any important decision, from birth. , to travel, to death? Who can't show themselves in public without being accompanied by a man, let alone ride any vehicle, even a bicycle? Someone said that this entrance serves as an encouragement to them. Instead, I say it is a shame, and it is a shame for us, and especially for the Member States of the Union who voted in favor. Colleagues, Commissioner, all of this happened while Raif Badawi, our Sakharov prize, is still in prison. I remind you that consistency and principles are worth more than a handful of weapons sold for another handful of petrodollars.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - Mr President, I was also surprised by the Commissioner's words because he had virtually no comments on the subject. He did use words about the shyness of those reforms, saying that we were seeing some progress on the basis, for example, that women could re-drive or marry under a permit. This comes to me as proof of how misunderstood this debate by the Commission was. He wants to tell me this story: at the lowest level, as far as I know, women are now allowed to vote in Saudi Arabia, and if two women joyfully talked about it and danced that they could vote, then the latter answered the first in the joke, which she asked her why she hadn't made the election. Well, she couldn't drive, no one drove her there. I think this is illustrated by a picture from Saudi Arabia. A goat has really become a gardener, and if Saudi Arabia is on the committee responsible for women's emancipation and women's rights around the world, that is certainly reprehensible.

name: Christos STYLIANIDES
text: on behalf of the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Mr President, dear colleagues, you can realise my uncomfortable, personal position. You know well, and I share your concerns and I take note of your observations and your suggestions. Definitely all of you know well my personal strong convictions about gender equality and, of course, about LGBTI rights. Nevertheless, Saudi Arabia continues to embody the complexity of the region, and I am not here today to defend any such decision. But I hope that constructive engagement after the new reality and a frank dialogue on issues of common interest will yield results. In this sense, this election to the UN Commission on the Status of Women will put the burden on the country to deliver and to show that it is determined to make real advances in this crucial field. Of course, the first, useful step will be for Saudi Arabia to ratify the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. And the European Union, and in particular the European Commission, will naturally continue to plead for change and to assist any of our Saudi counterparts in realising their social transformation. There is no doubt that, as the European Commission, we will help any activities by the women in order to transform the social conditions and circumstances in Saudi Arabia. Thank you so much for your strong advocacy. But at the same time we have to deal with the new reality in order to improve the circumstances inside Saudi Arabia.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - It is unacceptable that Saudi Arabia is part of the United Nations CSW (Commission on the Status of Women) because it is a misogynistic country, where women suffer systematic discrimination and crimes against women are committed that go unpunished . Society is governed by the male guardianship system: parents, brothers or husbands decide whether the woman can study, have a job, receive medical treatment or obtain a driving license ... There was no option to vote against the choice of Saudi Arabia, but only 7 of the 54 countries that voted abstained. 12 EU Member States participated in this election. At least three, possibly more, voted in favor. This situation raises serious doubts about the consistency of the EU in its position vis-à-vis the United Nations. The EU Treaty establishes that the Council and the High Representative shall ensure that Member States actively and unreservedly respect the EU's foreign policy and ensure consistency in Union action. Member States must ensure that their common commitment to uphold gender equality as a fundamental human right is also reflected in a coherent position of the EU in international bodies.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - It is unacceptable that Saudi Arabia is part of the United Nations CSW (Commission on the Status of Women) because it is a misogynistic country, where women suffer systematic discrimination and crimes against women are committed that go unpunished . Society is governed by the male guardianship system: parents, brothers or husbands decide whether the woman can study, have a job, receive medical treatment or obtain a driving license ... Member States must ensure that their common commitment to uphold gender equality as a fundamental human right is also reflected in a coherent position of the EU in international bodies.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - It is unacceptable that Saudi Arabia is part of the United Nations CSW (Commission on the Status of Women) because it is a misogynistic country, where women suffer systematic discrimination and crimes against women are committed that go unpunished . Society is governed by the male guardianship system: parents, brothers or husbands decide whether the woman can study, have a job, receive medical treatment or obtain a driving license ... There was no option to vote against the choice of Saudi Arabia, but only 7 of the 54 countries that voted abstained. 12 EU Member States participated in this election. At least three, possibly more, voted in favor. This situation raises serious doubts about the consistency of the EU in its position vis-à-vis the United Nations. The EU Treaty establishes that the Council and the High Representative shall ensure that Member States actively and unreservedly respect the EU's foreign policy and ensure consistency in Union action. Member States must ensure that their common commitment to uphold gender equality as a fundamental human right is also reflected in a coherent position of the EU in international bodies.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - A few weeks ago, within the Gender Equality Commission, I had the sad honor to announce that Saudi Arabia had just been appointed member of the United Nations Commission on the Status of wife. Saudi Arabia will therefore help protect and promote gender equality and women's rights around the world. It might be a laughing matter if it weren't so appalling, dismal and outrageous! This country which considers women as being minors all their life, and therefore under permanent supervision of men. this country which forbids women to drive. This country which, in March, launched the “Women's Council”… but without women! Let's face it, Saudi Arabia's huge lobbying for this job is all about buying itself a "human rights" label to improve its deplorable image in this area. In order for Saudi Arabia to be nominated, at least five European countries had to vote in favor of the state. Europe has been complicit in this deception, and in particular Belgium and its Minister of Foreign Affairs Didier Reynders. This vote is nothing more or less than yet another violence against women's rights!

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the joint debate on: - the recommendation drawn up on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the Union, of an Agreement on Political Dialogue and Cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic ofOf Cuba, on the other hand (12502/2016 - C8-0517 / 2016 - 2016/0298 (NLE)) (rapporteur: Elena Valenciano) (A8-0232 / 2017) and - a report by Elena Valenciano on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs containing a draftnon-legislative resolution on the draft Council decision on the conclusion, on behalf of the European Union, of an Agreement on political dialogue and cooperation between the European Union and its Member States, on the one hand, and the Republic of Cuba, on the other hand (2017/2036 (INI)) (A8-0233 / 2017).

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: speaker. - Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the Council for the 2014 decision to instruct the European External Action Service to start negotiations leading to an agreement with Cuba. Europe had limited itself in its relations with the island, in December 1996, with the so-called Common Position. The European Union actually imposed a self-imposed blockade on that relationship, but actually isolating Cuba was not a good decision. Within two years, an exemplary negotiation has been carried out and concluded and, in December 2016, the Agreement on Political Dialogue and Cooperation between the European Union and its member states and Cuba was signed. The High Representative deserves the recognition of this Parliament for having promoted the change of decision, for having promoted this Agreement and for having led the negotiation politically. We are going to succeed in closing, in part, the map of political relations between the European Union and Latin America and the Caribbean. Cuba stops being the exception with this Agreement, and I think that is good news. Thus, it joins the rest of the Latin American and Caribbean nations with which the European Union is going to cooperate. I also want to congratulate Cuba for this step. The effective negotiation that has taken place has resulted in an international political Agreement that is as adequate as it is sophisticated and at the level of the needs of a relationship that will surely be complex and highly sensitive. It is a model Agreement of which there is much to highlight. I ask Parliament to grant its approval tomorrow to this Political Dialogue Agreement with Cuba, as our Committee on Development has done, unanimously; as our Foreign Trade Commission has done, practically unanimously; as the Foreign Affairs Committee of our House has done by a very large majority. The three committees have worked a lot and they have also given me a lot of work, but I think the result is good. The groups decided also process a Resolution; I presented a text, which I think was balanced, and the difficult part came later. Compromise after compromise, we have distilled the majority positions of this Parliament and I agree to acknowledge that I have all my colleagues to thank for accepting my limits. We have decided not to make demands, but political goals for the dialogue. We do not put conditions, but we establish challenges to a political cooperation that is now beginning, and always with respect for the sovereignty and independence of Cuba. Even so, I prefer that you look more at the Agreement than at the Resolution: I invite you to know it in detail, it is worth it. I would like all the agreements that the European Union signs from now on to be as clear and well structured as this one, and also for the way in which the European Union and the counterpart are going to work on human rights to be as clear. - by the way, a dialogue on human rights that is being very positive, as has been assured here in Parliament by the European Union's special representative for Human Rights, Mr Lambrinidis, whose work is always excellent. With the Agreement, we will all win: Cuba and us. I have no doubt that the Union is interested in cooperating with the island. This has been demonstrated by the central countries of the Union in these last two years: the President of the French Republic, the German Vice Chancellor ... all have traveled to Cuba with the same objective and, soon, the President of the Government of Spain will do so. and the King of Spain, who are preparing official visits for the next few months. We have always been interested in the relationship with Cuba. All Member States practically had bilateral agreements signed with the island, despite the Common Position, and in these years the European Union has positioned itself as the island's first customer and first supplier. It has been a great responsibility for me to be a speaker at this very important step that Cuba and the European Union are giving.Europe has a great opportunity to demonstrate to the United States, which intends to back down, that it is possible to maintain the highest level of demand with the highest level of compliance as well.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Elena Valenciano, but also all the members of this Parliament, for an excellent job done in accompanying these two years, two and a half years, of negotiations, which have been difficult, important, courageous , on our part and on the part of our Cuban counterpart, and which have brought us today, with the vote tomorrow, to a very important step. I share with Elena Valenciano the assessment that the political signal, I would almost say the cultural signal, of this passage is extremely important, not only for relations between the European Union and the island, but also as a strong sign of total commitment of the European Union in our partnership with all of Latin America and the Caribbean. It is a commitment that takes concrete form in many aspects, with bilateral relations with very different countries: sometimes we make the mistake of thinking that Latin America and the Caribbean are a single coherent bloc, while there are extremely different situations. The strength of Europe, the strength of the European Union - I think you know this very well in this House - lies in the fact that it is able to build relationships of commitment, dialogue and even cooperation and partnership, in some cases, with all of Latin America and the Caribbean, in a sense and in a spirit of frankness, of open friendship, also by addressing difficult issues with a sense of cooperation that derives from very strong ties: cultural ties, historical ties, even economic ties and politicians, in some cases, that Europe has always maintained, including with Cuba. They have been two years of courageous, exemplary path, as Elena Valenciano said, in some cases, which testified to a true commitment of the European Union to dialogue. We have made part of this journey together with the American administration, in parallel. I believe it is even more fundamental, today that some in Washington are investing more in a change of pace, again, to reaffirm that the European Union does not change its mind, does not change the course of its policy and proceeds in a courageous, open way, without taboos. , firmly on the path of commitment, dialogue, cooperation with Cuba and with all Cubans. Because our friendship, our agreement will allow us to accompany the whole island, all Cuban citizens, in the process of social, economic and political modernization that has been initiated since 2008 by the island's authorities. A process that will certainly be difficult, complex, in which the European Union will be able to accompany them not only with dialogue, but also with technical expertise: in some sectors it can be extremely useful. The agreement is not only a political dialogue agreement, but it is also a cooperation agreement that opens up the possibility of working together on many key sectors for the European Union as well, from cooperation on global issues in international forums to cooperation on regional issues . Let us not underestimate the role that Cuba can play in helping to resolve or understand some of the crises in the region which are also fundamental for the European Union - I am thinking of Venezuela, first of all. It is an agreement that allows us to initiate sectoral dialogues and cooperation in very important sectors, from the protection of artistic heritage, to cultural cooperation, energy, migration, the environment sector, scientific cooperation and many others, including dialogue. on human rights. Elena Valenciano said it very well: this dialogue that we have initiated and of which I know - our Special Representative for Human Rights, Stavros Lambrinidis, has reported to this Parliament - is possible exactly because the European Union has moved on, it has engaged in a respectful dialogue, recognizing the differences there they are in terms of the political system, even of values ​​in some cases, but also the points of convergence of some values. I believe that this open, frank, constructive and respectful dialogue can be an extremely useful basis, also for this Parliament, as we move forward with the provisional entry into force of the agreement, with ratification by the Member States, in an extremely pragmatic but also transparent approach, which bears fruit. And I believe that this commitment, this way of committing ourselves as equals, without having lessons to give, but by making our experience available and affirming a friendship with the Cuban people, first of all, can be a useful way to go. I would like to sincerely thank not only Elena Valenciano, but also all of you and the commissions who have been involved in this process, which I know was particularly intense. I would like to share with you the satisfaction I experienced in December last year, when we signed the agreement with the Cuban Foreign Minister in Brussels, with the clear and distinct feeling of having turned a historical page. I believe it is fundamental for the credibility of the European Union in the region, but also in the world, that this becomes the way we deal with situations that have been difficult for years: with respect, without hiding from us the problems we have and will continue to have, but with the firm will to work for dialogue, for openness, for cooperation, to accompany the modernization process that has been started, with all its contradictions, with all its difficulties, without hiding them, but also without falling constantly in traps of ideology that belong to the past century. This is not the Europe that our citizens are asking us to have, and I believe that together - Parliament and all institutions - we have managed to offer a beautiful page of the European Union's international commitment. I would also thank on this occasion - then I will make some very brief conclusions - our Cuban counterparts, who have engaged with great openness, even mentally, with great negotiating effort during all these years of negotiations, with a great sense of respect for differencesand also for difficulties, but always looking for a solution.And I think they really showed a great ability to meet.Here I am reminded of the words Pope Francis used in his last visit to Cuba, when he said that the island can be the capital of a crossroads, a bridge, of many worlds: north, south, east and west..I believe that this agreement of ours, your vote tomorrow, somehow honors this idea of the island as a bridge with which the European Union, all of Europe, has decided to build a commitment.

name: Frank ENGEL
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. - Mr President, limiting myself to development issues, because that has been my role, I would simply like to say that this agreement is certainly good news. It will now usefully frame the aid and support that the European Union provides to the Cuban people. In terms of development, we will always focus on aspects of food self-sufficiency, which is essential, and sustainable energy production, which is a sector of the future for Cuba. The only pitfall is that Cuba is now classified as a high middle-income country and therefore the European Union's development cooperation instrument may soon no longer apply to it. It will be necessary to take this into account when we revise this instrument, because it would be a shame if the cooperation effort that we are maintaining with Cuba - an envelope of 50 million euros until 2020 - simply comes to a halt. because we classify this country in a specific income category. In conclusion, I will say again that we all hope that through more exchanges, also economic, we will contribute gradually but effectively to instill socio-economic, social and political changes in Cuba that will go in the direction of our dialogue on the human rights.

name: Luis de GRANDES PASCUAL
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Mrs Mogherini, ladies and gentlemen, I will begin by saying that I have no doubts, and neither does my group, about the advisability and the opportunity that the European Parliament represents tomorrow in favor of both the Agreement and the accompanying Resolution. And not because the European Union ever overstepped the Common Position, but to overcome the paralysis of a fortunately terminal regime. The European Union makes a brave bet and the United States also, in the hope that a new time will begin for the new Cuban generations. And we, ladies and gentlemen, must accompany that effort. The Resolution has been the right place for the European Parliament to express itself with greater freedom and the moment of the nuances and the formulas for meeting. In the Resolution we have highlighted the commitments that the Republic of Cuba is assuming with the European Union and the responsibility and willingness of both parties to comply with the terms of the Agreement. The European Union urges the Cuban Government to align its human rights policy with the international norms defined in the international letters, declarations and instruments to which Cuba is or should be a signatory. The role of the European Union is to help the economic and political transition in Cuba, promoting the evolution towards democratic and electoral norms that respect the basic rights of all citizens and that promote trade in the region, as well as economic cooperation. Our Group demands that the Cuban authorities open a democratic process that includes full respect for human rights, freedom of the media, the right to free expression, assembly and association, and access to information in all its areas. forms, and culminate in free elections. I am grateful to the rapporteur in that, as far as possible, she opened up to the opinion of others, through commitments that unite many.Unanimity is not always possible, but there is agreement on important issues.This way we have been able to improve the initial report.I trust that this Agreement will serve for a better Cuba and, what is more important, for the lives of Cubans.It is an opportunity that we cannot miss: the train of hope, ladies and gentlemen, passes for the Cuban people and they must take it.We hope, we hope that all this leads unequivocally to a democracy without surnames, based on the will of the Cuban people expressed by all, by political prisoners and in the street, to decide on their political, economic, social and cultural issues, and that it triumphfreedom.

name: Pier Antonio PANZERI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in thanking Elena Valenciano for the excellent work done, I stress that with this resolution a new chapter is being written in the history of the relationship between Cuba and the European Union. However, this is not the final chapter, as the most important work starts right now, from this text. The document we are discussing today must be taken as a starting point for deepening dialogue and cooperation with the island, including with regard to human rights. Cuba needs to work to eliminate the numerous and varied forms of discrimination that still afflict its society and which do not allow respect for the fundamental principles of man. It is imperative that this country increases the pace of its race towards the fulfillment of these rights, and we are convinced that the agreement will be useful for all this and that it will be able to offer its citizens the conditions for a more dignified life. It is also advisable for the European Union to identify effective tools in measuring the parameters for the successful implementation of the agreements between Europe and Cuba. It is up to both of us to evaluate progress if we want Cuba to be able to take this important path and generate, as we hope, good fruits.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: for the ECR Group.- Sir.Chairman!Cuba is a country in which we have neither great strategic nor commercial interest on the part of the EU, and therefore an agreement such as the one concluded should only be implemented on the premise that it brings significant benefits to the Cuban people who have lived under communist for decades.dictatorship.Therefore, in this context, the most important thing for the ECR Group is that the guarantees and agreements concluded in the areas of human rights improvement, individual rights and labor rights, and in particular the relationship between religiously and politically persecuted, are followed up by action by the Commission.page.Otherwise, it does not make much sense to conclude co - operation agreements with communist dictatorships that are far from the EU and in which we have no immediate strategic interests.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr. President, ladies and gentlemen, in the ALDE political group we maintain a firm position on the situation of human rights in Cuba and, therefore, we wanted to accompany this vote of consent with a Resolution where we express our concerns. Furthermore, we cannot forget that the defense and promotion of human rights is one of our foreign policy priorities. Within the framework of this Agreement, human rights dialogues have been held with Cuba and no progress has been made. Still, to this day, the Cuban government continues to repress dissent and political criticism; continues to have political prisoners and prisoners of conscience - such as Mr. Cardet, leader of the Christian Liberation Movement - in their prisons, where they receive deplorable treatment, or the case of Daniel Llorente, an opponent accused of public disorder and resistance, who has been locked up in a psychiatric. Freedom of movement is still restricted: just last month, Saily Navarro, Lady in White, who we had officially invited to an event in this Parliament, was prevented from traveling. The Agreement establishes a suspension clause in the event of human rights violations. This Parliament and the European Union cannot ignore the involution of basic freedoms in Cuba and, therefore, it is their duty to monitor the situation and respect for human rights on the island. To conclude, I would like to borrow a few words from the Cuban artist and activist Tania Bruguera, who in this Parliament, on the occasion of that same event, said: «I hope that we can see Cuba not only as a place of investment, but also as a country where citizens can be free. I share the same wish and I also hope that the European Union does not turn its back on Cuban civil society.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr. President, we celebrate the forthcoming signing of the Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement between the European Union and the Republic of Cuba, a bilateral agreement built with a frank dialogue, respect between the parties, and open to all issues: this is how we understand the international relations. In addition, we celebrate this Agreement because it supposes the definitive burial of the infamous Common Position promoted by the "helper from the Azores" trying to emulate, as a bad copy, the policy of aggression that the United States has maintained against Cuba to achieve a government submissive your interests. We will vote in favor of the Recommendation granting approval of this Agreement. On the contrary, we will not do the same with the report of the motion for a non-legislative resolution. It should be noted - and it is fair - that the first version that the rapporteur, Mrs. Valenciano, produced was balanced, it was weighted, and all the groups could have signed it. But since the devil is in the details, certain groups have turned this report, which has good things, into something that perverts the Agreement, which looks like a Resolution that examines Cuba, which aims to protect it to reach a transition to neoliberal taste. Some in this House should learn the lessons of history: if for more than fifty years the greatest power has not managed to subdue an island small in population, but great in dignity and sovereignty, there is little that the version of the soft disguise that drinks can do, deep down, from Miami extremism.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, tomorrow is an important day, we are going to validate the Agreement. First of all, I want to thank the Foreign Service and the High Representative for the speed and good work of these negotiations. I think it has been a diplomatic success that is above all yours, Mrs Mogherini. So thank you very much and congratulations. I also wish to congratulate the rapporteur on a good job. As the high representative has said, we turn the page of history. We open a new stage and tomorrow we begin to walk on a new path. The only thing I have to regret is that some groups in this House have included elements in the text of the resolution that are more typical of the past, of the Common Position, than of the future. And the Common Position was not a good tool in relation to the island: it was clumsy, it was ineffective, it was dogmatic, and fortunately we have left it behind. And the high representative has said it: the new context with the Trump Administration raises questions, and it is here where the European Union has to become strong and has to prop up the new scenario that President Obama opened and that now we have the responsibility to help keep pushing.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - Mr President, there are few times in these years that, as an MEP, I have felt proud of this European Union. The Agreement on Political Dialogue and Cooperation between the European Union and Cuba today makes me a proud European citizen. Sustainable agriculture, food security, support for the best use of natural resources, vital for sustainable development, and the commitment to inclusive economic and social modernization: this is music to our ears and for the well-being of our soul and conscience human. I hope that this Agreement represents for Cuba a firm step towards the conquest of its full rights, as a sovereign people, and of civil and democratic liberties. Furthermore, it is appropriate to point out the path that has led to this Agreement: the will to have a respectful dialogue meeting, founded on the sovereignty and independence of Cuba and that of the European Union. The Resolution that will be voted on not only represents an agreement on cooperation for development and political dialogue between Europe and Cuba, but also represents an exemplary model to be replicated in other realities and by all developing countries in the world.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: - Mr President, the unacceptable resolution promoted by the European Union and the European Parliament is an organized plan to penetrate European monopolies and set up reactionary mechanisms for non-governmental organizations in Cuba. Both the US embargo and the European Union's intervention are directed against the Cuban people. The European Union and its governments of imperialist wars and interventions, the 20 million officially unemployed and the tens of millions living below the poverty line are pointing the finger at human rights at the Cuban people who for decades have eradicated unemployment and unemployment. abolition of human-to-human exploitation. In a country that, despite sanctions, has achieved tangible achievements for the capitalist countries of Latin America and the Caribbean. We condemn the long-standing blockade of US imperialism and the European Union's intervention in Cuba. We stand resolutely on the side of the Cuban people and express our solidarity with the Cuban revolution.

name: José Ignacio SALAFRANCA SÁNCHEZ-NEYRA
text: - Mr President, High Representative, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow Parliament will grant, by a large majority, its approval to the Agreement on Political Dialogue and Cooperation with Cuba. Parliament has wanted this approval to be accompanied by a Resolution. It is surprising that some political groups have opposed this Resolution, but it is even more surprising that those political groups that have unconditionally defended the Government of Cuba are those that, in a pirouette that is difficult to justify, oppose the agreement with Canada. It is very difficult from a perspective of defending freedom, in which this Parliament is always situated, for one to oppose a Resolution that only has three observations: first, that, on a hierarchy of values, the European Union bases its agreements in a democratic clause, in this case as in the rest of the cases. Second, the situation in which dissidents, peaceful dissidents, independent journalists and human rights defenders live; and third, a Resolution that remembers the courageous Cubans who were awarded the Sakharov Prize: Guillermo Fariñas, the Ladies in White and, of course, Oswaldo Payá, whose words echo in this chamber, saying that he had no hatred in his heart, but that he was not going to be dominated by fear. Madam High Representative, you have referred to the words of Pope Francis. I think that one of the most astute diagnoses that has been made about the situation in Cuba is that made by Pope John Paul II: that the world opens up to Cuba and that Cuba opens up to the world. The European Union is opening up to Cuba today, but, unfortunately, Cuba has not yet opened up to the world and, therefore, I hope, I hope, and we ask that this Agreement serve, at least, so that harassment, persecution and the imprisonment of the Cuban opposition, end.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: - Mr President, I join in congratulating, Mrs Mogherini, Mrs Valenciano. I believe that it is very important for the European Union to occupy this political space that opens the door to relations with Cuba. Of course, it is important to end the Common Position, which did not give results, and it is above all important to take advantage of what geopolitics calls "the space left by the American Administration", which seems to want to reverse Obama's positions. But I think it is also important for Cuba because democracy and human rights in Cuba - which I believe is an objective that we all have - will be favored with this Agreement. Because this is going to help the reformist forces in Cuba. There are reformist forces, within the regime and outside it, that will take advantage of this opening and this Agreement to promote democracy. We have found the opposite: that hostility reinforces immobility. That is why this Agreement is important and that is why we have taken a fair and intelligent step on this occasion.

name: Bas BELDER
text: - The Cuban Commission on Human Rights and National Reconciliation reported in January 478, in February 482, in March 432, in April 475 and in May 373 politically motivated and arbitrary arrests. Tellingly, there were no public protests from the EU side against these restrictions on freedom. A European condemnation of the Castro regime would have been appropriate, necessary and justified on the basis of these facts. By its silence, the EU legitimizes the restrictions on freedom of Cuban dissidents. Surely that cannot be the aim of the intended political dialogue between Brussels and Havana! Also of great importance is the dominant influence of the Cuban military on the country's economy. I would like to hear how the EU deals with this obvious fact in its relationship with Cuba. Finally, I ask for your support for my amendment which calls for the Cuban churches to be given full freedom to provide social and economic aid to all citizens in need and to receive aid themselves from Europe and elsewhere in the world. Who can be against this fully humanitarian aid? Neither do you, Madam rapporteur, as you did in committee. Think about it!

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: – Mr President, let me start, Madam Vice-President, by saying that ALDE and myself will vote in favour of the agreement and the resolution exactly because the resolution sends out a clear message on what we expect from the implementation. May I say that we have a person that has been in prison in Cuba for 16 years that is one of the key representatives of the Cuban opposition, and in his presence I would like to read out a message that we are getting from them: ‘We are Encuentro Nacional Cubano, an open assembly representing more than 60 independent entities, civil and political organisations, both from Cuba and from the Cuban community in exile. We take note of the decision of the European Union to start a new chapter of relationship with Cuba by concluding a new treaty of cooperation with the current Cuban Government. We understand and appreciate the role of the European Parliament for taking an active stance for the defence of human rights in the process of its ratification and having this important debate. But having said that, we would like to remind you, referring to the fundamental values and elementary principles the European Union itself is based upon: it is the Cuban people and not just those in power right now who must be an essential and indispensable party to this treaty. We call on you to insist that the application must not be adjusted just to the wishes of the current power holders, a totalitarian military junta whose only is just to keep themselves in power and preserve their privileges to the detriment of the Cuban people. We appeal to you to express your support clearly to the just demands of the freedom-loving Cubans who observe today’s debate, united in a common goal to bring their beloved country peacefully from the current misery to the path of democracy, the respect for undeniable human rights and economic prosperity. Last sentence. We ask you to urge the EU institutions not only to assist Cuba on the path of economic recovery and development, but at the same time to help materially the emerging bodies of the Cuban independent civil society. ... (Interrupted by the President)

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I have repeatedly expressed my belief that the Agreement on Cooperation and Political Dialogue is a strong framework for the development of equal relations between the peoples of Europe and Cuba. I have emphasized that this joint effort must be governed by the principles of reciprocity and cooperation, without conditions but also without discrimination. The fact that it took only two years to complete the negotiations, given the different views, is due to the fact that both sides showed mutual trust, respected the political commitments and worked with the necessary dedication. On the contrary, despite the rapporteur's great effort, it is unfortunate that some political groups have tried to turn Parliament's resolution into a human rights resolution. This has not happened again and the political expediencies are obvious. However, I believe that the approval of the agreement by the European Parliament and the speedy completion of the ratification by the competent authorities of the Member States will be in the best interests of all.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: - Mr. President, the agreement that we are going to sign with Cuba must serve as a priority two objectives: to advance the democratic transition of the country and to improve the economic situation of Cuban citizens. This is not a carte blanche given to the Cuban authorities. We must remain vigilant because, despite the apparent openness of the Cuban system, the human rights situation remains very worrying and the human rights dialogue established with this country has not yet borne fruit. I am thinking in particular of journalists and human rights defenders who suffer from persecution, including the 2010 Sakharov Prize winner Guillermo Fariñas. I am also thinking of political and public prisoners who are detained for exercising their freedom of expression and assembly. The lack of judicial independence and the denial of freedom of movement for the great majority of Cubans are elements on which the European Union must show the greatest firmness.

name: Norbert NEUSER
text: - Mr President, High Representative, dear Elena!We were in Havana together a year ago and saw what a good job our EU delegation is doing.Now there is an agreement - it is good, necessary and overdue.We can now achieve more when it comes to respecting human rights.But Trump and the U.S. administration are threatening to cut back developing relationships.We must therefore work together to ensure that this US embargo is not tightened again and that it has no impact on the EU.It cannot be that the US is imposing fines on European companies or European banks because the US is torpedoing trade and investments between Cuba and the EU.Affected European companies and our banks must be better protected in order to ensure the sustainable development of Cuba.

name: Lars ADAKTUSSON
text: – Madam President, the Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement (PDCA) is an opportunity to bring hope to a nation in need of freedom and democracy. We all know that the EU could make a difference. We have a unique negotiating position but also a moral obligation to stand up for the oppressed and abused people of Cuba. However, any normalisation of relations with a dictatorship needs to include conditions for democratic reform and respect for human rights. Regretfully, that is not the case with Cuba. The PDCA establishes a dialogue on human rights. At the same time, no specific demand on the regime is presented by the Commission, a fact that has been described as a political victory for the communist regime. The brave men and women of the political opposition in Cuba have advised us, the European Parliament, not to support the Treaty. Personally, I will follow that advice and, dear colleagues, I urge you to do the same.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: - Madam President, Madam High Commissioner, I welcome the political dialogue and cooperation agreement with Cuba, which I consider to be a correct option from the point of view of the European Union's foreign policy, given the importance and importance that the entire Latin American region has for the Europe. So, from that strictly foreign policy point of view, it seems to me a good option that has been made and, fortunately, that a very reasonable conclusion has been reached. I also recall that, in the initial recitals of the Agreement, the States of the European Union and Cuba affirm their respect for human rights as stipulated in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights and recall their commitment to the recognized principles of democracy, good governance and the rule of law. It turns out that we have witnessed, in recent months, flagrant situations of disrespect for human rights in Cuba: increased arbitrary arrests of opponents, intimidation of former prisoners of conscience, university students who are expelled from their universities for defending doctrinal plurality. So I finish by saying that this agreement should be welcomed. But we cannot, under any circumstances, forget those who, in Cuba, resist in the name of freedom.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, relations with non-democratic states must be based on a clear balance between economic interests and respect for basic values. This balance is not yet there because the present approach is more based on good hopes that the repressive regime can become more humane and respectful of human rights. The Cuban Ladies in White have sent a different message. They complain that there is a deafening silence from Western governments on continued human rights violations in Cuba, and they expect that the EU should take first of all the side of the Cuban people, not the regime. At this point, trade relations and its investments will not necessarily serve the Cuban people, but rather the ruling elites, enabling them to survive longer. There is a role to play for the EU, because the EU is the largest investor and main trade partner. We are in a position to pressure the Cuban government more to open up. However, trade volumes with Cuba have doubled, but the human rights situation remains a source of concern. Hence the EU’s policy toward Cuba must remain conditional on genuine opening-up of the respect of human rights and democratic changes there.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: - Madam President, in the European Parliament we will approve the Agreement on Political Dialogue and Cooperation with Cuba, which will normalize relations between the island and the Union and, furthermore, which will allow them to be fully resumed. It puts an end to twenty years of Common Position, twenty years of paternalism and blockade, which simply have not been useful, effective, to influence the island and the future of Cubans. Getting here has required the tireless work of our High Representative, Federica Mogherini, and the European Parliament rapporteur, Elena Valenciano, whom I would like to congratulate for months. But above all, the Agreement is an instrument for dialogue, cooperation and mutual understanding; an instrument that has to be able to contrast with the United States and the new Trump Administration and occupy the enormous space that it leaves free; an instrument to effectively influence the island, to improve the lives of Cubans, to improve our political, commercial and economic ties; and, above all, to gain dialogue and presence in Latin America, a strategic region for the Union in its foreign policy.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Madam President, the Political Dialogue and Cooperation Agreement aims to fully normalize the Union's relations with Cuba, since the island was one of the few countries that did not have an agreement of this type with the European Union. Cuba is in a decisive stage, which I believe can mark its future. The relay in the historical leaderships of the island will soon continue. The winds of change are blowing in Cuba and it is convenient for the Union to develop its full potential there, which will happen thanks to this Agreement. I hope it will contribute not only to political modernization, but also to economic modernization and the prosperity of a Cuban people with a very low standard of living. The Agreement does not mean that we abdicate our principles and values ​​in matters of human rights, pluralist democracy and respect for fundamental freedoms. The Agreement, and the Resolution that we will test tomorrow - sections 7 to 14 - insist on these principles. I would like to underline sections 7 and 12, on human rights defenders and the necessary release of political prisoners. And I also want to highlight the fact that the Agreement includes - I think I have a minute and a half, President - an institutionalized dialogue on human rights ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: – Madam President, after quite an unexpected change in the Cuba-US relations, I was hoping that there is a chance for a better future for the Cuban people. Unfortunately, from the information we have received, the oppressions have got even worse. This seems to be also confirmed by the number of arbitrary detentions in the recent months and a letter from the Damas de Blanco to the President Trump administration. In order to be able to proceed with this agreement, in my opinion, the European Parliament, which stands for the protection of human rights and is the Parliament which condemns exercising any sort of pressure of governments on their people, I think we should demand respect for human rights, especially considering the fact that Sakharov Prize winners still have the problems with leaving Cuba and returning safely to their homeland. I believe the economic implications cannot be treated as more important than the respect for human life and wellbeing of the citizens.

name: Laima Liucija ANDRIKIENĖ
text: - I think we can welcome the EU-Cuba political dialogue and cooperation agreement.It is not perfect, as always, it is a political compromise that the countries have managed to reach.It reflects our pragmatic view that at least what is set out in the agreement will be implemented.I emphasize that the progress of EU-Cuba relations must be based on the further democratization of Cuban society and respect for human rights.The EU should apply the principle of more, more for more: taking into account progress in Cuban public life, the exercise of citizens' right to vote and to stand for election, giving more space to civil society and private business.Human rights guarantees must not be called into question, otherwise our agreement with Cuba will become a non-honorable deal.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: - Madam President, I do not know if I and my generation will see a true European political union; I don't know if we will see the end of the social dislocations that part of globalization is producing; I do not know if my generation and I will see the end of the fatal attraction of a part of our societies by authoritarian regimes, a product of our insecurities caused by this globalization. What I do know that my generation and I will see is the end of the dictatorship and the arrival of freedom and democracy for our Cuban brothers. That is my wish, which is absolutely compatible with any action taken to improve that peaceful transition on the island towards democracy. I believe that the task that our Vice-President Mogherini and many European diplomats are carrying out is worthy of being followed in that dialogue and cooperation that they want to carry out, of course, and like any action whose ultimate goal is to facilitate the democratic future of the Cuban people, So I respect, desire and support her. Yes, I turn to the European left, to the democratic left, and I tell them: don't add another brick to the Cuban Berlin Wall.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: We now come to the catch-the-eye procedure, and I will take one person from every group that has come forward.Speakers came from only three political groups.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Karol KARSKI
text: - Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen! The example of Cuba shows that the most important thing for a state is not that it respects human rights, but that it is a democratic one, but that it is a stable state. If this state persists, if its government persists, ultimately those relations are established with it. And in this case, there is a sort of realism. On the other hand, I would like to appeal to just one thing - because this agreement will be concluded, as you can see - that its content, as well as further implementation, include at least the most general reference to the need to respect human rights. Many times - when we visited, for example as a DROI committee in different countries - even such general references allowed us to ask about these basic human rights issues and gave us an institutional, legal title, in order to make the performance of the agreement dependent on the state of observance of human rights.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Mr. Millán Mon, I just want to explain to you that the information reached us that we should give Mr. Preda 30 seconds more and 30 seconds less for you;so there was only one minute for you.Sorry, that's the information we got.There is no discussion.Sorry, I can't discuss this right now.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: - Madam President, from my group we support the European Union-Cuba Agreement, which implies the normalization of relations. We are going to vote against the resolution that is proposed for interference. We reject the European Instrument for Democracy and Human Rights, which aims to finance the opposition and promote regime change in Cuba. Relations and dialogue with Cuba have to start from scrupulous respect for its decisions, without interference and without trying to impose changes that the Cuban people do not decide. The blockade imposed by the United States on Cuba limits the development of its people and its ties with the European Union and, in terms of human rights - I said in another speech yesterday - let's fix our house first, because in the Spanish State there are Trade unionists imprisoned for exercising the right to strike, obstacles and impediments are placed on journalists and the Government delegate in Galicia acknowledges that they control, monitor and investigate people who regularly attend demonstrations. And we still dare to teach human rights lessons to others.

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, with tomorrow's vote we will definitively leave behind the common position governing relations with Cuba adopted back in 1996. This is a historic and unique opportunity to relaunch a process with a country that certainly presents important critical issues in terms of respect for human rights, but which has also suffered immensely from an absurd embargo that has brought an entire population to its knees from a social and health point of view. Just pointing the finger, highlighting only the shortcomings of our partners, closing in ideological clashes overtaken by history: this is what some wanted, who also use very different meters with other partners. But it would be useless for the Cuban people and not worthy of the Union we must be. Tomorrow, on the other hand, begins a path that is certainly challenging but essential for a partnership of friendship and sustainable development, to make our nations and the entire Cuban people turn the page. And we want to follow this path together with the Cuban people.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to say that I appreciate the unity of this Parliament, because it is true that we have had - you have had - different tones, different accents, but great determination has already been expressed in the votes of the competent committees on the need to turn the page and make sure that our Union can be, as it should be, I believe, not one of the actors in our work with the island and with Latin America as a whole, but the key actor for relations with everything the Cuban people. I remember very well the last time we had a debate in this House on Cuba, I believe it was about a year and a half ago: many of you complained about a certain delay, a certain absence of the European Union, which saw the United States of America, traditionally, economically, politically, socially and culturally less close and engaged in a dialogue with the island, be instead the forerunners of an opening - as has rightly been said - a reciprocal opening, on which it is necessary take a lot of steps on both sides.
