Today we are definitely in another post, today we are definitely facing a change of pace in which the European Union represents for the island, for the rest of Latin America and the Caribbean, but also for the rest of the world, for a certain concept of international relations and relations in the regions of the world, and also for the multilateral system represented by the United Nations, the fixed point on which we can count. Our path is always this: dialogue, frank, constructive, sincere commitment, without hiding any of the difficult and tiring elements of our confrontation, but always dialogue, openness and commitment, looking forward and not looking back. Few points: there is a political importance of the agreement - it was mentioned here - including for the dynamics regional, there is an economic importance, given the commitment of investments and trade relations between Europe and Cuba, there is a social importance, given the possibility and responsibility that the European Union has to accompany the island modernization process. I would like to underline the fact that the position of the European Union and this Parliament is, and remains, that of opposing the embargo and its extraterritorial effects. There is a dimension related to democracy and human rights. I would like to underline the fact, which some of you in this House recalled, that it is precisely Cuban civil society that supports this agreement, which asks us to implement it in all its parts, precisely because it represents a channel for dialogue, partnership, of cooperation, and I would invite colleagues who have not done so to at least read the agreement, because it is clear that the part on human rights dialogue is an integral and fundamental part of the agreement. And it is thanks to this political commitment that we have initiated, that we have also started a dialogue on human rights, frank, difficult, but constructive with Cuba. I believe that today, tomorrow, the most important work begins, namely the implementation of the agreement in all its parts, and I count on the support and accompaniment of this Parliament, in all its competent committees, to be able to do it in the best possible way.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: speaker. - Madam President, thank you very much, Mrs Mogherini, for your words and for her commitment. I am going to ask you for a small favor: tell Mr Juncker that we are working very late today in Parliament. Well, I think that on the road to political dialogue with Cuba we will see if the results that we all hope are achieved. I think so. In the work of preparing the approval, the Accord, I have seen that there is a large majority in the House in favor. It is true that the Resolution has been very conflictive, because where the political groups put the main thing in their ideology, as has been seen, the distance is enormous. Cuba is Cuba, it is a very important international actor, as it has shown on many occasions; without going any further, in the very important dialogue for peace in Colombia. And there are many things that we would like to change in Cuba, as in many of the countries with which we have relations - of course we do - but it is up to the Cubans to follow this path, as we Spaniards did, or the Poles, or all the peoples of Europe. It is their turn to make the journey. It is up to us to dialogue, cooperate from the defense of our values, of course, and trying to understand the other. I want to thank all my colleagues for their interventions and, very particularly, the shadow rapporteurs for this report, Javier Couso, from the GUE; Ernest Urtasun, from the Greens; Teresa Jiménez, from ALDE; and Luis de Grandes, from the European People's Party. As you can see, a cast of Spanish MEPs. For us, the answer to whether the relationship between Cuba and the European Union is profound is very clear. It is. For Spain it is and, therefore, for Europe it must also be. When something is difficult in politics, only rigor, generosity, flexibility and a few doses of patience can find the optimal solution. I ask that, as Parliament, we allow the European Union and its Member States accompany Cuba in its future, on the path that they decide, because it is its people who must do it, always based on sovereignty, independence and freedom, which are also our values.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The joint debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 5 July 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Theodor Dumitru STOLOJAN
text: signed up. - I welcome the conclusion of this agreement with Cuba. However, this agreement is not a trade and investment promotion agreement. Any future step in this direction will have to find a solution for the regulation of Cuba's old debts to some former socialist countries, including Romania, made during the functioning of the Council for Mutual Economic Assistance (CAER). At the time of its dissolution, Romania had a debt to Cuba of about 1.3 billion transferable rubles, coming from trade in goods and services between the two countries. It should be noted that Romania, in the 6th and 7th decades of the last century, when it wanted to restore normal trade and cooperation relations with Western countries, the first condition was for Romania to recognize its old debts committed by the Romanian state and canceled by the communist regime that came to power after the Second World War. The last old debt settlement took place with Sweden in 2001-2004. Any country that recognizes the rule of law cannot simply cancel its public debts. If it has difficulties, there are international mechanisms and practices for regulating them. This is the lesson learned by Romania, since the socialist regime.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Elmar Brok, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs and Silvia Costa, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on the future EU strategy for international cultural relations (2016/2240 (INI))(A8-0220 / 2017).

name: Elmar BROK
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, High Representative, dear Vice-President, my colleagues! We had the funeral for Helmut Kohl here on Saturday. I think it became clear in what way the depth and diversity of European culture is expressed - as a supporting element. Culture in its diversity and commonality is a decisive factor in Europe's attractiveness. Ortega y Gasset once said: four fifths of the culture of European countries are the same, one fifth differentiates us. Today we do not see this as a conflict, but as a common wealth. This Europe came together through this path and the experiences we had. This could be an example - also for other parts of the world. This Europe, in which we overcome borders and understand culture not as a contradiction but as a common wealth, can also be a message to other parts of the world in order to make a contribution as a soft power, to make peace and at the same time to promote to be for us - in a very sober sense. I think that with a cultural diplomacy, dear Ms. Mogherini, we can also use this as one of the instruments as part of your global strategy. I think that for this reason we can do a lot here, as in questions of human rights policy within the framework of the United Nations, the United Nations Charter on Human Rights. We can involve this person who overcomes the limit in discussions. We should ask the Commission to include these elements in contracts to a greater extent, in order to create such links in this way. But I believe we should also use the interests of our Member States for this. I am fully aware that culture is the responsibility of the nation states and that under the treaty we only have a supporting effect. This is how you can build it up. We don't want the work of that Overcoming nation-states in securing their cultural identity, but we should also make clear to the outside world what we said in the European draft constitution: unity in diversity. That is then beneficial for the member states to participate accordingly, to use this as a common instrument and at the same time to bring about an impact in the world. I think that it is important that this should of course be done with respect for subsidiarity. But I can imagine that, for example, High Representative, we can also hold exhibitions within the framework of the delegations that we have abroad, so that smaller states in particular could present their culture there, which they cannot do on their own in such countries . It's a small start: exhibitions. As the Presidency of the Council of Estonia, Estonia is holding exhibitions on the premises of the European Union delegation abroad. The big countries are all proud to do it alone. But giving the small countries such an approach here seems to me a wonderful opportunity to represent what is common and what is different. I think that for this reason, also in cooperation with international organizations - also under the obligations that exist with the Unesco Convention and cultural diversity, we have an interesting instrument here, with which we also strengthen politics in the interests of Europe and the Member States can do.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Dear Colleagues!Now that the time is so advanced and we, if I break up every minute at one minute, the speakers are now at 12:10 a.m., I will not do a catch-the-eye procedure or take any blue cards.I ask all of you to really keep your speaking time.Under no circumstances will you get more than ten seconds.Thank you for your understanding.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Madam Vice-President Mogherini, I thank the co-rapporteur Brok and the shadow rapporteurs from the CULT and AFET committees, but also the many interlocutors from the world of culture and art who have collaborated with us on our report. Dear Vice-President Mogherini, You know very well how much we have fought in Parliament since 2011 to develop a European cultural strategy at the international level with one of our reports, which was followed by an important preparatory action up to the specific address entered in the conclusions of the Italian Presidency of 2014. I remember with emotion the important resolution of two years ago, which I see collected in your proposal, after the destruction of the cultural heritage of Nineveh and Palmyra by Daesh, with the barbaric killing of Khaled al-Asaad, for a common European commitment to the persecution of what we consider a crime against humanity. We appreciate the Commission's support for documentation and reconstruction, and the commitment to present a directive on the trafficking and import of illicit cultural property, which is the subject of a recent and important Council of Europe convention. You also know that we have fought with specific proposals to make culture and education a priority of the Commission, also under two other profiles: as an instrument of freedom, of human promotion, of intercultural and interreligious dialogue, and also to prevent radicalization. , but also as the fourth pillar of sustainable development, an engine of creativity and innovation, a new economy, quality employment, tourism. In the communication, which we greatly appreciated, we find these three areas as priority areas of a new European strategy which, while recognizing the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, intends to strengthen cooperation between the European Union and the Member States in the field of cultural relations. international. This will be good for Europe, but it will also be good for the world. Indeed, Europe has in common a great wealth of cultural, linguistic, historical and religious roots, on which it has built common values ​​and a culture of human rights, which are an instrument for understanding other cultures. This is why it is important for us that Europe recognizes, also in its external action, the value in itself of culture and cultural rights in the context of human rights, together with artistic and expressive freedom, giving coherence to the politics and actions of 'EU in the international arena, and making it truly an authoritative global player in the work of reconciliation and peace. The structured dialogue with cultural actors and stakeholders, the multi-annual partnerships with international organizations such as UNESCO and the Council of Europe, in particular for cultural heritage and trans-European cultural itineraries, will therefore be fundamental, but also the experimentation of European cultural platform. We want this strategy to be effective by including culture and education in all agreements and partnerships between Europe and third countries, starting with the renewal of Cotonou with the ACP countries. But we need good multilevel governance, as we have indicated, strong coordination between the four DGs concerned, a dedicated budget line and adequate human resources in the EEAS, with thematic and geographical priorities defined in annual and three-year plans. Each European delegation will gradually have to equip itself with a dedicated focal point, which dialogues with civil society, cultural institutions of the European Union and local authorities, with a people-to-people approach. It will be important to develop the international dimension of European programs such as Erasmus, such as Horizon, and above all greater coordination is needed to prevent and rebuild the cultural heritage at risk or destroyed, also giving life to that intervention activated by UNESCO, which unfortunately sees only the Italian participation with the blue helmet of culture.We propose to create a new international mobility program for artist residencies, aimed at young artists and culture professionals, a European cultural portal and digitization as the main use for new languages, aimed at young people, also by activating European media.We also want the current situation of refugees and migratory processes to have a strongly cultural dimension, which is essential for a future of peace.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: vicepresidente della Commissione/alto rappresentante dell'Unione per gli affari esteri e la politica di sicurezza. – Signora Presidente, onorevoli deputati, vorrei innanzitutto ringraziare Silvia Costa ed Elmar Brok per il loro ottimo lavoro. Spesso dico che l'Unione europea è una superpotenza. Non c'è dubbio alcuno che nel settore della cultura siamo una superpotenza: è il cuore stesso del nostro soft power, e finalmente abbiamo deciso di usare questa forza che abbiamo e che è unica al mondo. La relazione contiene elementi estremamente importanti per il nostro lavoro, un lavoro che abbiamo portato avanti in quest'ultimo anno in modo molto determinato e con una grande unità di intenti: il Parlamento, il Consiglio – io sono stata onorata di essere il primo Alto rappresentante a partecipare a un Consiglio sulla cultura – la Commissione, il SEAE e le nostre delegazioni sono già al lavoro con moltissime iniziative a sostegno, tra l'altro, della possibilità per i singoli Stati membri di usare la diplomazia culturale per le loro stesse agende. Veramente quello che vedo è uno sforzo di coordinamento e di sinergia interistituzionale in questo settore che mi fa ben sperare.  Culture is first of all a crucial resource for our diplomacy, opening new channels and facilitating mutual understanding, and it can help bring peace and reconciliation inside divided communities around the world. Beyond that, international cultural relations are also a resource for our economies in Europe and beyond. As Elmar was saying, this is something we have learned from our European history. European cultural excellence comes from Europe’s openness and diversity. As we have learned as Europeans, cultural exchanges make us stronger, and never weaker. It is in this spirit that the joint communication was conceived, with the focus on three pillars. The first is intercultural dialogue: the promotion of culture and intercultural dialogue for peaceful relations among countries and communities. A very good example of this is the recent agreement with Tunisia, which will become the first country from the southern shore of the Mediterranean to join the Creative Europe programme. More than ever, there is a need to create a space – I would say a common ground and a common language – to engage in cultural exchanges inside and outside our borders. Sometimes we struggle to find the right language to talk to each other or to find ways to ensure that everyone’s voice is heard. Think of young people. At times people who have difficulty in making their voice heard or finding a channel of active participation in societies in their communities, find that voice through culture, be it music or even street art, because our understanding of culture goes beyond classical music. This is also the strength of European culture. Culture can be a very powerful channel for engagement, participation and active democracy. Second, culture is a resource for growth and sustainable development, as acknowledged in the 2030 agenda for sustainable development. This is true both inside the European Union, where culture and creative industries account for over 7 million jobs, and in other regions and countries of the word. We are working with developing countries to support cultural industries, establish creative hubs, and develop professional training and competence in new technologies. I will give you one example. We have recently started to support a project called Ethical Fashion in the framework of the trust fund for Africa. We provide craftswomen and tailors from West Africa with vocational training and with the opportunity to work with fashion companies from all over the world. Some of these people are migrants who were given the opportunity to go back to their communities and, with new skills and a new job, restart a different life. Thousands of jobs have already been created through just this project alone. A third strand of our work – and I conclude – aims at reinforcing cooperation on cultural heritage. Let me say in this regard that the first ever G7 ministers meeting on culture in Florence was a very big step forward for the international community, under the Italian presidency of the G7 this year, to promote support for cultural heritage. I would like in particular to express my support for the work done by some Member States, notably Italy and Germany, to protect cultural heritage from human and natural disaster. This month I will table a paper in Council with ideas to take this work forward at European Union level. In 2018, the European Union and Member States will celebrate the European Year of Cultural Heritage. Europe has built an unrivalled expertise in the protection and restoration of cultural heritage. It is our duty and our responsibility, but also in our interest to share this with the world. When we contribute to the restoration of cultural sites in Kosovo or the rebuilding of the Sarajevo city hall, we are also contributing to stability, reconciliation, security and peace in the Balkans. This is in the heart of Europe. Our work in Timbuktu to restore the mausoleum and the library is also a way to re-launch the local economy and tourism and to prevent terrorism. We will soon sign a EUR 1 million programme with UNESCO to support the recovery and reconstruction of Syria’s cultural heritage. This is also a very important element of our fight against the financing of terrorist activities and organisations. For all these different strands of work to succeed, we need to continue our work together with all European actors and all our partners in the cultural environment sharing the same sense of direction. Parliament has been one of the strongest advocates of a European Union policy for international cultural relations. The preparatory action launched by the European Parliament in 2014 laid the groundwork for the drafting of our own joint communication, so it is now time for us to work on our first strategy for international cultural relations. This is perfectly in line – as Elmar was saying – with our global strategy for foreign and security policy that contains a strong reference to culture. I will push for a specific focus on cultural diplomacy in the next phase of the global strategies implementation. So I count on continuing our joint work, together with the European Parliament, to finally fulfil our huge potential as a cultural superpower.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Culture is included in the community policy. On the one hand it is good and on the other hand it is bad. It is not good because culture really has some potential that allows Europe to be stronger, on the other hand it is good that it is not covered by the community policy, because it is not subject to excessive bureaucracy, it can develop in a more free, diverse and individual way. What I want to point out is, first of all, on time. It must be remembered that the European Cultural Agenda had its formal start in 2007. Ten years on, we are in exactly the same situation with today's report, but without the tools at all. If the next stage comes after another ten years, it can be said that this potential will be wasted or at least not used. Second remark - one must clearly distinguish the promotion of culture because of its value in itself, because of the value of artists, institutions, museums, people, and another thing is using culture as a tool to improve the image, to communicate better. We also cannot allow some kind of schizophrenia: in this room we say that culture is a great potential, and at the same time the Horizon 2020 program has been limited, Erasmus + or Creative Europe are in trouble, financial resources are being cut that are shifted to the European Solidarity Corps. We must be consistent, very professional in this respect and remember that if we want to use culture, we must not do it rashly.

name: Julie WARD
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, culture is a political issue. It is also a political tool, and I am glad the Commission has officially recognised that meaningful cultural relations – supported by the EU, based on diversity, equality and with reciprocal partnerships and locally-based initiatives – can help address stereotypes, extremism and populism, foster intercultural dialogue, peace-making, capacity-building and community development, and promote more harmonious and cohesive societies, both in the EU and in third countries. Cultural institutions and artists from all disciplines have a key role to play, and such a strategy must be founded on people-to-people contacts and civil society involvement. In an increasingly complex and dangerous world characterised by an unprecedented migrant crisis and the rise of violent extremism – which includes the destruction of cultural heritage and the annihilation of minorities’ cultures as well as an increasing polarisation of international relations – deeper understanding and a willingness to work together is what we need.

name: Zdzisław KRASNODĘBSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President! I would like to say a few words about one thing, but it seems to me to be a very distinctive one, and that is this online platform for cultural diplomacy, which the authors of the report so welcome. The assumed goal of this platform is to conduct activities that strengthen the cultural commitment of the European Union with third countries and their citizens. Well, as Mr Brok said, the aim of European cultural diplomacy should be to show the complexity and diversity of Europe's cultural heritage in all its diversity, including national diversity. So the question is: why in the case of the platform was selected in the tender a consortium that de facto consists of cultural institutions from only one part of Europe? Could the assumptions of the project not take into account the necessity of geographic diversity, precisely showing the cultural diversity of Europe? Unfortunately, this resembles the story with the House of European History, which is also, after all, an element of the cultural diplomacy of the European Union, where history was presented through the prism of the experiences of only some countries in Northern Europe. It seems to me that we should take what Mr Brok said seriously - right? The history of Europe and the history of culture and heritage are more complicated and this diversity should also be reflected in the implementation of EU projects and also in the cultural diplomacy of the European Union. Really, Europe is not only Germany, it is not only France, not only Great Britain - and that is why it is so - not only the countries of Northern Europe.

name: María Teresa GIMÉNEZ BARBAT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, dear colleagues, since 2011 our Parliament has recognized the need to incorporate culture into the Union's external relations. I would like to thank Silvia Costa and Elmar Brok for their work, and High Representative Federica Mogherini for the Joint Communication on a European Union strategy for international cultural relations. We emphasize in the text the importance of culture as a tool for diplomacy and ask that it be recognized as the fourth pillar of sustainable development and as a human right. Among the concrete measures, we recommend: an annual action plan with a separate budget line to support international cultural relations; a mechanism for the prevention, evaluation and reconstruction of heritage in danger, including an emergency instrument to safeguard heritage in countries in conflict; the inclusion of culture in all existing and future agreements of the European Union with third countries. The political objective of this report is to foster cultural cooperation between the Union and its partner countries and to promote a world order based on peace, the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights. In the long term, a cultural cooperation inside and outside Europe that is respectful of basic values ​​of civilization and common principles represents the only way towards this much desired order. We need to promote international cultural cooperation, understood in the broadest possible way, from policies that ensure the conservation of cultural heritage to a scientific diplomacy capable of spreading more rationality and love of knowledge in a divided world. The development of prosperous and cooperative cultures also represents a "vaccine" to prevent movements, for example, destabilizing migration for host countries and that are not the same. solution for the countries of origin, as we are sadly seeing these days.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, the report on the new European strategy for international political relations sets quite ambitious goals. Commissioner, culture can become a lever for the development of employment and social cohesion, for contributing to the mutual understanding and peaceful coexistence of peoples, as an integral pillar of the European Union's bilateral and multilateral agreements. But this requires sufficient and increasing funding and, above all, youth programs. Ladies and gentlemen, I express my reservations about the interpretation of the methods and means of preserving cultural heritage and combating illicit trade, and I point out that this alone is not enough. An imperative practical proof that we respect the cultural heritage of every people is the immediate return by the Member States of cultural relics and World Heritage sites to their countries of origin. Global awareness of the return of the Parthenon Sculptures demonstrates the need for ambitious declarations to protect and promote cultural heritage to be demonstrated by concrete actions.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President, including the cultural dimension in the Union's relations with other countries is an essential aspect to strengthen friendly and peaceful international relations, based on mutual respect, dialogue and on strengthening or promoting human development in all its dimensions. . It is also an opportunity for the European Union, an opportunity to be recognized as an important global player of reference in this field, in the field of soft power, but also to project at the same time their common culture and diversity as a factor, a value and a wealth to be preserved; a diversity that, by the way, goes far beyond the diversity of the Member States, the majority cultures or the official languages ​​of this house. We are particularly pleased that our proposal for a cultural visa for artists and other professionals related to the world of culture has been included in the report.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank both our rapporteurs for this important report. We should make cultural relations with third countries an asset of our foreign policy. With the European Union’s increasing presence on the international stage, our actions should rely on the use of our instruments and the regional programmes. I fully support the idea to include cultural diplomacy in the toolbox of our diplomatic relations. We should develop a strategy for cultural diplomacy at European Union level.  European culture is rich. Our action in third countries needs to be more visible, and our communication channels more open. We should enrich our contacts with stakeholders active in this field. I can already see many possible benefits of a developing closer cultural relations with candidate countries and countries in our neighbourhood. We are part of a common cultural framework, and in many cases we share a common history. It could help us to use this soft power in areas such as conflict prevention or as a catalyst for stability and reconciliation.  We also need the systematic support of independent media. In the modern world I see them as essential in promoting cultural diversity as well as credible information. We have to be more attentive to truthful information about European values, and we should recognise damaging propaganda and false news.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Madam President, the rapporteur, Silvia Costa, rightly points out that culture is key to the European Union's external diplomatic relations because it has the merit of stimulating dialogue and mutual understanding. In addition, I believe that it must be an integral part of the dialogue with third countries and be systematically integrated into development projects and programs. I support the call for the creation of a mechanism to support the protection of the world's cultural heritage. Efforts at international level need to be stepped up, as must the fight against the illicit trade in cultural artifacts, conflict prevention and the promotion of creative industries. Last but not least, I would like to draw attention to the need to remove barriers to the mobility of artists and cultural figures, as well as to promote preferences, such as the provision of special visas.

name: Patrick O'FLYNN
text: – Madam President, it is 23.00, and my heart goes out to Mr Juncker in whatever fine-dining establishment he happens to find himself at this precise moment. Instead of seeking to impose European cultural values on other countries, Europe’s nations should concentrate on protecting those values at home. it is good that gender equality, human rights, democracy, freedom of expression and the rule of law are listed as key values under pillar one of the EU strategy. But the sad fact is that these values are under increasing pressure within European countries. A major cause of this, especially in respect of gender equality, is the importing of hundreds of thousands of young men from countries that do not respect those values. Not for the first time the EU’s ambition drastically exceeds its ability to deliver. Let us look to protect the key and precious features of our own culture instead of automatically believing that more diversity must always be welcome, no matter how much strain that diversity is already placing on our countries. The best contribution Europe can make to the world in cultural terms is to carry on being a great example of tolerant, free and peaceful societies, where ideas are respected and where superior values prevail. Far more than a strategy for international cultural relations, we need a strategy for European cultural protection.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Mrs Costa and Mr Brock for creating this document, but also Mrs Mogherini who has accepted and wants to apply culture as part of the Union's foreign policy and I hope that culture will become a diplomatic instrument through which we cantalk to those who share the same cultural space.Here, I also support the inclusion of culture as an instrument or tool in relations with third countries in all agreements relating to third countries.So, the cultural space that we share with similar or equal values we really need to know how to promote in some way more.I am glad that there is talk of protecting cultural heritage, that illegal trade in cultural goods will be prevented, I hope, and I take this instrument as an invitation to Europe and the whole world to protect cultural heritage and I want to express my joy that 2018 will beyears of cultural heritage.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Madam President, I would like first of all to congratulate Mr Brok and Mrs Costa on their report. The European Union and the Member States are a great cultural power. European culture is and must be a very useful instrument in international relations, and I believe that the European Union and its Member States should coordinate their efforts in this area. Furthermore, I understand culture as a vehicle of understanding, not as an instrument of confrontation; I believe in intercultural dialogue as a bridge between countries and communities of different origins in such a complex world, where many want to divide and polarize. I would also like to highlight the importance of the Cultural Routes program of the Council of Europe. This program is very important to reinforce the European identity, promote tourism, the preservation of the cultural assets of European countries and, furthermore, many of these Cultural Routes also run through countries that belong to our southern and eastern neighborhood. For this reason, the European Union must increase its support for this program managed by the European Institute of Cultural Routes, as it will strengthen relations with neighboring and candidate countries, as stated in section 80 of tomorrow's report.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Madam President, I would like to thank Silvia Costová and also Elmar Brok for their joint report.Determining a long-term strategy for international cultural relations is very difficult in a society in a world that is evolving so fast.Examples and activities such as the European Year of Cultural Heritage in 2018 can be used very well here. In the report presented, I particularly appreciate that the results should be used, as well as graduates of the program, such as Erasmus +, Creative Europe or Horizon 2020. Culture isalso a means of combating respect for human rights and radicalism.I therefore welcome the initiative to provide greater support for cultural professionals in countries and regions where human rights are at stake.We also know from our own experience that culture can cross borders and build bridges even where there are no other tools.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: - We all have human nature, but we express it with different cultures.We are in trouble when diversity overshadows our fundamental and basic equality.It is therefore important that the European Union, as a force for peace, promotes a peace-oriented dialogue between cultures, at local, regional, national and global levels.A precondition for progress in this dialogue, however, is mutual respect for cultural identities.I am convinced that more intercultural dialogue can make a significant contribution to more understanding, more cooperation and more peace in the world.The Brok / Costa report welcomes this in this regard.

name: Željana ZOVKO
text: - Distinguished Commissioner, Distinguished President, I would like to thank my colleagues Elmar Brock and Silvia Kosta for an extremely high-quality report. Supporting culture as a driver of sustainable social and economic development and promoting culture and intercultural dialogue for the purpose of peaceful relations between communities and cooperation in the field of cultural heritage are prerequisites for building a sustainable and tolerant society. I therefore particularly welcome the sections calling for close cooperation between UNESCO and the European Union in the protection and promotion of tangible and intangible heritage, and the section calling for cultural rights to be promoted as equal fundamental human rights and for culture to be considered a fourth independent pillar of sustainable development, together with the social, economic and environmental dimension. What I see as a key element of culture in the context of international relations, as a powerful tool for cultural diplomacy of the European Union's foreign policy, is to promote fundamental European values ​​that include respect for the right to cultural diversity and unity in that same diversity.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, we will stick to two seconds because we see eye-to-eye on this. It is only to say we need to continue this wonderful interinstitutional cooperation. We count on continuing to work with all committees and the entire Parliament now to move forward in this fight.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President! I can see that this debate, you, Mrs Mogherini, and also the participants in this debate have made it clear that there is a high degree of agreement and will here, that we can lay some value on consensus and that it is an important entry point to take appropriate action in these areas. I believe that in these general approaches that we have talked about, as well as in the very practical things that are raised here - with the preservation of cultural heritage, if we see the situation through ISIS in Iraq and in Syria, which one Wise cultural heritage is being destroyed - have raised awareness that these people are committing a crime against our common wealth. Then, I believe, it is also an important message that we stand up for the identity of everyone, not only when it comes to our own culture, and that this can have a unifying character. I would be happy if we could expand this more if we have to go step by step. We're not going to do it all at once, I am fully aware of that. These are new fields that can still be effectively advanced if we go step by step in order to include the cultural scene, the people who live out of the culture, and this Europe in the Bringing in the world and making our contribution to the world.

name: Silvia COSTA
text: rapporteur. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank all those who have spoken for the contribution they have made. As the Hon. Brok, this choral sharing really shows that Europe needs culture and that we are all perhaps more aware of it than at the beginning of the legislature. This pleases me very much, it means that we have worked well together: Parliament, Commission and Council. I would just like to say that Federica Mogherini is right - naturally I also thank Commissioner Navracsics, even if he is not present, because it was a joint production, and all her staff - she is right: an effect has already been achieved, I have been able to I also verify personally, in the sense that not only in Parliament for the first time are two committees together that have addressed a topic like this, and they are important committees, but also that an integrated task force between different DGs has actually been activated in the Commission , which is already a very promising result, overcoming the somewhat "siled" approach, which is what sometimes sets us apart. I believe that another fruit is what you mentioned: we made a great request to the Commission, in particular to DG Culture, and certainly the climate that has been created has favored the fact that Tunisia is finally the first country on the southern shore. of the Mediterranean that can effectively participate in the Creative Europe program. I also hope that it will be the European Union, as you said, and we look forward to this initiative by the Council, which can effectively take over, as the European Union, the initiative regarding joining the task force for protection. cultural heritage at risk, but also to adhere to the European and Council of Europe conventions on the protection of cultural heritage. One last wish: it would be very nice that in Milan, where in December it will take place for the first time - not in Brussels, in Milan, and this makes me very pleased - the European Forum on Culture, where the European Year of Cultural Heritage will be announced and European cultural diplomacy will be illustrated, that we can think of a launch, a launch event in all European delegations, in all institutionscultural events in the world of this great initiative: the European year in an international dimension.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 5 July 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. - The report under discussion deals with a very important and complex issue. When it comes to international and cultural relations, I believe that we must avoid maintaining an ethnocentric and self-referential attitude. In fact, not only would this not be in line with either the founding values ​​of the European Union or with the very idea of ​​aid and development of the poorest countries, but would produce counterproductive effects for this purpose. The European Union should promote its own culture, in terms of reciprocity, thus avoiding imposing its own cultural hegemony, which too often is used as a picklock to impose precise economic and legal choices. Choices that too often have hidden, and continue to hide, economic and human atrocities. Culture and cultural heritage represent common goods that belong to everyone and as such must be safeguarded and managed. Only by example, and not by aseptic export, can the European Union make other countries aware of the importance of its own values ​​and culture, while respecting the values ​​and cultures of others.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - This report could have been titled "Stripping Member States of the last sovereign power they still retained". Indeed, I am surprised at the ability of the European Union to define a diplomatic role for itself. In "united nations" there is the word nation, and, despite all its Promethean efforts, the Union is not and never will be a nation. It is all the more unfortunate that the report mentions fundamental issues, such as the fight against the destruction and trafficking of cultural property. But the Union prefers to gloss over the importance of strengthening intercultural dialogue. What about collective rights? The rights of peoples and nations to preserve and enhance their heritage, history, language and cultural traditions, as well as to fight against all forms of cultural imperialism. It is for the recognition of these rights that we should work, at a time when the national cultures of the Member States are threatened with disappearance by globalist homogenization, summoned to all eat the same thing, listen to the same music, to merge our values ​​in a so-called abstract common ground above ground. Does Parliament claim to want to defend culture? Let it begin by preserving what constitutes its foundation, namely the identity of the peoples of Europe.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - I would like to thank my colleagues Elmar Brok and Silvia Costa for their work on developing a future EU strategy for international cultural relations. Throughout history, it has been proven many times how important it is to use the tools of cultural diplomacy in shaping the international image of a country, the so-called international relations. ‘Soft’, that is, promoting it through cultural means. I appreciate the recognition of the importance of cultural diplomacy in foreign relations and the paramount importance of culture in today’s globalized, accelerated, impersonal, and marginalized Christian values. The European Union must externally represent European values, with human dignity, freedom and equality at the center. That is why a balanced approach to strengthening cultural relations that respects cultural differences is important. The tools of culture should also be used by the European Union in shaping its foreign policy strategy, and this can be particularly effective in developing relations with third countries. The report specifically addresses the strengthening of cultural relations with countries covered by the EU's Neighborhood Policy. The so-called The aim of the cultural visa program is to facilitate the exchange of experiences between artists and to strengthen cooperation between cultural institutions in EU Member States and third countries. I am pleased that the report encourages the establishment of programs by which the EU facilitates the participation of third countries in cross-border cultural and scientific projects, which also serves this purpose.

name: Antanas GUOGA
text: in writing. – I support the approach of the joint communication presented in the report which identifies three work streams: supporting culture as an engine for sustainable social and economic development, promoting culture and intercultural dialogue for peaceful inter-community relations, and reinforcing cooperation on cultural heritage. Only by targeting all three mentioned areas can we reach positive results. Also, the role of independent media in promoting cultural diversity and intercultural competences is significant and we need to assure their effective functioning when sharing credible information, especially in the EU neighbourhood states. We have already created a good background for strengthening cultural diversity – the Erasmus + programme serves here as the best example. However, we have to involve other EU programmes such as Horizon 2020 and COSME in order to cover the strategy for international cultural relations and boost it.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Andrey Kovatchev, on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs, on the European Parliament's recommendation to the Council on the 72nd session of the United Nations General Assembly (2017/2041 (INI)) (A8-0216/2017).

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to share with you our views on a number of key topics in the traditional form of an annual recommendation to the Council. The objective is to contribute to the preparation of the EU priorities for the United Nations General Assembly session each autumn, which the Council normally adopts in July. We agreed on 18 compromises based on 255 amendments. I would like to thank all the colleagues who contributed to the final version of this report, the members of the EU-UN Working Group, the shadow rapporteurs, rapporteurs and political advisors for their constructive approach and the Secretariat of the Committee on Foreign Affairs for its excellent support. The annual United Nations General Assembly Recommendations report empowers our institution to present its opinion via the Council to the UN General Assembly on issues ranging from peace and security, through climate change, to advocacy of human rights, democracy and the rule of law. In its report, Parliament recommends that the Council, inter alia, should: continue to call for full respect for the sovereignty, internationally recognised borders and territorial integrity of Eastern European and South Caucasus countries, namely Georgia, Moldova and Ukraine, in the light of the violations of international law in these areas; draw the attention of the UN member states to the increase in tensions between some countries in the Western Balkans; urge their leaders to show restraint in their regional policies, with the EU and the UN remaining fully involved in seeking lasting solutions to bilateral differences, including by acting as mediators where necessary; further encourage the UN’s efforts to bring about peace in Afghanistan and to overcome the fragile security environment in the country; strongly condemn the actions of the North Korean leadership that threaten peace and security in the Korean peninsula and beyond; reiterate its unequivocal condemnation of terrorism and its full support for actions aimed at defeating and eradicating terrorist organisations; and step up efforts to clamp down on the recruitment of terrorists; support UN efforts to prevent non-state actors and terrorist groups from developing, manufacturing, acquiring or transferring weapons of mass destruction and their delivery systems, and to insist on full compliance with the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, the Chemical Weapons Convention and the Biological Weapons Convention; call for a strengthening of the global response to migration and address the challenges and security concerns stemming from aspects of illegal migration, such as people-smuggling and human trafficking; reiterate its condemnation of any act of violence, harassment or persecution against human-rights defenders, and push for stronger engagement in promoting the rule of law; take concrete steps to ensure the efficient implementation of the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development and its 17 Sustainable Development Goals, adopted by the UN General Assembly in September 2015; ensure that the EU remains committed to the fight against climate change and call on all UN member states to uphold the Paris Agreement; regain trust in multilateralism and try to convince all the UN member states that this approach is the right one and that the UN should remain an internationally recognised organisation in so many challenging places on our planet.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission / High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, this year I celebrated Europe Day, 9 May, in New York with the new Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres, to stress the natural partnership between the UN and the European Union, at the precise moment when the UN system is coming under growing pressure – if you want to be diplomatic – or under attack, if you want to be clear. We have seen a resurgence of the very old-fashioned idea that national interest is not compatible with a cooperative global order. And we Europeans know from experience that this is not the case. Our national interest, our European interest is to invest in the UN system, in multilateral decision-making and in cooperative global solutions for global problems. The United Nations needs our support now more than ever, and Mr Guterres made it very clear in this Chamber just a few months ago. It is a pleasure to see that the European institutions share exactly the same views on global governance and on our support to the UN system. Your report is perfectly in line with the work we are doing to define the European Union’s priorities at the next General Assembly and, as it was the case also last year, the report has been itself a source of this inspiration for our work. The Foreign Affairs Council will adopt the EU priorities for the General Assembly on 17 July, and the draft text aims to be political and focused, reflecting the new context. The multilateral system of global governance is under attack, as I said, and it is the moment to somehow renew our vows, to commit even more to effective multilateralism. I would like to stress the word ‘effective’ because the best way we have to protect the multilateral system is to make it deliver. Over the last few years we collectively have achieved some impressive results through the multilateral system, through the UN system: the nuclear deal with Iran, the sustainable development goals, the Paris Agreement on Climate Change, to mention just a few. The European Union is working and will continue to work to guarantee that all these agreements are implemented fully and properly. We have this responsibility. We are exercising this, building strong global partnerships, starting with the Paris Agreement. With our consensus on development, we are leading the way in the implementation of the sustainable development goals. At the same time, we know that the United Nations needs reform. António Guterres has put forward a very ambitious reform programme. Changes to the UN culture, structures and operations will be necessary. And we will use all our political and diplomatic capital to help build a coalition in support of UN reform, and to support the UN Secretary General in this respect. We are ready to do so because we know that this is in our own interests. We know that we truly need a strong and effective United Nations, and this is why the European Union’s voluntary contributions to the UN funds and agencies amount to half of their total budget, and we are proud of that. This means that we invest as much in them as the rest of the world combined. We do this, not only because it is right, but also because it is smart. It is smart to invest in the World Food Programme to prevent a humanitarian crisis or a refugee crisis. It is smart to invest in the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees to help millions of displaced people. It is smart to invest in UNICEF to help children in a war-torn country to go to school and prevent the radicalisation of future generations. And the list could continue. Investing in global governance, sustainable development, climate action – and here again the list could continue – is for us an investment in our own security. Hours ago in this Chamber we had a debate on European security and defence. I also stressed then that this is part of our work on security. Investing in a strong multilateral system and in a strong UN system is for us an investment in European security. Not only European security, global security. This is the European way to security and it is also the UN way to it. This is the contribution we will bring to the next UN General Assembly. Beyond the ad-hoc things we will continue to do, this is the main message we bring. We will focus on conflict-prevention, thereby making a contribution to building peace. We will continue to work to implement the sustainable development goals via development cooperation on human rights – a key pillar of our work – and we will work with Mr Guterres and with all our partners towards a more effective multilateralism. Reading your report I know these are priorities that we share because they correspond to our values and to our interests, which is serving and reforming the UN system.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Madam President, allow me first of all to say that I am making this intervention 16 hours after arriving here in Parliament, in this "ridiculous Parliament", to use Jean-Claude Juncker's phrase. It’s a part of the same story of this institution. Then let me congratulate Mr Kovatchev for drafting these recommendations. This traditional exercise, through which Parliament gives its position to the Council, such as (on?) As well as the themes addressed, can improve our action on the international scene and strengthen multilateralism. We need - I believe - stronger commitments at the multilateral level in order to find a lasting solution to the conflicts in Syria, Iraq, Yemen, Libya, Ukraine or even the frozen conflicts in Moldova and Georgia. The UN bodies obviously play a major role in this regard. They are also the appropriate framework for dealing with recent tensions in the Western Balkans region and adopting a firm stance on Russian actions which threaten the stability of reform processes in this area. We must, of course, continue to support reform of the United Nations, including the Security Council. I will highlight, in particular, a point that also appears in the report I wrote on war crimes, genocide and crimes against humanity, which we voted on today. The use of the veto power by permanent members of the Security Council is unacceptable when atrocity crimes are committed. Finally, I will mention that the PPE Group has requested a separate vote on point paragraph 1, point g),): and we will vote against this part which deals with the mandate of the United Nations Mission for the organization of a referendum in Western Sahara (Minurso). This point contains several inaccurate elements, and we believe it is not at all appropriate in this text.

name: Soraya POST
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, I would like to start by thanking Mr Kovatchev for the good cooperation during the writing of the report. Looking at the world today, it is clear that the EU and UN must strengthen the role of women in all segments of society. We especially need the representation of women from marginalised groups. The empowerment of marginalised women is not only democratic. It holds out the prospect of how to build democratic societies.  To this end, I have tabled multiple amendments to stress the importance of women’s participation in peace and security processes, all in line with the numerous UN resolutions on this issue. I have also requested the full implementation of the Beijing Platform for Action. And to be honest, as a feminist, I find it embarrassing to still have to put this argument forward. The Beijing Platform should have been implemented a long time ago. We need implementation, we need reform and we need a UN Security Council that reflects the new world reality. It is time for the EU to have a single seat in the Security Council.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Before I give the floor to Mr Notis Marias, I would just like to remind you that I no longer accept blue cards and also no longer do the catch-the-eye procedure.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Madam President, we are discussing the report on the recommendation of the European Parliament to the Council, concerning the 72nd session of the UN General Assembly, and while the report is addressing almost all the major issues of world peace, while it is dealing with Africa, with Asia, with the ends of the world, does not consider what is happening nearby, does not consider what is happening in Cyprus, does not say a word about the illegal invasion of Turkey in Cyprus and does not say a word about the illegal occupation of 37% of Cyprus by Turkish troops. Why; The report also does not say a word about the threats of Turkey against Greece, about the violations of the Greek airspace and the maritime territorial waters of my country by Turkey. What kind of European solidarity is this towards Greece and Cyprus? Finally, the report does not mention the debt relief of developing countries, but also of the countries of the European periphery, although this is the only way to achieve the growth for which the report in question is so much cut.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Madam President, Mrs Mogherini, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Andrej Kovachev, for his efforts, as well as the other colleagues for preparing this text. A positive vote on the recommendation is crucial, as it outlines the framework of the European Union's priorities for the forthcoming UN General Assembly. Moreover, it is no secret that many of the Member States of the European Union are divided on a large number of global issues, and I believe that setting common priorities is an opportunity to show the international community that the European Union can play an important role. on the global stage, but also to speak with one voice. As a shadow rapporteur for the ALDE Group, I am extremely pleased that the Committee on Foreign Affairs has been able to draw up a consolidated text in which some important proposals for our democratic values ​​have been voted on. The report makes it clear that the European Union is one of the most committed defenders and advocates of human rights, fundamental freedoms and diversity, the fight against climate change, democracy and the rule of law. At the same time, the European Union must continue to support multilateral efforts to find lasting political and peaceful solutions to the ongoing conflicts in the Middle East and North Africa. But also to continue to call for full respect for the internationally recognized borders and territorial integrity of the countries of Eastern Europe and the South Caucasus, and to support the resumption of diplomatic efforts for a peaceful settlement of ongoing and frozen conflicts. Of course, the recommendation clearly outlines our consistent support for a comprehensive reform of the UN Security Council so as to best meet the new global realities. In conclusion, I would like to draw your attention to the ALDE Group's amendment on the reunification negotiations in Cyprus. We are currently in the final phase of these historic negotiations and I believe that the European Union can send a strong signal by expressing its full support for the UN's efforts to settle the island in its entirety.From the successful completion of the process there are no losers, only winners.And we must support all our… (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Helmut SCHOLZ
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Mrs Mogherini! The non-entry of an Arab king to the G20 meeting made it to the top report, the months of work of the United Nations sank into neglect in the media. The first undoubtedly brings better photos. The second alone leads to the solutions that we need in order to meet our common challenges, in order to live in peace and mutual balance. The SDGs, the Paris Agreement on Climate Change, efforts to create a regulatory framework for the restructuring of national debt or for fair and orderly trade in global value chains or, in general, the further legalization of our international relations - all of them can only be achieved through continuous focused work. Where this does not take place, more and more states will withdraw from the common rules and put their interests first. This is where the Commission, Council, Member States and EP share responsibility. In 2018, our resolution must finally set more priorities and measure itself against the fact that discussions in the UN are often much further than our positions.

name: Barbara LOCHBIHLER
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! The UN Secretary-General Guterres gave us a very impressive speech here in the plenary in May and showed us the most important challenges that the United Nations is facing. It is important to me that the EU supports his approach both to advance the reform of the UN security structures and to strengthen the capacities for mediation and conflict resolution tasks. The EU member states must significantly increase their financial and personnel support for the peacekeeping and peace building missions of the United Nations. Our resolution fully supports Secretary-General Guterres' reform agenda. But the UN member states are also called upon to provide the financial means for this. The UN's peace policy must not be jeopardized. The EU must make a contribution here, an EU that the UN Secretary-General has described as the greatest peace project in history. Thank you, Mr Kovatchev, for a very good report.

name: James CARVER
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, usually I defend my country’s privileged position as a Permanent Member of the UN Security Council, but tonight, a year after the UK’s sensible decision to leave the European Union, and with Article 50 negotiations finally under way, I turn my attention across the Channel. So, my French friends and neighbours – I can say that, can’t I? – will surely come to expect similar increased pressure over the retention of their own permanent UN Security Council seat. France must not subjugate its international and security interests in the name of the EU collective. Since the Brexit vote, and in the rush for ever closer Union, the EU has demonstrated its inability to adapt in its rush for greater powers in relation to defence and security matters. Through our joint efforts and sacrifice, the United Kingdom and France have greatly contributed to the maintenance of international security. Although this partnership has not always been perfect, it is strong and it must continue as such after Brexit. On this basis I would urge my French counterparts to abandon their support of the EU project, and instead throw their full weight behind this bilateral partnership, and fully commit to NATO. If they do not do so, I fear it will be to the detriment of security for Europe and La Francophonie and internationally.

name: David McALLISTER
text: – Madam President, I would first of all like to thank Andrey Kovatchev for this really interesting report. It is well worth reading – Mnogo blagodarya, as you say in Bulgarian. As UN Secretary General António Guterres emphasised in this plenary just a few weeks ago, we need ‘an investment in international cooperation to face the global challenges that are in front of us and that no country can face in an isolated way’. Among the numerous topics that require close cooperation between the European Union and the United Nations, our focus should be on prevention and early action to stop the onset of crises, as the High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy has already pointed out. I believe that out common EU-UN efforts in addressing the root causes of terrorism, countering hybrid threats and promoting cyber defence must be strengthened and coordinated. Early action also includes fighting terrorist propaganda through social media platforms and supporting counter-radicalisation policies, in line with the UN plan for action to prevent violent extremism. Yes, this requires close cooperation, responsible innovative solutions and early action, but we should keep in mind that an ounce of prevention is worth a pound of cure.

name: Jo LEINEN
text: - Madam President, Mrs Mogherini! The G20 meeting that will take place in Hamburg over the weekend is a sign that the UN is not working well. How can it be that 175 countries are just around the corner and 20 countries determine the course of world history? So I agree with you: the UN must be reformed, it must become stronger, it must become more efficient. We should do everything we can to support the Secretary-General, as you said. Here in Parliament tomorrow we would like to see a parliamentary assembly set up alongside the General Assembly. After 70 years of existence of the UN, it would be important that the chambers of citizens are not just observers there, but that a subsidiary body is set up under Article 22, and there are more countries that agree to this than is realized: Canada, Switzerland, Norway and loads of third world countries. I would ask you to stand up for it. I also believe that for multilateralism, China has to be on board if the US is attacking this system now, attacking the UN as it is attacking the EU. China also needs to make more financial contributions. You should try that too.

name: Francisco José MILLÁN MON
text: - Madam President, I must first of all congratulate Andrey Kovatchev, the rapporteur, on his report, which addresses many of the challenges we are facing, challenges that are common, global; which therefore require a collective response. And that is why I welcome the efforts that the United Nations is making in areas such as, firstly, the fight against terrorism, in matters of financing and international judicial cooperation; sustainable development, where the implementation processes of the 2030 Agenda and the application of the Paris Agreement stand out; and the massive displacement of people, through the follow-up of the high-level meeting last year. We have to maintain the European Union's commitment to multilateralism, in the face of isolationist or protectionist temptations that create division and uncertainty. The United Nations is the cornerstone of multilateralism. The European Union, which has to be a global actor, a factor for peace, stability, progress, must continue to work actively in and with the United Nations. David McAllister remembered Guterres; I'm going to do it here too: a strong and united Europe - he said - is a fundamental pillar for a strong and effective United Nations.

name: Federica Mogherini
text: Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy. – Madam President, again there is less than one minute to say that the debate we have had tonight in this Chamber will be duly reported and reflected in the forthcoming decisions and debates with the Foreign Ministers in the Foreign Affairs Council ten days from now and, most of all, in the work we do daily with the UN system and, in particular, in view of the general assembly. I cannot tell you that I will see you in New York, because I guess we will see each other before that here in Strasbourg. Apart from that, we will continue our good work together.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank all my colleagues, and also Ms Mogherini, for the good cooperation. The key word is indeed effective multilateralism, as you called it, and to regain trust in this global system of preventing conflicts and having long—lasting solutions for citizens in different places on our planet. As you said, we support the newly-elected United Nations Secretary—General’s reform agenda. The EU must encourage the impetus for reform of the US peace and security architecture, the function and the architecture of the secretariat through simplification, decentralisation and flexibility, and the streamlining of financial organisation. But we also need to do our homework here in the European Parliament and in our representations in order to coordinate the work of our ambassadors there as much as possible, not only in Europe, but also in other places in Rome, in Bonn and other UN places where we have representations, to work for a common European architecture for security and defence, as well as a common European system for the exchange of intelligence information, which can also be used to prevent terrorism.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 5 July 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- The UN traditionally deals with all kinds of problems and solutions, including human rights, humanitarian aid, development aid, etc.It is equally important to focus on the United Nations as an institution itself and the changes it faces.The need to reform the UN and its Security Council has been talked about for decades, but it has not come far.A fundamental reform of the UN Security Council is needed to better reflect the new world situation and to be able to respond more effectively to current and future security threats.It is important to agree that members of the UN Security Council should refrain from using their veto power in cases of crimes against humanity.In addition, the EU should aim to have a seat on the reformed UN Security Council.This requires constant work.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the recommendation for second reading by the Committee on Budgetary Control and the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a European Parliament and Council directive on theCombating fraud directed against the financial interests of the European Union by criminal law [06182/1/2017 - C8-0150 / 2017 - 2012/0193 (COD)] (Rapporteurs: Ingeborg Gräßle, Juan Fernando López Aguilar) (A8-0230 / 2017).

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner, Commissioner! I would especially like to warmly congratulate Commissioner Jourová on a great achievement. Today is a great day for the European Union and for the fight against fraud. I warmly greet Commissioner Oettinger, who spared himself four years of tough negotiations, but who finally got on board in time for success. We are convinced that we have made a real milestone today in protecting the financial interests of the European Union and in the new competences for the European Commission. We have completed a legislative process on the directive on combating fraud against the Union's financial interests by criminal law - the so-called PIF directive - a cumbersome term. We are dealing with a historic moment because we are removing a major legal loophole within the EU and taking the step towards becoming a European Public Prosecutor. The Committee on Budgetary Control has been calling for such a European Financial Prosecutor to be set up for 20 years, and now we are finally ready. I'm happy that it was still possible before midnight. I very much regret, Madam President, that this House has dealt with all sorts of marginal issues, but it has not been possible to put this essential part of real progress for the European Union and real European unification on the agenda at a Christian time, where perhaps someone is also watching. I very much regret - and I appreciate that Mr McAllister is still here with us in the sitting room - that this Parliament can no longer distinguish between what is important and what is not. That is a milestone for the European Parliament. I'll book it under personal revenge that we are now around hit this time - I don't mind, I can't sleep at night anyway. I want to tell you that this vote marks the end of four and a half years of hard work on this directive. In April 2014, shortly before the European elections, Parliament adopted its position at first reading. I would also like to thank my colleague López Aguilar, the co-rapporteur from the Interior Committee, very warmly. We held trialogues from October 2014 to December 2016, with a break of almost a year and a half from June 2015 to October 2016 because the Council refused to accept Parliament's key demand - including VAT in the scope of the directive. The compromise text ultimately achieved is quite impressive from a parliamentary perspective. In particular, the inclusion of VAT is a very important step. I would like to thank the Slovak Presidency - even if everyone on the Council side is already in bed. I would like to thank the Council very much for the fact that the various presidencies have made it possible time and again to move on in this difficult matter. I would also like to mention the Italian, Latvian and Dutch Presidencies, under which significant progress in negotiations was also achieved. I would also like to thank the many committed employees of the Commission, but above all you, Commissioner Jourová. This would certainly not have been possible without your continuous and persistent constructive commitment. Today we are laying the foundations for the European Public Prosecutor's Office, the so-called EPPO. The PIV Directive harmonises the definitions for relevant criminal offenses - including fraud, active and passive corruption, improper use of funds - and lays down a minimum level for the associated maximum penalties. For It is precisely these crimes that the EPPO will then have investigative powers.It will also have the opportunity to investigate VAT fraud from ten million euros if at least two Member States are affected.I would like to tell you: Today is a good day for the European Union, for the finances of the European Union, and that is why I believe that we should definitely not rest in order to make EPPO a success now.Madam President, I have waited so long for the moment, that is why I have decided to brutally overrun my speaking time, so you have to unplug my microphone today because I think it is a really good day to fight fraud.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: speaker. - Madam President, thank you Commissioner Jourová and Commissioner Oettinger for being here at this late hour of the night, at the stroke of midnight. After hours of debating strategic guidelines, recommendations and the situation in countries on which the European Union cannot legislate because it has no jurisdiction over them ... finally a legislative initiative! Finally a piece of legislation under debate in this House; nothing less than the one that best expresses the political dimension, including the constitutional ambition of the European Union, because it is European criminal legislation, finally, in the protection of the financial interests of the Union, in the protection of the European budget against fraud of European scale. These have been years of debate in which I greatly appreciate the cooperation of the rapporteur for the CONT Committee, Mrs Gräßle. We have worked for more than four years to fulfill this objective of the area of ​​freedom, justice and security, this Directive that harmonizes European legislation, making fraud against the European budget an objective of European criminal law that will be necessary to launch the European Public Prosecutor's Office , provided for in Article 86, with the protection of financial interests as the primary jurisdiction, but it is expected that - pursuant to Article 83 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union - it can be extended to other serious transnational crimes. Well, here we effectively have a discussion of those that are worthwhile, because it is about preventing fraud from being subjected to forum shopping, that is, to the choice of the most favorable legislation, harmonizing the criminal response legislation of the States members. And this is exactly what this Directive does with regard to fraud, corruption, misappropriation and embezzlement, finally establishing minimum penalties, minimum penalties and a penalty of up to four years in prison for these crimes - for course, optional for the judge, to be decided by the judge. But the really important objective is that Parliament has entered into dialogue with the Council, and this dialogue has lasted no less than two and a half years, because we adopted the first reading in April 2014 and we have been discussing four main issues with the Council. .. Include VAT fraud as an objective of European criminal law, resisted by the Council. We have finally managed to ensure that this financial resource of the Union - because it is indeed a budgetary resource of the Union - is covered by this Directive. The final compromise states that VAT fraud will have to actually import a significant amount - more than 10 million euros - and that it will have to be cross-border in nature, that is, involve at least two Member States of the Union. Secondly, the discussion on fraud in public tenders has a European scale, and the Council undertakes to consider the matter in the future application of the Directive. Minimum and maximum penalties: a minimum penalty, applicable throughout the Union, for crimes of fraud and related crimes, with a commitment of at least up to four years in prison, provided that the fraud amounts to at least one hundred million of euros.
