It is a necessary objective to protect the financial interests of the Union. And the discussion regarding the limitation period, which is what is always more heterogeneous and divergent in the national laws of the Member States: we have established a standard period of at least five years from the date of the alleged crime, but can be reduced to three in the event that there has been an interruption of the limitation period by national legislation, in accordance with the appropriate considerations in the process when the suspect has fled the country or had to be extradited before it can continue the process. We meet, by Therefore, with a piece of European criminal law.Finally, European criminal legislation that fulfills the objective indicated by the Lisbon Treaty, an area of freedom, justice and security, necessary so that the Council can finally adopt its enhanced cooperation, launch the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which will be,undoubtedly, an achievement of this legislature so fast of legislative achievements in the development of the area of freedom, justice and security.This legislature, which has dragged its feet in meeting the objectives of the Lisbon Treaty, today, at last, is scoring a goal at the true gate.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it is pleasure to be in the Parliament today together with my colleague, Commissioner Oettinger. Yes, to achieve the consensus on how we are going to fight against fraud against the Union’s financial interests by means of criminal law, this is a historical moment. I am happy to be here at this historical moment in spite of the late hour. I would particularly like to thank the two co—rapporteurs, Ms Gräßle and Mr López Aguilar. Without your tireless efforts and your continuous support in moving this initiative forward, we would not be here today. A quarter of a century after the adoption of the Convention on the Protection of the European Communities’ Financial Interests, it was time to modernise the legislative framework on the protection of the EU budget. The Directive updates the definitions of criminal offences affecting the Union’s financial interests. It also introduces common rules as regards sanctions and statute of limitations linked to these offences. The Anti—Fraud Directive is a decisive step forward and, in combination with the European Public Prosecutor’s Office, we are entering a new era. The Anti-Fraud Directive will essentially frame the activities of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office (EPPO). It will provide the material scope for the investigations and prosecutions of criminal offences falling within its competence, and will ensure that the EPPO can rely on harmonised definitions of these offences across the Member States. The Council reached a general approach on the EPPO in enhanced cooperation in June, and this Chamber will soon be asked for consent. I am confident that the EPPO Regulation can be adopted as soon as possible with a strong backing from Parliament. I am happy that 20 Member States have already notified their participation in the EPPO. This will make it an efficient tool to protect the financial interests of the EU, and I invite more Member States to join. The work has just started. It has not finished with the adoption in the Council. I will finish now because I know that we are in a hurry here. I will now be happy to hear my colleague, Mr Oettinger.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Member of the Commission. - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Mrs Gräßle, dear Mrs López Aguilar, dear colleague Jourová, ladies and gentlemen! Fraud, breach of trust, bribery, and corruption are crimes of considerable financial weight. But if they go against a public budget - whether on a national level or here in Europe - then they are also endangering democracy. Because if we allow the European budget to be enriched and thus harm taxpayers and citizens, then this will be anti-democratic. That is why today's step is something to do with the budget and the democratic principles of the European Union. So far there has only been one Council convention - after all. It's over 20 years old. Today you create parliamentary law. We are strengthening the legal basis for all activities of our services against corruption, bribery, breach of trust and criminal offenses of this kind with this PIF directive and with the reform of the OLAF regulation that we are currently preparing, with OLAF as before and EPPO new. On the basis of the EPPO regulation we have legal bases and organs and instruments which - I believe - are considerable, which correspond to the European citizen and which make a great contribution to the credibility and honesty of European budget programs. I am grateful to the rapporteurs, Parliament, Mrs Jourová and their services, and I promise, on my responsibility for OLAF and EPPO: We will do everything we can to ensure that both institutions work perfectly and in a coordinated manner. I would like to ask you to put the EPPO regulation into legal force as soon as possible. Then we will have a European Public Prosecutor in 20 Member States and OLAF will work with it. And in the other seven or eight Member States, OLAF will continue to do the work and assist the national public prosecutor's offices. In the course of EPPO / OLAF job development, we will do everything we can to ensure that EPPO can get off to a good start and OLAF is not weakened - along the lines of the tasks that remain in all European Member States.A good day indeed and a success, thanks to the tenacity of you, the rapporteurs in the European Parliament!

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: for the PPE Group. - Madam President, I am very pleased with this compromise, which has been reached for so long, because it is extremely important for the European Union to finally put in place measures to ensure the effective protection of its financial interests. I appreciate that one very important thing has been achieved in the negotiations, and that is to include VAT fraud in the scope of this directive. Given our closely linked European integration, it is completely unthinkable for me that it is precisely VAT fraud and the associated criminal law measures that were outside the scope of the directive. After all, the convention on the protection of financial interests itself provides for this inclusion of VAT. Nevertheless, I see this new directive only as an initial step in the joint development of the European Union in this area, in the area of ​​the protection of the European Union's financial interests. Ladies and gentlemen, above all, cooperation is needed not only with the Member States of the European Union, Europol, Eurojust, but also with the Public Prosecutor's Office, which must play its part in protecting the European Union's financial interests as soon as possible. So far, the European Union is lagging behind. And it needs to be strengthened as soon as possible, precisely at European Union level. In particular, it is necessary to combat tax fraud, which is increasingly common in the European Union, and its link to organized crime and terrorist financing, which pose a huge threat to the European Union. Ladies and gentlemen, when you ask why MEPs are not in session at 9 am, it is mostly because they are talking about such directives by the evening.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Madam President, yes, every year, in revenue, VAT fraud costs taxpayers in the order of EUR 50 billion. Imagine, the moment we started, Mr Oettinger, talking about upcoming budgets, about the need to find resources. Hence, I would like to congratulate the co-rapporteurs, Mrs Gräßle and Mr López Aguilar, for having managed to bring this ship to fruition and, of course, to the commissioners, Mrs Jourová and Mr Oettinger. I congratulate them enormously, not only for making history in terms of what criminal law is and for being able to fight against fraud of the resources of the European budget and give that legal basis to the prosecutor, but also because, in a certain way, today we have rescued the VAT, we have defended it from those who at some point and in a state secretariat, in Berlin specifically, wanted to end VAT as a resource of the European budget. In that sense, I too congratulate myself tonight.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, I am sorry that the debate on such a serious issue as fraud against the European Union's financial interests is taking place at such an advanced time in front of almost empty seats. The European Commission estimates that the European Union's losses from fraud are to the detriment of its interests. Do European citizens have € 600 million a year to waste in this way? Obviously not. Is it necessary to criminalize fraud at European level? Obviously yes. However, this can not be done beyond the limits of the division of competence between the Union and the Member States, set by the founding treaty itself and for this reason our final vote on the issue will depend on whether they are accepted. our amendments concerning in particular the minimum levels of criminal sanctions or not.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Ms. President! I would also like to thank the rapporteurs, Mr Aguilar and Mrs Gräßle. I agree with them that this is a historic step when this Parliament has finally gotten there to create this regulation. In particular, the European Parliament can be considered a success in bringing VAT regulation and VAT-related offenses within the scope of the directive. So this is an extremely important step forward, but it is only a first step. It is clear that regulation is only the basis for us to be able to take effective action against corruption in Europe. This also requires institutions, in particular the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which can effectively detect, investigate and prosecute such crimes. Unfortunately, the European Public Prosecutor's Office will be set up in Europe without being a member of all the Member States. Among them, countries that are key beneficiaries of EU funds are not participating in the cooperation. So I am afraid, ladies and gentlemen, that the European Public Prosecutor's Office will not be able to monitor the use of EU money in the countries where they are most at risk.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Madam President, first of all, I would like to thank the rapporteurs for their very important work on this very important file. Maybe it is only natural that we are here in the middle of the night in the Parliament building, speaking about this extremely important affair in the true spirit of prolongation, because, after all, it was the Council that prolonged this process for quite a while. But now we can all be happy to have reached the final outcome. This particular directive will form an essential part of the fight against fraud against the EU budget. Having common rules designed to protect the financial interests of the Union is not only necessary, but it also makes the recovery of misused funds significantly easier and more efficient. Even more, the directive is an important step for the effective functioning of the future European Public Prosecutor’s Office, which will soon be established through enhanced cooperation. Unfortunately, the Council could not agree with all of Parliament’s views on the harmonisation of criminal matters affecting the EU budget. But I am glad that, for the most important issues, our hard-working rapporteurs were able to include review clauses in the final text. Overall, this directive is a very positive step towards a better functioning union in the fight against fraud. Achieving concrete measures for the protection of the EU’s financial interests is the key to ensuring the most reliable and efficient use of European taxpayers’ money. So, once again, my sincere compliments to the rapporteurs on their excellent work.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Jourová, Commissioner Oettinger, first of all I thank the rapporteurs for the difficult but important work carried out through years of intense negotiations to define the text of the PIF Directive which, together with the now forthcoming establishment of the European Public Prosecutor's Office , represents a fundamental step on the path towards the harmonization of criminal law and will form the backbone of the new criminal system to combat fraud and corruption, which have weighed on the EU budget for about one thousand billion euros. Among the most significant provisions of the directive is the reference to the Union legislation on the fight against money laundering and corruption, which is essential for targeting the activities of criminal groups which, through these crimes, find money to use in their illegal activities. Particularly important - as has been said - is also the introduction in the legislative text of VAT fraud, which represents a fundamental step forward to guarantee more complete protection against financial crimes against the Union.

name: Claudia SCHMIDT
text: - Madam President, Commissioner! The conclusion of the negotiations on the directive on the need to better protect money and the financial interests of the European Union is - I think - really a historic moment. Google, Starbucks and Amazon selected the countries with the best tax advantages, while criminals chose the countries with the weakest judiciary. That is precisely why we need the European Public Prosecutor's Office. Every year the EU budget loses EUR 50 billion due to VAT fraud, in my home country Austria it is between EUR 2 and 3.5 billion. So there is an urgent need for action. Since the European single market, the national borders for the movement of goods and people have fallen. At the same time, crime and organized crime no longer stop at national borders. Now it has finally been determined what powers the European Public Prosecutor will have. This has created the legal basis for the work of this authority. Above all, the right of the European Public Prosecutor to intervene in national authorities is very important - a first step towards common European criminal law. 20 states are involved, and binding minimum and maximum penalties have been set. We are now starting with the European Public Prosecutor, who aims to protect the EU's financial interests. One thing must be clear: fraud with EU funds is fraud with taxpayers' money. Money laundering, corruption and fraud in tenders must be eliminated. And, Commissioner, one request: Greetings to Mr Juncker. It is now 12:10 a.m. and I - a member of the ridiculous European Parliament - am here.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: - Madam President, Commissioner Jourová, dear Ingeborg Gräßle! If European funds are misappropriated through fraud, then the EU must also get hold of its own weapons in order to defend itself. That is what the citizens expect of us. Different definitions of fraud and inconsistent practices by Member States almost invite fraudsters to commit fraud and it becomes very difficult to prosecute it. This agreement, this directive is therefore a big step in the right direction. I expressly welcome the fact that VAT fraud has also been included in this directive. It is estimated that 170 billion is lost to the member states every year, which is more than the entire EU budget spends on all policy areas. The creation of a European Public Prosecutor is also important in this context. European cases of fraud must be prosecuted, investigated and punished at European level. I stand by that, that opinion is a good one and this directive is a milestone and it is not ridiculous or ridicule to honor this ten o'clock tonight.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, many Members mentioned the inclusion of VAT as a big achievement. I must say that this is very much thanks to the continuous pressure from Parliament’s side, because I understood from the beginning of the negotiations that this was a red line for the Parliament. So we opened the second negotiating front with the ministers of finance and we achieved something which all through 2015 nobody believed we would manage, namely to have VAT under the Anti-Fraud Directive and the EPPO as well. So thank you again for this continuous pressure, which helped us a lot in the tough negotiations. Some Members mentioned the time it took and the lengthy processes for both the Anti—Fraud Directive and the EPPO. We all knew over this process that it was worth investing time and energy in this, because we knew for sure that we were fighting for something good. We were doing it not only because of the worrying statistics and the money which was being stolen or going into the pockets of corrupt people, but only because there was much more at stake than the money itself, namely the trust of EU taxpayers. I see this as a very important historical moment, since we can now say to Europeans that we are doing our best to protect their money. I would like to thank Parliament once again. I count on your support tomorrow and in a few weeks’ time in this plenary when you will debate and vote on the EPPO.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: Rapporteur. - Madam President, Commissioner! I would like to thank my colleagues very much and would like to talk about the formalities. We have EFDD applications that we must - please - reject tomorrow. We all have to stand together. I really want to speak to everyone's conscience again, we have to do that because otherwise the whole story won't become reality. Now it is up to us to make EPPO a success. We have to organize coordination with OLAF, with Eurojust, with Europol. We have to ensure that the EPPO is really a success in practice, because this is the only way we can guarantee that we have created a good cause. We have twenty Member States - seven not yet - and pressure is needed here too. Commissioner Jourová, don't avoid an argument! We have to put pressure on the seven Member States. It's Poland, it's Hungary - important Member States who are not exactly my greatest role models when it comes to handling European money. We have to get these Member States to join the EPPO. We have to get them to see the added value of EPPO, and you can know that we are by your side. I would like to thank you very much again. I would also like to encourage us to involve OLAF and its great experience in the transnational fight against crime. OLAF is the most experienced institution we have, and of course we have to approach it in particular here and include OLAF in the entire structure. I think it's really groundbreaking today, no matter what time it is. Thank you again, and I believe that it will be a great commitment for us, the Committee on Budgetary Control, for the months and years to come, to ensure that we have a really functioning organization.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: speaker. - Madam President, this morning, more than twelve hours ago, in this same plenary hall, we paid tribute to Simone Veil, symbol of the first Parliament directly elected by European citizens 38 years ago. Since then this Parliament has grown, it has matured. At last it is a legislative Parliament; it legislates on fundamental rights and legislates on nothing less than criminal law, a competence traditionally attributed exclusively to the sovereignty of the member states. It is time for us to say very clearly that this Parliament matters, that it is not a second-degree Parliament; that we say this to the 500 million citizens that this Parliament represents and we say it with special courage, at a time when we are adopting criminal legislation that, in addition, provides additional resources in the protection of the financial interests of the Union, when they are so necessary to cope with the destruction of the austerity policy, to provide the necessary resources to restore the badly wounded European social model, so that all the politics of the European social model that made the best Europe can once again make sense. I believe that it is time for this Parliament to claim its legislative, normative and binding nature, because it encompasses criminal law and legislation in matters as important as fundamental rights in the protection of data of the national Parliaments of the, still today , 28 Member States; that it is a Parliament that can really improve the lives of citizens and can provide resources in something as important as the fight against cross-border VAT fraud, the large-scale fraud that imports billions to the European budget, being as it is a fundamental resource for the financing of the European Union. And this Parliament is doing it, demanding of the Commission and demanding of the Council. We are putting in European criminal legislation in force.We now want, at last, for the Council to advance the enhanced cooperation of the European Public Prosecutor's Office and to complete the architecture desired by the area of freedom, justice and security in Europe.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place tomorrow, Wednesday 5 July 2017.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- An effective fight against the financial interests of the Union can only be waged in an integrated way.For this reason, the relevant criminal legislation must be adopted at European level and the report under consideration constitutes a first step in this direction.VAT fraud constitutes an important part of the fraud in question, and is facilitated precisely by the existence of the internal market (the so-called "carousel fraud").The fact that these are included in the scope of the directive is very important, as is the fact that the relative threshold is part of the aspects subject to review in three years.The same goes for fraud in the management of public procurement, another major problem for many states, including ours.The text is therefore, as mentioned, only a first step, but it certainly goes in the right direction.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: in writing. – The PIF Directive is vital for the fight against European funds fraud. We have to find the money and return it to the taxpayers. This directive provides for minimum rules concerning the definition of criminal offences and sanctions with regard to combating fraud and other illegal activities, such as money laundering and corruption affecting the Union’s financial interests. This directive will also cover VAT fraud but only serious cross-borders cases of fraud, where the total damage caused is over EUR 10 million. This is a very high threshold considering that VAT fraud affects every EU citizen. The carousel of VAT fraud is well-known and it steals millions of euros every year. Moreover, the directive will not affect the competences of Member States to structure and organise their tax administrations as they see fit to ensure the correct determination, assessment and collection of value added tax, as well as the effective application of VAT law.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - Dear Mr. PRESIDENT! Another OLAF report, another disgraceful figure, has come to light about the proportion of public money that falls victim to corruption in each Member State. The EU Anti-Fraud Office uncovered a record number of cases last year. In Hungary, four times as many EU funds had to be recovered due to irregularities as anywhere else in the EU. EU funds are also our money, money that could be used to build a school, a motorway and a playground. These disappear in billions of items, and we read news about them every day, which politician’s family member they landed with. It is therefore outrageous that there are Member States that do not want to join the European Public Prosecutor's Office, which would roll up the misuse of EU funds. The European Public Prosecutor's Office would ensure that EU money is in the interests of Hungarians and Europeans, not the governor's few. There is a suggestion from several EU capitals that those who do not accept the European Public Prosecutor's Office or the rule of law should not receive EU funding. We would therefore join the European Public Prosecutor's Office immediately after 2018, which would ensure not only EU funds but also our shaky membership of the European Union.

name: Emil RADEV
text: In written form. - For too long, European funds have fallen into the wrong hands and there was no strong mechanism to combat fraud. According to the European Commission, in 2010 frauds were committed with European funds worth 600 million euros. With the adoption of the Directive on the protection of the EU's financial interests, Member States will have a new, modern and adequate instrument to ensure that European funds go to their intended purpose - to help the average European, businesses, municipalities and not to the pockets of criminals. Given that 80% of EU funds are managed at national level, the introduction of common definitions, the criminalization at European level of diversion of funds, the submission of false documents, the laundering of European funds, active and passive corruption will help national authorities to investigate fraud cases. Including VAT fraud worth more than € 10 million in two or more countries is a great victory for the European Parliament and will contribute to an even more effective fight against this type of crime. It is now time for the Member States to transpose the directive as soon as possible so that the fraud with European citizens' money can be stopped.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – The road to hell is paved with good intentions. It is sad but probable that current ideas to launch an EU defence plan could bear out this dictum. An EU defence plan can only work if it is based on a clear definition of what the common EU interest is by way of security and defence against external threats from state entities. That definition does not yet exist in a coherent manner. Moreover, such a plan would need a military doctrine explaining how security/defence interests would be ensured, based on pooled or jointly coordinated resources, able to conduct warfare. No such doctrine seems available for the foreseeable future. Worse, according to current thinking, internal and external security are different sides of the same coin. Not true. So the defence plan will likely proceed on the basis of contingent military responses, ad hoc. Though the European industrial-military complex is right to lobby for a harmonised armaments market, this does not justify a ‘defence plan’ and is achievable without it. Likely too, a ‘defence plan’ will overlook the interests of neutral countries while another European dual structure of ins-and-outs takes shape. Is this really worth it? I think not.

name: Tadeusz ZWIEFKA
text: in writing. - Every year, millions of euros flow out of the EU fund as a result of extortions related to false information in applications for EU funding. That is why I am in favor of adopting this directive, which deals with fraudulent offenses affecting the interests of the EU in public procurement, money laundering, corruption, VAT fraud and the willful misappropriation of funds. Since these are measures to support the development of countries and regions, we must not allow a situation in which money intended for the general good ends up in the pockets of criminals. As a rapporteur for the opinion in the Committee on Legal Affairs, I was tasked with developing a definition of an official that under the directive covers not only EU officials and employees of the Member States' institutions, but also private persons to whom public functions related to the use of EU funds have been delegated. The same definition should also apply to activities in countries outside the EU, as a significant proportion of the EU budget funds are distributed beyond its borders. This directive will also be the basis for the operation of the future European Public Prosecutor's Office, to which I hope all Member States will eventually apply.
